ArticleFamily

A Life in the Twentieth Century: The Memoir of Iris Jean Yandle Beatty

Iris Jean Yandle Beatty

Fri 08 December 2006
                ********

I am truly an elderly lady, and at the age of Seventy-five I decided to do something a lot of old folks do—think about, and then write about, events my family and I have lived through, with hints of the experiences that were delightful, or those that were harder to manage, or to overcome, or just to live through. Over the seventy-five years of my life there have been sad, glad, terrible, and marvelous, and sometimes even blessed changes in the way all people live, and move, and have their being. When I was born in 1931 the medical community—that is hospitals, doctors, nurses, and makers of medications—had few medicines to offer to patients. There were palliatives, and life-saving surgeries, but not much at all that could truly be called medicines, as we think of them in 2007.

I was born in 1931. I was not the first child in our small family. My sister, Ella Cornelia, was born in November, six full years and a few months earlier than me. In those days different families had different rules about explaining to “innocent” children that a child was on the way. My sister was well into her seventh year, as her birthday was in November. In February of 1931 our mother arranged it with a neighbor to “invite” little Ella Cornelia to her house for a day or so, and it happened just like that. Innocent, and unwarned Ella Cornelia went with Pauline Funderburk to her house for an overnight stay, and was having a lovely time when Pauline told her to get ready to go back home. My sister had been the only—not just the only, but the ONLY—grandchild in the Yandle family, and in the Park’s family she was the oldest grandchild. She had been the star of the show for six, going a couple of months into the seventh year, being the star of the show with aunts, uncles, grandparents, cousins, and friends. She in no way expected even the slightest competition as the star of the show when it came to grandparents and aunts and uncles.

Ella Cornelia walked confidently into her own house, and didn’t at all understand why her mother was sitting down holding a little baby girl, with several neighbors sitting around the room, all of them paying no attention to Ella Cornelia, who was the only child in the family, and instead watching her as she beheld the fact—and it seemed to be a fact—that Mother was holding a little baby. Since I was so young I can’t offer a quote of just how I was introduced to my sister, but I heard several reports of what my sister squalled out when she actually understood that she had a baby sister. Her first, and for a long time her only unrequited wish was: “Take her back!!!”

Ella Cornelia (named for Grandmother Ella Yandle, and Grandmother Cornelia Parks so that she was accustomed to hearing her entire name as neither grandmother could be slighted just to shorten her name) was angry that her parents would actually “buy” another baby without at least warning her. She—at seven years old and happy as an only child—most definitely didn’t want a new sister who would share her very satisfactory world. It took about ten or eleven years for my sister to come to grips with the fact that Mother and Daddy were not going to “return” me to where I came from, and that that I might have some use around the house, since I learned at an early age to dry dishes and be her “hand me that” step and fetch it person. I remained unwelcome to Sis until I leaned to read music, because, since Ella Cornelia couldn’t get rid of me, she, being a month or two more than six years older than me, bossed me around without worrying about how little, or how young I was. If she was in charge of me, she was bold, and absolutely positive that I wasn’t worth much of anything. I was unwelcome to her from the beginning, and it didn’t help my sister at all that when I was two, or close to three years old, she became seriously ill. Those were days, nearly fifteen years away from penicillin, when there were no sure medications. Medicine, in those days, was mostly helpful in surgeries, injuries, and the birth of children. They could offer nursing and constant and consistent nursing, but Illness was still mostly not curable unless the patient was strong enough to simply overcome the illness with their own bodies. When most people were entered into a hospital with a truly serious disease, the patient was not at all sure he would live to return home. There was careful care—real and heartfelt on the part of the nurses. But there were no guarantees, and sometimes, from the beginning there was no hope of recovery.

For instance, my aunt Helen, as a teenager, about seventeen years old, had an illness, and her doctor told her family there was no cure, but if they were willing to try a potion he had been testing, he would treat her. He brought out his concoction that contained an acid that ate her teeth—all of them. She lived, but her teeth had to be pulled, and so she wore false teeth for the balance of her life, from her late teenage years to several years past her ninetieth birthday. Losing her teeth made her more shy than she might have been when she met people who were not kin-folk. She was an intelligent person, and she was also the oldest daughter of a woman who was blind, and who had been quite frail after birthing seven or so children. My father said that his mother had been quite fragile most of his life, and said Aunt Helen, his oldest sister, had helped to raise him. The five surviving children—two boys and three girls—sort of raised each other. My Dad was the youngest boy, and the strongest man I had ever seen. He was over six feet tall, wide shouldered, and could pick up lots of heavy things. He was a painting contractor, and climbed ladders to paint the outside and the inside of houses. He had something wonderful. He had a truck that would carry ladders, and buckets of paint along with brushes and drop cloths. He had one younger sister named Pauline who was the only sibling younger than himself.

Uncle Eddie, my Dad’s older brother, didn’t resemble my Dad at all. By the time that I came along and was old enough to notice people, I wondered why my Dad was over six feet tall, and Uncle Eddie was not even as tall as Aunt Helen. He was thin, and looked frail. He had few teeth, smoked cigarettes, and on Sundays when we came to visit, spent the entire day near the kitchen stove in the winter, and in summer would sit on the porch, or in less pleasant outdoor weather, beside the kitchen stove, or with his mother who was blind and bedridden, who lived in a room that was warm in winter, and sort of shaded by shrubs and trees in the summer. Sometimes Uncle Eddie would spend part of Sunday afternoon keeping company with the man who ran a gasoline station literally “next door” to the Yandle house. The owner also had cold drinks and candy and chips for sale. It wasn’t actually a grocery store, but there were items that were pleasing to travelers and handy to local folk who lived several miles from actual grocery stores. I loved to go to the “filling station” where they had ice cream on sticks or in small paper bowls with tops. There were cold drinks like coca colas, Pepsi colas, Seven-ups and grape drinks in a bottle. There was a tray of chewing gum, and another of candy bars. There was also a tall jar stuffed with small packages of cheese crackers that held between them delicious penut butter smeared between two crackers, with five in a package for a nickel in the earliest years, and later for a dime a little later on. I loved to get a snack and a drink, and there was a wonderful one when I was very young called a three center (which meant that it cost only three cents, and was sort of a poor man’s coke-a-cola). I did like the taste, and it was a wonderful treat to be allowed to follow my sister from our house down to the corner café to buy one each for a treat on a hot summer’s day. My joy of having a three-center drink died one day when I was about five years old. We had a neighbor who ran a café which my sister and I could reach without crossing a street. Ours was the first house facing Eleventh Street in the 400 block, and at the other end of the four hundredth block was Mr. Kanasas’ café. He sold a all sorts of things, like ice cream bars, and candy, and cold drinks (not to mention beer as well). He also provided food he prepared himself, and he sold hot dogs and such, and ice cream. The café was at the other end of the four hundredth block of Eleventh Street. He had a long counter that offered swivel chairs so customers could order food or drinks in comfort. At lunch he served very nice meals, though I don’t remember his serving food in the evenings. He also sold beer, and other cold drinks, and I wasn’t allowed to go to the café late in the evening, because then he had a café full of people who drank beer. But in the early afternoon I was sometimes allowed to visit the café and buy a popsicle or a drink called a Three-center. Three-Centers came in a clear bottle that looked a lot like a Coca-Cola bottle, but it wasn’t actually the same size.

t wasn’t actually a Coca-Cola, but it was sort of similar, and cost only three cents. It actually looked a little like a Coca-Cola bottle, but that was truly an illusion. The bottle itself was clear, and not sort of green like Coca-Cola bottles. It was made of very thick glass. On the inside, that thick bottle held only three ounces. That illusion of a full bottle was made because the bottle which it was sold was made of a very thick glass that was Coca-Cola size on the out side, and only three ounces in the inside. I remember that bottle, and I have to this day a scar to remind me should I suddenly loose my memory.

Mr. and Mrs. Kanasas had three children, the oldest a young man a a little older than my sister. tiny bit older than my sister, a girl a little younger than my sister but at least four years older than me. He also had a son a bit younger than me. about my sister’s age, and a younger child who was a year or so younger than me.

By the time I was moving into my teens beer couldDuring the years that the alcoholic drinks was forbidden except in a few cafes like the one our neighbor Mr. Kanasas ran was North Carolinaand a counter, behind which he could make real dinners, and he served plates with good foods and soft drinks—but he also sold beer. since it was . . . withstuffed with peanut-butter that cost only a nickel. other treats. Mr. Estridge sold bread and milk and soft drinks and candies along with a few other eatables. And many Sunday afternoons my Uncle Eddie would sit with him, and that fact meant that if I asked permission, I could take my nickel or dime down to the gas station and buy a treat for myself, all by myself. That was truly fun for me. For once, I didn’t need my sister to “take” me or accompany me to the gas station. She bossed me without mercy, and I had to be extremely nice to her or she wouldn’t take me. My parents and aunts would not allow me to wander alone beyond the borders of the yard, . nor was she required by my parents,

in the coolest room in the house.

, but I’m not sure about that. I was never told the actual agesonly five of whom lived to adulthood. Aunt Helen took over the kitchen at an early age, as her mother was blinded by an illness called eyeritis, and to this day that particular illness can still cause blindness because no cure has been found as yet. Only this year—2007—a memberof our church contracted that illness, but modern treatment, though not actually claimed as a cure-all for eyeritis, helped her enough that she did not loose her sight.

Care was available. But care did not cure if the patient was a fragile person. Care was easier in a hospital than in a home, and hospitals were available for surgeries and accidents. Sickness was about the same as it had been forever—there were few cures.

When I was nine years oldOne winter evening I went to vespers at the churc.

Ella Cornelia loved music, and listened to the radio. She would purchase (ten or twenty cents each) what was called Song Sheets, on sale in small stores. Radio was popular, as were motion pictutures, and a few people (the list growing greater every day) had phonographs that would play records of the music introduced by the growing hoard of people who watched movies in the five or six theaters in Charlotte. There were at least four, if not many more, “Five and Dime” stores in uptown Charlotte, and most of them had a piano player who would be available during the day to play on a piano the many tunes and songs published on cheap paper that had notes and words of the “popular” music offered on radio and in the moving pictures shown in theaters. About the time I was starting to school Radios were becoming easier to purchase, both because more were being manufactured, and more people were recovering from the Depression that had thrown most of the United States into a hopeless poverty that saw banks fail and close, and businesses of all sorts to simply close their doors. People without work had no money, and banks where “rich” folks had placed their wealth found that their banks, also, had no money with which to reimburse them. Things were tough all over, though I was too young to realize what a tough time people all over the South, and the North as well, often lost all their money, all their possessions including their homes, and the entire country had money problems.

Charlotte had several movie theaters, and most of them played a show only a couple of weeks before ed their ey papersung on the radio or during movies. The “Song Sheets” were published on cheap news-print paper and offered written music, or sometimes just the words, of popular songs broadcast on the radio, or shown as part of movies shown in local theatres. People who enjoyed radio often wanted to sing along with the performers, and so they bought the cheaply published song sheets to learn to both play and sing the popular tunes. oodge. somewhere in the twelve, going on thirteen years for her to admit .

not been warned of the coming event. Instead, sixth year, and moving toward her seventh birthday while I was only “expected” and so no one told her she would have a sibling. Therefore my arrival was not only a surprise to my sister, it was an insult. One day a neighbor lady came by the house and “invited” my young sister to come to her house for a visit. She went for a couple of days. Then that neighbor lady announced that she would be going home soon, and so they drove to little Ella Cornelia’s house. There was a car, or perhaps two, already parked in front of her house. Ella Cornelia went into her house and found several folks already there in the living room. Mother was sitting there holding something, and Ella Cornelia walked over to see what it was, and it was me—her infant sister.

In the 1930’s most families had a “medicine cabinet” somewhere in their house, and it would, in most instances, have a bottle of rubbing alcohol, salves that were used to fight the discomfort of colds or skin itches or such, but sulfur was about the only real drug to fight wounds. There were surgeries and protocols to help people through illnesses, but apart from those few there was little else. Medicine—as a cure-all did not exist. Measles brought the Health Department to homes and a notebook size sign was tacked beside the front door warning neighbors of communicated disease. I can remember once that after measles I was allowed to tear that terrible sign off the wall beside our family’s door the morning I was no longer contagious. My mother had to lift me up in her arms in order for me to reach it—but I was glad to snatch it off. Then I could have playmates on my porch, and then I could go outside to play. I was no longer a danger to my neighborhood.

A few years after that eager snatch to remove from our porch the warning bulletin on measles or chicken pox, there was a terrible outbreak of Infantile Paralysis in North Carolina. Not very far from Charlotte there was an outbreak of that communicable illness that was taking lives, causing crippling of its victims, and there were no medicines that would protect the helpless children and adults who were stricken, and no way to prevent the rapid spread of the disease. The Charlotte Schools closed within a few days of that outbreak. We would have a month or so longer for our not far from Charlotte. The Schools in Charlotte closed after a few days, cutting the school “year” very immediately that spring. We finished out the week, and the doors closed for the summer. Parents in Charlotte, North Carolina, were warned to protect their children by keeping them indoors where they were unlikely to mingle with neighbors, never take them into a crowd such as school class-rooms, or churches, or movie theaters. Adults were warned to keep their children away from other children, and so there were no trips to stores of any sort, nor of churches, and certainly not movie theaters—and that was long before television. Older siblings, or parents could borrow books from the library for children to read, and there were radio programs aimed at young people, but at home. No visits to movie theaters, or parks, and no playing with neighborhood children. lsis. nailed beside our door, another there came a different kind of quarantine to the City of Charlotte, N.C. The “new” one was not really new, but I had not heard very much about it. Not far from Charlotte an epidemic occurred. I think I was in about the third grade, and that year school was over for the year more than a month early, as I remember it. School simply stopped right there. Children, and some adults, in a nearby area were suffering from what my parents called “Infantile Paralysis” and what I learned years later was Poliomilitus.

illnesses that surgery would help, there really wasn’t much to offer or other quite ordinary ches and pains, but most of the remedies were ineffective, and served mostly as proof of “doing something” to help pain or discomfort. There were very few effective palliatives. Most home made remedies were an effort to actually “do” something to help the suffering, whether or not it was effective. I know that my family had such items. When I had a cold, my mother rubbed my chest with Vicks Vapor Rub, or metholatum. 888888888888888888888888888

tumif sulfa couldn’t cure an illness, folks were mostly out of luck. There were no antibiotics at that time. There were few “medicines” on the market that actually did what they were advertised to accomplish. Physicians, sometimes in desperation, tried untested combinations of the “remedies” that were offered, but most of those concoctions were either destructive or ineffective and worthless, so that people who were desperate for a helpful medication were often given unproven medicines, because to a dying person something that might help them was always more comforting that the news that there was no remedy.

My Grandmother was a small woman, and I always thought of her as being frail. She birthed at least six children that I know about. I’m not certain about the order of birth, but I was aware that Aunt Helen was the oldest daughter, and that Uncle Eddie was older than my Dad. I also knew that Aunt Pauline was the youngest, so that left Aunt Martha the middle girl, but she was the Aunt who was very bossy. When I was very small my Aunt Pauline had a boy friend who eventually became my Uncle Henry. I must have been four or five years old at the time, but I liked Uncle Henry, and I remember that I solemnly told my Aunt Pauline, that she couldn’t marry Uncle Henry because I, at the very young age of four or five, was going to marry Uncle Henry. Despite my plea, Aunt Pauline married Uncle Henry, and they rented a house so near my Grandmothers house that it took only three minutes to walk there. As I grew up I had wonderful Sunday afternoons at Aunt Paulin9999999999999999e spent most of the afternoon with her visiting Aunt Pauline’s house on Sundays, when I had her living room . Aunt Pauline and Uncle Henry were at my Grandmother’s and the grown-ups were having a nice time talking, and I was having a nice time wearing Aunt Pauline’s satin housecoat while listening to Gene Autry on the radio. , and listening My visits Most of the time she and Uncle Henry were at my Grandmother’s house. , and Aunt Pauline had a beautiful satin house coat that I loved to put on, and just sit by her radio and listen to a thirty minute program staring Gene Autry, one of my favorite cow-boys. Aunt Pauline was very nice to let me have that lovely time in a nice house, listening to a wonderful cow-boy show, and looking at my reflection in her mirror wearing a wonderful sat housecoat.

Never the less, for all of my boasting, she managed to marry him first, and they seemed to love each other very much. There was a house available for rent that was really close to house where my grandparents lived.

The land my grandparents lived on was very near a red dirt road that went from the Pineville highway along side of my Grandparent’s land, all the way to the railroad. Then that unused road seemed to keep right on going across a grassy field. I asked my Dad where the road went. He told me it didn’t really go anywhere now, but that at one time there was a building out in that field, but it had burned down. Some years later there was a Sunday when my Mother and Dad decided to take a walk. We walked up that red dirt road, and crossed the railroad tracks and kept walking. , and I went with them up the red dirt road, and across the railroad tracks. We kept walking Took a short walk across that track, and followed the narrow level red

There was one little The house my grandparents lived in was next to a red dirt road that now led absolutely no where except into a field that grew nothing much but grass. As I grew up my Dad would sometimes Their first home was a rental, and was the second house though I was quite young, I decided their house was a half block away from my Grandparent’s housewas just about the length of half a block before I was old enough. Even so, I always did like that gentleman, and he was always kind to me. For many years Aunt Pauline and my Dad were the only two married children in that family. After Aunt Pauline and Uncle Henry lived almost close enough to the house my Grandparents lived in to toss was married she no longer lived in the house with my grandparents and my other two aunts and my Uncle Eddie. Aunt Pauline didn’t move very far away. There was, actually, only one house between the house Aunt Pauline and Uncle Henry rented and the house in which the rest of his immediate family lived—except, of course for my Dad and Mother and my sister and me. We lived in Charlotte, but nearly every Sunday afternoon we went to see my grandparents, and often it was not only the Yandles, but also my mother’s parents, the Parks family.

that cameand visited nearly all of my Dad’s family lived where my Dad grew upwas so bossy it didn’t take much to know that she was older than Aunt Pauline, that though I seemed to know of my aunts and uncles; however, I think Uncle Eddie and Aunt Helen were the two oldest, and then my Aunt Martha. I think that my Dad (Leroy Samuel) was next, then Aunt Pauline. For years I was not aware that there had been another child in that family. One day I followed my Uncle Eddie into the There was another child whose name was Stella, but she died when she was still a toddler. My Dad spoke of her only once, when he said sadly that she was a beautiful child. I had never heard of that name until one day I asked for a rake or some other garden tool, and my Uncle Eddie took me into the barn yard to a small square storage hut to get the tool. On the ground before the shed was a scuffed up slab of marble almost buried in the dirt of the barn yard. I turned it over, and discovered that it was a grave stone, with a name etched into it. The name was Stella Yandle, and she had died very young. I asked my Dad about almost in the with a found near a small a chipped grave stone with her name on it

When I was old enough to notice how a house was run I discovered that Aunt Helen was the one who ran the kitchen, but Aunt Martha helped her, and also assumed the position of “chief nurse” to my Grandmother, who was an invalid, and was blind. My Grandfather Amos along with my uncle Eddie ran the farm. Aunt Helen was the cook, though Aunt Martha helped her, and helped to care for Grandmother. My Aunt Pauline and done a wondrous thing not often heard of in the South in those days: she had gone to college. After her graduation Aunt Helen went to work for an engraving company, and she worked at that job until she retired many years later. . looked after my grandmother and I think my Aunt Helen was the first child. , and she grew up helping to care with the other children, and also helping in the kitchen. In those days it was a rare family that did not lose small children to illnesses. My Grandparents raised five children, my Dad being the youngest boy. There were two girl children younger than my Dad, however, only one lived to adulthood. My Aunt Pauline was the youngest child, and she attended college. I don’t think my Uncle Eddie or my Aunt Helen attended school long enough to actually graduate, though they were both intelligent and knowledgeable people. My Aunt Martha and my Aunt Pauline actually finished school, because Aunt Martha planned to become a nurse, but because she became ill she was unable to complete her training. My Aunt Pauline, the youngest child, actually went to college. They had to take on rather adult positions within their families at an early age. My Dad left school after the firstAs the oldest children they had to help Aunt Martha enrolled in a nursing Pauline was the only one of the family that went to college. , and First there were two girls and one boy, and Their first child was a girl who was named Helen. In the early 1900’s , though Helen, their oldest daughter, spoke of having to take care of the kitchen at a very young age. and her oldest girl, my Aunt Helen, took over the kitchen work at an early age. My Dad was the fourth child, though not the youngest in the family. Two more children were born, though only one livedand there were at least two children born awhen he was youngBefore my sister not well after she started having babies. I know she had at least six, and probably more children. Five of them lived to adulthood. My Dad remembered that there was a little girl whom he thought was quite beautiful as a child. She died from an illness when she was a toddler. I didn’t know she had ever existed named Stella who died as a very young child.

In most instances the physicians who prescribed for patients who were dying from an illness for which there was no effective antidote, often put together some sort of tonic that might help. Otherwise he had to say there was no help. Rather than doing absolutely nothing he often created a medicine that he hoped would provide whatever seemed to be lacking in a patient’s system. The medicine he gave Aunt Helen turned out to have a genuinely active reaction; though that reaction left a great deal to be desired. The medication dissolved the enamel of her teeth, and before she was twenty years old she was wearing false teeth. Aunt Helen was not an outgoing sort of person to begin with, as she had been cooking the meals for the family for years. Grandmother Ella Yandle became an invalid quite early in her married life. She gave birth to at least six children, and suffered a number of illnesses when she was relatively young. One of the illnesses was called eyeritis, and it was blind, and very frail. t was what caused my Aunt Helen to loose all her teeth. This I know because a doctor in Pineville tried to help my Aunt Helen when she was eighteen or so, and provided her with a liquid medicine that ate the enamel from her teeth. She survived the illness and the medication, but at the age of eighteen she lost all of her teeth. Of course it affected how she lived, and though she eventually wore dentures, she never married. Aunt Helen, and her brother, Uncle Eddie, seldom left the house. There was a filling station that sold cold drinks, snacks, and cigarettes that was next to on Pineville Road, only a hop and a skip from my Grandparent’s home, and the man who ran that station was, I think, the only friend my Uncle Eddie had. Uncle Eddie’s life consisted of taking care of the animals (cows, mule, pigs) and the fields where he did the plowing, sowing, and harvesting. I don’t know how much schooling he had, but my Aunt Pauline was the only one of my Dad’s siblings who finished high school and then went to college. the fields The man who ran it was about Uncle Eddie’s only friend. She lived on the farm owned by her parents, and became the cook and house-keeper when her mother was blinded by an illness called eyeritis.

Strangely, just this past week, I was advised that a woman attending our church had contracted that disease. There is still, in 2006, no medication that will make eyeritis go away. I know that it is painful, but I don’t know much else about that illness beyond the fact that it caused my Grandmother pain, and she became blind, never even knowing what my sister or me really looked like. She was old, of course, and very frail. She had a rocking chair with cushions, and she moved only between her bed and her chair for the rest of her life. One day when my Dad wanted to do some hammering and sawing and painting on the house, he and Uncle Eddie picked up Grandmother’s rocking chair while she sat in it, and carried her, chair and all, a short distance to Aunt Pauline’s house where she sat in comfort while Daddy did some work on her house and her room. My part of that afternoon was to keep Grandmother company, and put drops in her eyes when she needed them. , and I never knew her when she could walk

inflammation within the eye, and it can cause blindness. That was what happened to my grandmother, and because she was already quite frail, she was never able to attend to the work needed in the kitchen, nor could she see well enough to move around in the house. She remained an invalid for the rest of her life.

As I was growing up, more and more antidotes were being discovered. I was twelve, or perhaps thirteen, when I received my first Penicillin injection. medicine—with a capital M

Strangely I heard very recently—in 2006—that eyeritis was still an incurable disease. It affects the eyeball, and my grandmother became completely blind as a result of that illness. She never actually saw either my sister or me, and there was no medicine, nor treatment of any kind that would help her, except for a small bottle of fluid that seemed to soothe the pain she often suffered. In my memory I can still hear her rather pathetic request, “Put some drops in my eyses,” she would say. She required frequent applications of eye drops to avoid pain tto

for her parents and her brother; Eddie, who, as a very young boy was injured by a mule kick. Though he lived a long time, he tired easily, and after my grandfather died, Uncle Eddie depended a great deal on his younger brother, my Dad. Daddy would leave his own business at sowing and at harvest time, helping his brother with both planting and harvesting. Uncle Eddie never had a tractor. He had a mule that pulled his plow. They never had to buy milk at a grocery store. They kept cows, made their own butter, and actually never bought loaf bread at a store. Aunt Helen made her own loaves of whole-wheat bread or pans of biscuits. They had chickens, pigs, cows, and a mule, usually a bunch of cats, as well as at least one dog. When I was very small my Dad was the only one of their children not living at home. Aunt Pauline was the youngest child in my Dad’s family, and she was the one of the two girls who actually graduated from high school. My Aunt Martha graduated, and she began her training as a nurse at Presbyterian Hospital soon after she graduated. My Dad’s youngest sister, Pauline, also enrolled in college; and I think she graduated, and not so long afterwards, married. She and her husband rented a house very close to the Yandle farm so that she and her husband would be quite close to her parents. since her mother was truly an invalid.however, went to school until she graduated, and then went on to college. As a young adult she took a job with a publishing company in Charlotte, eventually bought a car, and commuted to Charlotte every work at that job until she retired in her old age. Aunt Pauline dayworked for that sambreadand help pick cotton, or harvest the corn or grains. My Dad also looked after their house, providing any repairs that were needed, and when I was in High School he built a small room with a door, and near the roof of that room he placed a window, and a toilet. at the end of their back porch. How he managed, I don’t really know, but he installed running water into the house (they had always carried water from a well) and when he was finished there was a toilet, which was much onto their house where he installed a modern toilet. At harvest time my Dad had to help Uncle Eddie , though she outlived all her siblings except for her for the rest of her life, which was spent in the home she was born in, along with her older brother who had been injured as a youth, and was never as strong nor as sure nor as active as my Dad. not actually have effective drugs to suggest to their patients. There were no true antibiotics. Sulfa was one of the very first, and most people realized that drinkable alcohol would dull pain, though it had side effects that were not at all helpful. Doctors truly wanted to help their patients, and actually they did. Some years before I was born one of my Dad’s sisters had a problem, and her physician There were a number of over-the-counter items that seemed to help. But there were few, , though there were lots of pills, that were, to some extent, . Yet some of the behaviors that are prominent in this day and in this time are neither new, nor good for people, whether or not someone is watching those events. Some times an idea that seems marvelous turns out to be harmful, and we all know that not every good deed is actually good, nor is every accidental change in the way we live always terrible. The attempts to improve our lives as we live and move and have our being sometimes bring defeat instead of victory, pain instead of healthhow we live and move and have our being can be either wonderful and powerful or terrible and never very old, avenues available in this Twenty-First Century are neither beautiful nor healthy or good for mankind, and yet they openly, enticingly exist, and often have no warning signs that admit that the glittering and seldom do such “opportunities” have warning signs that reveal the against such indulgences. Instead, there are advertisements urging the unwary to partake of excitement and pleasure, despite the difficulties that could arise from unwise use of some of the new and enticing eresting , but dangerous, opportunities. First there were motion pictures, and at their beginning they were fairly gentle and careful, often simply funny representations, made for all audiences, and along with radio which was also growing, there were interesting and amusing ways . Then there was radio entertainment, and to be frank, I don’t really know which came first—the phonograph, or the movieswith careful rules to prevent programs from giving offense.

Motion pictures improved, and rules were set to prevent nudity, and to protect yothere were special laws established to prevent the portrayal of motion pictures Then there is also television. In the early years of television there were strict rules about what could be portrayed before cameras, as there was about what could be said or sung on radio. Motion pictures also adhered to rules that kept filth off the screensand protection against ugliness and filth in the earliest days. Now you can find nudity, foul language, actors portraying sexual misconduct, very ugly fights, murders,

I can’t write much about my babyhood as I have only scattered, tiny flashes of memory, of my life before I started to school. Actually, during some of my earliest years I was not, as the baby, the center of attraction in my family. My sister was about six years older than me, and my family lived on East Fifth Street at that time. when she was in grammar school, probably either the third or fourth grade, there was a day when she played jump rope with her schoolmates. The school she was attending was very old. By the time I started to school Some of the rooms had been roped off as unsafe for use, and the playground, which I saw some years later, was not grassy nor was it furnished with slides or swings. By the time I saw it the school was no longer in use,re was little or no she became ill, quite suddenly when she was she was nine or ten years old. Because her illness was both quick and deadly, at least five doctors at Presbyterian Hospital in Charlotte, North Carolina, examined her. Four of those doctors said that in their opinion there was no hope of her recovery, and it would be better to keep Ella Cornelia as comfortable as possible until she died, because she would never again be really well and healthy. Dear, dependable Dr. Ashe said she would recover. It was brave of him, because in those days there were no effective antibiotics. There were few if any of the wonderful medicines available today. My sister had pleurisy, and her illness affected her heart.

The year was 1933 or 1934. Of course she was taken to a physician immediately when she developed a fever, and she was fairly quickly admitted to Presbyterian Hospital in Charlotte, N.C. One of the four or five physicians who examined her was Dr. John Ashe, Pediatrician. In those days there were no actual antibiotics, at least not as we know them today. Doctors could deliver babies, operate when people had appendicitis, and other illnesses, however, truly effective . . My Mother My sister’s illness began in the early 1930’s.

T It would either overcome the illness, or succumb to it. Of course there were palliatives for illnesses, but though they reduced pain, they did not actually fight the diseases. Sulfa had been a true help to fight infections, but it didn’t always work.

When my sister, six years older than me, became seriously ill, I was about two or three years old, and required a lot of attention, as would any other child my age. Because my mother needed to give all of her attention to my very ill sister, I was farmed out to her sister, my Aunt Ola, who had no children of her own, but had helped to raise her siblings who were now all adults , though they were adults, and married.

I was twelve, or thirteen years old in the 1940’s when I received my first penicillin shot. It was put on the market after the beginning of World War II.

If a person was strong and otherwise well, there was often a chance that his own , though no true promise, of recovery. For some years when I was a child people who went to the hospital were far more at risk of their lives than occurs today. The generation that included my parents saw wondrous improvements in the field of medicine. And I, myself, was among the earliest patients in Charlotte, North Carolina, to use penicillin. I was aware that most people resisted going to a hospital because the seriously ill more often than not didn’t come out alive. Hospitalization was often considered the last resort, when there was no genuine hope for recovery. For some illnesses that is still true today. But the marvelous treatments available today make

before but it wasn’t nor were there new and wonderful treatments, or machines, or special new inventions that would help her.

you can as , and only prayer and the attention of dear old Dr. Ashe stood between my sister and her predicted death. My sister, Ella Cornelia, was six years and a few months older than me. My parents had been married about a year when Ella Cornelia was born. Then came the Great Depression which hit the North with terrible and immediate devastation of bank holdings and savings, businesses and jobs. When businesses closed, their workers had no income. Working people suddenly had no jobs, and rushes to the banks to withdraw savings caused banks to close their doors, denying their customers access to their savings. People without jobs or money couldn’t pay either rent or promised amounts to mortgages, , and therefore jobs working people South with its terrible and devastating difficulties were married

One day recently while I was talking to my older sister on the telephone, she asked me if I actually had memories of living in the house on East Fifth Street in Charlotte. She, being a little more than six years older than me, had quite vivid memories of that home. I, because infants rarely remember ordinary events, and very young children seldom comprehend or before they are at least three or four years oldSince we had moved from that house when I was not quite three years old she was curious about how much I remembered about living there.

since that was the house our family lived in when I was born. Since we moved away from that house when I was very young it seemed unlikely that I actually did remember the interior of the house. Since my Dad’s Aunt and Uncle lived directly across the street from that house, my parents often reminded me each time we visited Aunt Lizzie and Uncle Edward—little older than a toddler. Because Since my Dad’s uncle and aunt lived across the street from that house and we visited them frequently, I was aware , for about twenty yearssaw the outside of that house frequently as I was growing up because my Grandfather Yandle’s sister and brother lived precisely across the street from the duplex we lived in when I was a baby, and we visited them on Sundays about once every month while I was growing up.

All children everywhere understand some things about people that their family visits often, even when they don’t really perceive all the reasons why their parents visit certain people, or don’t visit others. Small children simply accept the fact that they will be seeing some old people. At least that was the way I felt.

My Aunt Lizzie and Uncle Edward Yandle were, in my estimation at the age of five or six, two of the strangest folks I had every met. Neither of them resembled either of my grandparents, and certainly not any of my other aunts or uncles. They didn’t look like either of my parents, and they behaved differently from any other aunts and uncles, or grandparents, in our fairly wide family when you consider that there were three generations of us, including two sets of grandparents, and two sets of aunts and uncles who were really just brothers and sisters of both my parents. And since my Mother’s brother had married and had three children who lived within driving distance of Pineville, we had three cousins, and lots, and lots of older people who were cousins of our parents. When I was small we went to picnics in the summer down in somebody’s pasture when people of all ages gathered about once every year, and all those who attended brought food that was laid out on picnic tables so that everybody could eat all they wanted, and the tea was cooled in large metal tubs like the one’s my mother used when she washed our clothes every week, only these tubs had ice in them, keeping the tea cool. So far as I was concerned, I was flabbergasted by the fact that we ate from plates made of paper, and drank from cups made of waxed paper so they wouldn’t leak. I loved to collect and save the paper cups others discarded. Mother allowed me to play with them until they disintegrated—however I never tried to drink out of them. They were wonderful, for a short while, to play with in the sand pile.

. Across the street from that house , going on four years old. The year was 1933 or 1934. I had to think for several moments, and then I told her of two memories: one was of a dark, frightful place that I couldn’t escape, and the other was bright half circles on the floor. My sister, Ella Cornelia Yandle May told me that the dark place where I was frightened was a tiny entry at the back of the house, and that there

when I was about two and a half years old I managed to trap my small self in the back hall of our house where there was either no light at all, or one beyond my reach. I was, of course, quickly rescued. I’ve always had a loud mouth, and on that occasion I let out a scream that quickly brought my sister to help me. My other recollection of living in that abode was of the bright spots on the front porch floor. The banisters were unusual as they were solid from railing to the floor, much like a half wall. However, at intervals there was a crescent shaped opening cut through that solid wall to allow rain water to drain off the porch floor. When the sun was shining, those crescents were bright sun lit half circles on the porch floor that was otherwise quite dark in the shade of the solid banister, and I remember trying to pick up those lovely bright arches. on an otherwise shaded area, and I remember that I tried to pick up the beautiful half circle. I was probably close to three years old when our family moved to Eleventh Street where we lived in a two story duplex with six rooms in each side of the house—three downstairs (Living room, dining room and kitchen) and three bedrooms and a bathroom upstairs. The two dwellings were under one roof, and there was a shared wall which separated the two attached houses. In those days it was possible—not against the law—to rent out the upstairs of a house even though it meant that the downstairs folks had to share the bathroom with the upstairs folks, and the upstairs folks didn’t actually have a kitchen, and had to wash their dishes in the lavatory in the bathroom. It also meant that the downstairs folk had total control of the hot water tank. Granted, it was awkward for the person who did the cooking and dishwashing up stairs, and awkward for the down stairs folks who had to use the bathroom upstairs, but we managed, and so did the people in the other side of our duplex who also had two families in their side of the house.

When I was about thirteen our upstairs folks who had rented all three rooms of the upstairs left the house and things were re-arranged. Only two of the upstairs rooms were rented to a newly wed couple, who had a bed-sitting room and a smaller room that served as their kitchen. Mother and Daddy then placed twin beds in the third upstairs room and my sister and I had a bedroom to ourselves, and mother and Daddy had a bedroom between the kitchen and the living room, all by themselves. My sister and I slept on a double bed, and had a nice window that looked out over the back yard. From our window we could see the steeple of the Tenth Avenue Presbyterian Church, and hear its bells. Our window allowed us to enjoy any breeze that happened along, and we had—wonderful and marvelous for our own use—a radio. There was a small closet for our dresses, and we were just across the hall from the bathroom. We couldn’t “hog” the use of it because there was a young family renting the other two upstairs rooms, which meant we had to keep our door closed, but we enjoyed our own radio, and being able to listen to what we wanted to hear, and during the winter when the door was closed our parents could not hear that we were listening to late night programs on the radio.

When we had enjoyed our upstairs room for about two years, the family that had rented the other two rooms upstairs bought themselves a house, and then our family had six rooms—three downstairs, and three upstairs. Mother and Daddy moved upstairs, too, and we had another room that was sort of an “all purpose” room. Mother could sew there, we kept the washing machine there, and it became a place to store our bathroom towels and wash clothes, as well as out of season clothing. I had outgrown my dolls and my doll baby carriage, and they were stored in the extra room, which actually had a small closet in it, and all of us could use it for out of season clothing.

I was so happy to have a room of our own, and I decided that the dingy walls needed to be refreshed, and one day talked my Dad into giving me a bucket of paint.

with three windows instead of the one window we had at the back of the house. We could have twin beds, instead of sharing a double bed, and we had a nice sized closet for our clothes. We now had a dressing table that had a very nice mirror, and in our closet we could store our under clothes as well as hang our dresses, and my sister, who had five or six pairs of shoes had a place to keep them. ies as well We also had a chimney in that room, and Daddy put a warm morning heater in the room so that we could build a fire in it during the winter. moved our bedroom into a larger front room that had a large closet in it. Our parents took what had been the renting family’s kitchen as their bedroom, and then we had a junk room where we kept our newest and most wonderful modern item: a washing machine. Up until then we had washed clothes in the kitchen in two big wash-tubs, using a scrub board to get dirt out of my dad’s work clothes. We filled the tubs using our largest cooking pot to transfer water from spigot to tub. It took a lot of energy to transfer water from spigot to tub. Now we had an “attachment” that allowed us to fill the tub form the faucet, and a wonderful wringer to push the washed or rinsed clothes through—one that got out most of the water, it still took a long time to wash a week’s worth of clothes because we still had to run every rag we washed through the wringer, and then hang the clothes on a line in the back yard.

though we continued to use one tub of rinsing water as that had to be filled from the kitchen sink with bucket by bucket of water. Now we could affix a hose and fill the washingmachineby unless they came upstairs to the bathroom. not being in the room with Mother and Daddy a breeze when easily from our window, and at last could open our window at night in the summer to enjoy a breeze should one happen to be moving in the warm summer months. toThe last family that shared the house with us had only two roI was, I think, about ten or twelve years old before we could afford to pay rent for all six rooms just for our family. Then one day the Nance family moved out with their little red haired baby, and my sister and I took the largest room at the front of the house with three windows, and Mother somehow provided two single beds, one for each of us. We had a dressing table with a mirror, a stove for warmth in winter, and wonderful, wonderful large closet—something we had never had before—just for our own use. Our parents used another room where they had a closet, and they already had a bedroom suite and for a change they could use the double bed for themselves, because for a long time my sister and I had slept in the double bed, while our parents slept Eventually the upstairs people moved out, and my parents took one of the upstairs rooms as their bedroom, and placed my sister and I both in the same room , and I lived in that house with my sister and my parentsuntil I was married.

also quite awkward for both the people downstairs who had to share the bathroom. However both sides of our duplex housed two families, making four families under one roof. Togetherness was satisfactory only if everyone cooperated, and for the most part our family fared pretty well during the years we shared the house with other folk. The Depression era was still pinching families in the South, mostly because jobs were still scarce, and money was tight. My own memories of our early years in that house were that we lived in only two rooms: our kitchen and our bedroom. We had access to, and could use, the “front” room, however we had no furniture, and couldn’t serving as home to two families per side. It was the depression era, and such problems were simply dealt with because otherwise people couldn’t afford to rent a roof over their heads.

first floor kitchens and hall, including the staircases.

and the upstairs back bedroom and the staircases like mirror images of each other, with a single wall serving as the partition between them. The year I started first grade there was a family living

Strangely, the front porches did not connect, though the roof that covered both The kitchen, and the front hall of each house shared a single wall. that included a staircase had both front and back porches, but very little yard. . amily moved to Eleventh Street as they were shingled like a roof from the railing to the floor all the way around the porch. To prevent rain from pooling on the porch there were very small crescent shaped arches at intervals to allow water to run off. When the sun was positioned just so there was a bright made a bright crescent shaped shining had an arched opening that allowed rain water to drain off the porch floor. level with the floor that would allow rain to drain off the porch floor. shapeedIn those days that were definitely pre-air conditioning, the front porches were considered necessary, and in the city there were few houses that didn’t have a front porch with wooden chairs and a swing. Most of the porches were several feet off the ground, and they usually had a banister surouncing them. Most, though no all, porches had a railing to prevent people from falling off the porch. into bushes or ing yearHere in the South most of the houses had porches, usually furnished with “outdoor furniture” such as sturdy rocking chairs and/or bench shaped swings that hung from the ceiling. hat would hold at least two persons, while the constant movement of the swing would provide a soft breeze on warm evenings in the summer. Most porches offered little privacy, but were enclosed by railings upheld by inch square uprights that protected babies and old folks from falling off the porch, but didn’t hinder sunshine or cooling breezes, or wind driven rain. The porch at the front of our house on East Fifth Street was different. The banister was like half of a wall that reached a little more than three feet from the floor. To prevent rain from standing on the porch floor, there were at intervals a small opening that arched in a half circle at intervals all around that otherwise solid banister. I remember playing on the floor, and trying to touch the very bright half round arch only about four, or perhaps five, inches high at three or four inchesto allow , or rather, half a wall. The folks who sat on that porch had a lot more privacy than most porches. The builders that went only . were surrounded by a railing made of slender inch square banister with inch-square “pillars” that rested on which did not usually hinder full vision of the yard since the railing usually rested on small wooden upright, usually only inch square d hung on chains from the ceiling, and banisters usually surrounded the porch if it was more than a foot off the ground so that small children wouldn’t fall off the porches. or swings benches, and perhaps a wide swing that would accommodate at least two or more persons, and in the South, many of the porches were screened in to protect from bugs. surrounded by banisters that provided valuable safety against strong winds carrying off light-weight chairs, or children or unwary adults from stepping off the edge of a porch floor into bushes or other undesirable a careless step off the edge of were different in the house we lived in at the time. Instead of being a railing with narrow little poles holding it up, as is more usual nowadays, the porch of the house on East Fifth Street where we lived when I was less than three years old had a solid banister, except that at intervals there were small arched openings along the floor to allow rain run off. Since we moved away from that house when I was three years old, that memory is somewhat like a quick flashback—it has no beginning, nor does it have an end. It is of me, sitting in the shade of the solid banister, patting the bright arched reflection of the sun on the floor of the porch. I probably would have totally forgotten any small memory of that house had I not seen it many times as I was growing up. My Great Uncle Edward, and his sister, Great Aunt Elizabeth (called Aunt Lizzie) lived just across the street from that house my parents rented when I was so very young. It was not until I had a child of my own that my mother mentioned to me that our family had once lived in the 500 block of East Fifth Street in Charlotte.

When my parents were first married they lived with my Dad’s aunt and uncle. When I was old enough to understand that aunts and uncles were the sisters and brothers of my parents I was somewhat confused, because Aunt Elizabeth looked as old as the hills, and my Dad was quite young looking in comparison. Uncle Edward didn’t look quite as old Aunt Elizabeth, but I thought he was the strangest sort of person I had ever met. Both Aunt Lizzie and Uncle Edward me a lot better than I knew who they were, and what they were going to do, and so forth had a different vocabulary from anyone else in our family, and he definitely did not have a Southern drawl. His speech was always short, to the point, with no nonsense to it at all.

Those two people, Aunt Elizabeth (whom we called Aunt Lizzie) and her brother Edward Yandle, really were odd, and not like any of my other aunts or uncles. My Dad had three sisters and one brother, and my Mother was the younger of two girls, and she also had two brothers. None of them were as old as Aunt Lizzie and Uncle Edward. I think I must have been about eighteen when I finally realized that Aunt Lizzie and Uncle Edward were siblings, not of my Dad, but of my Dad’s father, or perhaps not him either. They were probably sisters of my Grandfather Yandle999999999999999999999999999999. married befor was a door to door salesman of a great many items such as Mentholatum, and/or Vicks Vapor Rub,

I thought all uncles had a wife who was an aunt. If they were uncles and aunts, they were brothers or sisters of my parents; however, Uncle Edward and Aunt Elizabeth didn’t fit any pattern I had ever learned about. My Grandmother Yandle was a skinny little old lady with very long black hair worn in a bun at the nape of her neck, and I never saw her in a dress. She wore night gowns with a lightweight house coat on top of it. Grandmother Yandle was an invalid, and blind. She had suffered from an illness that caused inflammation in her eye—not just on the outside of her eye, but the inside of it. She could upon some occasions tell whether or not it was dark outside her window, but she never actually saw either my sister or me, though she heard our voices often. There had been no medicine that would battle the illness. There was none when she lost her vision a little more than eighty years ago. To my surprise, by the time I, myself, had several grandchildren, I heard again that a lady in our church had eyritis.

, and had a way of talking that was totally unlike anyone else I knew. His sister, my Aunt Elizabeth who was fondly called Lizzie, was the most different female I had ever met. Both of them had different vocabularies than most of our kinfolks, and I never discovered why they talked so differently from anyone else in the family. My sister and I called her Aunt Lizzie. For one thing, she was very thin, and she wouldn’t touch a doorknob. If she had to open a door she would put her hand behind the apron she wore every day if she was in her own house. He used her apron as a buffer between herself and any germs that might live on the knob of the doors in her own house. , or in my house, if she happened to visit us. Both were slender, ented one or perhaps two rooms from my Dad’s uncle and aunt. They were brother and sister, and neither had ever married. Both were tall and slender and both had absolutely marvelous vocabularies. I never saw either of them less than well dressed, and never heard either of them talk with less than a beautiful vocabulary, and a very, very gentile manner. Both were always well dressed, and both were well educated. one, or perhaps two rooms from my Uncle Edward and Aunt Elizabeth Yandle, who lived directly across the street from the duplex my parents pointed out to me as the place our family lived in when I was born. Every time we visited my Aunt and Uncle they mentioned that we had once lived in that house. Uncle Edward and Aunt Elizabeth were, so far as I was concerned when I was very young, among the oddest sort of persons I had ever met. Today I would describe them as having been a little eccentric, but when I was a child, I thought there probably were not any other people in the entire world quite as odd as Uncle Edward and Aunt Elizabeth.

First off, they were brother and sister, and neither ever married. They shared a nice house, and the house itself was interesting to me. For one thing, it had both electric lights and gas lights. Why it had both I never actually learned. However, there was a fireplace in every downstairs room, and above the mantel there were gas lights in every room, and the stove in the kitchen was a gas stove. In the center of every ceiling in the house there was also an electric cord dangling with a light bulb at the end of it. Remember that these were the 1930’s and though Charlotte had both electricity and gas lines, street cars, and telephones, people who lived on farms a few miles from Charlotte did not yet have either running water or electricity in their homes. Both families used kerosene lamps after sun down, and both cooked on very large black wood stoves, not just in the winter, but all year. When it was cool or down-right cold, the kitchen was usually the warmest room in the house, because the fire in the kitchen stove was rarely allowed to go out. In summer cooking real meals could make the kitchen a miserable hot box, even with all the windows open. In really cold weather the big iron kitchen stove usually kept that room quite cozy and warm. In most country homes during the winter the fires usually didn’t go out, and instead were banked with ashes and rekindled in the morning. never actually died, but they were usually banked at night, which was a simple process of adding firewood, but covering the old red hot coals as well as when they had burned down to mere red coals, they were given more fuel, but were completely covered with cool ashes which prevented oxygen from reaching the coals. Simply removing the ashes and allowing the coals to and thereby prevented the fire from igniting the new fuel. Beneath the ashes the fire did not go out, nor did it flare up—it waited until it there was a source of oxygen, and then it rekindled itself burning the wood placed to prevent the fire from building up to a temperature that would cause wood to burst into to feeding the . instances the During the winter stoves were rarely allowed to truly extinguish the flames all together, and were seldom allowed to actually . Even to burn itself out, in winter as it was not only a cook stove, but the source for warming the kitchen and eating area of most country houses it was important to keep the fire burning throughout the day and into the evening. Near bedtime the stoves were usually “banked” which was simply covering the living fire with cooled ashes, hoping that the living fire would smolder beneath the ashes all night and that when morning arrived a few shreds of wood and a bran , though when morning came again the fire was expected to take up hoping that red coals would still be hot enough to start the fire again when early morning chores were began morning otally Most of the old black iron stoves had a reservoir at one end—which was simply a not very large tank (maybe holding three or perhaps even five gallons) because the stove would increase the temperature in the already hot kitchen making the process of cooking during the summer a miserably hot chore. It was especially difficult Some folk built a separate small building as a summer kitchen to prevent heating up the house for several hours in order to cook meals; however, my farmer kinfolks didn’t let a little heat bother them, and at least once every day they cooked a substantial meal even in the summer. . neither of my grandparents followed that Many in the middle of the day, or in the late afternoon a truly miserable time of dayOnly in the very warm summer did the fire actually go out during the day. . and though the chairs were usually the ordinary straight chairs used around the kitchen table people didn’t complain because they had “only” a straight chair to sit in. erefore the most comfortable room in the house. Rooms not in daily use, such as parlors or unused bed rooms d just for sleeping were rarely kept warm in winter in houses heated only by fireplaces. It was unsafe to leave most warm and comfortable room That made the kitchen extremely warm in summer, though it was wonderfully cozy in the winter. though my Mother’s older sister sometimes didn’t bother to use her stove on Sunday evenings if she was only cooking soup. There was a big hook that could be swung directly over the fire in the sitting room fireplace, and the same fire that warmed the room would warm the soup. Then Aunt Ola would dip out soup, and we would sit around the room and carefully spoon our soup into our mouths while the fire crackled and made us warm outside, and the soup warmed us all from the inside.

There was a very large arm her soup instead of taking the trouble to build another fire in the big black stove in the kitchen. If it was really cold, and our family was going to eat with them, we would not eat at the kitchen table, but sit in straight chairs in the sitting room and hold our bowls carefully because since no fire was built in the kitchen, it was warmer in the sitting room. sat in the sitting room that was between the kitchen and the bedroom Aunt Ola and Uncle Vance used. When I was very young, theshe hung a large black pot over the fire in the , because of my grandparentsThe parents of both my Dad and my Mother, both of whom lived south of Charlotte near the town of Pineville drew their water from either wells or springs, warmed their houses in winter with fire places in central rooms, and worked their farms with mule or horse drawn equipment. Their cooking was either in a pot hung over a wood fire in a fire place, or on top of, or in the oven of, a wood burning stove. The kitchen stove of usually kept the kitchen much warmer than the outside temperature in both winter and summer. served to warm the kitchen as well as heat a small tank of water, while baking food in the oven, or cooking it on top of the stove. The kitchen stove usually heated the kitchen in winter all through the day, and only in summer was the fire allowed to burn out, because the stove was usually the only access to hot, or even warm water, as all water in the olden days had to be carried into the house in a bucket from a well or a spring unless there was a river near by. a tank at one end to provide hot water, and an oven to a cooked on wood stoves, and went to the drug store, the hardware store, to church, or on a visit, either walked, rode in a buggy, or walked.traveled in buggies. Though the City of Charlotte had telephones before I was born, along with electric trolley cars that, like those still running in San Francisco, were connected to overhead electric lines as their power source, the people living in the countryside a few miles away from large cities still used kerosene lanterns or lamps. Water was drawn from wells or springs, and within Charlotte there were neighborhoods where there was a central pump to supply drinking water for people who lived in houses built so long ago that they had no piping nor indoor facilities like toilets. that were not had no access to rarely had running water inside their homes, nor the luxury of indoor toilets. Delivery for blocks of ice sold to homes for use in ice boxes to preserve foodwho had an As a child it was quite normalacked my grandparents had neither electricity nor running water in their houses.

buI was well aware that they were my Grandfather Yandle’s brother and sister, though Uncle Edward was nothing like my Grandfather Amos Yandle, and Aunt Elizabeth, who called my Grandmother Yandle Sissie, was nothing like my Grandmother. . Uncle Edward died when I was in my early teens, and his sister Elizabeth died when I was in high school. When

in the following yearsdesigned where the porch was sunshine bright because of the where the solid banister curved to allow the sun to touch the otherwise shadowed floor. days the porch also had bright arches of sun at the edge of the porch where that would attract a small child sitting on the floor in the shade of the solid banister. Because my Great Aunt Lizzie and her brother, Uncle Edward, lived across the street from that house, I was familiar with the outside of it, but I have no real memory of its interior.

Our family visited Aunt Lizzie and Uncle Edward for years, when parking was allowed along East Fifth Street. The sun cast a lovely shadow, allowing a small child to play on the floor in the shade, while there was still a half circle of sunshine on the floor at intervals where the arches designed to allow rain to run off the porch also entirely open to breezes, leaves, rain or hot sunletting sun or rain very small At

I was about the age five, going on six, and in Charlotte, North Carolina, the damage of the Depression was slowly fading, little by little, for the working people. historical time-wise in the southern part of the United States, it was an era when ordinary folk in the South were beginning to climb out of the difficulties caused by the Great Depression. My parents had arranged with my older sister to take me out of the house for the afternoon, and to return home with me a day or so before Christmaswhen our family acquired a marvelous home entertainment item that my family called a radio. Radio had been available for several years, of course, but those were “depression days” and only people without children to feed, or with lots of money, could actually own one of those marvelous devices. As the was beginning, and then expanding and growing, and when motion pictures were shown in movie houses there were rules about decency concerning dialog and the poses and clothing of actors and actresses that prohibited nudity, sexual acts, and foul language. Of course, as time passed and movie makers as well as television producers had used up most of their “nice” ideas there were requests to have one “bad” word in a movie, or one glimpse of nearly unclothed performers, and little by little the rules and protocols were stretched to include more and more unpleasant or actually foul language, with less and less decorum where conflicts were portrayed, until eventually decorum diminished until it no longer existed.

At first only the late night programs allowed the bad words. Then I noticed that some programs no longer hid terrible violence, blasphemy, or foul languages. It no longer mattered what time of day it was, until bad words and hate and sexual conduct was openly shown. The first time I encountered such a program it was about 1:00 A.M. I had worked eight hours, and then left work and went directly to the hospital, though my Mother was comatose and didn’t know I was there. On my way home I stopped at the home in which my Mother and Father-in-law lived, as they both were confined to their beds. They had a care-taker, however, several of the people hired to care for them had proved incompetent, and therefore I checked on them at least once every day. When I left them, I went by the hospital where my mother was a patient, stayed for an hour, and then went home to fix a supper for my husband who worked at night. I usually arrived there in time to make him a meal, pack his lunch box, and see him off to his job, which was from midnight to morning. That night I was later than usual since I had checked on our parents before coming home. After Bobby left for his job I turned on the television set, hoping to find a nice little story that had a happy ending—or something like that.
99999999999999999999 . in which my mother -my in-lawsat the house my father and mother in-law where both my father-in-law and my mother-in-law were bed ridden—I always checked to be sure their nurse was attending to them. When I arrived home I made and packed my husband’s “lunch” since he worked at night, and kissed him goodnight as he left for his job. Our children were married and had their own homes. I was alone in the house, tired, grieving because I had already done all I could to help those who were ill. I worked during the day, my husband worked every night, our children were married and had their own homes, and heart-sick myself because, though I could and did do my best to help the suffering ones, I could not

they didn’t among people were forgotten until one night before the turn of the century—still in the late 1990’s, I turned into a late night TV program. I was extremely weary, worried, and deeply sorrowing because there were no cures to be offered, and few effective palliatives for their discomfort. , nothing I could do beyond my Mother, who was in the hospital, was dying and the only thing the hospital could do was keep her drugged. My Mother-in-law was at home, however, she, too, was ill. Within a matter of time I was going to lose both of them. and I loved themin the hospital-in shown on TV, and actually witnessed a performance that included a man having intercourse with a woman, revealing their movements from the waist up and leaving no doubt about the effort it took to achieve their climax.

“making physical “love” to a woman, leaving very little to the imagination—with movements and gasps and mostly faces—however no one could have and that forbade the reporting of , and children could listen to most of the broadcasts without hearing curse words nor were there even the suggestion of filthy language. or details of sexual .
Not every indulgence is of God, and not all indulgences are good. My Mother told me that I should use the brains the Good Lord gave me, and think through the offerings of the world before making a decision, and always stay away from wrong doing. Because I am not perfect, I’m not certain I did all the things my mother told me to do, nor that I have withdrawn from situations that were not exactly good for me, but I can admit that I tried very hard.

I suppose I am taking for granted the idea that someone, somewhere, would ever care how I grew up, or how the world looked to me as time passed. My father was born in the Nineteenth Century, my Mother very early in the Twentieth. Their first child was born in 1924, and I was born in 1931. My husband of more than fifty years was born in 1925. My father served in the Merchant Marines in World War I, and my husband served in World War II. Many of my male friends during my teenage and college years served in Korea, and a little later I knew people who went to Vietnam. I was grateful that neither of my children had to serve in any war, however, our first born grandchild did enlist in the Air Force and served for about two years, however, there was no actual war during that time.

I am very near my seventy sixth birthday, and my husband of more than fifty years is eighty three. We seem to be mostly healthy, and quite mobile; however, neither of us could now manage to dance a jitterbug. We don’t do much running, and we don’t hold paying jobs. We live across the street from Louise and Mike, our daughter and her husband, and five of their nine children. Their first born is married and lives in Oregon with his wife and daughter, and one of their grown-up daughters along with her several pets lives in an apartment three or four miles along with her several pets only a few miles from her parents. only a few miles from us in an apartment, and we see her often. Two of their children live Louise and Mike’s grown up but unmarried children live in our house. Two , Louise, her husband, Mike and where four of their children still live. Ther family, and they are very good to us. Two of their children lived in the sam Most folks would mark me as a silly old woman, as I am a very ordinary and average person. I have never been mentioned in print except for a small paragraph in The Charlotte Observer when I performed a dance in a kindergarten presentation at the age of five, and again in 1954, because about a week before our wedding I sent a picture of me in my wedding gown to The Charlotte Observer, along with a short blurb about the wedding. The picture appeared in the Sunday edition of the paper the day after the wedding. That has been the extent of the publicity about my life.

Of course, in my long life amazing events have occurred, and of course many wonderful, frightening, exciting, and a few foolish things, as well, but then I comfort myself by admitting that no one is perfect, and lots of people live through mistakes.

From the time of my birth our close family was made up of only Mother, Daddy, older Sister and me, though there were lots of uncles, aunts, grandparents, cousins, and of course, after my sister and I married, there were our children. My Sister and her husband, Harry, had four children, two of whom married and both of them have children two children, each. My husband and I have both a daughter and a son. Our daughter married, and over the years she and her husband birthed or adopted children. There are six born children and three adopted children. The oldest adopted child was born with cerebral palsy, and spoke no English when he arrived home. He was immediately placed in school; however, language was difficult for him, as he didn’t realize for several long years that he could learn if he wanted to learn. By the time he realized he really could learn to do things, his school years were over. That young man goes to work at a sheltered workshop five days of each week, and has missed work for only two reasons. His trip to Disney World in Florida, and

only . He is paid a stipend, which is banked for him, and is accessible for his needs for clothing or special items. One of the most wonderful events in his life was the year his oldest brother planned a surprise for him. Roberto had already graduated from High School, and was working full time at a sheltered workshop. One Sunday morning the family went to church as usual, and after the morning service Roberto discovered that his oldest brother had rented an automobile—a snazzy red car—and his parents had packed clothing and toiletries for Roberto. Kenneth had made reservations at Disney World in Florida for both of them, and Kenneth and Roberto rode the rides, and visited the shows, and looked, and enjoyed the sights and the presentations in theatres, and the meals and seeing Mickey Mouse, and whirling and bouncing and swinging and eating special foods, served by fancy waiters. They both had a wonderful time. and in taking rides on the His brother Kenneth went to church, and when the morning service was over, his elder brother drove up to the church in a rented automobile, loaded with baggage containing a week’s worth of clothes for Roberto, is handicapped, and had very close to no training until he arrived in the United States.
