He attended school, however he knew no English when he arrived, and didn’t realize he could learn how to read, and therefore graduated from high school, however, he canTwo of the adopted children wanted a lot of children, and so our daughter birthed two children, adopted a little girl, and had another girl child, then a little later she had another oldest child birthed a bunch and adopted some, and has those two young couples had a lot of children. Our daughter and her husband cheated a little, and adopted childrenas she had four children, and has four grandchildren. As time went on, our children married and had children, and sadly we had to attend funerals for the older folk in our family. Even so, through thick and thin, good times and not so good times, my husband and I, who had only two children, now have fourteen grandchildren, three nieces and one nephew, and, recently we counted four great-grandchildren. We, ourselves are now elderly; our son is 48 years old, our daughter 51 years old. My sister, is seven years older than me, and is now a widow. My sister was named for both her grandmothers, and to prevent dismay at the dropping of either one of her names, the family has always called her by both names: Ella Cornelia—five syllables. I, too, have two names, however, had it have turned out that I was a boy, my mother had decided to name me James, and planned to call me Jimmy.

I have seldom been called Iris Jean, at least not since I was three or four years old, though my sister was always called by all six syllables of her double name. There was one cousin, almost as old as my sister, who gave her a nickname: “Corney” short for Cornelia. I thought that was neat, but no one else in the family agreed, and because of my early training in speaking her name, though I have almost reached my seventy-sixth birthday, I still call her by every clear syllable. When she reached high school her fellow students and teachers found her entire name a problem, and often shortened it. However at home and among kinfolk, she was still called her full name. Only her fellow students made up a shorter name for her. She answered to Ellie, Ella, or only Cornelia. After she was married and had children, The one that was eventually used most often by fellow workers and neighbors was Ella.

As in most families, names often were slightly altered to lessen the length of long names, or to make pronunciation easier, so that boys called James were often called Jimmy, and girls named Virginia were called Ginny. Since my name used only one syllable I didn’t have a problem. Even so, my mother had several names for me while I was still living at home. As an infant, I think she tried to give me my full name: Iris Jean. Then there was a catastrophe in our family, and I was no longer the center of attention and care.

Those who were born after 1945 will wonder both how and why such a thing as Poliomyelitis, or tuberculosis, or Infantile Paralysis, or even an infected cut could possibly do the damage it actually caused to the people stricken with the disease or injury before there were antibiotics. Medicines that actually cured illnesses did not always exist. Hospitals gave pills and potions to patients, and used pain killers and put people to sleep for surgeries and the setting of broken limbs, but when I was a child, and when World War II began, Sulfa was about the only medicine available, and that didn’t work on every illness. Surgeries and knowledge was not as great as it is today. My Dad’s sister, Helen, had a problem. Her doctor diagnosed her illness, and decided she needed some substance that was not actually a medicine, and therefore he made up his own concoction. I took the enamel off her teeth, and before she was twenty years old Aunt Helen had to have her teeth—every one of them—pulled. She wore false teeth from her twentieth year. I, myself, have seen huge changes in physical care by doctors and dentists. As a child The physicians of those days tried to help the sick, however, they had very little to work with. Surgeries were

Of course we had a few pain-killers, and vitamins and minerals, there was alcohol to cleanse wounds, and a number of palliatives that worked; however, there were few injections that would prevent illnesses, and no student could enter school without a small pox vaccination. In some parts of the world contagious diseases were rampart, and leprosy could not be cured anywhere on earth, and neither could tuberculosis. Women all over the world continued to die during childbirth, an most families, even today, can remember stories of families where one man would have married four or five women because four of the them died in childbirth. that about two generations back there would be members of a family who married three or four times, not because of divorce, but because the wife and mother died in childbirth, and the husband married again. there was no people were without the knowledge or a method were required before a child could enter school, and there were other injections that were meant to provide immunity to common illnesses. no wide spread usage of injections were no actual antibiotics, and diseases such as chicken pox, measles, mumps, coughs—and dreadful, terrible, Tuberculosis—as well other frightening and sometimes fatal illnesses killed and . Children who contracted measles and chicken pox, and several other “children’s diseases” were quarantined. They could not leave their homes until they were well, and could no longer pass the disease to other children or adults. A very noticeable pasteboard placard was nailed to the wall beside the front door warning all who approached the door that there was a contagious illness within that home, so that vulnerable persons could avoid the risk catching that disease.

The illnesses that were common, and usually didn’t cause much damage nor last very long were not subject to notification in such a prominent way as a colorful notice beside the front door. There was no warning on the door when my sister, at about the age of ten, in about 1932 or 1933, became extremely ill. Our mother blamed the illness on intense exertion when playing games with schoolmates.

In those days when there was no television, and few radios, children actually went out into the yard and played together. Schools, particularly, encouraged students to be active during recess, making it likely the children would be quieter and likely to actually listen to the teacher after a strenuous play time. Teachers in charge of school playgrounds urged the children to play team games, to allow as many students as possible to move around during recess and be tired enough to sit down and listen to the teacher when they returned to the school room. It usually worked pretty well, and the students usually enjoyed playing the games together.

One day the teacher of my sister’s class handed her female students a long jump rope, and they went outside to play during recess. The girls in the class enjoyed playing jump rope, which wasn’t a complicated game, however it did command very careful movements, rhythm, and stamina to win, and win again. The game usually began by choosing sides, so that one team would be the jumpers, and the other team would provide the strong arms of the rope turners. When a jumper touched the rope, she had to step aside leaving her teammates. When all of one team had stepped aside two people in that group would become turners of the rope, and the other group would become the jumpers. However, if the last jumper could manage to jump ten turn

It is only a child’s game. There were no prizes for the winning group, and no disgrace for the losing group. However it did keep students moving so that when they returned to their desks they would probably enjoy sitting down, at least for a little while, and could complete their assignments without being fidgety. Since I was only about three years old at the time, I don’t really know what the temperature was that day, nor did I ever learn how many children were playing that game of jump rope. I was far too young to realize either the difficulty that faced my entire family nor the seriousness of the illness that struck my sister after that strenuous game of jump rope. truly pleased with herself. g , so it didn’t It it would be the other team’s time to become jumpers, and the losing team’s tityime to turn the rope.

On that long ago day my sister was in the jumping group. The rules were, that when only one member of a team was still jumping, she could restore her group as jumpers instead of their becoming the rope turners if—and it was a big if—the last jumper still jumping in the game could successfully jump ten turns of the rope alone without touching the rope. For such a wonderful performance, her entire group could rejoin her as jumpers, and jump until they again touched the rope. There was no limit to the number of times the last jumper of the team could jump ten turns of the rope, keeping his team in place to jump. That day my sister’s group was the jumping group. Of course, even very good jumpers would eventually stumble, and the other team could have a chance at jumping the rope. However, that day didn’t turn out that way. My sister was a determined person, and she was a pretty good athlete. When her first team began to dwindle she didn’t worry, because she was very good at jumping, and eventually she was the last jumper, so she jumped ten turns of the rope by herself, and won another chance for her team. Her team rejoined her, and the game continued. There were no rest periods except those imposed when jumping teams changed from jumpers to rope turners for the other group.

So she was the last surviving jumper in her group, , instead of becoming the turners of the rope, and the spectators of what the other team could manage to achieve. that would allow his team to start over again. and f only one jumper was left when a bunch of them had stood in a line and jumped the rope together without touching itiIf the jumpers were touched by the rope, they had to leave the game. If all except one jumper had been touched by the rope and had left the game, leaving only one jumper still eligible to jump, the rope turners would count the jumps, and if the single jumper could jump ten times without touching the rope, his entire team could return to the game, and the would still be jumpers, and the onlookers would hope that pretty soon they could become the jumpers, and the The group was usually divided into two teams. One team became an audience, and the other team would try to jump a moving rope without touching it. Touch the rope, and you must stand aside and become an on-looker. When only one jumper has not touched the rope the one jumper can redeem his team, and start the game all over again by dodging the rope for ten swoops. Then the game begins, with the same group of jumpers still jumping, and the same crew would swing the rope again, hoping the entire group will be hit by the rope of the rope. However, the person who of jumpers by jumping the rope ten times without touching it. Then the entire group can join the jumpers and jump until . . Usually two students turned the rope, and half of the remaining students other students who wanted to play began to jump the rope as it hit the ground, trying not to touch the rope with hands or feet, while a half of their number became spectators. elected or volunteering students would stand as far apart as possible with the rope loosely stretched between them, allowing the middle of the rope to touch the ground for several feet. Jumpers could actually line up, and when the rope was lifted and Then the chosen jumpers would either stand by the rope until it swung over their heads and then when the rope touched the ground on the other side of them touched the ground again at two holding the rope would begin to swing the ends of the rope in a circle that reached above their heads, but touched the ground for several feet, and one strong armed were divided into two teams. One team would provide rotating players to turn the rope, and the other team would, as a group, stand in a line and try to jump over the rope as it swept the ground under their feet, and the and then whirled over their heads, descending until the rope again swept under their feet. in an and again sweeping under their feet, then rising up and under their jumping feet. My sister was one of the jumpers. As the rope swished over their heads and swept downward the slip under their feet, one by one the jumpers made the error of touching the rope, or the allowing the rope to touch them. Once touched by the rope the jumper became a spectator instead of a jumper. However if the last jumper could, all by herself, jump ten turns of the rope without its touching her, her team of jumpers could rejoin her as a jumper. She had won reinstatement for her team. jumpers were touched by the rope, they had to leave the game, diminishing the number of jumpers. When only one jumper was left, she could, if she had the stamina, jump ten turns of the rope, and her teammates could join her again as jumpers. If the last jumper failed to jump ten times, the jumpers took over the chore of turning the rope, and the other team, which had mostly been watching the game, became the jumpers.

999999999999999999999999999

If er they became the rope turners and spectators, while the other team with its rope turners became jumpers, it gave the jumpers a break and the waiting team a chance to jump. However, there was a way for the very last jumper in the team to “win” another chance for her team, by jumping ten turns of the rope without touching it, and redeeming all of her team mates allowing them to rejoin the game. Ella Cornelia on that day was the champion jumper.

Her team jumped rope for ten games. Most of her team mates, had the opportunity to rest a little, however, my sister was the one who jumped ten turns of the rope when she alone was the only one on her team so that most of her team had some short stretches of rest while Ella Cornelia single handedly jumped to ten between each of ten separate games. She had no rest, s team were the jumpers, and she jumped every turn of the rope until she was the only jumper left, then she jumped ten times without touching the rope and won the return of all of her team mates. However, she could not rest, as she had to be part of her team when they began to jump again. Ella Cornelia was very proud of herself that day. She was the teammate who jumped ten times so that her team could continue to jump, instead of just turning the rope. Though her teammates touched the rope, she, alone, jumped ten games, and jumped ten turns ten times, every game, jumping ten turns of the rope Her team

T

except one jumper had been touched by the rope, that probably tired jumper had the option of jumping ten turns of the rope without touching it, and “winning” her team back as jumpers. Otherwise, the other team would become the jumpers, and the and therefore was out of the game, the last jumper could jump ten turns of the rope, and “win” her team back as jumpers.

had toand at school was often played by two teams, with as close to an equal number of players as they could manage. One team selected two girls to turn the rope, and their teammates became the spectators. The other team became the jumpers, and all of them lined up to jump the rope at one time. Of course when the team was large the jumpers at either end of the group were at a slight disadvantage, as the turning rope touched the ground in the middle, but was higher from the ground near the turners. Usually the jumpers became tired and touched the rope as it turned, and that team became the rope turners, and the former rope turners became the jumpers.

On that particular day my sister’s group became the jumpers, and she was in the very middle of the line of jumpers. All of her team-mates touched the rope, however,

the teams changed places, so that the jumpers became turners, and the turners and their team mates became jumpers.

One day at school my sister played that game. Her “team” was first to jump. And she was

and the other team became the jumpers. The teammates of the rope turners became the spectators. The team that was to jump took their place, and tried not to touch the whirling rope, as the jumpers were “out” of the game if they were touched by the rope. Lots of people on the same team usually lost the clumsy jumpers quickly, and eventually most of the jumpers became tired, and touched the rope. However, if only one team member was left, that jumper could jump ten turns of the rope, and thereby win the right to invite all his teammates to rejoin him as jumpers. It was great fun for the winning group keep jumping, keeping the other team standing there watching. When all of the jumpers had jumper was left and

their other teammates watched the game. The second team, all at one time, lined up and all jumped the turning rope at the same time. However, any jumper who touched the rope was out of the game, which eventually reduced the jumpers to only one which had not been touched by the rope. If that, by now very tired jumper, could jump ten turns of the rope without touching it, she won the continuation of her team as the jumpers, and all of that team could return to the game as jumpers. leaving her teammates to continue the game. When all the jumpers had touched the rope, the teams changed places, and the rope turning team became the jumpers, and the girls who had been jumpers became the rope turners with her teammates forming the audience. only one jumper was left, that girl, if she was not too tired, could jump ten turns of the rope without touching, and win back her entire team of jumpers to try again.

teams jumpers for another she could bring her team back into complete action by jumping ten turns of the rope without touching it. Then the jumpers in her team could all come back into the game. classmates could return, that jumper could continue to jump for ten turns of the rope, and if successful, had not been touched by the rope, that girl, if she was not too tired, and would try to jump ten turns of the rope without touhing it. could win the return of all of the girls who had jumped with her by jumping ten turns of the rope without touching it.assuring that the number of jumpers were depleted, usually one by one, until there was only one jumper.

trying not to touch the rope as they skipped over it. Jumpers touched by the rope were out of the game. However, when the next to the last jumper had to step out of the game, leaving only one jumper, if that remaining jumper could jump ten turns of the rope without touching it, her team could return to jump with her, and that meant that there was a team of jumpers who had not yet had the opportunity to jump. that girl cwere out of the game when they touched the whirling rope. My sister was quite athletic, and on that warm day she was in the group of girls who were jumpers while members of the opposite team turned the rope and watched the jumpers to report any contact with the rope. Touching the rope The game had rules. If the jumping team was left with only one . producof a rope turned by two girls on the other team. Even group jump rope had rules. One team selected rope turners, and the other team—the entire team—fell in line between the two rope turners and jumped at the same time. A jumper touched by the rope was out of the game. When all the jumpers were out of the game, as it turned, or stepping on the rope, was out of the game. When only one jumper was left, she could, if she was not too tired, or thirsty, jump ten turns of the rope without touching it, and her entire team could return to the game, and all of them could resume the game. there was Touching the rope while jumping

so very young, I don’t know which house my parents lived in, or which school my sister was attending. when my sister became illyear, and schools and governments were affected by the Depression as well as all working people all over our nation. The children in school usually A group of her schoolmates and friends were playing jump rope, not as individuals, but as two groups.

One group turned the rope One group would supply girls who would turn the rope, and the others would watch to make sure no one in the Jumping group actually touched the rope, because touching the rope meant that jumper was out of the game. When . One group picked out two young persons to turn the rope, and the other group became the jumpers—all at one time. With each turn of the rope it was possible for at least one or more jumpers to touch, or be touched by, the turning rope, which would disqualify the person who came in contact with the , and jumper to touch the rope, the . Touching the rope meant the jua group of the other team became the jumpers. others . (I was not quite three years old) became extremely ill. I was too young at that time to put the syllables together to actually name the illness, but it affected both her lungs and her heart.

When Ella Cornelia was quite young as the youngest also the most important child in the family. I was, for the most part, a healthy child. I am sure I had the normal and expected illnesses of any child, but my illnesses were always ordinary, more than likely my sister had suffered them also because she was the oldest, and I was a normal, healthy child. I, of course, was still a very small child when my sister was suddenly so ill that four well known doctors in Charlotte told my parents she would not recover, she would die. There was no hope of recovery.

Only one of the five doctors who examined her said she could live, though she might be frail fro a while. He believed she would live and not die.

The doctor’s name was John R. Ashe. And Dr. Ashe was correct. He did not give up, and kept treating my sister with strength and courage and after a time my sister did begin to mend from the attack of pleurisy as well as another illness, the name of which I cannot remember because I was only a few months older than two years at the time, and because I was so young, it was seldom discussed in my presence. By the time I might have understood the illness, my sister disliked hearing about that part of her life so that it was seldom discussed within the family. Though she lived as if she were strong and healthy she was not really either totally strong nor was she totally healthy and immune to ordinary aches, pains, and illnesses. Even so, she fought being treated as an invalid, or as one susceptible to illness, despite being actually vulnerable to whatever illness popped up in her school or within the group of children she played with. Nothing made my sister angrier than a warning aimed at curtaining my sister’s play time because someone else was ill.

While Ella Cornelia was ill, and during her recovery, I was actually quiet healthy. Because I was healthy, and my sister needed constant nursing and attention, I needed only to be fed, kept clean, and put to bed on time in the evening, and therefore did not need my mother as much as my sister did. I was farmed out, mostly to my mother’s sister, Ola Davis, who had no children of her own. However, as the oldest child, she had helped raise her three siblings, and had also taken care of a wheelchair bound cousin who had survived Poliomyelitis, a crippling disease. My mother felt I would be safe with Aunt Ola while she gave all her attention to Ella Cornelia who had been diagnosed with two diseases that, in that day and time when there were no actual antibiotics and few palliative medications. Both her heart and her lungs were involved, and four well known physicians told my parents she would die because there was no cure, no medicines, and she was very ill. There was one physician who was a pediatrician in the early 1930’s, and who had two children of his own. Our mother was fighting for her child with all her faith, all her energy, and all her courage, as was our father. Dr. Ashe said she could get well. She could live. And my parents believed him.

It was not an easy process. She was in the hospital a very long time. When she was allowed to return home, she was forbidden to walk at all. She lived in a wheel chair for months. She missed a year of school, though she could do some studying at home. She was not allowed to walk across a room. She could not be left alone since she was forbidden to move very much at all. In this day and time a person in such straits could at least turn on the television and see what was happening in the world. Our family didn’t even have a radio. She could read, but actually reading had never appealed to her as a rich way to spend a boring day. Think, too, that this was early in our nation’s recovery from the Great Depression. Hospitals, medicines, medical appointments were certainly not as expensive as they are today—but they were not by any stretch of the imagination free. My Dad had become a paint contractor when he lost his job at a lumber yard which closed when no one could build houses or anything else, nor could builders pay for the lumber they had already used to make houses not yet sold. Nothing could be borrowed from banks—they had failed. Banks simply closed their doors.

Of course, some people did have money to live on. Some home owners who were not actually buying their houses by monthly payments didn’t have the problem. However men and women who had lost their jobs did not get paid, nor were there job openings when stores closed or the businesses stopped doing business because no one could pay them. Had most people been frugal and saved money for a rainy day? Of course many had been that wise; however, the banks were also struck by the shortage of business, and once a crowd of their depositors took out all of the money they had on hand, the banks had to close their doors. They no longer had money to hand out, even if it was owed. If a store or business closed, the people who worked there were out of a job. If a business stopped doing business, no salaries were paid, and no one could afford to buy much of anything in the way of groceries, clothing, medicines, or any other absolutely necessary commodities. Families who had bought a home to shelter their families, and were making steady payments each month, discovered they could no longer make the payments, and therefore they had broken their commitment and could be ordered to leave the property as they had defaulted on the payments. 999999999999999999999999999999999 , homeowners had lost their incomes, could not pay rent and were bumped out of their houses, had had no problems they pay for the lumber and nails and roofing they had delivered just before the when the Depression hit Charlotte and affected almost every sort of business. The lumber yard closed, and therefore he had no job. He had not trained in any way to be a painter, but he borrowed two-by-fours from his former boss at the lumber yard, and built himself a ladder, bought a brush on credit along with a bucket of paint, and went to work as a paint contractor. That was the business he worked with until he retired. . , and neither were hospitals. My parents were renting a wheel chair, which my sister hated.

there was hope was no novice where child care was concerned. , though she had helped and was well taken care of,

the youngest, and When I was very small I was called Jimmie upon occasion, as a nick-name. I could never figure out why they occasionally called me Jimmie. Then it dawned upon me that since my parents already had a girl child, they had wanted the second child to be a boy. That meant that my birth, since I was only a girl instead of a boy, I disappointed them—that I, being a girl, was less welcome in the family. I assumed that I was a disappointment since I turned out to be female that they didn’t even want to try again.

In those days, and before them, there were many people who never, ever admitted that a child was on the way. It was believed that small children should not be bothered with that knowledge lest they learn too early the exact processes of producing children. When observant children remembered physical changes of pregnancy they were not so surprised at the result, but my sister had not noticed how “fat” mother was, and she had a very unexpected introduction to her sibling, after a little more than six full years of being the only child. She was also the only grandchild in the Yandle family, and the first grandchild in the Parks 999999999999999999999999999

, as well as the only grandchild in the Yandle family, and held the position of being the first grandchild in the Parks family, as well as the first child in her immediate family. She had also been the first grandchild in the Yandle and the Parks families. been, when she had been not only the only child, but the only grandchild in the Yandle family, and the oldest grandchild in the Parks family. In those days when the Depression was a heavy burden in the South the cousins, who lived in South Carolina, rarely visited their grandparents. Therefore, they were not much of a threat to the standing of Ella Cornelia within her close family. She was important as the only child, the only grandchild in the Yandle family, and though not the only child in the Parks family, she was the very first grandchild, and her cousins were much younger than she, so that she was still in an enviable position.

in the Parks family. e , not only as the and Queen , and therefore didn’t seem to be a problem even though I was female, they could at least call me Jimmie. Both my paternal and maternal grandparents were living when I was born, and I had the pleasure and the privilege of knowing all four of them when I was young. As we were growing up my sister and I had two sets of Grandparents. Our Mother’s parents had the surname of Parks, and our Dad’s kinfolk had the surname of Yandle. I, of course, have no idea where either of those names originated. My forebears may have been among the people who, at one period of time, left Scotland to live in Ireland, or were simply from England, before they migrated to America.

I, my young self as I was growing up, was aware of only three generations of our family—my sister and me, with our parents and the parents of both our mother, and our father. Our parents had brothers and sisters, and a few of them married and some had children so that we had cousins, too. Most of our close kin lived within fifty miles of our house, though of course there were a few not so close kinfolks who lived in other states. The far away kinfolks were seldom seen and rarely visited, not because we didn’t want to see them, but because my sister I, and our parents, as well as our grandparents were born without those silver spoons. I do mean there were no fortunes to spread out, as every generation had to work, and work hard, to earn a living Our great-grandparents had come from England in the 1800’s and my great grandfather ran a grocery store during the War Between the States, otherwise known as the Civil War. When he came to the United States he was one among a very large group of Yandles and Johnstons. A search for ancestors showed that a very large group—twenty or thirty people at least—almost all with one of two last names. Most of them were either Yandles, or Johnstons. When I saw a list of names of a long list of Yandles and Johnstons, I discovered that most of the Johnstons women had married Yandle men, and Most of the Johnston men had married Yandle Women. My Great Grandfather was a Yandle, who married a Johnston wife, and when she died young, he married a Johnston wife. Grandfather and his second wife celebrated their Fiftith wedding anniversary when my father was a young lad. It was a grand occasion, and he had a special reason for remembering it so very vividly.

My dad and all the youths who were still considered “children” were warned that since there was only one dining table available, the special meal would have to be served one table at a time, with guests taking turns according to age. Therefore the young boys would be last at the table.
There was a table-full of boys who thought poorly of that announcement. Realizing it would be a long hungering time until they could be fed, they thought up a way to make the time go faster. One of the brave youngsters swiped a cigar from a very large box of cigars given to Grandfather as a 50th wedding anniversary celebration present. They had some matches, too. Behind the barn where they could not be seen from the house, they lit the cigar, and took turns puffing on it. None of the boys had ever before tried smoking. At that time there were not many regulatory rules on how potent the tobacco could be in the smokes, and by the time they had smoked it down to a very short stub, every boy who had puffed the cigar felt sick on his stomach. And just as they began to feel nauseous they were finally called to the banquet table. The women who had made the meal, and who served the meal were puzzled that the boys only picked at their food, and actually didn’t eat very much. However, they were too tired to make a fuss about the uneaten meal, and they simply cleared the table and washed the dishes, very happy to be finished with serving dinner to a large crowd of people. Daddy told that story to us at home, many years latter. He laughed when he told about himself and the other boys, but he wasn’t laughing when he couldn’t eat his meal. He had always loved eating—and he ate a lot. Since tobacco made him sick, so far as I know, he never smoked another cigar or cigarette in his life, and wouldn’t stay in a room with smokers if he could help it.

Another thing my Dad did not do was drink alcoholic beverages. He told me that he wasn’t old enough to drink liquor. The first time he said that to me I was about six years old. He said it year after year, and he never got old enough to indulge in alcohol.

ided to go out into the pasture in the shade of the barn and try out something they had never had the opportunity to do before. Gifts, of course, had been brought to the couple who had been married fifty years. One of the gifts was a large box of Cigars. The boys decided that one cigar would never be missed, and none of them had ever tried one. They took only one cigar,

older guests would eat first, his young cousins, and other young persons who had been invited to the Golden Wedding celebration, were warned that, since there was only one dining table, the guests at on that wondrous occasion so well attended occasion could not eat at the same time, and all would be served one table full at the time. The children were, of course, last. A bunch of boys close to my Dad’s age at that time were keeping each other company, and all of them had been warned to be on their best—their very best—behavior. They endeavored to accommodate their parents; however, they were hungry, tired of waiting, and bored while their all their elders took turns at the table for the exciting and generous meal. Among the visitors there were a number of boys about my Dad’s age, and they were among the youngest guests and would be fed last, and were bored. That was, for the boys, a real Bummer! While they were waiting, there was nothing much to do, and so they walked out behind the barn and concocted a new and wonderful idea. Their grandfather had received a marvelous gift the boys had noticed. It was a big box of cigars. Hungry boys had to do—really do—something. One of them went back to the house to purloin one cigar from the big box that had been Grandfather’s anniversary present. The boys had matches, and decided to light up the cigar and take turns smoking it. So they did. A little while after that they were called into supper. The servers could not believe their eyes when the boys, each and every one, ate so very lightly, not asking for more food, and not even eating all on their plates. None of them seemed hungry. It was a mystery to the cooks and servers. The boys, hungry, forced to wait until later, went out behind the barn where it was shady, and decided that simply waiting and talking was far too dull, especially as they had been waiting to be called to the table for hours. One of the boys had strolled through a room where some Fiftieth Wedding as there was only one table. Everyone would eat according to age and stamina, and the young children would be last. My Daddy was one of the last. There were a bunch of boys about his age, and they were bored since they were in their best clothes they couldn’t do daring tricks

’s wifeof those kin folk I found thatabout that group It would be confusing only the name of Yandle, or Johnston. Yandle’s had married Johnston’s and Johnston’s had married Yandles, and I was a bit confused to see that some Yandles had married Yandles, and some Johnstons had married Johnstons, thou that may have that I wonder how in the world they ever kept everybody straight. While going through information about them, I found that Johnston’s had married Johnston’s and Yandles had married Yandles, and that, too, struck me as odd. I wondered how they sorted out all those connections. and Johnstons had married Yandles and they settled in the Carolinas, working for their living, going to church on Sunday, and taking care of their families. Oddly enough, some members of my husband’s family and some members of my family grew up in the same area, and were acquainted with each other, though in my generation my Yandle Grandparents were old, almost never leaving their home. Most of their children, Aunts Helen, Martha, and Pauline, and my Uncle Eddie still lived at home when I was small. My Dad was the only one who was married and living away from the home place. The Home Place was a large two story house with both a front and back porch., in front of the steps in the front of the house was a grassy pathway lined on both sides with daffodils which bloomed every Spring. The front yard was grassy all the way to the ditch that ran along both sides of the highway to catch the rain that fell on the roadway. Close to the road one swath of the yard was the same level as the road, itself. However, about fifteen or twenty feet from the highway there was a slanting hill that was easy to walk up, or down and at the top of that fairly steep bank that was always covered with grass, there was another level of the yard, and for much of the way there was a well-kept level earthen walkway up to the steps, with and on each side of that walkway there were daffodils in the Spring, and little green leaves that stood straight up in rows during most of the rest of the year. All along the upper level of the yard were huge oak trees that shaded the house. 999 The front of the two story house had a large front porch and on it there were rocking chairs and straight chairs for resting, and a nice porch swing at one end of the porch. The famly could sit there in the shade of the marvelous trees that grew around the house, and watch an endless series of trucks, cars, motorcycles, as well as the occasional horse-drawn conveyance or even a pedestrian, move with an even and determined pace along the road. Pineville, on the nearly white cement surface of Pineville Road, with a big black line right down the middle of the road. . move toward either away fromThere was ers and a swing, ready when folks wanted to sit quietly and watch the traffic roll by on the highway. Sitting in the swing you could see all of the front yard, the side yard, part of a pasture, and the acreage my Grandfather owned across the highway which was usually planted with cotton, or corn, and sometimes with vegetables and lovely things like water melons, and sometimes beans and squash and okra and tomatoes. I was only in that field once or twice, because as a little girl I was not allowed to cross the highway without my parents or other adults. Most of the visits were spent in Grandmother’s room, where grown-ups talked and remembered, and discussed what was going on in the world. Though it was Most of the time we visited there my parents spent the afternoon talking with my Grandmother, because she was blind, and bed-ridden. The sitting room of the house had become her bedroom before I was born. During an average day in warm weather she would sit in her rocking chair near a window to eat her meals, and as long as she was comfortable in her chair. When she felt tired, she would go back to bed. Her daughters helped her with washing and dressing, and allowed her to snap beans or do any small chore that didn’t require sight, and that she could do sitting down. , f bed. When she became tired, she lay in her bed. If there was a visitor, or any member of the family to converse with, she would listen to the people who talked to her, and she would talk with them also. She ate in her bedroom her three meals each day, brought to her by one or the other of her oldest two daughters. Grandmother had a rocking chair with a pillow on the seat, and a soft pad that covered the back of the chair, as well. She walked only from her bed to her rocking chair, or from her chair to the bed. She did not go to the table to eat even on special occasions. She literally lived in that room, and left it only once that I was aware of during my childhood. One day my Dad spent the day doing something, probably painting the walls and ceiling of the room, and it was decided that Grandmother should be spared the entire process of painting walls and ceilings as well as window frames and doors, and my Dad and my Uncle Eddie picked up the rocking chair my grandmother usually sat on, and carried her outside the house and across her own yard, a dirt road, and two more back yards into another house rented by Aunt Pauline and her husband. Grandmother then spent a long part of the day in Aunt Pauline’s living room. Aunt Pauline had married a family Henry On Sunday mother and . that ran in front of the house. It was a busy road, and led to York if you kept straight down the highway from the house. However, if you drove only half a mile past the Yandle house, then turned right and kept on going, you would find that the road itself widened for a short distance, making room for cars to park diagonally along the street where there were stores: a drug store, a barber shop, a hardware store, a five and ten cent store owned by Mr. and Mrs. Jaffa, who owned several five and ten cent stores—six or more of them—all over Charlotte and in small towns ten or twenty miles from Charlotte. The road that went straight through the town of Pineville crossed the railroad track, then a little beyond the tracks there was a bridge over a wide creek, and a little bit further from Pineville was the South Carolina line. Not far from the town of Pineville there was a road that stretched into South Carolina, city blockand there were buildings on both side of the street just like uptown Charlotte, with shop windows, a drug store, a bank, an office building, a cotton mill, and the railroad track. Beyond the railroad track there was just road going toward a bridge that extended over a large creek, after which the road continued toward the fairly close South Carolina Line.

The road through the town of Pineville covered more space than an ordinary road in Charlotte, because cars could park on both sides of the road, and they did not parallel park in Pineville. They parked the cars nose-in to the curb along the sidewalk, , and a little just the was, of course, went straight road

were still living with them when I was very young. My Dad was the youngest boy of that family, and he had one older brother and two older sisters, and one younger sister, named Pauline, who was the only one of her siblings who completed High School, and went to college. My Dad was born in 1896. I don’t know when the others were born, but Aunt Helen was the oldest girl, and Aunt Pauline was the youngest surviving girl. One day when I was following my Uncle Eddie around the yard of their house he took me into the barn-yard where I discovered a little—a tiny—little boxy tool shed. But near its door there was a stone, and it looked like a grave stone. I examined it and discovered it was a grave stone, with a girl’s first name and the Yandle name engraved on it. It was an extra grave stone for my Dad’s baby sister who died when she was about three years old. I had never before even heard of her. However, years later I saw her grave 999999 nameThere was another little girl who was my Dad’s little sister, who died many years ago when she was about three years old. I had never known she even existed , many years. For some reason there were two gravestones made for her. One of them marks her grave, but there was another that lay on the ground near a small square wooden structure behind my Grandfather’s well house. One day Uncle Eddie allowed me to follow him into the barn yard. He went into a little hut that I hadn’t actually noticed before, as there was a good sized well house beside the well. Connected to the roof of the well house, there was an extension of roof that covered a platform in the middle of which was a box-like shelter about for the well, itsel. There was a box-like cover above the well, with a pulley and chain aboveand above the and a chain well house on the other side of the fence kept it from view. I could see that the interior of that oddly small building standing inside the barn yard if I was in the barn yard, too. The well from which all the water used for either animals or people was drawn from a square well that had a roof over it. I decided that the nearby trees and the roof of the well house helped to keep the water cool, and it probably did do exactly that. The trees offered shade to both the well house and the roofed platform of the well itself. The well-house had a cement floor, and it was cooler there, where there was running water most of the time. I never knew where, or how, there was water in the well housesheltered by the tree than and mostly hidden from view from the yard because it was behind the well house inside the barn yard. , not even as big as our smallest closet at homesmallnarrow and to keep hoes and hatchets for breaking wood for the big black wood burning kitchen stove. There were rakes and other garden tools leaning against the narrow walls of that weather beaten and worn out little shed, but lying on the ground near its open door was a flat stone. It was a grave stone, and was just lying flat on the ground. Of course I asked , was a grave stone, with a name I didn’t know then, and unfortunately don’t remember now. and was put away in a small square shed that was separate form the barn, and I had not even noticed it before that long ago day when I had followed Uncle Eddie beyond the wire fence that served as an entry into the pasture and also the barn. hheld hoes and rakes and shovels and other similar items weather beaten shed that held tools and

I didn’t realize until I had children of my own how often babies died in the 1800’s and in the early 1900’s. Now, when there are antibiotics and marvelous medications to make older persons more comfortable and much healthier. People are living longer, and are able bodied much healthier for many years than most people were when my grandparents were young.

I have one Great-Grandchild who was premature, though she is a bright, healthy, and beautiful youngster now in the first grade. Had she been born in the times my uncles and aunts were born, there would not have been the weeks of special treatment in a hospital to help her survive, as none of the medications or breathing devices had been discovered or invented before, and just after the turn of the Twentieth Century. People today take for granted that there is now an easy, if expensive, cure for most of the problems and illnesses of folks from pre-natal up to more than a hundred years, and that there are treatments and protocols that can defeat pain and help to extend lives. In the Twenty-first Century such wonderful relief and curative actions happen everyday in hospitals and doctor’s offices all over our country and in many other parts of the world.

When my parents were born doctors were handicapped by the lack of knowledge, not because the physicians had not been trained, but because information did not flow across the world as completely or as swiftly as it does today. Antibiotics were not discovered until about the time of the World War II. Sulfa was used in those days, but that was about the extent of it. Information did not travel across oceans and deserts and unoccupied areas of the world, nor were medical discoveries always shared world-wide.

When the and most of the medicines were not invented until the 1940’s, when communication became tremendously better across both the United States and also in many other nations all over the globe. I am quite aware that much of our world does not have the conveniences enjoyed in Europe and North America, but the sharing of information and the invention of most of the rest of the world, though

, though they had my Uncle Eddie and my Aunts Helen, the oldest, the middle Martha, the who were and Martha and my Parks Grandparents, who traveled only in horse-drawn vehicles, usually traveled only to Church, or into Pineville to buy medications or some other important item they could not grow or configure from their home or farm. make, or infrequently and mostly staid at homethe two of us met for the first time after I had finished college and took a job at the church where his family worshiped. Much later I discovered that my grandparents and his grandparents knew each other when they were young.
It was interesting to know that my Aunt and Uncle who lived close to Piineville lived for many years across the road from Bobby’s Uncle, and that they had been friends for years. My Grandmother Yandle mentioned that she had seen my father-in-law when he was an infant, as the two families, both riding in conveyances behind horses had passed each other on the road, and had stopped for several moments to talk with one another.

Since we both grew up in Charlotte, it seems strange that my husband and I never met each other until I finished College and went to work in the church he and his family attended. However, Charlotte was a big town when I was small.
99999999999999999999999999999999999999

rom the town of Pineville, and their house was in a wide space of land between the main highway from Charlotte southward and the railroad tracks that led from Charlotte to Pineville. When my Uncle Edward who was my Dad’s brother, walked to Pineville from the Yandle house, he usually followed the railroad because it was the shortest route to the stores in that small town. During my childhood there were stores in Pineville, however I remember only a drug store, a barber shop, a five and dime store, a post office, and a hardware store. There were others, of course, but not many. The drug store was where my Dad bought his mother’s medicine when he was growing up. Near the little town there was a large house that was the doctor’s house, and it sometimes served as a hospital—a very small one—when the illness did not require aids that only a larger better equipped hospital could provide. I faintly remember that among the businesses in Pineville there was a place where train tickets were sold, though it was not a station where passenger trains stopped every time they passed by. If there were no travelers to either leave the train or join it at the Pineville station, passenger trains didn’t stop.

As a child I was not often in the town of Pineville, though I visited my Yandle grandparents nearly every Sunday afternoon. When I was very small we also visited my Parks grandparents; however, I was very young when they were still living in their own home, because when I was probably about five years old they moved from their own home into the house owned by my mother’s sister, Ola, and her husband Vance Calhoun Davis. I have three memories of the home place where my Parks grandparents lived, and two of them were when I was very young. The first memory was a walk with my Granddaddy Parks, and during that walk we passed a very little building with no windows, but a narrow sort of door. Granddaddy opened the door and took a bucket full of dried ears of corn, and we went back to the house while he shucked the corn and took the little yellow kernels off the cob and then we went out to feed the chickens. The next memory concerned another day when we visited them, and on that day it was raining. The grownups wanted to talk about important things, and I was politely asked to go out on the porch while they talked. I remember climbing up on a hump-backed trunk that sat against the wall of the house, well away from edge of the porch where raindrops were falling very hard on the tin roof and then running off at the side of the porch. Some of the drops actually hit the edge of the porch, dampening the floor at the edge. My Dad’s car was wet. The steps were wet, too, and the driveway was getting a little muddy.

On that day I didn’t know that day about a special treat that was going to be offered to me. While my parents and Aunt Ola were making plans to move Grandmother and Granddaddy Parks from their home to Aunt Ola and Uncle Vances house, they were also talking about the fact that once Grandmother and Granddaddy had moved, they wouldn’t need to drive to church behind a horse. They had always driven to church behind a horse—a white one, with black spots on it. After moving in with Aunt Ola and Uncle Vance, they would be able to ride in the car with Uncle Vance driving it whenever they needed to go anywhere. They wouldn’t need their horse and buggy any more.

Now that sort of shocking change took away from Granddaddy Parks a job he had always done, week in and week out all of their married life. Granddaddy had always taken Grandmother to church in his buggy. They went every Sunday from their home behind Old Pink. And from that time on, they wouldn’t need Pink, nor would they need the buggy. They could ride in Uncle Vance’s 1928 Ford car wherever they needed to go.

Of course my grandparents had ridden in the car before. But living in Uncle Vance and Aunt Ola’s house they would never, ever again, really need to hitch old Pink to a wagon or buggy to go anywhere, or do anything. Uncle Vance used a tractor in his fields. Though people had been using cars and trucks for a long time, now the modern travel method was intruding into the lives of my Grandparents, and the change was intruding on their very mobility, and on their entire way of life. Their world, not just the house they would be living in, was changing, and because of Grandmother’s health, the change was being thrust on them, and it was a traumatic change for both of them, to give up their own house, their independence, and move into Aunt Ola’s house and thereafter, though they would have their own bedroom, they would be living in Aunt Ola’s house instead of their own.
88888888888888888888888888888

their usual The lives . a white horse with black spots named that on a nearby Sunday I would have a really wonderful treat. I was a very young child, but I knew that not everybody owned an automobile. The Great Depression had been very tough on the South, though the brunt of it was delayed somewhat from 1929. Country folks and farmers didn’t rely on banks as completely as did the Northern businesses. However, eventually the closing of businesses in the North began to affect businesses in the South. For one thing, the South was not as “rich” as the North. More people in the South made their living on farms than those in the North, where mills and other industries had flourished before the Wall Street collapse. Think of the actual dates. The SouthAs the 1. It took a little bit longer to strike deep into the South, because the South was mostly farming country, with only a few cotton mills and a few other industries that were actually attached to large businesses. However, into the early 1930’s rather than striking its worst problem in 1929. enough to know that But that was in my future, too. My Daddy had a car. We drove to Pineville from Charlotte often, and on that day we had come to see Grandmother and Granddaddy Parks in our car, but in those days people didn’t move about as they do now. . But we didn’t run about in cars in those days as much as folks do now.

, and other drops hit the edge of the front porch, splattering the edge of the porch floor, and wetting all of the yard, the top of my Dad’s car, and the leaves on the trees. Each raindrop made it individual silvery splash on the edge of the front porch.

There wasn’t anything else to see that was extremely riveting. My view was of grass, and trees with wet leaves, the small shelter above the well that was in the front yard not far from the house, and if I turned to one side, I could see a very small little house that looked like a play house, but in the fall it would hold lots of ears of corn. If I looked off to one side and stretched to see beyond the edge of the house, I could see the barn. squenched upHowever, the rain falling on the tin roof above the porch made lot of noise. So I sat for a long time watching the rain, while inside the house the adults talked. Not long after that day I was told that Because not long after that visit I had a wonderful treat, I think the talking the grownups were doing that day was about my grandparents moving from their own house into the home of my Aunt Ola and her husband Vance Davis.

The nice house my grandparents were moving into was more modern than their own, though drinking water was still brought up hill from the spring in enameled buckets. The spigots in her kitchen were great, because there was a huge tank at the corner of the house that caught rain that ran off the roof of the house and that was piped into the kitchen over the sink. It was good for washing and rinsing things, but not for drinking. Therefore, drinking water was brought still brought from the spring from the spring. Aunt Ola cooked in her old fashioned wood stove in her kitchen for all of her life, but in summer there were a lot of suppers , but there was But there was no running drinking water, nor electricity in Aunt Ola’s house either. The drinking and cooking water came from a spring that was located down a path—and I mean actually down hill from the house, that I, when I was in grammar school, I measured by counting my steps down to the Spring, and up again. I decided that the spring was about three fourths of a city block from the bottom of the back steps to the spring. It was always , and going towards the spring it was down-hill all the way, and that little more than a half of a a city block long.

Aunt Ola was my mother’s sister. She and Uncle Vance had no children, though they did have a lovely house with six lovely rooms, and porches on both the front and the back. Uncle Vance was very clever in the placement of the house. There was a porch on the front of his house, and anyone entering the front door had to make only one step up onto the porch. There were also comfortable chairs and a swing on the porch. Once a person entered, there was a wide hallway that lead to the back of the house, and if you walked out on the back porch you realized that you had a lot of steps to walk down if you wanted to go into the back yard, because Uncle Vance, instead of digging a basement beneath his house for a machine shop, and repair shed, set the front of his house on the top of a hill, and built the rest of the house over the descending slanted side of the hill, shoring up the few places that needed shoring, and building brick pillars to support the house in every place they were needed. His workshop was sheltered by the house, itself, and along the sides of the house near the front of the house there was a brick foundation.
However, there was a large opening to his basement at the back of the house, letting in light for most of the day. There was also a long set of steps from the very tall back porch to the ground. To a very small child that outdoor staircase was frightening because of its length. I particularly felt uneasy using the back door steps when I was small, partly because the under side of the staircase was open, so that you could see a lot more than just the next step—you could see between the steps precisely how far from the ground you were climbing to reach the solid platform at the top. Once at the top on the platform leading into the house it was not frightening. I remember that when I was very small I preferred walking up hill to the front door rather than climbing those steps.

If a person of my acquaintance during my childhood had wondered how folks used to live without electricity, I could have said, “come with me to Aunt Ola’s house, or my Grandmother Yandle’s house, and I will show you. My Parks Grandparents had not enjoyed electricity, either, but

where there were banisters around the porch so no one would just fall over all the way to the ground. , not just the next solid step, but between the risers leading and high set of steps leading to the door of the back porch which was screened in—except the screening was cloth—not ordinary thin wire screening like the screens at our house. When I was a small child each spring brought lots of cloth screening complete opening very near the back door of his house, though he did have to climb steps to his back porch. His back porch was a large outside room with a very good roof, and a half wall that kept out rain. The space above the half wall was screened surrounded the porch was screened in, making a sort of almost outdoor room which could hold the round dinner table in the summer, providing a much cooler dining room since cooking was done on an old fashioned wood stove that added unwelcome heat to the kitchen in summer. On winter days that warmth was truly appreciated, but in summer it was nice to eat on the back porch where any breeze could cool the summer . warmed the kitchen . eating room sinceimbing his back steps allowed him to enter the kitchen of his house, and below his house were a great many of his tools, and a satisfactory work place. were out of the wet, . I’m sure he had some digging to do to make both the entry and the dirt floor of his “basement” work shop level , and beneath the house he could walk easily, and it was there that he placed his wood working and metal working tools. He could make needed items from metal, because close to the house was a small 88888888888888888888

to thMy Davis aunt and uncle had no children, though they had a lovely house with six lovely rooms. It was built by my Uncle Vance who was one of those marvelous people who could turn his hand to a lengthy variety of skills. He was a farmer, an inventor, a skilled innovator, and he ran a home-made lumber mill, took care of his farm, raised chickens and kept cows, planted crops and harvested them.

My Aunt Ola had several cows, and in those days the government did not require that milk sold to the public had to be pasteurized, so Aunt Ola delivered milk from her cows to lots of people in Pineville. She also sold butter milk and butter, and sometimes also delivered eggs to her steady customers.
to see beyond wet leaves of the trees, nor was there anything interesting to listen to, except the sound of the rain on the tin roof. So I sat on the humped top of the old trunk until the rain stopped bouncing on the edge of the porch, then I stepped into the wet place, and put the print of the wet soles of my shoes on the floor of the porch. However, I couldn’t go into the yard, and I didn’t want to go into the house to sit quietly while the grown-ups talked and did whatever grownups do when they want to discuss something important.

When the rain eased up I walked along the edge of the porch, daring to step into the wet spots left by the rain, and tracking my footprints on the floor of the porch.

except the , which, to tell the truth, wasn’t all that comfortable. However, the swing and the chairs on the porch were damp because rain was falling, and the edge of the porch was wet that was on the porch were wet, There was another day I visited them andwhen rain was falling. There was a narrow door, and inside was a large and when Granddaddy opened the door he took some dried ears of corn from it, and we to feed the chickenswhere we stopped, and Granddaddy opened the door and took fr

that was . to the Southwith the surname of Parks were farmers, and had five children. The youngest boy died when he was very small, though the four other children grew up strong, good people. Uncle Luther married a lady who taught school in South Carolina, and had lived for all of her life in a house that was built before the War Between the States by her forebears. Our family visited that house only once during my childhood, and my childish memories of that old house were that it needed painting though it looked sturdy enough. There was a pump next to the kitchen sink that provided running water in the kitchen. There was an old fashioned wood burning stove for cooking. It was a two story house with a wide front porch which is where we sat most of the time we were there visiting during that warm day. The yard and porch was shaded by tall trees with long limbs that offered shade all around the house, and especially the front and back porches. Uncle Luther and Aunt ____ had no children. She was a school teacher, and my Uncle Luther also worked for the school system, repairing damaged desks and broken windows, replacing light bulbs and taking care of other similar chores for several schools in that county area. He was well known by the students of several grammar schools in that District because he was the person who fixed most of the break downs in the school system in that area.

I remember only the one visit to Uncle Luther’s house because it was a long drive to where they lived, though when my sister was in her teens she spent a week with them during the summer. I don’t remember seeing animals—not even chickens—at Uncle Luther’s house, though it sat on a large plot of land. nd other damagedI don’t think there were many farm-like animals there, as I have no memory of visiting them. herbelonged to her family and boys and two girls. The youngest child was a boy, and he died when he was very young, however, the youngest little boy had died at a very young age. had two married brothers and one mamy Dad’s three sisters and one brother, none of whom were married when I was very young, and my Mother’s one sister who was married but had no children, and her two brothers, both of whom were married, though only Uncle Dennis and his wife Aunt Mary had children. Therefore, there were three cousins—Dennis, Jr., Patsy, and Mary Cole Parks.

and her husband, and my Mother’s acquainted with the parents of both my Dad and my Mother when I was a child. My parents, my sister, and I all lived in the city of Charlotte. My Grandparents lived in the vicinity of Pinevillewere living, though both were growing old. My mother was the youngest child in her family, however she had two older brothers, and one sister. Her sister was named Ola, Her oldest brother was named Luther. I liked Uncle Luther quite well, but we seldom saw Uncle Luther because he and his wife, Eliza, lived on a farm that had belonged to Aunt Eliza’s family for more than a hundred years. 99999999999999 . There had been a little boy named Ray who was younger than my Mother. He became ill, and died quickly. My Mother had loved the little baby very dearly, and she treasured a small toy that a china replica of a boy in long pants Little ; however he, as a very small child, became ill. In those days (the very early 1900’s) there were very few effective medications available. Antibiotics had not yet been discovered, and when serious illnesses fell on children they either died or they got better. or ines available had two brothers and one sister, and all of them were married. Only Uncle Dennis who Both families lived near Pineville, North Carolina, about ten miles from Charlotte where my parents lived. We had lots of kinfolk, and at the same time, had few that were close in age to either my sister or me. My parents lived in Charlotte, North Carolina, and their parents were about ten or twelve miles from Charlotte near the town of Pineville, which was very close to the line that divided North Carolina from South Carolina.

In an era when people were actually still using horse drawn buggies and wagons for travel—and that period was in the late 1930’s—it was not unusual to see horses in Charlotte, and quite ordinary to see them in the Pineville area. The church where my Parks grandparents worshipped was named Flint Hill Baptist. My parents went there often enough for me to know that My Granddaddy was quite special to the members of the church. Though Grandmother usually sat with my mother’s sister and her husband, my Grandfather sat in a chair facing the congregation a little to one side of the pulpit, because he was a deacon. , and they drove there behind a horse named Pink. Pink was really supposed to be white, but somehow or other his coat was not very heavy, and his pink skin showed through the white coat. Therefore, his name was Pink.

went in a buggynamed ______Baptist, had a Line. In the early part of my life we spent almost every Sunday afternoon visiting my Dad’s parents, and sometimes we also visited my Mother’s parents, too. My Dad’s parents lived about ten miles away, and my Mother’s folks were about two or three miles further down the road. There is a large mall built where my Parks grandparents once lived, and there is a well known stores famous for building materials where my Yandle grandparents once lived.

As a child I often visited the homes of my grandparents on both sides of the family.
and often visited my Grandparents on both Mother’s and Daddy’s side of the families, and many of them lived only ten miles from Charlotte. There were my grandparents, along with lots of Aunts and Uncles and cousins that my parents liked to visit, and of course when my family went visiting kinfolks, I went with them most of the time. Both my parents lived in and grew up in the vicinity of Pineville. My mother’s parents were still living, and she had a sister and two brothers, all of whom were married, but only Uncle Dennis Parks who had married Aunt Mary, had children—three of them—two girls and a boy. On my mother’s side of the family, she and her brother Dennis were the only ones who had children, as neither Aunt Ola, her sister, nor their brother Luther was the only one of her siblings who had chiher sister was in easy traveling distance, and on my Dad’s side of the family there were even more people. My Yandle grandparents lived on a farm about a mile from Pineville, and in addition to his parents, he had three sisters and one brother. When I was small my Dad was the only one of his brother and sisters that was married, though his youngest sister, Pauline, married when I was about six years old.

, and there was a bunch of who live at our house) visited my grandparents (two sets of them when I was five: Parks Grandparents who lived on a farm not far from Pineville, though the last part of the journey was on a red dirt road, and my Yandle Grandparents who lived along a very old road near Pineville that looked nearly white to me, though years before I was born that road was red mud all the way from Pineville to Charlotte. Road which I thought was a very wide and nerly white cement highwaywas paved but the road from the highway to their house was mostly red mud)often, and my Dad and his family often talked about their Grandparents—about something they said, and My forebears were, most certainly, brave. Travel in those days—before the Civil War and long after it—was a bit iffy to say the least. Ships were small, powered mostly by sails, and had few conveniences. The people who packed a few clothes and set sail in ships somewhat but not greatly larger than a row boat were tremendously brave and strong, and had not only courage, but stamina also. A largish number of my ancestors came to the United States in the mid 1800’s, and when researched it was discovered that they arrived within a close time frame99999999999 a large number of persons who were surnamed either Yandle or Johnston sailed across the Atlantic and settled somewhere in the new nation of the United States, often times in the same vicinity of Carolinas, and with other members of the family scattering into Philadelphia or California, or other more northern destinations. I remember my Dad talking about his family in the same vicinity, and others who with the same name who settled in other areas of the growing nation. It struck me as unusual to have so many people with the same two names travel from England America at the same time, often on the same ship, either of two names, the Johnston’s and the Yandles, was requested, the number of them was most interesting to me. There were Johnston men whose wives all had the same maiden name: Yandle. There were Yandle men, who’s wives all had the maiden name of Johnston. the list was interesting to me because on that list there were only two surnames. The women who were already married to Johnston men seemed to have only one maiden name which was Yandle. If their maiden name was not Yandle, it was Johnston, and their husbands were Yandles, and vice-versa. Upon a few occasions, Yandles married Yandles, and Johnstons married Johnston. There was a bunch of them who came within a short length of time, or they c mostly farmers, with at least one Great Grandfather who ran a store during the War Between the States. My forbearers were strong people. One of my distant cousins made a search of our forebears, and discovered kinfolks from Philadelphia, California, and both North and South Carolinas. The arrival in the new world of people using two name: Johnston, and Yanele, A search for family was mostly a large one, and there is evidence that two families left England before the Civil War to come to America. There were a number of couples, and a few unmarried grown-ups who, about the same time, came to make their home in America. I found it odd, to some extent, that most, if not all, of that particular group belonged to one of only two surnames. Some of them were single, some of them were married, and though they did not entirely settle in the same part of the United States, many of them began in the Carolinas. Howfamilyose particularthe majority of that particular family had oabout the same time two families had inter-married. There seemed to be a fairly large number of Johnston women who married Yandle men, and also a large number of the Johnston men married Yandle women. Then most of them came to America from England, and scattered all over the new country called the United States. They were mostly well settled all over that young and growing nation, some in Philadelphia, and other points North, and a large group of them in the Carolinas. There were four Yandle brothers, most of whom had married into the Johnston family, and there were also a goodly group of Johnston men who married Yandle ladies. They menfolk had various skills, and some had extensive educations. My Dad often spoke of the beauty of some of the Johnston ladies who were his kin. the South. , upon at least one occasion, a Yandle woman married a Yandle manwho sought education when it was available, and who worked hard, more often than not on a farm, and almost all of whom belonged to either a Baptist or a Methodist Church. Though I believe that many of them were experienced farmers, there were store keepers and mill workers as well. Some were well educated, others had less schooling, but somehow most of the first group of American born youths of the Johnston or Yandle families was determined to attend school whenever possible, and never actually stopped learning and seeking knowledge. I was always surprised at the variety of knowledge my older family members showed as I was growing up, though they kept telling me how fortunate I was to be able to graduate from high school, because most of them had not achieved that goal. For instance, my Dad finished eighth grade, but had to go to work from that time onward, studying on his own when he could. My Dad had three sisters, and one brother, and of the five, only the youngest sister finished high school and went on to college. My Dad was eager for both my sister and me to attend school and, and he also paid for me to attend four years of college. My sister had the opportunity to attend college, and enrolled in a college in Western North Carolina; however, she was not impressed by what she was learning, and returned home with all of her belongings when the College temporarily closed for the Christmas vacation during her first year. Ella Cornelia had worked most of the summers while she was in High School, and she had worked for a while after she graduated from High School. She had not been impressed with her freshman year in college where she, who had gone to school with neighbors for twelve years, having lots of friends, and acquainted with most of her teachers before she actually sat in their classes, found the freshman year with its basic classes boring, and unproductive. So she came home with all her belongings, and brought a schoolmate with her—one who agreed with her completely. That was the end of her college experience. I’m not sure how much school was actually available to my Mother, but she read constantly when she could spare the time. She had, when I was small, always made every stitch of clothes we wore, except Daddy’s shirts and overalls. and Daddy were disappointed, but Ella Cornelia went to work again, and not long after that World War II began and life and the living of it became very different even though we were far from the actual battles.

all over the world. Before there had been there washad no problem finding a job. however, that was the year that decided that repeating ordinary freshman courses she had touched, however briefly, in High School when college cost so much money She, who had always been surrounded by schoolmates she knew well, was studying things she had already studied in High School and there was not even one old, or new, friend in the whole college whom she really knew, the entire experience seemed a waste of time. known most of her classmates taking courses

When she left school that Christmas I was in the Seventh Grade, and I was determined that if I, too, had the opportunity, I would go to college, and I would graduate. As we were growing up my sister and I knew what to expect every day of the week. Monday through Friday were work days for our Mother and Dad, and for most of our lives, both of them had jobs. Saturday was wash the clothes day, as well as scrub and mop and dust day, and most of the time it was also change the sheets and iron the clothes that day that you wanted to wear each day of the following week. Sunday morning was church time, and Sunday afternoon was visiting Grandparents day. Because visiting Grandparents was really important to my parents, we didn’t often miss seeing them at least once a week. By the time I was old enough to appreciate the importance of, not only love within our family, but caring, and caring enough to be active in attending and providing the care needed by family members. Both of my parents were had older brothers and sisters, but they did not ever shirk their duties to their parents.
