My Grandparents on both my Mother’s and my Dad’s sides of the family were old when I was a child. Any one could tell that my Yandle Grandparents were obviously old. My Grandmother was blind, and left her bed only to sit in a rocking chair for her meals, unable to do anything for herself, or for anyone else. My Grandfather was also old, and though for some years while I was growing up he continued to go into the fields at sowing and harvest time, he grew less and less able to pick cotton, or vegetables, or to plant and sow in the Spring. Milking and feeding pigs and cows became solely Uncle Edie’s chores, though he was not nearly as strong as my Dad. Often at harvest time my Dad spent several days helping his parents and his brother with the harvest, and later, he often helped with the sowing of seeds in the spring.

Helping on the family farm took my Dad away from his own business, but he never failed to offer his parents and his brother and sisters the help they needed because farming was not only their food supply, but also their wages that would pay for medicines and doctor visits, as well as foods and clothing that were needed because they couldn’t be, or simply weren’t, grown or produced in their own fields.

I had been married at least a year when my Dad installed an indoor bathroom at the house his parents had lived in all of my life, and of course, when water was piped into the bathroom, it was piped into the kitchen also, which was a wonderful help to Aunt Helen and Aunt Martha.

My mother and her family were also farm bred; however, though the parents of my Mother remained farmers, her brothers did not. The oldest brother, Uncle Luther, married the lady who became my Aunt Lisa. For many years Aunt Lisa’s ancestors had lived for a long time in the house she inherited. It had been built before the Civil War began, and it survived the war, and at intervals had been improved, however, though Aunt Lisa’s kitchen had running water, it had to be pumped by hand into the sink in the kitchen. Aunt Lisa was a school teacher, and had lived all her life in that house. She was the only surviving member of her immediate family, and sadly, she and Uncle Luther had no children. Uncle Luther worked for the School Board also, making repairs to a number of local schools, including the one where Aunt Lisa taught.

I was in my early teens when my Dad took our whole family to visit Uncle Luther and Aunt Lisa. Aunt Lisa was still teaching school at that time, and Uncle Luther was still repairing broken desks, chairs, windows, and other items that young students often broke. He was quite clever with his repairs, and had enjoyed working with wood for most of his life, sometimes simply for his own satisfaction. He repaired the old furniture in Aunt Lisa’s house, and now I have two of the table chairs that Uncle Luther and Aunt Lisa used, though they don’t match. We use them at our table every day, and we enjoy them.

My mother’s other brother was named Dennis, who was a little bit younger than Uncle Luther. Uncle Dennis had to go into the army during the First World War. Since it was a long time before I was born, I don’t know much about his days in the armed forces, however, I did hear that he was in the trenches in France during the First World War. When he came home, he married Aunt Mary, and they had three children, Dennis Junior, Patsy, and Mary Cole. I liked young Dennis because once when I was about thirteen or fourteen he came to Charlotte and visited for a while at our house. I don’t remember why he made the trip, but he had an appointment to see someone in uptown Charlotte, and I helped him find the right street. He, in turn, bought me lunch, and I felt wonderfully pleased at so grown-up an event. He seemed to enjoy the time he spent with me, too, and I went with him to the bus station and saw him off on his bus. The Bus Station was only about eight blocks from our house, and I knew quite a bit about uptown Charlotte.

My knowledge of the uptown area grew rather wide when I was about six years old because my Mother, when I was a first grader, took a job in a building only about twenty-five steps from the very center of town that everybody called simply, the Square, now simply an intersection where Tryon Street and Trade Street crossed. Once it was actually the very center of Charlotte, because there was a wooden building right in the center of that intersection which was the Court House for the town which was, I think, first made of logs. That small building was, indeed, the very center of the town. Eventually, of course, the town outgrew the smallish building, and because most of that area already had permanent buildings along the streets, it was eventually decided to erect a City Hall and a Mecklenburg County Courthouse further down East Trade Street, and so they did. In the space where the center of the Court House once stood, a large circular marker was made and placed in the center of the space where the original Courthouse stood that marked the center of city where so many decisions and laws were made when Charlotte was mostly a muddy little town. The last time my husband and I drove through Charlotte, I saw that circular metal marker still embedded in the asphalt of the still very busy intersection.

I spent part of my childhood very near that marker. On the first day of school when I was beginning my education, I walked alone to the school, two blocks away from my house. I had to cross only one street before I came to an intersection where there was a crossing guard. The street I crossed alone was seldom used because it didn’t lead anywhere important. The street was not actually aligned, as it was wider for a couple of blocks, and extremely narrow at the intersections at both Tryon and Graham Streets. I wasn’t afraid to cross Tenth Street by myself. It was wonderful to realize that there was for many years a policeman at Graham and Ninth Street which made it a lot safer to cross that busy thoroughfare. And so I learned to depend on myself when I walked to school.

On my first day of school it was a first day for my mother, as well. She was going into business in a shop with her friend Mrs. King, and when school was out I was going to walk almost twelve city blocks to the Square in the middle of downtown Charlotte all by myself so that I could spend the rest of the afternoon in my mother’s new sewing shop where she was beginning work the very day that I started school. That excited me, and I was a little uneasy, too, because I had to walk from school to my mother’s new shop all by myself.

My first grade teacher was Miss Belvin. I knew which door to enter (the front door) and which room to enter (the first one on the right-hand side of the hallway) and I knew how to walk to my mother’s new job. I was set for the year. I was going to learn to read and write. I was pleased. I could have used a friend to walk with on the way to school, and on my way to my Mother’s sewing shop, but my sister was beginning the seventh grade at a brand new high school named Harding High School, and she wouldn’t be home until 3:30 that afternoon. My school was named Bethune, and it was very old. I arrived at the school on time, and began my adventure into learning to read, write, add, and subtract, and how not to make your teacher mad at you if you could help it. But I also learned to take up for myself, because there was no body else to help me when some person was going to treat me wrongly.

My first day of school was also the first day I walked the mile from school to my Mother’s Sewing Shop on the Square all by myself. You can believe that when I left school I wasted no time getting safely to my Mother in her new sewing shop. When I arrived at the single room of the sewing shop I realized that the room was large, but it was also crowded. There was the cutting table, two sewing machines and chairs for the seamstresses to sit in, and against one wall a little home-made stand that had spools of thread in about every color a person could think of, and there was another chair for a customer to sit in if she, or he, had to wait for a while. Of course, most of the clients were women. And I also discovered that there was a beauty parlor just up the hall, and they had a telephone. The ladies in the shop were always nice to me, and I met all the ladies who gave permanents and curled hair, and once in a while I would help them make shampoo (on near, and that the door nearest us was a old man who took photographs of photographer’s , Just by a large table for cutting out garments, and

9999999999999999999999999999999999999

a friend, When I entered first grade at Bethune School my Mother went to work in uptown Charlotte, and I was not allowed to go home after school where I would be alone. Instead, each day when school closed for the day I walked close to a mile from the corner of West Nineth Street and Graham Street, all the way to the Square where I turned a corner onto first block of East Trade Street where my mother and her partner worked together in a one room sewing shop on the second floor of an old building, and it had two windows that looked out on East Trade Street, and on one of them there was a sign visible from the street that said in red letters: “King and Yandle Sewing Shop”. The sign hung over East Trade Street, but from my motherMrs. Octavia King and my mother, Minnie Yandle, were the two owners of the shop located in a building that was nearly as old as the city. The building was owned by Miss Sally Davidson, who was still hale and hearty, and came each month to collect her rent money from my Mother and Mrs. King.

That building does not exist now, as fifteen or so years ago it was razed, as were several other buildings on that corner, and in its place a huge auditorium was built. For many long years there had been no suitable Auditorium for performers. When in the 1920’s motion pictures became the rage, several motion picture theatres were built, and one of them was built with a limited stage area for live performances. Although it served the purpose for years, it was not totally satisfactory for large performances. but none of them were actually built for live There was one or perhaps two theaters which to aid The year that I enrolled in the first grade at Bethune School that was located on the corner of Graham Street and Ninth Street, and it was not a new school. It had served Charlotte well for many years. There was a very nice schoolyard beside and behind the school, however the school had been there for many years, and though at one time there had been monkey bars, a sliding board, and swings for the young students, when I entered the school, only the money bars and the ladder of the sliding board had survived near the back door of the school, and where there was a larger open area at the side of the school, all that was left of the swing set was the steel tubes that could have supported six or eight swings. The steel tubes that might have supported swings no longer had chains or swing seats. The ground at the side and back of the school was red dirt, and the only real accommodation for the students was a water fountain close to the side door of the school.

e years the original Court House though it was probably made of wood, and didn’t do much for the . In the 1930’s Charlotte had been a city for many years. By that date many of the schools were showing their age, and had portions of their buildings roped off because they were considered unsafe. By the late 1930’s at least one school had been condemned

I was five or six years younger than Dennis, and saw him and his sisters rather seldom, and mostly when his family and mine visited our Grandparents at the same time. mother and Granddaddy Parks. grandparents at the same time. Since I was younger than he and Patsy, the sister closest to his age,

and he married Aunt Mary, and had three children, one son and two daughters. They lived in Fort Mill, South Carolina where he worked in a building in Fort Mill, South Carolina in the “up town” area. The building had two spaces, side by side, and through one entrance you would find Uncle Dennis’ barber shop, and next door to it was Aunt Mary’s beauty parlor where she cut, and styled ladies hair, and gave them permanents. Uncle Dennis was my mother’s brother,unt Mary, his wife, worked in the other space where she ran a beauty parlor and gave permanents and cut ladies’ hair.
99999999999999999999999999

in one ved in North Carolina Mother’s brothers married, though her oldest brother had no children. He and his wife lived in South Carolina, and both of them worked for the School District in which they lived. Uncle ----also lived in South Carolina, and as a made repairs for the county’s schools, and his wife was a teacher. They had no children. Uncle Dennis married, and moved to Fort Mill, South Carolina, which was only a few miles away from Charlotte across the South Carolina border. Mother and her sister Ola who lived in Pinevillewas the child nearesther parents and her sister and brothers, had also grown up on a farm. Mother was the youngest child, and she had two brothers and one sister, all older than she. Her brothers served in the First World War, and along with her older sister, the brothers married soon after the war ended. Her brothers Dennis and Luther both married, and her older sister also married a marvelous young man named Vance Calhoun Davis. boys had also

My sister Ella Cornelia was almost seven years older than me, and when I started school as a first grade student she began the seventh day. was six or. Saturday was clean up day, and if we did a good job of it, we could depend on coins that would admit us into movies

a., and always I knew the parents of my parents because we visited them often, and they were hard working folk, and some were farmers, one of them was a train engineer, others were storekeepers or machinists, some worked in mills, and most of those I knew lived in the Carolinas, though sometimes they had spread out into other States. I knew that one family disappeared when they left home for California, and after the San Francisco earthquake that family disappeared and was never hear from again, though family members traveled to California to search for them. I know that some of my kin lived in Montana on a ranch and that some lived in Detroit and were associated with the building of automobiles. I learned fairly recently that some of the Yandles moved into the Philadelphia area, and so our family and the many people who came from England simply spread out all over the growing nation, and in different areas of the country the spelling of the name was different.

When I was in high school I discovered there were several students of different ages who were also Yandles; however they did not spell their names exactly as I did. It is fairly easy to figure out why, because back in the early 1800’s when most of the people entering the nation that eventually became the United States were daring to travel across the Atlantic. Even those who were siblings did not always spell their name the same way. It was spelled Yandle, Yandel, Yandal, and Yandele. I met several cousins while attending Harding High School in Charlotte, North Carolina, and each of them spelled the name differently.

Travel back in the early days of our country was not as easy as it is today. The trips across the ocean in crowded boats which offered no privacy during the voyage didn’t seem to daunt them despite the discomfort of crowing themselves Almost all travel during the years this country was being “settled” transport from what is now Great Britain, Europe, North Africa, and China. The continent that was called “the New World” was scarcely populated, and the Indian folk didn’t have weapons strong enough to actually prevent the entrance of the hoards of people who came on ships to take up land in the “land of beginning again.”

Families who had lived most of their lives quite close together discovered that opportunities were open all over this vast nation, and they often chose to spread out all over the continent. , that embarked on the adventure from the they sometimes moved across the Catawba, they mostly lived in North Carolina. My Dad’s family was mostly Methodist, and my Mother’s family was Baptist. Church was important in both families, and has remained so for many generations.

My earliest memories are, of course, very sketchy. Most genuine memories of very small children are based on great pleasure, fright, or intense pain. Little things, sweet moments, and simple enjoyment, don’t usually write themselves indelibly on the memory. Because I am now seventy-five years old, my memories span years when the world, our nation, our home, was very different than it is today. Not long ago during a telephone conversation my sister who is seven years older than me asked me if I remembered anything much about living on East Fifth Street. I managed to drag quickly through my earliest memories of about seventy two or more years ago, and pulled up two clear mind pictures. One very vivid one was that I was in a black place, alone, terrified, and screaming because I couldn’t get out. The other one was of sitting on the floor of our front porch, playing, and trying to move, or pick up an odd half circle of sunshine on the floor. There was one more—not in our house but in the other side of the duplex. There was a grandmotherly lady who lived there with her husband, and they had a sofa in their living room. I remember standing on her sofa, then running across the cushions to cuddle in her lap.

My sister laughed at my memories, and told me that the one about the sun on the floor was because the porch was surrounded by a solid half wall instead of an ordinary banister, and the builders had cut small crescents at floor level to prevent rain from pooling on the porch floor. At certain times of the day the sun could shine directly through the curved openings making bright crescents of sunshine on the porch floor.

The other memory was of sheer terror because of black darkness. Ella Cornelia explained that one day I was allowed to play alone in the back yard. I decided go back into the house, which was, for me, a mistake. The very small entry way had neither window nor an electric light, and the back door closed behind me as I walked into the entry way, leaving me trapped in the dark. Ella Cornelia rescued me, making everything all right for a frightened little girl.

After that I remembered the kitchen of the house we moved into shortly after that scare. The new house was also a duplex, and in it we lived in the downstairs area that consisted of three rooms and a hallway. This was the house I lived in until I was married. 9999999999999999

and after about seventy years I thanked opened the door to the very small vestibule and rescued me from pitch black dark. Of course, as soon as I was out of a very small hallway Mother was busy in the kitchen, and when I began to scream she asked my sister to check on me. The entryway was very small, and without windows, however, the fact that there was no electric light in that small I decided to go into the house. Unfortunately for me, there was no light in the entry way which had discovered that a three year old couldn’t reache entry way had no She met me in the very small back entry way, and guided me into our kitchen. Ella Cornelia told me that the entry from the back yard was sort of odd. The outside door opened into a small entry way about three feet square which served as a hallway. There

Suddenly, both she and our Mother heard me screaming, and Ella Cornelia hurried toward the back yard to check Duplex houses are two dwellings that are separated only by one shared wall. Usually the kitchens and bathrooms were close to the center of the house to make connections to electricity, water and sewage The two dwellings are usually mirror images of each other, with connections to electricitykitchens side by side, and often with hallways also side to side. Usually the houses have adjacent front porches and back doors. That was sort of the way the house on East Fifth Street was designed. I truly don’t remember the layouts of the rooms, and I actually have three how that house was designed. However, my sister mentioned that there was a central back door that opened into a very narrow hall, that had openings to both left and right that led into that hall there was an entry to both the left and the right, each leading into there was a back door that opened onto a very narrow sort of hall way, My sister said that the back entry of that house was a little different, as there was only one back door that opened into a . Picture a square space only as wide as a door and its frame, and only long as a door and its frame. There are four equal sides to this hall which offered entrance to both sides of the duplex from the single back doorand three of the sides are also doorways. The fourth side may have been a doorway, too, though my sister didn’t remember clearly where that fourth door might have led. The door from the yard into the house was the back door. Usually the roof is covers both sides of the building, houses that share both have four walls, however one of them serves both However, the memory of the dark place was different. There was no electric light in that hall and it had at least two, if not three, other doors opening into it—one on each side, which led to each It was an entry way into the house, and once a person was inside that entry way there was another door to go through—this time either to the left or the right. Both of from the back yard, and once through the back door there was on both the left and right sides of the walls was another door. it seemed quite small, as it was actually no wider, nor longer, than the width of a door in any direction. On both the left and the right of the space was a door leading into both sides of the house, the left and the right as the space was narrow, and was not larger than of the house, and once inside it was a cramped space, as it was only as wide of the door. The side walls were also cramped, as they, too, were only doorways—one on each side that opened either into, or near to, the kitchens on both sides of the duplex. consisted of only a doorway, one opening to the left, the other opening to the right side At the back of the house there was a narrow hall, with at least three openings. There was, of course, the back door, and on each side of the hall was a door leading into both the left and the right side of the house, near the kitchen area. There was no electric light in that narrow square hall, The hall was as wide as the back door and its frame. On each side of that hall the entire wall space was taken up by door frames on each side, each opening into the , but no electric light within it. Three of the sides were held only the door and its Three sides were as wide as the doorway required, but not wider than that, only with doorways taking up all the but one was the door to the outside, and the other two doors lead both left and right into each into the separate areas of the The dark place did not have an electric light in the small space was without an electric light. The two opposite side doors offered access to both halves of the duplex near the kitchens on both sides of the dividing wall. house, sides were just as narrow as the back door, that lead into , each of the two doors and . It was only as wide as the doorway, meaning that the door and its frame took up all and its within the very narrow one about the dark place was different. My sister was probably about nine or ten years old, and I was probably close to three years old. She and our Mother were in the kitchen area, and they both heard me screaming. Mother sent her to get me, and she found me in the tiny back door vestibule. She said that it was an odd sort of arrangement, because the space was so very small, no wider than the door itself, and it frame. The walls on the left and the right were not really walls at all, because both sides of that entry way was no longer than the left and right door and door frame. a wall at all, because it, too, was only as wide as the door and its framebut was on both sides only as wide as a closed door and its frame, and when open, both lead into the kitchen area. leading intoOn both the left and the right there . First, she mentioned that there was neither a window nor an electric light in that small hallway. It was a solid half wall, and at intervals all way the back door was different from any other back entrance she had ever seen. She remembered clearly only one outside door on the back wall of the house. When a person entered through that back door he was in a narrow and short four-sided square hall that was no larger than the width of the three or possibly four doors plus their door frames. When my sister was describing that narrow square hall she could re-member only three doors, which of course would each have had a door frame. The floor space was square, and was just large enough to turn around in order to move to the left or the right through Th remember if there were only three doors or if there was a fourth one that had slipped her mind. However it actually was, there was a single back door into a narrow square hallway no wider on any of the four sides than a door and its framework. acings. anwhich opened into theopening into that tiny hall, or if there were four of them. There was of course a door into the back yard, and back entrance to both the left and right side of the duplexwere at least three, and perhaps a four doors into that tiny hallway. . The hall way was only wide enough to accommodate the width of the doors. doors, but the space was no wider from side to side, and from front to back, that the width of a door including its framing. There was a back door, and two side doors, one to the left, and one to the right. In our side of the duplex there was a door which opened into a very narrow space, aThe and making with an odd half circle shape of sunshine on the floor. My sister then told me about both of those experiences, as it was she who rescued me from the dark, and she remembered about the front porch, too

The easy one was the half circle of sunshine on the porch floor. The front porch was not surrounded by a simple banister with slender square sticks holding a flat board railing. There was a partition that would hold up a railing. There was a partition that separated the two porches and the front of the two porches was a solid That partition a solid wall about the same height as a banister would have been. It that a banister would be, but definitely not see-through, and made instead of solid woodof a banister that surrounded the porch. At floor level there were several cut-outs along the base of the porch’s half-wall to allow rain, or scrubbing to flow off the porch. The openings were rounded archeswater ting it. The house was sort of different in two ways. First, it was two houses separated only by one wall, with both sides of the house under one roof. Each side of the house had a front door, however, my sister remembered only one entrance at the back of the housethere was only one wall reaching from floor to roof that separated the two halves of the house, and above them was only one roof. between them, and they shared the same roof. There was a sturdy half-wall topped with a flat banister top that formed a sort of solid fence around both front porches. rather than a simple banister. At intervals there was an arch cut through that half wall, and and the wall

we were living in was a duplex, and there were two front doors. However, my sister remembered only one entry at the back of the house, which led into a tiny hall. That hall had only one actual wall, because the door from the outside took up the entire back wall of that small entry way, and on each side of that door were two other doors, one into each side of the duplex, and it was not larger than the space it took to hang a door on both the right and left sides of that tiny hallway to give entry to both sides of the duplex. Ella Cornelia, my sister, couldn’t recall if there was a fourth door, or just a narrow wall on the fourth side of that tiny hallway. But she can be forgiven for not remembering byou then only as wide as the doorways of the other three sides of that small member if there was a fourth door, each side that would open into both sides of the duplex close to the kitchen area. that wayentry from the yard , and didn’t really have a with a door on both the left and right, making a back entry way that was only as wide as the back door, and only as deep as the two doors that led into both the right and the left on both the right and left of the back doorand not an inch more than that. To the left and right were two other doors that led into the kitchen area of both sides of the duplex, , both entry space had three doors: the back door, and two side doors, and where there were doors there was no real wall space—only the door and the necessary space to attach the hinges on one side of the door, and the lock on the other side of the door. One door led into or out of the yard, one door led into our side of the house, and the other door led into the other side of the house. Sister thought there might have been a door sized wall on the other The door from the yard into the house led only to a small hallway that had no walls on three sides of a sort of hallway, no bigger than it had to be to have three doors on t that had no electric light. There were at least three doors leading into that small space, and may have had a fourth one, though she couldn’t remember. It was a very small place, as the three doors she was sure about had no wall space between There were n there may have been four doors, she couldn’t remember. However the space was like a box, It was like a box, with at least three sides in itblack place was a small entry way into the back door of the houseat the back of the house in which there was no electric light. The first one , but I didn’t remember anything else. She said she knew about that one, but what else did I remember from about the same time? So I told her about a shadow I remembered, and we both laughed, because . Then I recalled I recall adventures in my past I am seventy-five years old, and will be seventy-six within the next few months. Unfortunately for me my memory is so crowded that in some instances items I should remember seem to have been erased—perhaps by accident—but nevertheless, they no longer exist in my head. Several months ago I was speaking by telephone with my sister who is six years plus a few months of the seventh year older than I am. We speak on the telephone frequently, as we live in different States. My sister, Ella Cornelia Yandle May, and I were chatting away when I mentioned those two early memories and admitted I didn’t understand either of them. She chuckled, and said, “Oh, I can tell you that.” And she did.

One day about seventy two years ago, she heard me crying very loudly, apparently behind the door of an oddly constructed hallway. She immediately came toward my screams to see why I was so upset. She opened a door leading into a narrow hall, and rescued me.

My sister explained that on that day I had been allowed to play alone in the back yard, and had tried to enter the house without help, though I was only three years old. Unfortunately the very small back hallway had no electric light, nor was there a window. The entryway was exactly square, and was as wide on all four sides as a door and its frame. One of the doors opened into the back yard, and two of them opened in separate directions into each side of the duplex. Ella Cornelia couldn’t remember (after more than seventy years) if there was a fourth opening into that small hallway. She did remember opening the door and comforting me because I had been terrified in that small dark entryway.

The second memory was perhaps earlier than the one about the door. In that memory I was on the floor that seemed to be of wood. There were walls around me. However the sun was shining very brightly though I was in the shade, and in front of me there was a precise splash of sunshine that looked like half of a bright warm circle. My sister reminded me that the solid banisters on the porch of that house were like a half wall, and not like the banisters in the house we moved into when I was still three years old. 9999999999999 That banister was made of little square posts that let in rain, and/or sunshine, with a solid railing on top of the thin posts. just a railing held up by thin wooden studs through which wind and sun could that from top to bottom it was a sturdy solid barrier between the porch and the very close sidewalk. Because the top of that wall was, like banisters, only about three feet from the porch floor, it was prudent to have openings for rain water in the event that a heavy rain fell onto the porch from above the banisters. Therefore the builder designed several arched openings at floor level through which rain water could run off the porch, and through which the sun could cast a bright splash of precisely arched sunshine which caught my attention though I was very young.

My Parents, Minnie and Leroy Yandle, were not rich, but they were strong. My mother 999999999999999. Their parents were farmers, and they were folk who had lived near Pineville, in Mecklenburg County, about ten or fifteen miles from Charlotte. My Dad’s family had moved around a little, living for a while on the other side of the Catawba River near a town called Mount Holly. There were many farmers who were from families who settled in the area of Pineville, North Carolina, located about ten or twelve miles from Charlotte, North Carolina. Pineville had a mill that made cotton cloth, and was not far from Fort Mill, South Carolina. The Southern Railroad passed through Pineville, as well as Fort Mill, and of course there was a Railroad Station in Charlotte, North Carolina, which was the largest city in the vicinity. Charlotte had a fairly large population, and there were mills, and manufacturers in that growing metropolis. The Catawba River flowed through North Carolina and South Carolina, and eventually the river was damned so that its flow would power machines that made electricity for Charlotte and other towns in the vicinity. There were little towns and villages in North and South Carolina, and a few large towns were beginning to develop. Charlotte was one of them.

From the beginning people who settled in North Carolina in the Piedmont, not far from the border between North and South Carolina, were serious about establishing a city. They built a Court House, and proclaimed that its position was to be the “center” of the town they planned to name Charlotte, after the English Queen. The majority of the settlers were from England, though through that nation and most of Europe there were difficulties, and many people who were willing to risk their lives to move to a new country, even if it was across a wide and fearful sea. Thus it was that people who saw no hope for a good life in the place where they lived were willing to cross the sea in hopes that they could have better lives in the new land.

Therefore, from all of the European, British and Mediterranean countries people who had little hope of bettering their situations where they were living, simply left that place and tried to better their lives in a new and unknown place, where there were fewer people, and fewer bosses to take the cream off the milk of life before the poor could get a taste. In the new world, they were told, they could be more free of every difficulty except hard work, and that would be for their own sake—not for some overseer.

Moving across the sea was not free of cost. Families were often separated when some members of a family could make the trip, and others could not afford it. Moving to a new continent was never easy nor without difficulty, however, no matter what the risks, risk was more appealing than remaining where there was no hope of real freedom of movement, nor of moving outside a paltry way of life, no matter how hard you worked. Because some folk went to the “new world” and made a fortune, and then returned to their English home place with the wonderful news, many families made the trip to America as a group. There were many persons who struck out alone, or one husband and wife with their children who dared to cross the sea. Other families could not bear to separate themselves by such a distance, and therefore collected every member of the family who could make the trip to go as a group. And that was the way a large number of Yandles, and a large number of Johnstons came to the country that became the United States from England, Ireland, Scotland, and other points occupied by folk who had the name Johnston or Yandle. Those folks seemed to find Johnston fairly easy to write, and seldom spelled it any other way; however, Yandle was spelled in many different ways over time. It was spelled Yandel, Yandell, Yandal, and a few other versions. Many of the people with those two names were kin to each other. Johnston’s had married Yandles, and Yandles had married Johnstons, and when the kinship was not too close to prevent it, Johnstons had married Johnstons, and Yandles had married Yandles. It was a very large group.

In those years there was very little effective medicine for any illness. There was very little help for a woman during the birth of her child. Sometimes women had pregnancies too frequently, and had questionable health with no medicines that could be helpful, nor were there at that time such wonderful helpers as X-rays, and antibiotics and doctors who were specialists in birthing children. Sometimes there were neither available doctors, nor helpful medications. Another problem in that time was that Medicine, as we know it in the Twenty-First Century did not exist at all until late in the Twentieth Century. There were few medicines, and though there were doctors who were totally trustworthy, there were also doctors who discovered that medications were not effective by the trial and error. The lack of true antibiotics was often disastrous since physicians were helpless when there was nothing they could do to help their patients.

Having been born in the early 1930’s I suffered measles, and mumps, and chicken pox, and other illnesses, and there were no medications to prevent them. When poliomyelitis struck people either got well or were crippled for life or they died. People who had communicable diseases like Tuberculosis were required by law to enter a TB hospital, as it was highly contagious. They could not live at home. I had a friend not quite five years old who was suspected of having a lung illness, and she was snatched from her home (that happened to be next door to my home) and sent to the TB hospital where she stayed for at least five or six years, though she wasn’t really ill, because they didn’t know how to diagnose her problem. There were doctors who believed that trying to help a patient, even if it meant offering a medicine that had not been tested previously, was worth trying. That happened to my Aunt Helen, who took the medication, and discovered that the medicine ruined her teeth. A man my Mother knew became sick with a high fever, and the doctor said that his mother should use something that would splash water against his head every minute or so to reduce his fever. It turned out that the Romans had used that device as torture back in olden times, and the doctor didn’t realize it. People today still find there are illnesses that doctors and treatments cannot alleviate, but there are so many wonderful treatments for so many difficult illnesses today that people almost expect medicines or treatments to fix everything. When I was a child I was quarantined inside my house for measles and chicken pox, and I remember my Dad lifted me up so that for one of the illnesses I was able to jerk down the sign warning folks not to come into the house because I had a contagious disease. Though it was tough for me and my family while the sign was up, it was far better than allowing me to play with neighbor children and give them the sickness, too.

I have already mentioned that every afternoon when I had left school I went uptown to the Sewing Shop because there was no one at home to look after me. I spent the afternoon after school for three school years in my mother’s sewing shop, however close to the end of my Third year in school, a tragedy occurred in North Carolina and in other states as well. There was an outbreak of Infantile Paralysis in several states. Every school in Mecklenburg Country closed early that spring. A quarantine was ordered for all of Mecklenburg County that affected all children under sixteen years of age. Sixteen year old children who had jobs could go to work. It was suggested that those who did not have jobs or were not otherwise committed to being out in public to stay at home as much as possible. Parents were urged to keep their children away from other children, as Poliomyelitis was extremely contagious.

All over the city of Charlotte prudent parents obeyed the warning, and their children spent the summer inside, rather than outside, if at all possible. We had books at home, but I had already read all of them, more than one time. I loved going to the library, and read

In uptown Charlotte at that time there was to my knowledge only one major store in that vicinity that had air conditioning. All the others had a few ceiling fans to stir the warm air, and those in buildings with more than one floor usually did not make use of the top one, hoping the temperature would be less if it was not too close to the roof. School age children were bored stiff. The Charlotte Parks and Recreation people had very little to do, as no children were invited to the parks and were instead urged to stay away. Radio stations filled any spots in the stations morning and afternoon programs with thirty minute programs about games that could be played at home, and the Recreation Department sent out packages of pencil and paper mazes and games to help keep the children busy inside their homes on hot afternoons, instead of going outside to play with other children in the neighborhood. 

    School in ended abruptly that late Spring, and began much later than usual the next fall.  All through the summer children were not allowed in movie theatres, nor could they go shopping in stores, either grocery stores or department stores.  They were not to appear in any crowded area in Charlotte, or in surrounding areas.  I couldn’t even go to church.  Polio was such a terrible disease, and there was not even one medicine that could help.  It paralyzed its victims, most usually preventing legs to function at all, but allowing arms to continue move and work.  Sometimes the entire body was affected, requiring the victim to spend the balance of their lives in an iron lung, which was like a huge barrel with a device that forced oxygen into the lungs of the patient, also helping the patient to exhale.  Polio was a terrible affliction.  It was conquered after Jonas Salk discovered a preventive injection when our daughter was in school.  I remember standing in line with Bobby, my husband, and our two children in the hallway of the school where our daughter, Louise, was enrolled, and at planned intervals we went back until we had been injected three times.  This occurred all over the nation, and from that time forward Polio was not the killer and maiming illness that before that year had claimed lives, and ended the ability to walk. Years later, after I married and we had two children, both in school, a man named Jonas Salk discovered a preventive medicine, and at three intervals my husband and our two children stopped by a grammar school building in our neighborhood to get injections, and after those injections given to all school children and their parents, and to every one who showed up at the school in hopes that when almost every person in Charlotte had been inoculated there would be no infantile paralysis ever again, and that is what happened.  Polio was no longer a threat, thanks be to Jonas Salk and to God Almighty.

Even so, I remember that summer because I was bored. I couldn’t go to the library, I couldn’t see a movie, I couldn’t play with children in my neighborhood, and I couldn’t even go to church.
Each evening I telephoned my mother who was working in a sewing shop in the up-town area, and she helped me quickly plan supper, and I cooked it, so that supper would be nearly ready by the time she returned home. That was a long and boring summer. I swept and dusted and washed and ironed clothes because there was nothing else to do except read, and I read a great number of books from the library that my sister Ella Cornelia graciously stopped by to select for me.

There was no medicine and no cure for that illness. If you became ill the chances were that you would never again walk, and you might not even be able to breathe without an iron lung. That illness was one of the most terrible I had ever heard of, and then I learned that President Roosevelt had suffered from that disease. When I was in college I had a class mate who walked only with braces and crutches. She was a lovely girl, and intelligent. She graduated in the same class I did, but she died before she was thirty years old. I felt so very blessed that I did not have that disease.

over the responsibility of the kitchen work—cooking and serving meals, preserving food in the summer and fall for use through the winter, cleaning the house, washing not only dishes, but also the laundry usually outside in a boiling pot, and keeping the kitchen tidy. I’m sure her older sister Martha helped with the chores, and for a time, and the youngest sister also. However the youngest girl finished high school she went to college, and when she came home she went to work in Charlotte. the laundry, preparing meals, and laying by foods in the fall for use through the winter, until a new garden could be planted and

something to do with the way she lived her life. She was the oldest girl child in that family, and since my grandmother was not actually well as long as I knew her, and was told that she had beensort of fragile, as were a great many women who had no access to birth control. I was told as a child that my Grandmother Yandle was too sick to do anything except grandmother that. She lived well into her nineties, and was not far from a hundred years old when she died.

A large group of them came on the same ship, or quickly there after. I found it fairly strange that before they entered their new country there were a big bunch of those people who had once been Johnstons who married Yandle men, and another bunch of Yandle ladies who married Johnstons. There seemed to be so many of both that they were all kin to each other, and when would convince not only one ma and pa with On other And so it was with folk who left family members behind to begin a new life across the sea. Then there were families who did not want to leave parents, children, sisters, brothers, cousins, or other kin behind them. So when it was possible, entire families embarked across the sea at the same time. Parents, uncles, aunts, children, cousins, mates and their close family members, all sometimes came either on the same ship, or on carefully spaced trips across the ocean with plans to meet in this new world to offer support and help for each other when settling into their new and challenging lives. This was the decision of some of my ancestors, many of whom had the same last name. They came in family groups, and a great many of them were named Yandle, Yandel, Yandal, Yandell, and a few other odd spellings of the same name. Some were brothers and sistsers, parents and children, cousins, or aunts or uncles, and a few women who once had a different name, but married either a Johnston or a Yandle. strangely enough they were all related in some way, either closely or not so close, and there were Johnstons that married Yandles and Yandles, so that the folk who took that particular ship mostly answered to either Johnston or Yandle when those names were called. M that married Johnstons. It was customary in those days that when a woman died in childbirth, and that was a sad, but regrettably a frequent occurrence, and since there were few medications that would save folk from dying young there were some of them who came over the sea with one name, and later married some were cousins and a bunch of the Yandle group had kinfolk name Johnston, and a bunch of Johnstons came along with them. I suppose that any of those folk were related, being parents, children, cousins, uncles, aunts, grandparents, or half sisters, brothers, or some other relationship that I haven’t thought of yet.

really freelands had been taken over by other peoples the crowded Europe were of course there were people from other European and North African nations as well. Strong countries were attacking weaker ones,At that time there was unrest in several countries, with people who and travel, especially by sea, was frequent. When it was difficult to make a living in their birthplace, many people simply moved toward the lands across the Sea which had been discovered, and about which rumors had spread along with marvelous reports of riches and opportunity. In crowded areas with little hope of gaining a better way of life people who lived in near despair simply left those places that held little hope of bettering themselves to live in a brand new world where hard work and effort could make a person rich in land and possessions, with more freedom than they enjoyed in their present homeland. Many of the travelers were from England, Ireland, Scotland, France, Russia, China, Italy, and many from North Africa.

Eventually the European folk, including England, as well as nearly allof the entire world, was at the mercy of peoples who were powerful and ruthless. Many strong leaders had not one single qualm about killing women and children, as well as the defenders of whatever place they were attacking at the moment. Any strong ruler could decide he wanted more of whatever and whoever he had discovered, and if he believed he could win a battle with the expected opposition, that strong warrior took the risk of attack, killing those who opposed him, and risking the lives of all his followers who would be believed anywhere on earth either began, or continued, to believe that people who were different from themselves were much less worthy of respect than themselves, and the old habit from Bible times of making prisoners and slaves of both the soldiers and mere citizens of a captured nation whose options were to accept slavery or death. Families were divided, men and women and their children were separated and neither the lives or the health of slaves was not a problem. One of them died? There was another to take his/her place. No probl, treated more Slavery was usually cruel, became the cruel rule of the day.

Powerful people who could protect themselves and their holdings were forced to defend their domains successfully or become the servants of their conquer stronger believed the people from countries they invaded could be used as slaves, since that had been one of the results of Roman and Greek and Egyptian occupations of other parts of their world. Dark skinned folk from Africa were transported into the area to help change the wilderness into a more “civilized” sort of country. Most of the world, up to that time, had always used conquered people as slaves. Often it was the slaves who actually built huge cities, and provided strong defense during war times in almost the entire entire world.

As Charlotte grew, men with strong ideas of self government wanted to build a new and better nation, free from restrictions that kept working people from rising in the world, and denied them the right to education and opportunities to rise above their beginnings. Because they were human, those who became leaders on this new continent were not always perfect in their plans and decisions, but for the most part, the new nation of small states multiplied, and eventually established the United States of America. People from many countries all over the known world arrived to join those who were determined to have a fresh and new beginning in a place that was not already old, and so set in its ways that there was little hope for change for the people living there.

I was born early in the year of 1931. There were forty-eight States within the United States, and a world wide war had been fought to preserve liberty in the world. When the Great War was over, and the soldiers came back home, everything was different. Somewhere in my youth I remember a line from a song sung by our troops during that war. The lyrics asked a question: “How do you keep them down on the farm after they’ve see Paris”? The answer was that you couldn’t keep people from continuing to expand their thinking and their actions after such an experience.

Home Great Depression had already occurred Who is seldom actually the first one is of me, playing on a wooden floor. The sun is shining, and there is a shadow on the floor. The shadow is cast by the banisters that are like a solid half-wall between our porch and the street. There is at least one very bright spot on the floor because the sun can shine through a crescent shaped hole where the solid banister touches the floor. The opening was to allow rain to run off the porch through that very small opening. I think the shiny crescent is interesting, and put my hands in the bright light. That is the end of that scrap of my memory of the front porch. Ironically my other memory of that house is at the rear door, which had an odd sort of access. From each kitchen a door opened into the same small hallway at the back of the house, 99999999999999999999999999999999999

And within arms reach there was another door opening into the back yard. That tiny hall was a square, with a solid wall on one side, and three doors on the other three sides, one door into each side of the duplex, and one door opening into the back yard. Instead of having a door opening into the back yard for each side of the duplex, there was only one opening from a very small square hall, oddly fashioned to serve as an entry from the back yard, and two other doors offered entry to without an electric light. The doors and their frames It was , through which allowed occupants of either side of the duplex to allowed of either side of the duplex had access to the back yard for each side of the duplex, there was one solid door opening into the back yard from a very small square hallway. There were two other doors on opposite sides of the hall, one to the left, and one to the right. Each door led into each side of the narrow hall was a door opening door opening from into the yard.a hallway only a little larger than a doorwaywas a little odd. Between m. There was a very small four-sided hallway leading to the single rear door of the house. There were Two walls exactly opposite to each other had doorswalls There was one door to the back yard outside at the rear of the house, and there were two doors, each of which connected to a hallway it opening to one on that connected to both sides of the duplesBoth sides of the duplex had access to a small square hallway, that had on This rear door memory is of my terror. I was outside the house in the back yard playing. I wanted my mother, and after more than seventy years I have forgotten why I wanted her. I opened the door leading to a narrow square hall with three doors. The door behind me closed, shutting out all light, and leaving me alone in a small black dark space. I panicked and screamed. My sister heard me and opened the door from our house into enclosed entry way that had three doors try way tried to go into the house to find her. I opened the door and stepped into the small hallway, and behind me the solid outside door closed shut behind me, leaving me in pitch darkness. I was r. I was going into the house, but as soon as I entered a small square hallway, the door to the outside closed, making the hall pitch black. I was standing alone in the small totally dark hallway. I screamed and screamed until my sister opened the door into our house. I open a door and step inside the house. The door behind me closes, and I am in pitch dark. I can’t find the door in the dark, and I scream. Someone opens a door and I see my sister, so I am not frightened anymore, but I am still crying. I mentioned that memory to my sister who is older than I am. She told me that there was a very small entry way at the back of the house that served both sides of the duplex. It had three doors, one for each side of the duplex, and one leading into the back yard. There was no light in that space, and no windows. Once we moved away I was never in the house again, but I did see the outside of it from across East Fifth Street when we visited the house owned by my Great Aunt Elizabeth (nicknamed Lizzie) and her brother, Uncle Edward (nicknamed Ed). I had an opinion of both Aunt Lizzie and Uncle Ed when I was about five years old, and it was that they were different from anyone else I had ever met. Both of them were very thin people. Uncle Ed was tall and thin, and Aunt Lizzy was shorter, and also thin. At table they didn’t eat very much, as if they were not, after all, very hungry. My Daddy, who was a painting contractor, would sometimes as Uncle Edward’s advice on business, and he would often take his advice. I understood that both of these odd people were kin to me, but I didn’t really know exactly how they were related to us for a number of years.

It seems that my Dad’s Granddaddy, who was named Milas Yandle was married twice. My Grandfather Amos Yandle was Milas Yandle. My Grandfather Amos was the child of his first wife. When she died, he married again, and He had children by his first wife, and their son was my Grandfather, Amos Yandle. Amos’s mother died young, and his father remarried. Because Amos’s father was my Dad’s Grandfather , my Great Grandfather Yandle, mother died, as occurred often in those daysand his father married again. I think that his second wife already had two children, one named Edward and one named Elizabeth. Therefore Edward and Elizabeth were half brother and sister to my Grandfather, which made them Uncle Ed and Aunt Lizzie to my father, his brother, and his three sisters. that made my grandfather’s children call their children Uncle and Aunt. They were probably quite young when they earned those titles. However, my Dad’s Granddaddy married again, and I think now that his second wife already had young children, so that my Grandfather Amos was a step-brother to Uncle Edward and Aunt Lizzy. Of couse I could be wrong, and there is no one to ask, now, because Grandparents and all the uncles and aunts are now deceased. discuss thing with Uncle Ed, asking his advise on business things, and Uncle Ed would always tell Daddy what he wanted to know.
I, at a very young age, thought she looked like a paper doll—too thin to be real. Aunt Lizzie always wore a dress that was about ten inches from the floor—much longer than everybody else wore. She had some sort of problem with her eyes, and they always looked odd to me. She did not wear glasses, and she could read, though her eyes looked very dark. Uncle Ed and see tall and slender, and neither of them talked exactly like all the other people in our family who one and all spoke in the Mecklenburg County Southern Drawl. Though my grandparents on both sides of my family were all country people, all of them had gone to school. They all spoke good English with just a touch of a Southern Drawl. However, Aunt Lizzie and Uncle Ed pronounced words, and had vocabularies quite different from the rest of the family. Both of them had an odd way of talking—not like other folk raised in the South. Neither of them was funny, in the sense that they laughed a lot. I remember Uncle Ed’s smile, and a sort of change in his voice when he was amused, but not an actual laugh. I not sure I ever heard Aunt Lizzie actually laugh. She would smile and make a short lived humming sound, like “mn,mn,mn.” That was about the extent of their merriment. Both brother and sister were

The house where Uncle Ed and Aunt Lizzie (both given names were shortened Yandle house was a two story

’s house Of course I saw that house after I was grown, as my Great Aunt and Uncle lived across the street, but I was never in it again as my parents moved when I was about three years old from East Fifth Street to West Eleventh Street, and into another duplex where I lived until I married.

I remember the Eleventh Street house very well, though both the Fifth Street and Eleventh Street houses have been razed for years. The Fifth Street house was in the way of the Telephone Company I think, but the street still exists. West Eleventh Street has, along with the houses that once aligned the street, disappeared entirely. In its place there is a ramp which leads to an interstate highway that circles the city. Not too long ago my husband and I drove around in Charlotte during a visit, and I discovered that about the only thing left of that block of West Eleventh Street is the corner curbing that once touched both Eleventh Street and Pine Street. The Pine Street curbing, with , was once a part of the corner sidewalk where Eleventh Street met North Pine Street met. Only the North Pine Street curb is visible, as the 400 block of West Eleventh Street no longer exists. . b still has the name of the street Since we no longer live in Charlotte and it was razed when I was in grammar school. The house on Eleventh Sho, and that house I remember as and I I can’t see where I because there is no light. I scream. Someone opens another door, and lets me into a room where there is light. Recently I told my older sister what I remembered, and she told me that our house was a duplex, and that at the back, there was an unlighted space where there were there three doors: one into our side of the duplex, one into the other side of the duplex, and one to the outside. hall along our hall there was an unlighted a that has At the bottom of the banisters there is at least almost solid that surround the porch. But on more than one places along the half wall of the banixbright center of the shadow is a crescent of One of my first memories are dim. I am playing on the floor of the front porch. The sun is shining, but the banisters are not just a row of slender square sticks as they were on Eleventh Street. The banisters are solid, covered with something like shingles but where they touch the porch floor there are openings to let rain water drain off the porch. When the Sun is shining onto the front of the house the floor has a solid shadow where the solid banister casts a shadow, but at intervals along the banister there are half circle openings designed to allow rain or

on the floor that allow a bright crescemake and has made a pattern of shadows on the floor of our porch. Though I didn’t really know what caused the bright half circle on the floor, I liked it. The banisters are quite old, and unlike the porch of our next house, they are solid—not just solid, except that there is an cresent opening along the floor to allow rain to drain away, and that opening is an arched opening that allows the sun to create a half c cresent that

Having been born in February and the rules laid down by State and local School Boards, I did not enter school until several months after my sixth birthday, but that was probably very good for me as I moved right along, and had no problems in school, though there was one small event soon after I enrolled at Bethune School that proved I at least knew of a certainty the difference between right and wrong, and was strong enough to stand up for myself against one of the powers that be—a first grade teacher.

Bethune School was old. The floors were of dark wood, as children had been treading on them for many, many years, and Janitors had oiled the floors frequently. Student was a new word for me. I discovered that I, myself, was a student. I was a student because I was going to school. School was a red brick building with dark shiny floors and rooms with very large windows and small desks in neat rows, with a big desk in front that had a person named teacher behind it. The teacher behind the desk in the room I entered was not as tall as my mother. She was not skinny, but she wasn’t fat either. The floor of the hall way that led to the room was dark, almost black. The floor of the room was like the hallway. Just by walking on it I was aware that the floor of both hall and classroom was a little slippery, and as I had on new shoes, I walked carefully. That night I asked my Dad why it was so slick, and he said that the janitors probably put something on the floor to keep it clean. Of course I had never before thought of that, and don’t know that it was true, but I do know that the floor was slippery, and that the tables and chairs in that room skidded about at the least touch.

My teacher was Miss Belvin, and our room was very near the front door of the school. We had nice desks that were the right size—not to small, and not too big. The little desks were scattered in rows, one behind the other, and each one had a little chair just the right size for sitting at the desk. I had seen school rooms with rows of desks that were attached to each other and that were screwed to the floor so they wouldn’t move. My room was not like that. Each desk sat all by itself, with a chair behind each one. I discovered that the desks were not nailed to the floor, but could be moved. The chairs could be moved, too, so students could sit close to their desks, or move back to make room to stand up.

When the teacher began to talk to us she pointed out a table that had paper on it. When we were doing our school work we go to that table and get a clean sheet of paper when we needed it. There was a blackboard on the front wall, and plain walls on each side of the room. The back wall was different because it had very large windows that let in lots of light, and sometimes when it was warm outside and the windows were open, they let in a little breeze. The windows were so high we couldn’t really look out of them into the yard, and when they were open we could hear cars and trucks that moved along the street. There wasn’t much to see, anyway, except a red dirt school yard, and the pipes that had once supported swings for children to use during recess. Close to the brick walls of the school there were two water fountains. On our side of the school that was about all that was there.

If you walked all the way around the school, you would find that behind the school there had once been a sliding board, but there was no slick metal board to slide on. Only the ladder and two tall pipes that had once supported the top of a sliding board were still there. To my surprise, when other classes were out in the school yard the children would climb the ladder and then wrap their legs around the two pipes and slide down the pipes to the ground. When no one was sliding, students would use the pipes to pull themselves upward, climbing up those pipes like moneys, and then sliding down to the ground again.

A little way from what had once been a sliding board was something I had never before seen. It was called monkey bars. Children lined up at one end of the contraption, and was what we called monkey bars. This was also made with poles and ladders, but the longest ladder was two or three four or five feet from the ground, and it was horizontal. Children would climb a short ladder, grab hold of the rungs of the flat ladder high up rungs and slide down the pipes, sort of like the pictures in where Beyond the swings there was a low rock wall, a little bit of dirt, and a filling station. been a swing set, but now had no swings, and the beyond that the roof of the service station on the corner, and which had once held several swings for children to use. Now there were no swings hanging there, but the pipes that had once held them up were still there. Eventually I realized that older girls would fling themselves around those pipes, swinging out and landing as far form the pipe as they could. At one end of the swing set there was a low frock wall, and sometimes the girls leaned from the rock wall to hold onto the pipe, and then pushed themselves our to swing around the pipe and land on the other side of it on top of the wall again. Where there wasn’t anything to clime up on, the girls just sort of swung back and forth on the pipe, reaching higher with each swing, and when they were as high as they wanted to go, they would wrap their legs around the pipe and slide down. walked their hands up the pipe, and then slid down to the ground again. to swing by their hands, and sometimes they just walked up that pipe, with their hands, getting more than head high just hanging onto the pipe, then wrapping their legs around the pipe and sliding down. that were a little older than me could climb up those pipes using only their hands, and sort of swinging side to side while they lifted themselves higher and higher, reaching higher and higher with their hands around those pipes. but there were some tall pipes stuck in the ground that had been a swing set a long time ago. There were no chains for swings, but at each end there were three strong reaching up to the long pipe from which swings had hung. You could still see the hooks for the chains. It was mostly girls who played there. Counting both ends of the swing set there were six pipes in all, three pipes at each end of the swing set. Girls liked to play there, and they climbed the three pipes at each end of the empty swing set by pulling themselves up with their hands, But the girls now. But swings, and no chains, either. , and a long time ago there had been swings hanging from the top pipe that was held up by three strong pipes at each end, and another one that was in the middle of the long top pipe. Once it had held a lot of swings. That year there were no swings, but the school children used the pipes, anyway. The older girls would grab hold of the slanted pipes, and walk up them using only their hands, swinging back and forth, and going higher and higher with every swing, holding on with one hand. When they were as high as they wanted to go, they could wrap their legs around the pipe, and slide down. close both hands around the slanted pipes, and swing to one side, hanging on with one hand. The other hand would move up, and then the girl would swing her feet the other way, and lift with the other hand, sort of climbing up higher and higher ing from side to side and reaching up from side to side. Then they would reach with one hand to a higher place, and then reach with the other hand,

, and it any way. There was room for that formed a tripod. Of course, back then I didn’t know that a tripod was a three legged thing that could bear weight, but I did know that atthings (pipes, sticks, beams, or even pencils, well fastened together at one end and spread out at the other made a sort of legged , but later I learned that a three legged stool, or a contraption that could support a really heavy tripod made a very safe and sturdy prop for a great number of things, especially people could build. My Uncle Vance had one that would hold really heavy engines, and little short ones would hold a big pot so that a fire could be made under the pot, .from a little stool to sit on to that needed to be vast sort of different stuff, such as teepees (the tent of Indians) or of thewith a little bit of a rock wall in one place, and barely visible behind that the roof of the filling station on the corner was visible. aif I stood on the floor, but I was well aware that all I would have seen was a dirt school yard, with a little rock wall, and the top part of the filling station that was the only other building on that block.

On the first day I learned about recess. For a short time each day our class would go outside to play. I also realized that, since I didn’t really know any of the children in the class, playing might be sort of hard to do. A little way to the right of the school there was a tall strong pipe with strong metal legs that could have held swings—but didn’t. Way back and sort of behind the building there was two other strong things made of the same kind of pipes. One was a sliding board but the part a child could slide on was missing. The pipes that would 999999999 The other thing looked like someone had bent a metal ladder at each end, and stuck the ends in the ground, leaving most of the rungs of the ladder between the short ends. Then I saw children climb one end, and grab the level rungs, and swing from rung to rung all the way across the flat part of that ladder. lined up at one end of aid a metal ladder across two short ladders, and I saw students climb on one end, and swing on their hands all you could climb on each end, and I soon learned that children could climb up one end, and then swing from the bars it was I learned was a

here was going to be hard to do, since there were no swings, and no see-saws, and no seats of any kind. There was only the dirt

hey were not affixed to the floor like the desks in some of the rooms. The teacher had a big desk in front of the class, but it was not in the middle. It was near a window. There were windows only at the back of the room, but there were lights in the ceiling. The teacher told me which desk was mine, and that I would sit there everyday. I didn’t need a notebook like my sisters. I could not yet read or write, so I didn’t need a notebook. The teacher gave us paper to write on when it was time to write. She gave us drawing paper when it was time to draw. She handed out books from which we would learn to read, and she had a big black board that she could write on. Our parents had to buy pencils and crayons for us. To begin with we had to stay at school until one o’clock. Then we could go home.

There was one problem that I faced. My mother was not at home, because she now had a job as a seamstress at a Sewing Shop uptown. My Dad was a painting contractor, and he had gone to work with the man who worked for him. Since my sister had gone to High School for the very first time, and to a brand new school named Harding High School that had just been built, no one was at my house. Mother had explained to me—more than once—that after school I was to walk straight to her work place and spend the afternoon there, being a good girl and not talking too much. I was not, under any circumstances, to enter our house since there was no one there, and the lock on the front door didn’t work. “Someone who is a bad person could be in the house when you go in, so don’t go in,” she said. So I never did.

I was well aware that strangers could just walk in. It happened more than one time, and it was usually in the evening or at night. I well remember that one winter night a man who was drunk staggered down our hall and walked into the kitchen where all of us were sitting as it was the only warm room in the house that evening. The man was not sturdy on his feet, and swayed a little when he stopped. My Dad stood up, and asked “what do you want?” The man said, “I just want to go to bed.” My Dad, who was six feet three inches tall, and looked strong and able said, “You can’t go to bed here, you’ll have to go to your house.” The poor drunk man was almost weeping, and he said again, “I just want to go to bed.” But when my Dad walked toward him and told him that he couldn’t sleep here, and that he was in the wrong house, the man turned and went away.

As young as I was, I knew about drunks. 3 years drunks9999999999999999When I was about four years old I was never allowed to climb the stairs to the toilet. I had a potty inside the pantry, not because I wasn’t trained, but because my mother and dad didn’t trust the people who were renting the upstairs. It was a married couple, and they both used alcohol. They were often drunk, and mother said he was like a fox in a chicken coop—one that had a key to the door of the coop. It was inconvenient for my parents, but I never so often that

I decided that the old drunk man was sort of like the Rickmans who had once lived in the three upstairs rooms in our house. Mr. Rickman was a drunk, though I don’t remember whether or not his wife drank liquor. Mother wouldn’t allow me to use the bathroom by myself because it was at the top of the stairs and it was it was the only one in the house. She said “I don’t trust that man”because she didn’t trust that man. There was also a man and his wife who lived upstairs in hour house and he was often inebriated. Mother didn’t trust him, and until I was at least six she wouldn’t even let me go upstairs by myself because he was both a bad man and a drunkard. I was glad when they moved out.

There was house on both the other side of the street and the other end of the block that was a boarding house. He may have simply gone to the wrong end of the block on the wrong side of the street. been mixed up, Most of the boys in the class discovered that they could slide on the floor, and that it was easy to slip down on that floor. The school, my Dad said, was old. The walls looked old to me. The windows were different from the ones in our house. I expected to find rows of desks with legs that were screwed to the floor. I had been inside the school before, and most of the rooms had that kind of desk, and the tables and chairs looked new. I discovered that the first grade room was very different from the others. Our desks were different, and our chairs were not bolted to the floor. Instead, they had silvery button on ever leg of every wooden chair. We also had a very different kind of desk. Every student had a small table with a small shelf beneath it to hold books. Of course every pupil had a both a chair and a desk, and both desk and chair slid easily along the floor which looked damp, as if it had just been mopped. The floor didn’t look waxed, but it was shiny. The chairs were easy to slide, too, with little shiny ball-like things on the bottom of the legs. The teacher said that was so they would slide quietly, and easily. The problem that arose was that the chairs moved so easily that if you pushed a certain way, the chair and the student could slide away from desk or table and more often than not the chair would tilt a bit and turn over. On the first day the teacher would hurry to the fallen child, but soon she realized, as did all the students, that almost, if not all of the “accidents” were on purpose. Those chairs made a lovely noise when they hit the floor, and the kind teacher came running to help the poor little child (mostly boys) to stand up, always asking if he or she was hurt.

After a few days, Miss Belvin laid down the law: if your chair turns over, you must stand facing a corner of the room, and you couldn’t turn your head at all. The only thing you could see was the corner wall. Only the children who were “cut-ups” kept turning over their chairs, and though it took a while, eventually they stopped doing it on purpose because it surely wasn’t any fun to stare at a wall.
