Even so, there were still the “smart elects” who would risk turning over their chairs. The result was always loud, unexpected, and disruptive. The fallen ones usually laughed, and stood in a corner. Miss Belvin was less and less concerned about their possible “injury,” as most of them did it on purpose.

There were fewer and fewer splats on the floor, but they still happened occasionally. There came a day when I had to rise from my desk to get a clean sheet of paper from the supply desk. I wanted to finish my work, perhaps being a little less careful than I normally was, but the result was that my chair moved away from me as I sat, and I hit the floor with a mighty thud, jarring my spine, sending pain up my back, and hurting my bottom. I was really hurting, and tears ran down my cheeks. The teacher didn’t leave her desk, but she looked at me and told me to stand in the corner.

I was stunned by the pain of hitting that floor. And I expected, and felt I had a right to believe that my teacher should care. She didn’t. And right then and there my respect for her hit rock bottom. I had tears in my eyes, but I go up. I said nothing to her at that moment, but I picked up my chair, placed it before my desk, and carefully and painfully sat down in it. I did not look at my teacher. She, however, looked at me. I’m sure by that time the tears were visible. Then she told me again to stand in the corner. I looked at her, and I said, “I’m not going to stand in the corner, because I didn’t mean to fall. I got hurt, and you don’t care.” Then I picked up my pencil and continued with my task, while my back ached and my anger smoldered. From that moment, I didn’t trust teachers at all. I discovered that very moment how rage could shoot up totally through a person, hot and quick. I didn’t know that forever after that I would take it for granted that teachers were not everything they looked like on the first day of school, and that they could make mistakes, and that I could stand up for myself when I was wronged. I didn’t realize that my backbone grew solid and strong that day, and that I would never again expect a teacher to be a good person just because of the title. I passed the first grade at the end of the year with a good grade, and I stopped by Miss Belvin’s desk in June and thanked her for teaching me. But I never again fully trusted a teacher to be perfect. I had discovered that they, too, could make mistakes.

In the First Grade I learned to read, and I learned to use numbers. I learned grownups and governments could make really silly rules, such as girls couldn’t wear long pants to school even in freezing temperatures and I learned to read, I learned to write, and I learned to eat lunch in a cafeteria. I learned that not all students wanted to learn, and some could be rowdy just for meanness. I discovered that recess was not much fun because there were no swings, or other play things on the school grounds, and I learned that you shouldn’t run full tilt into a rock wall because it could break a hole in your scull as it did one of the older students who almost died playing a silly game that required her to break through a circle of other girls holding hands, trying to keep that person inside of the circle of girls. I copied lessons from the blackboard, and I read out loud when it was my turn. I learned numbers, and in winter when it was very cold outside, I wore leggings to school, but I had to take them off when I was inside my classroom, even if it was chilly in the room, because it was against the rules of the school for girls to wear pants like a boy. That rule was enforced even when it was freezing outside and still chilly inside. We could wear sweaters, but not pants. Those were the rules. Since I walked three blocks to school my mother made me wear leggings under my dress, and a knitted cap on my head but the teacher expected me to take off the leggings when I took off my coat.

At the beginning of the year when I entered the First Grade I discovered that First Grade students left school earlier than the other students, and could go home at one o’clock. That was a problem for me, but not a big one. My mother had taken a job outside our home and wasn’t at home at 1:00 P.M. From the first day of school I was forbidden to go home when school was out because none of my family was at home that early in the afternoon. Daddy went to his work as a painting contractor, my sister, Ella Cornelia went to High School which had a longer “day” than my school, and my Mother stopped being just a mother by taking a job in a sewing shop.

The shop was run by Mrs. Octavia King and another person, who discovered she needed to be at home for a while, and Mrs. King asked my mother to join her as a partner. The sign on the window announced that the King and Yandle Sewing Shop was in that building. Mother worked there for a nearly ten years. Every day when school was out, I walked from school to the sewing shop and spent my afternoons there, doing my home work, reading, and fairly often I went out to ramble alone through Belk’s Department Store, and Woolworth’s, and sometimes I went out of Woolworth’s and into Efrids Department Store and happily rode the escalators which were like magic. Up I would go, and if I thought no one was looking, I would walk down those moving steps, hoping no one would pay any attention to me. If the Floor Walkers (that was the security folk) saw me, they would stop the escalators, and that would stop everyone from using the moving stairs. They were not, of course, like the ones we have today which go both up and down. The Efrids rolling stairs only went up. Shoppers could use the elevators to go down. As I grew up I had more freedom to wander around the stores on my own.

Dolls

already existed before my mother went to work, and two ladies had a number of regular customers when one of them was badly needed at home, and and had been a going concern for several years before my mother became a partner joinedhad two seamstresses working there. One of the ladies was now needed to be at home instead of away at a job, and Mrs. King asked my mother to take the place of the other lady. Mother joined Mrs. King as an equal partner, and the new name on the window of the shop said King and Yandle Sewing Shop. Mrs. King had once been our neighbor, though I didn’t remember her from my childhood. The new name of the shop was the King and Yandle Sewing Shop, located on the second floor of a building very near the Square on East Trade Street. The shop had been there for some time, and it stayed there for a number of years after that. Mother worked there for at least eight or ten years, and quit only when my Dad needed her to open the Yandle paint store precisely across the street from our house on Eleventh Street.

I could claim that I grew up well acquainted with two businesses. One was my mother’s, as she was a seamstress, and the other was my Dad’s, who was a painting contractor. Then there was the fact that with both my parents working I also learned how to keep house, cook, wash clothes, iron them, and then there was secretarial work I did for my Dad once I learned to typewrite. As I grew up was given the great pleasure of learning to play a violin, and I was in the school orchestra for seven years. After graduating from and in between and after those there was housekeeping, choir singing, and secretarial work. Then I became an aunt, and a few years later, a wife and mother, and I nursed babies for a while, then went back to work as a secretary. After a while I became a grandmother, and here lately I have become a great grandmother. a little bit of the third different businesses: the sewing shop until I entered my teen age years, and then the paint store until I graduated from college. As a first grader I walked to school alone, and I walked alone to my mother’s sewing shop until the year that the Polio epidemic forced the schools to close earlier that summer, and to delay a little the opening of the schools in the fall. The City of Charlotte banned children younger than sixteen from movie theaters, and churches, and no one younger than sixteen years of age could work in a public place. Children were banned from department stores, and were advised not to travel on the city busses. These were the most s d a city government rule that children under the age of sixteen had to stay at home. Children were encouraged to avoid playing with neighbor children, and were not allowed in theatres or the public library, and most of them didn’t even go to church during that frightening summer. Wise parents kept their children from playing with all other children.

That business remained in that location for ten or more years, and when Mother changed businesses, Mrs. King’s daughter joined her, and it was still a well known shop for several more years. The King and Yandle Sewing Shop was located very near the Square in an old brick building that had a busy history, though I never heard many stories about it. The shop itself had been in business for several years and had a lots of customers. Mrs. King and my mother, but it had been there for some time because at first Mrs. King had another partner. The shop was housed on the second floor a very old but quite sturdy building owned by a very odd sort of person who was one of the most well known people in the city. She was Miss Sally Davis who was very rich, and very well known in Charlotte. She, herself, came once a month to my mother’s shop to collect the rent for the Sewing Shop, and she wore long black dresses that touched the tops of her black shoes, and she always wore a black hat. It had been years since any other woman wore an ordinary everyday dress that almost touched the ground. Hemlines were at that time almost always just below the knee for grown women, but Miss Sally did not mind being different. She was, of course, very rich, and very set in her ways, and she came each month to the sewing shop to collect the rent money. garment that almost touched the one roomon rented the room on the second floor of a building really close to the Square. That building doesn’t exist now, but back then it was very near a major department store owned by the Belk family, and years later several more buildings were removed and a marvelous performing arts building was built in its place. the building was torn down, leaving an empty space for a long while. Eventually a large portion of old buildings in that area were that space was place does not exist called King and Yandle Sewing Shop. The name was written in red letters painted on the window which opened onto East Trade Street. The building was owned by a lady named Miss Sally Davison the Second Floor window of an old brick building on East Trade Street. Mrs. King had once lived next door to us, but that was when I was very young, and I didn’t remember the lady at all, though my sister had played with the King children when they lived near each other.

When School began in September, Mother stopped being only a wife and mother. She stopped being just a Mother and a keeper of the house. She began to work up town in a sewing shop making dresses for ladies who couldn’t sew and preferred a garment made for them instead of buying one off a rack in one of the stores. The shop where she worked was in an old brick building very close to the Square on East Trade Street. Several buildings on Tryon Street and those that were near the corner on Trade Street were torn down to make way for the Performing Arts Center that occupies that space today. However, in the 1930’s the old brick building owned by Miss 9999999 had several small shops on the first floor, and a number of second and third floor offices or spaces that were used by Belk’s Department Store as a sort of attic storage space for the men’s store, and perhaps other departments as well. On the second floor there were some small businesses such as seamstresses who made clothing to order, and a beauty parlor, and a photographer, and perhaps other businesses that I didn’t know about, because I never ever walked down the third floor hallway, though I realized that there were some people who worked up there. Wthat was torn down when a large auditorium was built for the performing arts. . The first floor of the building was two very small stores, and one of them was the Belk Brother’s Men’s Store. which was the very center of Charlotte where Trade Street and Tryon Street crossed each other. just a littlwith a wide open doorway that led to a very tall staircase that turned a corner near the top, and led to a dingy hall. Along the wide hallway at the top of the stairs were lots of doors on both sides of the hall, and most of them were either empty, or they were rented by the Belk Men’s Store as a storage place for their merchandise. It always seemed strange to me, but once I had climbed all the stairs and passed only one business which was run by one lady who was also a seamstress

The building that housed the King and Yandle Sewing Shop was owned by one of Charlotte’s real, honest to goodness, oddball. Her name was Miss Sally Davis, and she was not married. She was also very rich, and owned a lot of the property on Trade and Tryon streets. She had a big house, and wore clothes that were exactly right in the late 1800’s and her style stayed exactly and precisely the same for the rest of her life. Very few women wore skirts that almost touched the ground, but Miss Sally did. Her black shoes were always shiny, and her hair always pulled straight away form her face, and into a bun. She always wore a hat—a black hat—on top of her head. She was very thin, and when I was about twelve I thought she was silly to walk around town collecting money. She was small enough for a thief to grab her money and run—but that was the brave Miss Sally, who seemed to have outlived all her family, and who now alone attended to her business in person, and was well known to important persons as well as the ordinary folk who pointed to her, and quietly told their companions that they were noticing Miss Sally Davis, the strange old spinster lady who owned most of the real estate in uptown Charlotte.

brick on East Trade Street next door to Martin’s Department Storehad a job, and she made sure that I knew the way to the place she was working. Of course I did, but I knew the way from home to her shop, but not from the school to her shop. So I walked the nearly three blocks from school to my house, passed my house and didn’t stop there, and continued to walk uptown, as I had been taught by my mother. It was eleven blocks from our house.

The rest of the afternoon was both boring at times, and exciting at other times. The sewing shop was a one room business with two ladies, two sewing machines, a huge tall table that Mother and Mrs. King used to cut out garments, and there was a “stand” which actually wasn’t very large, but it was interesting to me. It had spools of thread of almost every color and hue stuck on nails along the length of the stand, and to my delight the top was not altogether level, but stepped so that it was easy to place or remove thread from the skinny little nails. I played with those spools, and rearranged them, placing all blues of many hues together, and all the greens, and all reds, and all browns—and happily amused myself until Mother and Mrs. King put away their sewing, and we all left the shop. There were two windows that had a marvelous view of East Trade Street, and the intersection that was called “the Square.” I could see city busses come and go, and traffic moving along both Trade and Tryon Streets, and it was wonderful to watch parades march through the Square without having to be in the crowd. The Fire Department was several blocks away on East Trade Street, and the Fire Chief usually went to every fire, so that several times a day that red car with a screaming serine would rush up the street, and I thought it was wonderful that it was the only car that could turn either right or left from Trade street onto Tryon Street. Drivers were not allowed to turn at that intersection, except for the fire chief, or the fire trucks.

The building that housed the King and Yandle Sewing Shop was owned by one of Charlotte’s real, honest to goodness, oddball. Her name was Miss Sally Davis, and she was not married. She was also very rich, and owned a lot of the property on Trade and Tryon streets. She had a big house, and wore clothes that were exactly right in the late 1800’s and her style stayed exactly and precisely the same for the rest of her life. Very few women wore skirts that almost touched the ground, but Miss Sally did. Her black shoes were always shiny, and her hair always pulled straight away form her face, and into a bun. She always wore a hat—a black hat—on top of her head. She was very thin, and when I was about twelve I thought she was silly to walk around town collecting money. She was small enough for a thief to grab her money and run—but that was the brave Miss Sally, who seemed to have outlived all her family, and who now alone attended to her business in person, and was well known to important persons as well as the ordinary folk who pointed to her, and quietly told their companions that they were noticing Miss Sally Davis, the strange old spinster lady who owned most of the real estate in uptown Charlotte.

where it sat on a nail tha.

but walked eleven more blocks to the Square, an intersection where Trade Street and Tryon Street crossed each other, and then I walked down Trade Street past the corner drug store, and past a shoe store and then entered a dark staircase which I climbed

ets Drug store, and a store where only shoes were sold, and entered a doorway that led to staircase. shoe at the beginning of the year

The year that I entered seventh grade was very different from my first six years of schooling. For one thing, I moved from an old school that had been I doubted had looked as if it had never been refurbished, seldom been been there for

appearances, if you don’t count the newsworthy job of choir director in fairly small churches, or the occasional role of Sunday school teacher. Very few of my efforts have caused people to notice me. Nevertheless, my children, my grandchildren, and my great-grandchildren might one day want to know a bit more than the history books tell about the past, and about our family. They may want to know more precisely how life was lived when I was young. I now wish with all my heart that I knew more about the lives of my parents when they were growing up. Was the world very different then, than it was when I was growing up? Is the Twenty-first Century very different from the Twentieth Century? The answer is that of course life and the living of it changes tremendously from one era to the next, and with my own experiences I can truthfully say that I came from horse and buggy days into the era when men walked on the moon, and I have seen many of the early wonders of the Twenty-first Century.

During the lives of my grandparents, as well as the lives of my parents, life truly was extremely different than life today. My Twentieth and Twenty-first century grandchildren would be horrified if suddenly they no longer had television, radios, electric lights, other electric conveniences including computers, especially air conditioning, and running water. They would have been appalled to find no indoor toilets, nor bath tubs, and that baths were taken from a smallish sized wash pan, and clothes were washed outdoors in a black iron pot that required a fire under it to boil the clothing and bed linens clean. There were no dryers, therefore the laundry had to be hung on a line to dry. They would especially hate the entire idea of having a kitchen sink that drained, not into a drain pipe rapidly and quickly out of sight, but into a bucket set carefully just beneath a short, dripping pipe and into an open bucket sitting on the floor, one that had to be carried outside to be emptied in a place where it would not create an easily visible mess. There was in those days no nice drain pipe that would carry away waste water. There was no garbage disposal, nor was there a weekly pick up of garbage and trash. Garbage not fit for the pigs or chickens to eat were either buried or burned, and trash was also usually burned. Not much that could be used in some way was ever treated as garbage. Torn sheets or clothing became dust rags or cleaning rags, and almost anything that was once edible but not actually consumed at the table at breakfast, lunch, or dinner, was usually poured into a slop bucket that would be fed to the pigs. In the late 1890’s and well into the early 1930’s, food left on plates, or dabs of vegetables not eaten were fed to the pigs, along with other garbage such as potato peelings, or slightly rotten tomatoes or small portions of foods left over from meals and too small to serve again were not sent to the garbage can, but were taken to the hog pen, and fed to the critters that would eventually be the pork to be placed on the dining table after the pigs were killed and cooked. Trash was usually burned in a place where a fire would not threaten fields or houses, or barns; however, little that could be used for much of anything was ever thrown away.

To cook, even in summer, the stoves had to have a fire burning in one end, and all hot water would have come from a small reservoir accessed from a trap door at one end of the iron stove top. The fire made the kitchen extremely warm in summer, but in winter the warmth was appreciated, as there was em, sinks . Yet manual typewriters were novel when I was a child. Radio was in its infancy. My family didn’t even have a telephone until I was eleven or twelve years old. There were no real antibiotics when my sister and I were children. Sulfa was about the only medication that could actually fight some illnesses, and that was not always either available or effective.

Six years before my birth, my mother’s first born was delivered at home, and at the age of six my sister was aware that some little girls wore store bought clothes, while she, herself, wore home made garments. She must have thought their dresses were quite lovely, as she seemed jealous of their wardrobe. On top of that, she discovered that she had been born at home, but the new baby had been born in Presbyterian Hospital—and that sounded like a place that was much more fancy than a home birth, so she resented me, and particularly hated doing anything at all for me. Her angry attitude toward me didn’t truly go away until I was about twelve years old. id did not even go to the hospital for the birth. Ella Cornelia was six, when I was born, and somehow she got it into her head that she was a “home-made” baby and I was “store bought” and that was part of the reason she disliked my arrival so very much. It took a little more than ten years to convince her that Mother and Daddy hadn’t played a dirty trick on her by having another child, and that they didn’t like me better than they liked her.

Life in this year—2006—is widely different than life when my sister was born in November of 1925. I entered the world about six years after she did, in February of 1931. 999999999999999999From the days when I was an infant, the lives of working people and the way people live in the Twenty-first Century is so very different form the way my grandparents lived that it could be the description of another planet. When my grandparents were children there were stories about people like one of my Dad’s uncles who, in his older years, had to admit that he had been married four times. The first three wives died in childbirth. He had more than twenty children, all of them at home, the evening my Dad at supper with them. His relatively young wife had prepared the meal. My Dad’s uncle, though I don’t remember his name, told my Dad that the happiest time of his life was when all his children were still at home, and the entire family would sit at table at meal time.

and a goodly portion of life is much improved simply because both information and communication are greatly improved, education is much more wide spread, and medicine, itself, has changed and lengthened lives. Then there are gadgets and inventions, whether whimsical or unexpectedly life-changing, that are not only available, but are in daily use to reduce the drudgery of house cleaning, and the monotony of washing dishes, but more important there are the changes and victories that medicine and treatments of today have mastered.

When I was born early in the year 193l the Great Depression had devastated our entire country, beginning first in the Northern States and then seeping down into the South. Banks closed because depositors withdrew their accounts until there was no more money in their cash drawers. Banks who had no funds in their vaults could no longer accommodate their depositors who expected to withdraw their own money from the bank. People who suddenly discovered that businesses were closing causing widespread unemployment, and banks that were had closed their doors, people were no longer able to pay their bills, or their rent, or their mortgage payments. The result of that was that unpaid mortgages caused foreclosures after which people living in the homes they had been buying were evicted, and most of them had no other place to go unless they had kinfolk who had farms, where they could at least grow their own food. Banks, without weekly or monthly deposits from wages and facing heavy withdrawals from unemployed people, simply closed their doors. Businesses of all sorts closed because their stock was depleted and they could not pay for more merchandise, and others which closed because they either had no customers, or because they could no longer replenish their shelves nor pay their workers. With owners and workers from small businesses finding themselves without income, and larger businesses suddenly discovering they had few customers who could pay immediately, discovered also that their profits were drastically reduced or non-existent. More and more people had no income. The failure of the banks wiped out countless nest eggs that had been prudently laid by in what people had believed was a safe place.

Unpaid wages and failed banks meant that people could not pay rent or mortgages; it also hindered buying groceries, or medications. Within the City of Charlotte citizens who were unable to pay the costs of electricity and water found those amenities discontinued. Sometimes folks who lived in the country where water came from springs or wells, and food could be grown in their own gardens, would invite relatives or close friends to share their homes until jobs were again available, and that was usually a wonderful relief for those families, but generally played havoc with relationships that were immediately too close for real comfort. Unfortunately not everyone had parents or cousins, or aunts, uncles, or loving friends who could help them. The Salvation Army was quite active in those days, much appreciated, and a sturdy pillar when the sky was falling in on almost everybody. There were very few “safety nets” beneath ordinary, hard working, and honest people. Almost every worker in the entire nation was affected. No job—no pay—no food—no shelter—no answers—no hope.

Since banks had closed, no access to savings meant no money at all. City people often moved in with home folks who had a farm, or parents who could offer shelter. Some who lost their livelihood had friends, close relatives, or even distant cousins who could help them. But there were many persons who had no job, no home, and no friend or family able, or perhaps willing, to help them. Most of those folk had to depend on agencies or churches, or the blessed Salvation Army where the homeless could usually get a meal, or shelter, and perhaps a cot inside a building to sleep on.

I, myself, remember that during the early years that my family (Dad, Mother, Sister, me) lived on West Eleventh Street, there were knocks on our kitchen door, usually close to lunch time, or between lunch and supper, and there at the bottom of our porch steps was a man in shabby clothing, asking if we could spare food, as he was hungry. Homeless men regularly camped along railroad tracks, sleeping in lean-tos made of bits and pieces of wood and cardboard, building fires in barrels, and trying not to arouse attention, or to cause any incident that would end with meeting policemen. Within the city the railroad right-of-ways offered some privacy for the homeless since most city housing had at least a little space, usually separated by a barrier of bushes and trees, between the streets and the railroad right-of-way because of the noise of the trains as well as the soot from the engines that were at that time using coal to produce steam in their boilers.

There were at least three railroad companies serving Charlotte in those years. One was well away from our house, and was a short line that hauled mostly people who traveled into and out of Charlotte every day across the Catawba River. For close to fifty years my Great Uncle Renus was the engineer on that local line, however, most of his riders knew him as “Johnny”, and most of his daily commuters correctly believed he was their friend. There were two other much larger railroad companies that came through Charlotte, and both had tracks quite near our house on Eleventh Street, causing two very different problems for my family. The problem was not whistle noise, as we didn’t mind the frequent whistles when the engine crossed city streets. However, back then the trains used steam engines with black smoke bellowing from the smoke stack. In winter, when we had cool and slightly damp days or, frequently at sundown on winter evenings, falling soot from passing trains was expected. Soot fell, not only from trains, but also from nearby chimneys. Electric dryers had been invented, but I didn’t know a single person who owned one until after I was married. The penalty of leaving clothes on the line after sundown in cold weather was to be vulnerable to falling soot and the threat of having to re-wash and re-dry every garment, towel, sheet, and handkerchief before we could use them.

Railroads produced another situation that affected city people who lived within a few blocks of the tracks. During all the years we lived on West Eleventh Street in Charlotte, we sometimes had back-door visitors. Because my mother couldn’t bear the idea of people actually going hungry, we were subject to visits from hobos. Both the Southern Railroad and the Norfolk and Southern tracks were only about two blocks away, and the right-of-ways of the tracks were only a few feet from the roadbeds of the city streets or even of houses and businesses built quite near the tracks. Bushes and trees would offer some softening of the noise of the engines and the clack-clack of rolling box cars, gondolas, and/or passenger cars, but the noise was there, and people who lived close to the tracks eventually simply endured the noise, and were rarely perturbed by the sounds. Since so many trains passed near us, we never checked our watches or clocks by the noise.

There was, however, one sound to which we did pay attention. There was a factory not far form our house that had three shifts of workers every day of the year. Their day was divided into three eight-hour shifts, and it sounded at Seven o’clock in the morning, Three in the afternoon, and Eleven o’clock every evening, seven days a week. We often depended on the hoots to time our own actions. The hoot at 7:00 AM meant if I wasn’t already out of bed, I’d better hurry it up. The Three O’clock hoot meant school was out, and in the evenings I had better be in bed when the last whistle of the day sounded at 11:00 PM.

The noise of neither mill nor trains was bothersome; however, the trains did affect us, especially in winter, though it wasn’t the noise. We washed our clothes in hot water in a tin tub, using a scrub board for stubborn dirty splotches, and then rinsed them in cold water. Then we wrung them by hand as dry as we could. The next step was hanging the clothes on a line in the back yard to dry in the sun. Woe to the neighbor kid who ran across our yard under our wet clothes leaving dirt on freshly washed clothes. We didn’t wash clothes on a rainy day. In winter when we had to heat the inside of the house, we had to do the wash as early as possible, because near sundown the air grew cooler, people stirred up their fires and their chimneys belched soot that would rain down on roofs and on clean clothes hung on a clothes line, too. We endeavored to always have our washing safely off the line well before sundown. If we were late, we would probably need to wash the clothes again, or wear soot spotted clothes. Some, or perhaps most, of the soot came from the train engines which still burned coal in those days. As the sun disappeared particles of smoke fell like rain. Soot fell routinely onto and around our house as there were two tracks from two different railroads that passed within two blocks of our house.
88888888888888888888888888 From our house we could hear the chug and clanks of the engines and cars of the trains, as well as the whistles of the engines when they were near a street crossing. Another constant noise was of motor traffic not only on our street, but also on Graham Street, a block the streets near us. West Eleventh Street which ran in front of our house connected to two separate streets that were eventually entries to, or exits from, the City of Charlotte. We were four blocks from North Tryon Street, a major thoroughfare, and less than a full block from heavily traveled North Graham Street. Eleventh Street was not only a corridor between those streets, but also could allow traffic to connect to streets that pointed eastward. Traffic along Eleventh Street was usually both heavy and fast, despite speed limits. By the time I was in the second or third grade it was dangerous to cross Eleventh Street traffic increased became heavier, faster, and somewhat more dangerous. fast, em. uched Tryon Street which was a North-South corridor, and less than a block from our house Eleventh intersected Graham Street which, in one direction intersected with Trade Street, and in the other direction intersected with Statesville Road. We had a great deal of traffic that included not only automobiles, but long haul tractor-trailers, so that our street was seldom without traffic. There was a time from the early forties to somewhere in the late fifties that we didn’t like to go to the movies until after the wreck at the corner of Eleventh and Pine Streets, and we had at least one nearly every Saturday afternoon. The only one that had been genuinely entertaining was the time no one was hurt, but a taxi overturned. Quickly, but seven people crawled through a back window to get out of that taxi and the last one was on crutches. Understand, we didn’t look at it as entertaining, and upon occasion we even drove people to the hospital, but wouldn’t you find it—well, at least unusual—for seven grown people with one on crutches to crawl through a window from the back seat of a taxi?

The Square was the center of Charlotte. It was where the first two main streets crossed each other, right in the middle of Charlotte’s downtown area. Tryon and Trade streets intersected, and that intersection was called the Square. . We were eleven blocks from the Square. Our t section of Charlotte rarely had quiet streets. These were thoroughfares with long-haul trucks as well as automobiles heading for the center of town. Tryon Street was three blocks away from our house, and Trade was only a couple of blocks further which and Graham the centerOur street connected two roads, Tryon Street, and Graham Street, that seemed to go the same direction, but actually lead to different cities, and that made our street a busy, heavily traveled road. We could also hear the whistles and puffs of train engines from two railroads, both about two blocks from our house. . sound of the engine of the one of which at that point, ran North-South parallel to Graham Street, and another, the Norfolk-Southern tha ran within two blocks of our house. One of them ran North-South along the track near our , one track ran east to west, and the other from north to south. Those men knocked at our back door, and asked for food, thanking us for whatever we gave them.

to the west, and one to the north of our home. the not far from our house. They would come by our house, knock on our back door—not the front door—and ask for food. , Just because but a difficult their difficulties could be amendedfor city dwellers with

. Entire families, old, middle-aged, young, some with children, others with elderly folk to care for, had no income, meaning they could not pay rent, or their bills for electricity and water, and if they were buying a home, they were unable to meet the mortgage payment, either. They could not in many cases, purchase what they needed to keep warm, or to even purchase food.

Everyone was involved with difficulties during this time, and as winter approached, people were When the Depression bankrupted the business where my Daddy worked, it was devastating in a monumental way.

People with families who already owned their homes, in many instances people who already owned their homes could help relatives and friends who had neither job nor housing, and a lot of people moved, sometimes able to also move their belongings, but often unable to take more than the clothes on their backs when they owed a payment or rent. It was a terrible situation where people lost everything they had worked for many years to achieve, leaving them with no income, no shelter, and no hope of finding a new job. It was truly a sad and depressed time.

My Dad had been buying three houses—two as an investment, and one as a home. He lost all of them, because he lost his job and couldn’t make payments on any of them. The owner of the lumber yard where he worked had kept him on payroll as long as possible, but eventually he, too, had to close his business.

gings from where they had been living to the home that could , accommodate their kindred by allowing them to shr who , no only could they not purchase food, but they couldn’t pay rent, or continue mortgage payments. This was not just a matter of negotiating with a lender.

o customers, and therefore no income, resulting in the cold, hard fact that they could not pay their workers, either. Jobs of all sorts ended abruptly, sometimes without the final pay checks. Construction halted with uncompleted homes and buildings, houses being purchased by paying a set amount each month were emptied when the buyers could not continue to make complete or regular payments. and almost every person in the country was

Houses under construction simply Banks failed, and mortgages went unpaid. and many other and changed how and where people lived, and how businesses were structured, and yes, there is a huge difference between how life was lived then and how my grandchildren are growing up. The significant change from a few Indian Tribes who moved frequently, giving the land and the food animals the opportunity to replenish themselves, and leaving their home sites much as they had found it to the European idea of establishing permanent cities with large numbers of people who homes and . This allowed ing nature itself to replenish that area so that it could be used again after a reasonable intervalwhen it had to and left the areas they had inhabited for relatively short periods almost as it was when they found it.

Then people came from England and Europe and other countries around the Mediterranean Sea. Soon after they landed on the Eastern shores of North America they started cutting down trees, for houses, plowing the land, killing the animals who had roamed there, and congregating in areas that became cities. Their presence, unlike that of the Indian Tribes, was as permanent as possible, and that single difference changed what we call “Mother Nature” in the process.

Those early folk who crossed the Atlantic from Britain, Ireland, and also from the Continent of Europe, were few at the beginning, but they grew in numbers, and kept increasing in numbers and spreading away from their origins across the sea to the newly discovered continent we call North America. Spain concentrated on the southern part of North America, and also filtered into the Southward extension of South America. ards Europeans usually came ashore above the equator. Spaniards seemed to move more to the South, and settled in South America. , moving both North and South along the coast, and westward, away from the sea, spreading and exploring, often following rivers that emptied into the Atlantic. As goods, tools, people, and animals like horses and cows arrived in North America, groups of people moved west as well as south. In the earlier years there was plenty of space to settle along the Easter Shores of the Atlantic. Eventually, people explored, moving always away from already claimed land into unclaimed areas, and in those areas the Government of the United States allowed people to “claim” home places, if they would build homes and farm or ranch on a specific measure of land. , or otherwise use the land to the betterment of the new country that was eventually called the United States of America. Most of the time people could claim a certain measure of land, build a house of some sort, and farm, or perhaps breed cattle, or a little of both, for a specified number of months or years, and the land would be theirs, to keep for themelves or their children, or sell in order to claim their farms, their estates, their ranches, their farms, their towns, their ranches, and always wherever the people expanded their ownership, somewhere near by there would be a town of sorts. It doesn’t really take a lot of people to make a town. Once—and only the one time—Bobby and I drove westward from North Carolina across a great part of our nation, as far north and west as Oregon, and then we drove south almost to the Mexican border, and then turned eastward again, aiming across the country toward home. as far south . We crossed the Mississippi at the Tennessee border, and angled north-westward

or simply continued until they found a place to build their homes and farms. seldom crossed the great Mississippi river, sea. . inland from the Coast of the continent, and westward away from the Atlantic, crossing mountains, and plains and eventually finding the Pacific coast. Though the sail would be difficult, a westward direction from the coast of continent brought the ship into the area that Europeans called the “East.” , and discovering that by sailing South and East from that coast would eventually place the sailors in the Orient, and other points eastward. west, and also spread along the coast both north and south along the coast of Southern Africa. the , and west from the Atlantic Ocean, the Sea on which they had made their journey across from Britain, Ireland, Europe and the nations around the Mediterranean Sea. A little later The Pacific Ocean brought people to the West Coast of North America from China, and Southern Africa the relatively, and somewhat later those who came aross. Those folk were brave, yes, but many of them were desperate, also, because life in what is now Great Brittan and Europe, as well as North Africa and the Middle East, had for centuries often been interrupted by wars, famines, plagues, droughts, wars, floods, ignorance, and greed. All of those things were the result of strong, warlike peoples of many different sorts, from either close or distant countries who endeavored to subdue the original inhabitants in order to seize their land, their possessions, and sometimes make slaves of those people who survived the attack. their many different places within this world, most of whom always wanted more—more of whatever seemed good to them—land, water, food, trees, meat animals, fish, cozy homes, the good things that made pleasant living without the drudgery of working from early dawn to late evening. Everyone wanted good lives with as small a degree of effort as possible. People living, and suffering from droughts, wars, invasions, illnesses that killed, floods, selfish rulers, all wanted an easier life. Always, everywhere, the peaceful and plentiful years were wonderful. However, there were always either small or extensive wars, crowded and unsanitary cities, changing seasons, occasional climate changes, sudden destructive storms, and at intervals, discovery of iscoveries of unclaimed lands beyond current boundaries, and growing knowledge of ways to travel, and which often changed, and the powers that waxed and waned in cities, countries, and built cities, countries, and nations and then fought wars that depleted their holdings and destroyed their homes and fields, the European, African, Asian continents fought wars, built and destroyed cities, and, and eventually rebuilt cities and nations that repeated that cycle and were eventually overrun and destroyed during wars or famines. When people were powerful because of armies and strength they cared little for the weaker folk.

, so that there were more hopeless, homeless and poor people than ever before. or but many of them their as permanent as , and the settlement by people from England and Europe who changed the landscape and planned to stay for years and years of occupancy, cutting down trees, using creeks, rivers, and trees so differently from the way the Indians had used them. The newcomers plows, changing what grew on their land, land where they had Life is very different, more comfortable, and hugely different from my childhood. ved when I was a child.

I’m perfectly aware that neither persons nor groups of persons always make the very finest of decisions every time there is a challenge. Our government has tried and for the most part has achieved new decisions that will help solve problems, or stem the flow of a bad idea, or uplift a new and marvelous solution—but it also at times falls short of a good decision, or allows itself to be twisted into a situation that spoils rather than relieves a situation. What was it the poet said? “The best laid plans of mice and men often go astray.”

Men like Abraham Lincoln achieved great changes for the good of our country, and others also did their best. Some strive to achieve a change in precepts cognizant of what is truly best for our nation, like Abraham Lincoln who abolished slavery. However, there have been laws, or methods, or decisions made by persons who hold important offices that I wish had been left undone. One of those rulings that I wish could be undone is the one that banished God’s Word from schools, and took prayer away from the classroom. Another is the depraved notion that persons of the same sex can be husband and wife.

I am a person who literally, and I mean actually, came from horse and buggy days into an era that has seen men walking on the moon, and lives extended by medical treatments not even dreamed of during the years when I was a child. My Grandparents would have benefited had certain medications been available when they grew old. My Dad’s sister wouldn’t have lost all her teeth at the age of eighteen had her physician truly understood the damage his “medicine” would do to her teeth. The medicine didn’t actually help her illness; however, since she did swallow the potion her physician mixed up for her, the medicine removed the enamel from her teeth, causing pain, so that well before she reached her twentieth birthday she had no teeth. Of course she eventually did have false teeth that served her well. Did the fact that she had false teeth so early actually affect the rest of her life? Add to that unhappy problem, Aunt Helen, as the oldest daughter, at an early age assumed the kitchen duty, particularly because her Mother was, to some extent, quite frail. Her sister Martha, about two years younger, had almost always helped with chores within the house, but for a while when she was in her late teens, she was enrolled in the School of Nursing at Presbyterian Hospital, hoping that her training would prove helpful for her mother. Unfortunately, Aunt Martha began to have medical difficulties of her own which made surgery necessary, and while she was ill, and recovering from the surgery, she could not rejoin her nursing class. Though her training had been interrupted, she had learned a lot about nursing, and it helped her to deal with caring for her mother who was frail. Her mother’s most difficult problem was a disease called eyeritis. Tragically there was no cure for that sickness, and my grandmother became blind. she became quite ill, and . A huge portion of her life was devoted to nursing her mother who eventually became completely bedridden.

Apart from birthing six children, Grandmother had an illness named eyeritis. The illness caused painful inflammation of the eyes, and it blinded her. She could tell bright daytime from dark, however bright lights made her eyes hurt, and she needed to put drops in her eyes often to reduce discomfort. She did not really see my sister as an infant, and she never saw me until one Sunday afternoon when I was in my early teens. I was sitting very close to her on a low footstool, and the late afternoon sun seemed to shine directly on my face from an open window. I moved a little, and Grandmother Yandle told me to resume my former position because she could see me. Those in the room heard her, and they called my sister who changed places with me, but the magic moment vanished, and Grandmother could not see her.

Mother told me that Grandmother Yandle was stricken with a disease called eyeritis which caused her to be blind, however, I don’t know what year she suffered that loss of vision, and I think it was before 1925 because she told once told me she had never seen either my sister, Ella Cornelia, nor me, even as babies. There was no cure and no effective medicine for that illness at that time. Sadly, there has not been a breakthrough as yet for a cure for eyeritis, as quite recently, in November of 2006 Paw-Paw and I were asked to pray for a lady who was recently diagnosed with the problem, and who was told that there is not yet a remedy. In the year 2006—about 85 years since my Grandmother was stricken and blinded by that illness, there is no real help in overcoming eyritis. You either get better, or you lose some measure of your sight. We can rejoice that there are many illnesses that seldom, or even never, appear in this day and time, thanks to antibiotics and clever effective treatments. However, there are still illnesses for which there is not yet a cure.

My first five years of life were from 1931 to 1936, and there is very little that I remember from those years. In 1931 my family lived on East Fifth Street in Charlotte, North Carolina. Straight across the narrow street from our rented house was the house owned by my Great-Uncle Edward Yandle and his sister, my Great-Aunt Elizabeth Yandle. One day, after I was married and actually after Louise, our first child, was born, my mother told me a story. I think we may have been discussing the washing diapers and hanging them out, because for me there was a difficulty as I had no clothes line. Mother smiled and almost giggled. Then she told me that when my sister was quite young their young family was living upstairs in the house owned by Aunt Lizzie and Uncle Edward. My sister was old enough to sit alone, and on this occasion Mother had carried her onto the back porch and placed her in her sturdy high chair for safe keeping while she herself went into the back yard to hang her washing on the clothesline to dry. The porch was quite advanced in design as it was protected from bugs by screening, and also somewhat shaded by lattices. Mother could see through the lattices somewhat, but not clearly, though she could hear her little girl should she cry.

While Mother quickly penned her wet laundry to the line to dry she could clearly hear her little girl, but it was more difficult to see her through the lattice and screen. Mother was pleased to hear her little girl giggle and chuckle despite the fact that she was alone on the porch. Mother was, of course, pleased that Ella Cornelia was entertaining herself.

She was less pleased when, finished with her chore in the yard, Mother returned to the porch and discovered what had entertained her little darling, making her laugh. It seems that Aunt Lizzie had a prized fern that hung from the ceiling of the porch where it could get sunlight, and the large plant was flourishing with green leaves and health, adding a bright fresh green presence on the porch. Little Ella Cornelia had liked it, also, and, unfortunately had been well within reach from her high chair. She had discovered that if she caught and pulled at the stems of the fern, the little leaves would fall off and float to the floor, making a green carpet around her chair, which pleased her so much she laughed to see them float from her fingers to the floor.

Mother laughed at the memory. I laughed with her, and never learned what Aunt Lizzie had to say about the denuding of half her prize fern.

Living with Aunt Lizzie and Uncle Edward would, in my opinion, have been a little difficult, because I knew Uncle Edward, and Aunt Lizzie, and I though they were very, very different from most people. Later in my life I realized I was totally correct. Lizzie and Edward were the offspring of my Great Grandfather and, I decided, they must have been children of his second wife because they were much younger than my Grandfather. I’m not sure where Lizzie and Edward were born, but they definitely did not have any Southern Drawl in their speech. Their pronunciation of words was different as was their vocabularies, and the phrasing of their remarks and mannerisms were vastly different from that of my family who had lived and grown up in the South. As proof of my guess about their childhood, I do recall one visit made by Uncle Edward when I was about five years old.

It was meal time, and our family—Father, Mother, Sister, and me—were at the table having lunch. Uncle Edward, who made his living being a door to door salesman of items people often forgot when they went shopping. He sold small items like shoe strings, remedies like balms for aches and pains, small, but needed items that people in a hurry might forget to purchase in a department store, or a grocery store. He carried his wares in what I called his “suitcase,” knocking on doors, taking orders in a few cases, or producing what was needed on the spot. He was actually well known in most Charlotte neighborhoods, as he had been offering his goods to housewives for many years. That day must have been a Saturday, as my Dad was at home for lunch. We came when called to the meal, and had just begun to eat when Uncle Edward arrived at the front door. Since he felt quite at home in our house, he simply walked in the front door, and into the kitchen. My mother asked him if he would like to eat lunch. Uncle Edward replied, “I have no room.”

Of course, the four of us had taken our usual chairs around the table, and Uncle Edward was right, there wasn’t any room for him at the table. Quickly Mother rearranged our seating, laid a place for Uncle Edward, and again invited him to join us at the table. He chuckled, remembering how he had answered my mother when she had first invited him to join us at the table. He did take the place mother had laid for him, but he chuckled as he sat down, explaining that his remark had been misunderstood. “I meant,” said he, “that I have no room in my alimentary canal.” However, he sat with us in the place Mother had set for him.

I have no real memory of living on East Fifth Street, though I know that until I was about three years old my Dad had rented a house across the street from Aunt Lizzie and Uncle Edward. I do saw the outside of that house every time we visited Aunt Lizzie and Uncle Edward, which was probably at least once a month during my childhood. Of that house I have only mind pictures of the front porch, and a dark place that frightened me. During a nostalgic conversation with my sister she told me that my memory of shadows on the floor of the porch came from the solid half wall that enclosed it, but had small arches at the floor level to allow rain to run off the porch. The other recollection was of a dark and threatening enclosed space from which I could not escape. She told me that at the back door of the house there was a small entry way which had four doors, and nothing else. One led to the outside, and the other three led into different parts of the house. She told me that one day when I as two or three years old, I entered that space and the door closed behind me. I stood in total darkness and screamed until someone rescued me.

Within my small world which was peopled mostly by my parents, my sister, and the often visited Grandparents, aunts and uncles, and occasionally by friends of my parents, also only somewhat with our neighbors. I saw few children my own age. My world was not very large, and had always been blessed with love. My sister had not been happy when I was born.

once in a whilethere was As I was growing up there were great changes in the field of Medicine, and the medications available. There were vaccinations, and I had never heard of anyone else being afflicted with that disease. My mother said that it was a rare disease, and that not many people had it. That it was rare was even having such a sickness until I was grown and already a grandmother, myself. We were among the members of the Methodist Church we were attending at that time when the members were asked to pray for a young woman in her late twenties who had just been diagnosed as having Eyeritis—inflammation of the eye, for which there was no cure. That was . She had She did very well, and soon the illness went away without a significant change in her vision. It was fairly close to a miracle that she had not suffered a permanent loss of vision, because there was not yet, at that time, any real treatment or medication for that illness, and that incident was about forty-five years ago. Because so many wonderful drugs have been discovered and we are all so very blessed in this country to have the great number of medications to help us keep our health, to avoid sickness, and in this there are marvelous medications that are now in use; however, that particular illness does not yet have a cure, as only today (2006) I received a request from our Prayer Group to pray for a young woman who was just diagnosed with that infection. We, as a nation, or as a people the world over have not yet found a cure for all of the rather terrible health problems that harm people all over the world. However, we should thank God, and those persons who have worked, sometimes endangering themselves, to find a cure for diseases that can leave its victims with dire difficulties.

When I was a child there were very few curatives for the wide number of illnesses that were common in most areas of the United States. Some illnesses were, when I was a child, actually reported to the Health Department—a part of the government—and warning signs were affixed to the door of the house where the ill person resided as a warning to everyone who approached the door. This would prevent folk from entering the house without being warned, risking their becoming ill, too. 99999999999999999999999

health that persons or at least one person, was suffering with a contagious disease, and those who had not yet had that disease could s resided in that house. Those signs were generally nailed to a wall next to the door itself, and were garishly bright in color so that none could claim that the sign was not prominent. That protocol was to keep illness from spreading throughout a neighborhood. e , or arrived unexpectedly on the doorsteps without knowledge that those who entered the house would be exposed to a contagious illness.

, or should have been, quarantined to prevent spreading the sickness. at actually cured any disease. There were, of course, inoculations, that could reduce symptoms, or protect a person from illnesses like Smallpox, and when I was a child such vaccinations were required before children enrolled in school. Measles were communicable, and chicken pox, and other illnesses which required quarantines for a certain number of days. It was required by law in the City of Charlotte to report communicable diseases to the Health Department. Someone—usually a man when I was a child—who would arrive at our front door with a cardboard placard that announced the name of the illness, and the date when the quarantine would be lifted. For some illnesses the man from the Health Department had to return to remove the placard, and some placards could be torn down by the people who lived there. I remember the occasion when I could tear down a placard for measles, and with relish I reached up from my Dad’s arms and jerked that notice down, making it legal for visitors to come to our house again. which was easily communicable and deadly. Eventually other illnesses such as measles and chicken pox which now has disappeared entirely in this country, but which had frequent outbreaks when I was a child, have also disappeared. In Charlotte when a child had measles or chicken pox the Health Department came to the house and placed a card-board sign beside the door, warning visitors that entering the house was likely to cause illness for the visitor, or in his family. I can remember several occasions when that sort of card-board sign was on our door, because when it was legal to remove it, my mother or daddy held me up and gave me the pleasure of ripping it away from the weatherboard beside the door.

One of the most devastating illnesses when I was young was poliomyelitis, also called infantile paralysis. That illness was miss-named, though children were more likely to succumb to the sickness than adults. Adults did contract the disease, and Franklin Delano Roosevelt, President of the United States, was affected by that disease, and lost almost all of the use of his legs. He was elected President four times, and held his office until his death. During his presidency and for some years after that, there was a charity called the March of Dimes, and all over the United States people were asked to give at least a dime, or more, if they could afford it, to fund efforts to find a cure for the disease that struck both children and adults, and spread like an epidemic. The year I completed the fifth or sixth grade there was an epidemic of Polio in North Carolina. Schools in Charlotte were closed early that year. Youth’s and children were asked to stay at home, and not mingle with neighbors or regular playmates because Polio was so very contagious. Theaters had age limits, and could not admit young children. Parks were closed to children. Parents were asked to prevent their children from playing as usual with neighbors, and churches no longer held Bible School, or Sunday School classes for children during that summer. It was a lonely time for me, as my sister, being six years older than me, did not fall into the age group confined to their home. I was wearing braces on my teeth that summer, and I did keep my appointments with my orthodontist, but I didn’t ride the bus. I walked uptown, and didn’t go onto Tryon Street, a very busy and usually crowded street, until the last couple of blocks. My walk was only one mile to the Orthodontist’s office, with only a little over one block that was relatively crowded. However I didn’t mind walking the mile into townvery close to one mile in the summer heat, because the alternative was riding a bus, and my Mother didn’t want me to be enclosed with a bunch of other riders inside the bus. It was safer to walk alone, choosing streets that were unlikely to be crowded, the hot sun at least a mile on unshaded streets. I didn’t resent not riding the bus at all, as there was more space between me and persons who might be able to pass I knew the risk of becoming ill, and did not wish become ill. persons who had Polio might, but also might not, ever walk again, and there were some who had the disease and lived the rest of their lives using crutches, or lying on their backs inside a tank which breathed for them, because their lungs no longer functioned on their own. Some victims of the disease could, like President Roosevelt, walk with crutches, or live in a wheelchair. Many children and youths died from it, and most of those who lived through their illness spent the rest of their lives in a wheel chair, or on crutches, or worst of all, lying in an iron-lung that was a barrel like machine which enveloped the person except for the head. The person was alive, however, could not breathe for himself, or move his hands, or control his body in any way—it was as if only the head survived the illness, though the heart, and stomach seemed to function, not much else of the person’s body achieved movement either voluntary or involuntary. . Those stricken persons could not breathe without being encased in that barrel, with the rhythmic sound of motor that wheezed and clanked with every breath it “breathed” for him or her. head, because their muscles no longer worked, and they could not even breathe for themselves. The barrel-like “iron lung” had a motor that somehow helped them to breathe.

People below the age of sixteen, or perhaps eighteen that Spring before the planned end of the year, and parents were told to keep their children at home, and

were warned not to play together,which collected money from , though he used a wheel-chair after his illness. The President started a charity called the March of Dimes, and encouraged people all over the country to give to the organization which would devote its efforts to find a cure for Poliomyelitis. The actual cure did not surface that I know of, however, a vaccine to prevent the illness was discovered and it became mandatory for children to have the vaccine, and I think most adults were also vaccinated. After that national effort to prevent the disease, the illness became rare or not at all. , and though I can’t remember whether or not adults were compelled to tcan cause blindness beyon“old” age that still shows up today, suffered became blind when Helen was a young girl. She, as the oldest girl child, took over the household, preparing meals on a wood burning stove, coping with no water except that brought in from the well, and no outlet from the sink except for the bucket placed beneath the drain. The toilet was an outhouse and most of the food she cooked was grown on their farm. She kept chickens, and pigs, and preserved fruits and vegetables from their own trees, gardens, and fields. Aunt Helen did little in the gardens, because she had constant kitchen duties. She also was the chief “cleaner” of the house. During my early years I was accustomed to making use of every inch of the house we lived in, and I found it strange that the dining room and parlor of that house, both of which were beautifully furnished, were seldom used except for Christmas or the rare special occasion. I realized that use of those rooms in winter were difficult because it required extra fires that used up the wood needed to keep the kitchen and sitting room where my Grandmother lived, warm throughout the winter. The house had no electricity, no indoor toilet, and all water used in the house including the kitchen was drawn from the well. no running water. . which doubled as my Grandmother’s sick room

canned vegetables from the garpigs, , which had to be emptied by hand. She prepared the meals for her parents and siblings, helped to nurse her mother who was an invalid, and was always the one person who elected to stay at home with her mother, her father, and her brother Edward if her other two sisters left the house. Whether that played any part of her decision to settle into a life totally dedicated to simply keeping house for her parents with only one neighbor as a friend, , seeing no one beyond visitors to her parents, or members of her family. and she never married.

For instance, telephones were marvelously new to most of the people who lived in Charlotte, North Carolina, in the 1930’s. Of course the police had telephones, and the fire department had phones, and the building where the city, and the county governments were housed also had telephones. Businesses usually had phones, as did hospitals and doctor’s offices. Radio was also a prominent part of communication via news reports. Telephones had telephones. Only

, the police, the government folks, the people who had money to spend, doctors, businesses, and hospitals, ambulance companies (yes I meant ambulance companies to be plural, as most of the funeral homes, and there were several in Charlotte, handled ambulance calls, as well as companies that handled embalming and/or burials could also double as ambulances, and did so. also could Electricity within nearly every house in Mecklenburg County was still an unfulfilled wish. Schools, again, just those in use in Mecklenburg County, were, when I was born, very old. Some were actually so unsafe that they were no longer used as classrooms when I was growing up. There was no television. Moving Pictures existed, though most of them had no color, and were only black and white. Radio was a marvelous invention, and we had one at our house when I was about seven years old, because since my Dad was a Painting Contractor his customers needed to contact him. The city of Charlotte was still using trolley cars when I was a child. I actually rode on the last trip of the trolley car that passed my house on West Eleventh Street. My mother warned me to remember the experience because there would never be another, and I would be able to tell my children that I rode on that trip—and so that I could admit that I rode on the bus that passed my house when it was a true novelty to all the folk who lived on our street.

Remembrances of my early childhood are very sketchy indeed, mostly because I am now seventy-five years old, and that makes my childhood somewhat distant to today. When I was growing up my mother told me little stories about myself when I was very young, but I, myself, have only sketchy and uncertain memories of events that were actually important in my early life.

For one thing, I was born in 1931, and in the South, that was Depression time. The difficulties that began in 1929 and caused so much trouble in the North also affected the South. However, the total stoppage of jobs without hope of a quick recovery moved somewhat slower in the South than it did in the North. There were many more farmers and people who lived closer to the land than in the North. In the South there were mills and businesses that required employees, but there were also farms. Eventually the failure of the economy in the North reached into the South. Banks in the South failed, businesses closed, and people were out of work. Eventually the businesses in the South were caught up in the general alarm, and hundreds of people watched 9999999999999999999999their , and they, too, and the small businesses closed their doors, and the larger ones who had hoped for a jump start in the South discovered to their dismay that either closed their doors, or did smother the South and cause dreams to shatter along with the jobs, and , and I was told that it was immediate disaster in the northern part of the nation, when banks went bankrupt and businesses collapsed because there was no business, and no customers. Bank Accounts disappeared like water poured on sand. Money that had been horded against hard times simply disappeared.

. ” sometimes disappeared along with the banks, and could not be The South was not spared, and though people on farms could probably eat from their gardens life was rough everywhere.

ich continued toand that it seemed to strike with less haste, but with bitter and terrifying devastation in the lives of the people below the Mason Dixon Line. The fact that many people in the South were farmers, and could at least grow their food did not change the fact that banks had failed, and people who needed money had no access to savings that had been deposited into banks. People were certainly willing to work, but there were few jobs because many businesses had closed and people, for the most part, had no money to spend on much of anything. Banks closed, stores closed, other businesses closed. Most families were somewhat touched by the demise of businesses, or the closure of mills or other companies because they couldn’t pay their workers. businesses. People who had trusted banks to be a safe place to deposit savings discovered that the most honest bank could not had out all it’s assets and still remain in business.

Almost every working person one lost their jobs. Homes that were being paid for by the month were forfeit because without a job the people who were in the process of buying a home could not afford the payments.

closedwho were willing to workdidn’t have jobs. Money owed couldn’t be paid because people didn’t have jobs to earn the money. Losing their homes, their jobs, their savings because of the bank failures, left too many folk with nothing.
00000000000000000000000000000000000000 It was the the business itself in the process of buying their homes couldn’t pay none, . earlier, but of course it didn’t take too long to also touch and devastate the South also.

odd, or extremely short pictures inside my head that deal with of my early childhood. My sister was a full six, almost seven years older than me, and when I was growing up she disliked me so much she was mean to me if she had the chance. Once, when I was about six years old, my sister was angry with me, and since I had been left alone with her I had to obey her. She demanded that I cook my own eggs, and I didn’t know how to cook. Nevertheless, she badgered me until I tried to cook my eggs, and then she forced me to eat them. Strangely, I didn’t remember that particular problem. However, I have never liked eggs—except an occasional deviled egg. Perhaps that forced learning of how to cook my own eggs, though I don’t remember it at all, might have triggered my dislike of scrambled eggs.

And when she was ten or eleven, she had lots of chances. Of course I failed completely to understand why she was pleased if she could fuss at me, or make me do something I didn’t find pleasant, and I realized every time that she was happy to push that chore off on me. When I was a bit older I discovered that customs among my family were very tight lipped about the fact that a new baby would be joining the family. Of course the mother of that child had all the symptoms and the tell-tale shape that announced to the folk “in the know” that a new baby was on the way. When I was much older I learned that Ella Cornelia , who had been an only child for six years, came home after a visit with a neighbor, and found her mother holding a new baby. Suddenly, Ella Cornelia was not, truly NOT—the center of attraction in her own house. Both kin folks and neighbors came to visit, and they wanted to see the baby, not sweet little Ella Cornelia. People looked at the BABY. They didn’t pay nearly as much attention to young Ella Cornelia who hadn’t expected people to want to see the new little brat. Ella Cornelia seemed to be the only person in the world who had not expected such a thing. She had to accept the fact that the new kid took almost all her mother’s time. She, who had always been the center of attraction to her parents, and in the Yandle family as the only child, the only grandchild, and had always the center of the attraction.

Suddenly, there was a tiny baby that Mother held in her arms for hours—which meant that during the day no one was cuddling her. Not only that, but Mother asked her to fetch, or carry away, small necessities, while she just sat there, holding the baby. Ella Cornelia had not been told a child was on the way. She had no small hint of warning. The surprise was not shocking, not a happy revelation.

It was a custom in those days in many families to keep the secrets of how a mother managed to “have” babies and the truth was a total secret. If Mama gained a little weight, she trimmed herself back to normal while she nursed the new baby. Angels sometimes brought the new little ones, or they just appeared one day when any other children were suddenly sent away to visit Aunty for a day, and when they came back home there was a little baby that was an addition to the family. My entire existence was a tremendous shock to my sister, and it took a number of years to smooth over that shock. Her status her own home, as well as her Grandparents house, and even the neighbors, changed. That little baby was always taking so much of her mother’s time, causing Ella Cornelia to seem to be less important than the new child, being forced to stop her games to help fetch things while Mother held the baby. All of that kind of stuff was an insult to young Ella Cornelia. And it was adding insult to injury to require her to forfeit some fun thing because of that, that, that, baby.

There was another problem, too. A couple of years before I was born there was a dreadful event that changed many lives, thwarted many plans, and actually ruined the way people had lived for years and years. The Stock Market way up in New York collapsed. Banks held useless checks, but little actual money. People stopped visiting stores because they had no money to spend. Companies closed their doors because they had no customers, and customers who owed the stores money couldn’t pay because they had been “laid off” of their jobs because their bosses could no longer pay them as, they, too, didn’t have enough money. The banks and small businesses simply closed their doors and “went out of business.” People, who had used the money from their pay checks to buy food, suddenly couldn’t buy food because they had no jobs. Many businesses simply closed, and the workers were all out of a job. All of the people who used their salaries to pay for a roof over their heads and food for their tables, suddenly had no salary, no home, no food, and not very much hope of finding another job.

In the northern part of the United States the difficulties began in 1929. The Northern States had more large businesses than the South, and suddenly businesses in the North were closing. That meant that people who worked there suddenly didn’t have jobs, and then the banks that had taken deposits suddenly didn’t have any money to repay their patrons when they wanted to withdraw money. Suddenly businesses whose customers had no money couldn’t function, and their doors were closed. People went to the place where they worked, but found the doors locked against them, so that there was no pay check, even if one was owed. Almost everyone was affected by this terrible event. Businesses closed. Working people discovered their jobs had ended. People who had purchased anything on credit suddenly could no longer make payments since they had lost their jobs. People who had bought homes on credit—paying a little on each payday—were suddenly unable to make the promised payments.
