Rich people who had invested in the Stock Market were suddenly broke because the Stock Market collapsed. Formerly “rich” people couldn’t pay their electric bills, or their water bills. Because banks had paid out almost all the money in their vaults, they closed their doors. People said that the banks had failed and that was true. The banks could not return to their customers the cash they had deposited on their last visit. Banks simply closed their doors.

Without the failure of banks that had supposedly been the safest place to keep money, along with failed businesses that were forced to close because no one was doing business with them, people could not pay rent, or buy groceries, or make promised payments toward loans. Landlords have rarely been known as folk who accept news such as “I don’t have the money right now” with a hearty laugh and a promise to see you later. People who lost their jobs and couldn’t pay their rent had to leave the houses or apartments they had been renting.

People who were suddenly without funds were terrified and angry. When rent or payments on loans became due most people had to “make other arrangements” which for the most part meant moving in with relatives if they could. They would have to move whether or not it was desirable, or making serious steps down hill where beauty and comfort and pleasure and most of all, privacy, were not part of the description of their new “quarters”. In most homes even food became scarce, and people actually did go hungry. Single people who had neither job nor welcoming kinfolks, were truly “out in the cold.” In those days there were Salvation Army people who could offer food, and perhaps a bed for the night, but during those years most cities and towns were well aware of homeless people, both men and women, and sometimes those folk would break a window just to be put in jail where it was at least warm.

Women without shelter would seek help from the Salvation Army, and sometimes men also depended on them for help. The Salvation Army did marvelous work during that time in our country’s history. One of the ways they announced the presence of help in a community was to send a group to a corner in a neighborhood or near a place where Hobo’s gathered. The Salvationists brought their accordions, and trumpets and drums along with a few singers, and usually a man with a strong voice who would preach a short sermon. They would stand just off the curb, and begin to play their instruments and sing. The hymns would bring nearby people to the corner, and they would often stand on the sidewalk to listen to the music and then the fairly short sermon that always ended with an opportunity for the un-churched to give their hearts to Christ.

About every Saturday afternoon a group of Salvation Army folk would gather, on the corner of North Graham Street and West Eleventh Street. They would make a shallow semicircle a little way from the curb—standing in the street. Some of the group would bring musical instruments, and others in the group would sing the hymns. The one who could talk loudest would urge the audience to join in with the songs, and if I knew the song, I would sing with them. Then one of the men would read from the Bible, and preach a short sermon, ending with an invitation to the audience to commit their lives to Jesus. Then there would be a prayer of benediction, and the crowd would leave. The Salvation Army people would go on their way. Almost every time that group came to the corner, one of the participants in the group was a lady who lived alone three doors down the street from my house.

I was expected to return home as soon as the Salvation Army folks put away their instruments, and I did precisely that. I seldom went into the café, but they sold ice cream, and sometimes I did buy a popsicle from Mr. Kanasas.

From Grade one all the way to the sixth grade I attended Bethune School, located on North Graham Street at Nineth . I could easily walk the four blocks to school—one block from my house to Graham Street, and Two blocks to Ninth Street where the Crossing Guard stood with his stop and go sign. Miss Belvin was my first grade teacher, and Bethune School was an old school. So far as I was concerned, the age of the school itself didn’t bother me. The floor of my room was a problem. It was very slick because it had been treated with some sort of oil, and both desk and chairs slid very easily on the floor. On the first day several children knocked over their chairs by accident and they made a very loud slapping sound when they fell backwards or sideward. If you spend much time around young children, you know that noise is like music to the ears of the active child, especially the male children. Eventually it became a game, and the teacher laid down a rule—if you turn your chair over, you must stand in a corner. I thought that was a great idea for those few little boys who plopped over their chairs for the fun of making a noise and making the little girls jump. The slaps of the falling chairs against the floor were sharp and disruptive for the class. Then came the moment when I left my chair, and when I returned it slipped out from under me and I fell and hit the floor with a bang. It hurt. I decided not to cry. However, the teacher did not run to me, help me up, nor did she ask if I was hurt. The truth was that the smack on my bottom when I fell did hurt. She simply ordered me to stand in a corner like a bad girl. I was outraged. She didn’t care if I was hurt. There I was, slapped onto the floor and hurting my bottom, and even though I got up by my self, righted my chair, and was going to sit down in it, without even crying though I was hurt, the teacher was going to punish me??? Not by the hair of my chiny, chin, chin. I couldn’t help it because her slick floor made my chair slip!! So I told her, “No! I didn’t mean to do it.” She told me again to stand in the corner. I said no. She told me again, and I told her I had not done it on purpose, and I wasn’t going to stand in the corner. I sat in my chair and did my work, and minded my own business. When I got home I told my mother. I never knew what the teacher thought of that. But I remembered how my dance teacher punished me when I had not done anything bad. I intended never to let someone treat me like a bad girl again. As a matter of fact, all of the rest of my journey through school I expected to be treated fairly, and none of my teachers accused me wrongly again.

You see, that had happened to me once in Kindergarten. Most of my classmates took tap dancing as part of the kindergarten curriculum. One day my teacher told the class that if the children were bad, they would have to sit out part of the lesson. I, you see, was a good girl. And I was doing my best to follow directions from my teacher. Suddenly, she told me to go sit in a chair. I asked her why. She said, “You know.” I said “What did I do wrong?” And she said “you know.” And I said again, “What”. And she became angry and sent me to sit in a chair. I truly had no idea why. It made me angry that she had not answered me. I didn’t cry, but I was angry about her punishment. I never did find out what I did, or what she thought I did, that was so wrong. However, that very day I decided no one would ever treat me like that again. I was really angry that the teacher would not at least tell me why I was being punished.

wenty or thirty day students who were taking four or five classes, and a few who were taking only one or two courses, mostly to complete studies and obtain a diploma. The majority of the students lived in dormitories and stayed on campus for months at the time, going home only on holidays. I commuted every day, riding on busses from West Eleventh Street to Myers Park area to attend classes. As a day student I never spent the night on campus except for two nights when I was part of the welcome committee for new students who were coming to Queens that fall as freshman students. The students (all girls at that time) who lived on campus had very nice rooms with two girls in each room. There were probably twenty or so “day students” who did not live on campus, some of them male, but the girls who lived in dormitories and seldom left the campus were the majority. More than half of the students mother and I would occasionally buy one plate for each of us for our lunch. The clientele of the café was mostly men, and most of them drank beer. Even so, because he knew who I was, I was never worried about some drunk deciding I should be nice to him. I always stood close to his cash register until he brought my plate, and I never looked about me to see who was there. There were not many women who came in the café alone, and I tried to stay right where Mr. Kanasas could see me unless he had his back to me. No lonely drinker ever said even one word to me, and because I was tall for my age there were times when I was waiting on the bus across the street from the café that some one who had stopped by the café decided I was waiting for him instead of waiting for the bus. . one in that café ever said even one word to salways enjoyed being there on the corner and singing with the group gathered there. on most evenings , and draw a crowd with their singing of hymns. There was a group of Salvation Army people who regularly sang at least once a week on the corner of Graham Street and West Eleventh, right outside a café run by a Greek man.

The man who ran the café was Dave Kanasas. He was born in Greece, and spoke with an accent that I found difficult to understand. His wife was American, and their three children had no accent. Since Charlotte’s city blocks in that area really were square, with the east/west streets numbered and the north/south streets named, The Kanasas café was on Graham Street, right on the corner of Eleventh Street and Graham. Our house was on Eleventh Street, almost on the corner where Eleventh and Pine met, and the Kanasas house was on Pine Street, with it’s back yard touching the back yard of my house. The Kanasas children were an older boy, a girl older than me but younger than my sister, and a little boy named Pete who was younger than me by a about a year and a half.

east/weHis café was on the corner of Eleventh Street and Graham Street. His house faced Pine Street, and his Café faced Graham Street. Every day he walked past our house, on Eleventh Street, to get to his Café. was only a block away from his Café, and faced Pine Street. until some of the folks put up fences, he could have walked from the Café’s back door across about four back yards, and been in his own yard, which touched our back yard. s café was on the corner of Eleventh and Graham Streets, His house faced North Pine Street, with the side of his back yard right against the back of our back yard. and our house fronted on Eleventh Street, but our back yards touched, and my Daddy rented a garage from Mr. Kanasas. Mr. and Mrs. Kanasas had three children, one boy about the same age as my sister, a girl who was younger than my sister, but older than me, and a little boy named Pete who was about a year or perhaps a little more than one year, younger than me. who lived right behind our hous
Most of the homeless women would try to enter some sort of shelter, and the Salvation Army was active in most cities had such shelters for both men and women available. I am sure they had lots of people who depended on them, especially in cold weather.

Even with the help of the Salvation Army there were still a lot of people who were what my Dad called “bums”. They were given that name when they begged for food at someone’s door. A lot of the men simply camped even in winter along railroad tracks since most tracks had bushes or trees next to the right-of-ways, and because if they didn’t cause trouble, the railroads didn’t bother them. That way they had access to some place to sleep if they were able to build some sort of shelter, and since there were café’s and grocery stores, both of which had trash cans where they might find discarded edible foods and containers they could use to heat meals over fires. Households threw away torn clothes and old shoes and such, and those people could retrieve them and make use of them.

When they were first married my parents lived on East Fifth Street in Charlotte, in the upstairs of a house owned by my Dad’s Uncle Edward Yandle, and his sister, Lizzie Yandle. They were truly my Dad’s Aunt and Uncle, and Aunt Lizzie called my Dad’s mother “Sissie.” I’m confused a little about the kinship, because I have some information about my family, but am slightly confused about exactly where my Uncle Edward and his sister, Aunt Lizzie, fit into the family tree.

Sometime well before the Civil War (in the South it was called the “War Between the States”), a group of people came to the United States probably on the same ship who all seemed to be sort of kin to each other either by blood or by marriage. Some of them were married to each other in England, and some of them were married before they arrived in America, and some of them married each other after their arrival in the New World that would become the United States. In the crowd there were at least two very prominent names. One batch had the surname Johnston, and the other group had the surname of Yandle. Now the Johnstons had married the Yandles, and the Yandles had married the Johnstons. Since there were a few Johnstons who were not actually kin to each other, and a few Yandles also who, though they had the same name were not actually ken to each other, some of the Johnstons married Yandle girls, and Yandle men married Johnston girls, and once in a while a Johnston married a Johnston, and a Yandle married a Yandle, and trying to unravel all of those unions and was so confusing that I gave up, knowing that since my family must have been both Christian and educated, none of them would have married people that were too close kin to be safe where heredity was concerned. When they first arrived they didn’t all stay in the same town. Instead they scattered all over the nation, though a bunch of them stayed in the Carolinas. Some were in the Pineville, North Carolina area, which is only a few miles south of Charlotte, and a bunch of them crossed the Catawba River and lived near the little town of Mount Holly. At least one of them moved all the way to Philadelphia, and others scattered around the larger city of Charlotte, Pineville, Fort Mill, and Mount Holly.

If you were in or around Charlotte, or had kin folk in that area, you might remember that there was a train track across the Catawba from Charlotte to Mount Holly and points in between. It was not a long track leading everywhere, but a sort of commuter train. One of my Johnston Great Uncles was the engineer on that train that went back and forth between Mt. Holly and Charlotte several times each day. When I was four or five years old my kindergarten class rode on that train from Charlotte to Mt Holly, and back again. I was able to brag to my classmates that my very own Uncle Johnny was the engineer. However, I didn’t know him all that well, as he lived close to Mt. Holly. His real name was Serenas Johnston, and I think he was my Grandmother Yandle’s brother. He was the engineer on that train for an unusually long period of years, and when I was small we sometimes visited him on Sundays after Daddy bought a car. The steady riders of the train knew him by name, but they called him Johnny, not Serenas. My Dad said all of the regular riders seemed to be his personal friends. His sister lived in Mt. Holly too, only she had a different name as she had married name was Herms. Aunt Ollie always amused me when I was small because she was not very tall, and even though she bossed her tall boys and told them what to do, she herself was short, and her daughter was also not very tall, but both of them were quite bossy, and it was not wise to cross Aunt Ollie.
When I was very small our family had no automobile, and therefore we didn’t visit people who lived very far away all that frequently.

a large group of kinfolks came to the United States from England. They didn’t all have the same last names, but most of them were either Johnston’s or Yandles. The Johnston’s often married the Yandles, and the Yandles often married the Johnstons. And somehow, there seemed to be at least two or more sets of both, and because they mostly came to America about the same time, they married each other. . —so that could marry Johnstons and not be too c and settled actually in a scattered pattern on both sides of the Catawba River. Some stayed in South Carolina, and some in North Carolina, and sometimes they switched around, but they all stayed when they were married. My Dad had an uncle and aunt who owned a house, and I think it was in the 500 block, not far from railroad tracks, My Dad had made the arrangements to move in there. I visited the house many times when I was a child, and I often wondered why my parents felt so close to those two old people who, so far as I, as a very small child, was concerned. I thought they were weird, and strange. First, they

He was working, I think, for Cathey Lumber Company which was owned by a man named John Cathey. He and his wife were wonderfully nice people, good Christians, and as fair and honest as people could be.

for the most part, people without jobs or families became a creature called a “hobo” and that meant that he lived by the railroad tracks, in some sort of makeshift sort of lean-to, or tent, or just under a tree close , but no kinfolk to take them in to shelter and feed them becameduevery likely without housing or food. Within a few days they discovered that businesses, great and small were having the same difficulties. Without the money they had banked they couldn’t pay wages. People in cities, in villages, and on farms faced the same problems. Money was scarce everywhere. Those who had no savings were affected also, because when banks closed, businesses that had banked their funds could not pay their workers. The workers in turn could not buy food, or pay

Renters without funds couldn’t continue to live in that house, and owner’s couldn’t afford to allow them to stayhad nthat they would lose every penny they had placed in a bank for s, and in many cases,panicked. How would they eat, or pay rent, or continue to make payments on loans if they didn’t have jobs. in some cases continue to pay on househave a place to live, when their jobs were suddenly non-existent and no pay check on its way to help them. coming to buy their groceries or pay they rent. couldn’t pay them monies they had given to the bank for safe keeping, rich people found themselves suddenly poor, and without a job. Businesses certainly not Their because their jobs stopped. salaries stopped being paid because companies were not being paid because peoplekarues ceased to be paid by failing businesses. Therefore, the company or individual who had agreed to allow them to pay so much each month, were not being paid, and had the right to take back their property. That meant people lost whatever they had paid so far on their purchase. Their homes, their automobiles, their plots of land for future building, their hopes and dreams and even the ability to buy groceries were now gone and they could never get their money back. They had made promises, and through no fault of their own they could not keep their promises. Their money, if it was less than the total amount, was simply gone. The businesses or owners to whom buyers had been paying simply said, sorry about that, and took back their houses, keeping what had been paid, leaving the people who had lost their jobs and were because of that unable to keep up the payments simply the agreement right then, nor, sadly was there ever

ever. the lack of jobs that supplied pay checks that were spent on the necessary housing and food suddenly stopped handing out pay checks because the businesses were not making enough money to meet the payroll. Banks which had gladly accepted deposits didn’t have enough money to return those deposits to their customers. There wasn’t enough money to go around.

y had no pay checks. their pay check, too. Some people couldn’t even buy groceries. the squelching dreams and was difficult for her to accept. She was sometimes required to help her mother take care of the little child by bringing items like diapers or milk bottles, or other necessities to a mother who was sitting down and holding—actually holding—that little baby. Mother had less time for Ella Cornelia becAttending to that little baby instead of doing things with little Ella Cornelia, and making little Ella Cornelia wait, or even help with the care of that surprise sister. How could she like the idea of having a baby in the house? Since we, ourselves, have two children, I can certainly understand the shock to small children who are suddenly aware that It nature e which was a hush, hush event, and which never, ever, was actually explained to children, which left them with really weird ideas about

. When she was born my parents were living with my Dad’s Aunt Lizzie, and I think her brother, Edward, lived there with her. Long before I was born there was a young girl who lived with them. She was the child of a cousin who was judged by the family as not capable of raising a child, and the girl whose name was never, ever, spoken in that house since she had become ill and died at the age of seventeen or eighteen, was dead

in a house on East Fifth Street with her brother, my Uncle Edward. Recently I had the opportunity of seeing facts about my “ancestors” and discovered that my paternal family was quite large. I think at least four families with the surname of Yandle, and they had lots of children, both male and female. There had been an earlier time when older Yandles had already come to the United States, and they were living much further north and west of the Carolinas, yet they were of the same family. A bunch of them settled in North and South Carolina. One of the men was my Great, Great Grandfather. He was a store keeper and lived somewhere near the town of Pineville, I think.

One of the first of the Yandles was named Samuel Yandle. He ran a store, and he arrived in the new world before the War Between the States (the Civil War). He was well settled in when the men of North Carolina and South Carolina who fought for the Confederacy went into battle. The Confederacy was poorly funded, of course, and when the Southern men formed armies and fought the soldiers from the North they left their wives and children behind on farms or in small towns, and as the months passed the women and children began to suffer from lack. With no one to plant and harvest except women, most of whom had small children, and very little money. My Great Grandfather ran a store where, among other goods, foods could be bought. That became a problem, too, because Confederate families had little money, and had not been able to plant and harvest since their men-folk were in the Confederate Army. Some of the women and children were, quite literally, starving.

Great Grandfather Yandle, was a merchant. He ran a store with various necessities for sale, including food. He was a good man, and he discovered that he just couldn’t turn away those women who came in to buy on credit the foods for which they couldn’t pay. When a skinny and hungry mother came in to buy food for her thin and hungry children, my Great Grandfather would reason—out loud. “Well,” he would begin, “I SAID that she needed food.” And therefore the lady got some food for her children. Of course, eventually, Great Grandfather was giving away what he had either paid for, or owed money for, and because he wasn’t paid for the food, he could not pay his suppliers. Because he couldn’t pay his suppliers his business sort of went downhill fairly quickly. However he fed those poor women and children as long as he could.

Eventually my Great Uncle Edward Yandle, who was a younger than my Grandfather, helped him to make settlements with the suppliers who had not been paid for the goods he gave away during the Civil War. All of that happened in the mid, or late 1860’s. I never knew that Great Grandfather, but I did know his son, Amos, who was my Dad’s father, and I also knew Great Uncle Edward and his sister, Elizabeth, who lived in Charlotte on East Fifth Street. here is no one alive now, who could tell me about really tell me , who was called Lizzie.

I was born in 1931, and by the time I was five or six years old Uncle Edward often visited the house we lived in on West Eleventh Street, and we visited the house where Uncle Edward lived with his sister, Lizzie.

I found it fascinating to learn that my Great Grandfather Yandle married twice. His first wife died, and he married again. His second wife lived to be a very old lady. She was married to my Great Grandfather for fifty years. and. His first wife died, and he remarried. A bunch of people including four brothers came to America

and before they came to the United States a good many years ago, and they were brothers and sisters and cousins. A least one Yandle woman married a Yandle man, and some of the boys had married girl

One of the largest changes I recognize in that part of our nation’s history which I have personally seen and recognized is the number of people in this country. I was born in 1931. Up until about five years ago I had lived all of my life in Charlotte, North Carolina. My Mother was born in Pineville, and my Dad in Mount Holly, just across the Catawba from Charlotte. When I was a child my Dad told me that Pineville was about ten miles from Charlotte; however, both Charlotte and Pineville have grown through the years, and I expect that they are a great deal closer to each other in this Year of our Lord 2006.

As a child I realized that there were several ways to move around the city. There were tracks right down the middle of the street where we lived that was named West Eleventh Street. The tracks were for the trolley cars which had funny little pipe things on top of them that touched electrical lines, and allowed the trolleys to move up or down the street, carrying people to the very center of Charlotte at a place called the Square. One night when I was probably close to five years old my mother took my sister and me on a trolley ride. She kept telling me to remember the ride, and never forget it. “This is the very last trolley ride along our street that there ever will be. Tonight,” she said, “the trolley cars will go to their garage, and they will never come back. From now on,” she explained, “we will ride buses instead of trolleys.” I did try hard to remember. And I know that, sure enough, there were no more trolley rides in Charlotte. Eventually the rails that had carried the trolleys and the wires that had given them electricity were removed. However, it was the very next morning that I began to recognize the city buses that passed our house at frequent intervals all day and way into the night.

   I don’t know if any part of West Eleventh Street actually exists today, as the houses and businesses along that street were removed, and where there was once a neighborhood there is now a ramp leading to an interstate highway.   throughway was builtneighborhood where I lived before I married was

Grandparents had lived in a smaller town about ten miles away . That makes me about seventy-five years old in this year—2006. The house I have early memories of was not the first one my parents lived in when they came to Charlotte from Pineville area as newly weds, moving from their homes about . something like ten miles from the then center of Charlotte, I have no idea how many people were living in Charlotte, North Carolina when I was born. We lived eleven paved blocks from the Square, which was, by the time I was born merely the central intersection of two “main” streets, which were named Trade Street, which went East or West from that point, and Tryon Street, which went North or South from that point. The intersection there was one of the largest in the town.

About three blocks from the Square there was a street named “First Street” that ran east/west across South Tryon Street

probably two of the very first streets to be named. What I do know is that streets were laid out going in a fairly either East or West, nor North What I do know is that we lived about one mile from the Square in the City of Charlotte—the place where Tryon Street and Trade Street crossed each other. In the earliest days there was a building in the center of a space which served as a court house.

, That was also the point where the named streets abruptly changed where the first Courthouse was built, and that intersection was the focus point of the town. Some intelligent person way back at the time a small Courthouse was built on a hill, decided that the courthouse was the absolute center of Charlotte. There was eventually two roads that met near that Square, and one of them went from East to West from the Square, and was called simply Trade Street. The North-South road was eventually named for a Governor who’s last name was Tryon. ofrom the going North to South was eventually named for how it was used—where there were stores where business was done, and trades were made. It became Trade Street. The street that crofor a governor of North Carolinaa road that ran day when the city born decided that the spot on which a small building was standing that was called when it was first settled. Streets that stretched both east and west east and west . twenty minutes from the city limits if we it didn’t take much of a drive from our house almost any direction to find the city limits. It may be that driving North West from our house to the edge of town took a little longer than it took if we headed South and East from our house. if it was measured from our house, that a drive in a southeasterly direction.

was especially events that began after I could understand to some degree how very different things could become when can in our nation between my childhood and my old age is the population of this country, and the number of people in the world. Without doubt I can say there were fewer people in the world the year I was born than there are now, though it has been only seventy-five years. What has made a difference? Part of it is that When my Great Grandparents were young, there were situations fairly often like one my Dad’s told us about years ago.

I was quite young when my Dad told the story, however, the tale began with a man who married a wife, and they had twenty or more children. My Dad, of course named the man, but I was only about nine or ten years old at the time, and I am now seventy-five years old. I heard the story only once, on a winter evening.

My Dad’s uncle married a wife, and they had several children. However there were few remedies for illnesses in that day and time, and when his wife became ill, she died. She left a three or four very young children, at least one of them still nursing. The man knew he needed a mother for his children, and he also knew that a young woman who was recently widowed who needed someone to help her raise her children, and so they were married. Since she brought several children with her, and the farmer already and was nursing her own small child, so he married her, and she nursed both children. That young woman had other children; however one day she became ill, and she, too died, leaving a young child. The Uncle married again, and again the woman had a young child, and could nourish both her own child, and the baby whose Mother had just died. After some years, the farmer’s wife again died, and again he married fairly quickly as there was a tiny baby that had to be fed. His fourth wife also had a few older children, and she also had other children. ’s mther the two babies, children by her first husband, and again the Uncle and one day she, too, became ill, and died. No long after that she had another child had lost her husband, and she that needed to be bottle fed, and the

the mother of his children died. Because the man had to have someone to attend to those very young children, he married again, a young widow who had a child of her own that was quickly assimilated into the family. She of course had another child at least one child who was quickly assimilated into the family, and before long the step mother had

have forgotten the details it for no better reason than that I am now seventy-five years old, and the evening he mentioned his uncle I was only eight or ten years old. He mentioned that family only once that I remember, told us about his cousin (or an uncle, I forget which) who had about twenty-five children.

The why, from my point of view, is complicated because of the huge number of differences between way back then, and right now. I was born in 1931. The Great Depression began in 1929, and I’ve been told the crunch that was immediately felt in the North was not actually immediate in the South, but it didn’t take a lot of time to trickle right on down to Charlotte, North Carolina, where my parents lived most of their lives. My Dad was born in Mt. Holly, North Carolina, four years before the Twentieth Century began. My Mother was born in 1902 near Pineville, North Carolina. The parents of both my mother and my Dad were farmers. Both sets of Grandparents lived in the vicinity of Pineville by the time I was old enough to recognize where I was. My mother was a Parks before she was married. My Parks Grandparents lived not far from the area now dedicated to the birth place of President Polk. I never learned why it was necessary, but Granddaddy Parks built a new house at that location when my Mother was in her early teens, after his two sons and his older daughter had married and moved away. When I was in Grammar School if my Teachers asked me if I had any brothers and sisters I had to admit that I had a sister, however, I actually thought of us as both being “only” children. She didn’t like me and wished she had gotten her way the day I was introduced to her. She immediately suggested that since Mother had picked me up at Presbyterian Hospital, she should take me back to them, and leave me. She didn’t want a sister.

When my sister was nine or ten years old our family lived on East Fifth Street and there were lots of children her age in the neighborhood, and most of them were her friends. One day the Ella Cornelia joined a two team group of students who were playing jump rope. It was good exercise to have the students jumping about or turning the rope and using some of their marvelous energy out of doors. The game required a long and sturdy but not heavy rope, two members of the group with strong arms to turn the rope so that it touched the ground and arced over the jumpers to turn the rope, while all of the others would try to jump over the rope as it swished against the ground and up into the air over the heads of the jumpers, again and again. If a jumper touched the rope, or was touched by the rope, she was still part of the team, but she was for the moment, a spectator. The number of active jumpers diminished as the whirling rope touched them, especially as the jumpers tired. If only one jumper was left in the game, she could revive her team by jumping ten consecutive jumps meeting challenge . jumpers were touched by the ropekept on jumping, with the until each jumper touched, or was touched by, the they touched the rope, or the rope touched them, until there was only one jumper left. left her team of jumpers and became a spectator. was turned to touch the ground and then arc up into the air above the heads of the jumpers. If the turning rope touched a jumper she was out, and became a spectator. When only one jumper had not touched the rope she could, if her energy and skill was not diminished by her activity, jump ten consecutive turns of the rope without touching it. If she was able to do that, her team mates could rejoin her as if they had never been out of the game. The other team could not jump until the first batch of jumpers had all touched the turning rope and the last jumper left in the game failed to hop over the rope for ten times, which would restore her team as jumpers, instead of the the team changing places with th.

, and were, therefore, without anyone to keep to keep the game going. My sister was competitive, and on that day she jumped non-stop in ten games, and it was she who, each time, jumped ten times alone, earning the right for all of her team to rejoin her as jumpers. Two girls turned the rope, and the other team jumped it as a group. Ella Cornelia kept jumping. Her team mates, at least some of them, had a breather when they had to leave the game, but my sister didn’t have a breather. She was the jumper left alone each time, and she then jumped ten times turns of the rope, and was rejoined by her team mates, and continued to jump. I never learned exactly what time of year it was, or if the weather was warm, or hot, or even cold. What I do know is that very quickly after that she became ill. I was so very small then that I never actually knew any of the details. While she was in the hospital Mother stayed with her as much as possible.

The parents of my Mother and my Father were still living. However, my Dad’s mother was an invalid, and her two daughters were taking care of her. My Father’s mother was an invalid, as she had several health problems, and was also blind. My Father was the only one of his siblings to marry at that time. My Mother’s parents were elderly and not very well, however my Mother’s sister was not much older than my Mother, and though she was married, she had no children. It was to my Mother’s sister, my Aunt Ola, that I was taken when my sister became ill

Both my parents had siblings, and in both families my grandparents were still living. My Dad’s mother was an invalid, and blind. His father was still working on his farm, along with his oldest son, my Uncle Eddie. was still hail and hearty, and was running his farm. His youngest sister was either in college, or was already working at a job in Charlotte, but Daddy had two sisters and one brother still at home. , and one brother.
My Mother had two brothers, and one sister. My Dad had one brother, and three sisters. My Dad’s mother

when she pushed herself to jump ten games, and jumped ten turns of the rope between each game, without a rest. jumped that rope for so long, but I do know that the rope for ten games, and between each of themarm weather rather than was too young to remember what time of year nd each time her teammates touched the rope they had to leave the game, though they could stop jumping, but they cheered when young Ella, as the last jumper, jumped ten turns of the rope without touching it. Then they all, including Ella Cornelia who had no rest, began to jump again as a team. The group cheered Ella Cornelia, because they won. Their team had jumped ten games without loosing one. However soon after that triumph, Ella Cornelia became ill. Because I was very young—probably a little more than two years—I have not real memory of her being sick. When her condition became life threatening I was taken to my Mother’s sister for safe keeping until my sister was well again. I have very little memory of that time, but my Aunt Ola declared that I was not always happy. One day she, who had no children of her own, washed my hair, and I have a very faint memory of being in her arms and crying.

waited to see if the last teammate left jumping could jump the rope ten times, which would allow the entire team to rejoin their teammate and give their team another one of their team mates could j

their turn at jumping was over. and left the game one at the time, she was the one who jumped ten times alone in order bring her team back into the game. I was too small to remember her triumph, but that evening my sister became very ill. Of course she was taken to a physician. He was Doctor John Ashe, of Charlotte, N.C. My sister was very ill. Pleurisy attacked her lungs, and her heart was irregular.

My Mother believed that it was the jump rope game that triggered illness, making her breathless and straining her heart with her earnest efforts to jump every game until she was the last jumper, and then jumping ten turns of the rope so that her team could start all over again for ten consecutive games.

The year was probably 1932 or 33. I was a little young at the time, barely learning to talk, and remember nothing about the exact year, however, my guess is very close to the truth. I had no part in the events just then, except that I was taken to visit my Aunt Ola, who had no children, and hadn’t been around many children since she looked after her younger brothers and sister, all of whom were now married. I, myself, remember nothing of that period, except that she washed my hair.

Unfortunately there were few medicines that actually worked. Infections either went away, or they didn’t. People desperately ill either got well, or they died. The Medical profession was busy and in many situations they were wonderfully capable of saving lives; however, no there the medications we enjoy today had not yet been discovered. Sulfa was being used, and surgery was making a true difference in saving lives, but for the problems my sister was having there was very little anyone could do. may have been one antibiotic, if Sulfa could be counted as one, but thereIf the infection was life threatening, there were not many options. Rest, nursing care, and occasionally surgery, were the available treatments of nearly all the illnesses. If the heart had been strained and was not pumping correctly, and if lungs were not functioning exactly as normal, there was very little to do except pray, and hope for the best. It was not, money wise, the best of times to be expensively sick. My Dad was working at a Lumber Yard, but they had no business. Almost everyone in the entire country was in the same predicament. Banks closed so that people who had savings accounts wouldn’t empty them causing the bank to fail. Businesses were closing because they had no customers, and they couldn’t pay their employees if they didn’t have customers.

Life was tough everywhere.

If you noticed the date—the early 1930’s—you know this was smack in the middle of the time the Depression was causing difficulties in every part of the nation. Jobs disappeared when most of the population stopped buying much of anything. Any savings people had trusted to banks were mostly wiped out. Stores closed for lack of patrons. Businesses could not continue because there was so little trade of any kind. Employees had no salaries when their business closed. Stores that had managed to stay open had few paying customers. Most businesses were not bringing in enough funds to provide salaries for the employees and many stores simply closed because they couldn’t pay their rent nor keep their shelves stocked, or if they had something to sell there were no customers who had money enough to buy. No employer was hiring. People who rented dwellings, whether it was a house or just a room, could not always scrape up enough money to pay their rent, and were sometimes ordered to leave the premises and some times were not allowed to take their belongings with them. Housing on which monthly payments were owed could seldom continue the payments, causing them to lose not only everything in which they had already invested, but even the roof over their heads.

It was a sad time. Almost everyone was in the same sort of difficulty. People who had food often shared with those who had no food. Families who had shelter took in family members who did not. People who had gone to cities to “make their fortune” and now couldn’t even pay their rent simply went back home if they could, sometimes walking hundreds of miles to get there. At our house cousins who were looking for jobs in Charlotte would “stay” with us for weeks or months until they were settled in real jobs and could afford to live in an apartment.
My family and I lived within a block, or maybe two blocks, of at least two different railroads. Many times a knock at our back door—not the front door—would be a shabby looking man who would ask if I could give him food. Mother would always make them a sandwich, usually with cheese because we didn’t have much meat, and hand that and a cup of coffee, or a glass of milk, and the man would sit on the back steps and eat the food, then leave the plate and glass on the steps. None were ever threatening, nor were they angry if we were at that moment unable to accommodate them. We didn’t see women doing the same thing. And most of the men were middle aged or elderly.

Once an older lady lived next door to me, and I found her vocabulary, and the way she pronounced words unique. She could read, and she was not at all dumb about business, or caring for the house she occupied. However she had never seen a television until recently, nor lived in a city, or even on a well-traveled road. Her schooling was sparse, and her entire life had been busy with few moments of relaxation. Her name was Mae, and she sat on her front porch along a very busy Charlotte street. Early my relationship with her she would look at me in true wonder at the traffic that passed our neighboring houses, “It does look like they’d all get where their going sometime.”
She would sit on her porch and marvel at the traffic, and say in bewilderment as the cars passed in unending late afternoon streams of cars, “It does look like they would all get to where they are going sometime.”

had she listened to radio. She had read mostly the Bible, having very little access to books. or without

Most people had no salaries, any savings entrusted to a bank was gone, and there were no new jobs available. had lost any savings, and many banks had failed so that funds Jobs gone, homes gone, and little or no hope of retrieving jobs or investments. The and therefore lost everything they had already invested, which was another blow. Jobs were disappearing. No one was building new housing nor were folks choosing to renovate during those years. Stores of all sorts had no customers. People were actually going hungry. It was quite reminiscent of that period after the release of the

My Dad’s job was with a lumber yard. There were no customers as no one was building at the time, since very few, if any, ordinary persons could buy much of anything. If a builder had actually begun to build, he probably had simply stopped. No one was buying houses, nor were people spending on anything they could postpone. , and those who had not yet completed a building , and therefore quite soon there was no job. My Dad, along with his father, had invested in, but not completely paid for, several houses. Some of them were located in an area where only Negro families lived. They were fairly sturdy buildings, but they had neither electricity nor running water. Water was available and could be drawn from a central pump, and it was not terrible not to have electricity. Actually neither my Mother’s nor my Father’s parents had access to electricity or piped in water with indoor toilets. Their water came in from a Spring or a Well, and their toilets were out houses not far from their back doors.

If the sickness would not disappear after surgery, there was very little anyone could do apart form rest and problem area could be surgically removed, things usually went very well. However about the only hope for illness that surgery would not help was those that responded to good food, and careful rest. if the illness would respond to bed rest, diligent attention to rest and good food. usually only two options: If it was something that surgery could remove, the patient had a good chance of overcoming the illness. If it was not operable, but the patient was really otherwise healthy, and time could thereby heal the problem, the patient would only good nursing and strong healthy folk would surviveAt the time, there were no actual antibiotics that worked every time.

doctor, Dr. John Ashe, My sister was good at jumping rope. She, therefore, was the only one still jumping when the other jumpers during the first game, and she jumped ten perfect jumps therefore allowing her team returned to jump with her through the next game.

erson was left who, that jumper left the gameA touch meant that jumper was “out” of the game. When a group is jumping it doesn’t take long to thin out the less athletic jumpers, or the jumpers who tire easily, or those who loose their concentration on the game as they tire. team” of jumpers rope itself was fairly long, accommodating a group of jumpers which would diminish as jumpers touched the rope and therefore were out of the game. When only one jumper all were . As each jumper tired or misjudged the rhythm of the rope she would touch the rope and therefore be “out” of the game. When only one jumper of that team was left she was given a “chance” to successfully jump the rope ten times, which accomplishment would allow her entire team to return to jumping, instead of taking up the duty of turning the rope.

My sister was agile and always eager to excel. When she was the last one of the team jumping the long rope, she jumped ten jumps without touching the rope, and thus won the right for her team to return to jumping—not turning—the jump rope. Of course it was a tiring game. However my sister ignored tiredness. She jumped ten games, and each time her team faltered and her teammates were sent to the side

she loved to win, therefore each time all her team mates were “out” of the game, she managed to jump ten turns of the rope, therefore winning the privilege of having her team return to the jumping game instead of taking up the responsibility of turning the rope for the other team. her team of jumpers to return to jumping, instead of left the gameclassmates

their taking their turn of , if she could jump ten turns of the rope without touching the rope, the entire team was “in” again. My sister was in the group that was jumping. She jumped with the group and was the last one who had not touched the rope, and summoned the energy to jump ten good jumps, thereby allowing her team to rejoin her. Her team was still jumping instead of turning the rope. Jump Rope was both energetic and fun, and since it was a school game, bunches of students could jump at the same time when the rope was long enough to accommodate them. Usually there were two teams. One team would turn the rope, and the other would be the jumpers. When all members of the jumping team had touched the ropeThe rules demanded that when only one jumper remained students turned the rope. The others stood in a line, and as the rope touched the ground, the entire group jumped over it. When a jumper touched the rope, she was out of the game; however, the rest of the group could jump until only one jumper was left. If that jumper touched the rope, the team changed, with the former jumpers was still jumping. Eventually it was expected that the jumping team would touch the rope, and then that team would begin to turn the rope, and the other team could jump the all of the jumpers on that team would eventually touch the rope, and the group that was turning the rope would have hand the rope to tha turn to jump. another group would become the jumpers, and those who had served as jum and the other team would be the jumpers, and two of the of jumpers and had to stand aside while her teammates kept jumping. When only one jumper had not touched the rope, that lucky little girl could jump ten turns of the rope without touching it, and her team could rejoin her, until everyone who was jumping was “out”. was left

, and as the rope slapped the ground anyone who touched the rope, or whom the rope touched, had to stand aside, leaving only those jumpers who had successfully managed not to let the rope touch them. Usually the jumpers were a mixed group, some being athletic and competitive, some wanting to touch the rope so they could leave the game and stand around talking to their friends and the others who worked hard to win for their team. My sister was a jumper, determined that her group would win because she didn’t like turning the rope. She was skillful, and when everyone except herself had touched the rope it was up to my sister to jump alone for ten turns of the rope without touching it, and her team was “in” again, having “won” the privilege because one of their number jumped ten times without touching the rope. of jumping instead of since they could jump, causing the other team to stand just turning the rope, , instead of turning the rope for the other group. Ella Cornelia was good at jump rope. She willingly ignored tiredness to win another chance for her team. And so for ten games her team members disappeared one at the ti

she did. When all the jumpers except my sister had touched the rope and left the game, my sister concentrated on her task which was to jump the rope without touching it ten times—then her team could reenter the game, and her team would therefore win the game.

was a good thing my Mother and Daddy loved me, or I might have been one miserable little girl. Ella Cornelia did not seriously threaten harm to me when I was very small, however, when I started to school Mother went to work at a sewing shop with

, and upon occasion that left the two of us together for an entire afternoon.

That if I was told why it was necessary, I don’t remember the answer. Granddaddy Parks was a strong man, a farmer, a father of four children, and a grandfather of five, one boy, and four girls. My Grandmother was white haired, and I thought she was beautiful. Her complexion was very fair, and her hair was white as snow and pulled into a knot .

a teenager, They had once lived in another place, which I never saw. They built their house in the new location when my mother was quite young. She had one sister, and two brothers, all of whom were already married, so that she was the only child of her parents still living at home. She told me about a time that once something slipped, causing the weight of the house to descend on her father’s hand. The weight of the house was mashing his hand, and he could not move it. My mother stood beneath a place that she could reach, and she pushed with her shoulder, and stood straight, holding the floor high enough for her father to remove his bruised hand. From that time on, she often had back pain when she lifted heavy items. Mother, who’s name was Minnie Cole Parks Yandle, married my father, Leroy Samuel Yandle, when she was about eighteen. My Dad was in his twenties. I don’t really know much about the early years of my Parent’s married life, because I was wasn’t born until my sister was about seven years old. I do know that when my parents were first married they lived with my Dad’s Aunt and Uncle.

I have always been puzzled about those two people, my Great Aunt and Uncle, mostly because I never really understood their exact relationship to me. They were elderly, and I was very young when I knew them. Uncle Edward was never called anything else except “Uncle Edward” in my presence, and his sister was always “Aunt Lizzie.” Since I remember the story, I must surmise that I was about eight or nine years old, myself, because I never actually heard the story again.

Mother had washed some clothes and needed to hang them on the clothes line in the back yard. Mother had brought her little baby downstairs and had placed her in a highchair inside the screened in porch which was also latticed. Mother hurried into the back yard and began to hang up the clothes. She felt somewhat relieved that her little darling Ella Cornelia was happily cooing and chuckling all by herself. Mother hurried to finish her chore, pleased that her little darling was gurgling and laughing as if she were being happily entertained. When Mother entered the porch, though, she was surprised, but not pleasantly. My tiny sister’s high chair had been set, unfortunately, just in arms reach of Aunt Lizzie’s large green fern, and my little sister had easily entertained herself, with chuckles and squeals, as she reached out and pulled all the leaves off the fronds of half of the beautiful fern, and then watched them fall as if they were green snow flakes sifting onto the floor, as she laughed her happy little laugh. Mother didn’t tell her friend what Aunt Lizzie said about it.

Mother didn’t say anything about what Aunt Lizzie thought.

.

been set just in reach of the fern. She was joyously reaching up to the fern, and stripping the beautiful green leaves

My sister was sitting alone, but not very old. Mother had washed clothes by hand, and needed to go into the back yard to hang them on a line to dry. She didn’t want to take my infant sister seems that . Mother explained that she and Daddy and baby Ella Cornelia were living in the house owned by Uncle Edward and Aunt Lizzie, who were brother and sister. Mother had washed diapers and baby clothes and she carried my sister and the wet laundry down to a back porch, which was screened in. She left my sister carefully tied into the high chair, inside the latticed back porch, and went outside to hang out the clothes. She listened carefully to the sounds her little baby was making, and they were joyful sounds. She was laughing. Mother hurried to finish hanging out the clothes and started up the steps. It seems that the high chair my sister was sitting in was just close enough to touch the greenery in a hanging basket. The basket held a large and beautiful green fern, with lovely rich green leaves, however, with lovely thick leaves, spread out to catch the sun where it hung on the porch. a beautiful green fern. the was talking to a visitor, and told that person about the day

ter, and someone who was visiting—probably a neighbor—and she reminisced about something that had happened when my sister was an infant. Mother had washed baby clothes and Mother had washed clothes, probably mostly diapers, and brought the wet clothes and a high chair down the stairs to a latticed porch. She settled her little baby girl near the back door, and went outside to hang out the laundry. in a hallway close to the back door. Mother went outside to hang (whom I eventually knew as my older sister) into the high chair for safety while she went ou was my sister into the high chair for save The day that I heard the story, exelse in my house. I didn’t learn until years later that Mother and Daddy had lived in their house when he and Mother were first married, and that they were living there when my sister was born, and for some time afterwards. I know that only because one day my Mother was talking to some visitor, and told the visitor about a funny thing my sister did when she was a baby. It seems that Mother was hanging out clothes in the back yard of Aunt Lizzie’s house. The young Yandle family was living on a clotheslineone and told them

He was my Dad’s uncle. Ordinarily that would mean he was my Grandfather Yandle’s brother. However, they were nothing alike, and Uncle Edward and Aunt Lizzie were older than my Grandfather. They also had an entirely different accent, and their habits and their house, and Uncle Edward’s business seemed very strange to me. , mostly because my parents knew very well who they were, respected them both greatly, and treated them like revered elders in our family. , and I think they were step sister and step brother to my Grandfather. However, I could be mistaken as no one every told me why their conversation was so different from the way we all talked, being dyed in the wool Southerners. Uncle Edward, and his sister, Aunt Lizzie, were very proper. Aunt Lizzie always wore an apron over her dress, and she never, ever, touched a door knob with her bare hands. She lifted her apron and placed it on the door knob and then turned it to open the door. I never saw her without an apron unless she was going to church or to visit someone. They had a very different vocabulary than most of the people I knew, and they truly didn’t speak as if they were Southerners. They were also quite old by the time I made their acquaintance, and I have to admit that their way of life sort of fascinated me, and yet I thought they both were more than a little strange.

They both were well educated, Both of them were well educated, and did not converse exactly like the other aunts and uncles in the family. I know that my Grandfather Yandle’s mother died when he was quite young, and that he was raised by his father’s second wife, who was born in England. Apparently Great-Grandfather’s second wife had been married previously, and at first my parents and later my Ella Cornelia, too, lived on East Fifth Street in Charlotte in a house owned by my Dad’s Uncle Edward and his sister, Aunt Lizzie. Her real name was Elizabeth, but she was called Lizzie. Their house no longer exists, as it was torn down to build some large building when I was in my early teens. Although I lived not far from that location most of my life, I never wanted to see the building that had replaced most of the houses along that side of the street. mthe my Day’s early life as I wasn’t yet My Dad worked in a lumber yard, owned by a man named -----------. He and his wife were members of Garr Auditorium, a church . From what I was told much later, the lumber yard was doing a brisk business. My Dad had bought two houses, and he had rented them to people who paid every month. He used the rent money to make payments on the houses, and he used his salary to live on. He, and his father, had joined together to buy six rental houses in a section of town where only Negro people lived. It had been nearly fifty years since slaves were freed; however, in the South, former slaves two houses, . He was young, married, and had a daughter about three or four years old, . the entire nation was affected by the consequences. My Dad worked in a lumber yard. Of course people were not building homes. Without doubt there has been a tremendous, almost unbelievable increase in the number of people in the United States since then. This rise cannot be totally attributed to immigrants, though there have been many of them. Nor can it be because people desire to leave one country and move to another, although a great many people have come from other nations. Of course, since there has been no actual world wide war fought within the boundaries of our country except the time that Britain tried to force the colonies from claiming their freedom from all other nations. 88888888of Europekeep the United States as its Then why are there so many people in this country? Part of the increase in numbers within our nation has been because people left the countries where they were born and moved here. And that surely is part of the reason our nation has so many residents. However that logically would not change the total number of people, even if the “new” locations were cleaner due to never before having been occupied by crowds of people. Even so, people thrived in what some called the New World. there) simply moving from one place to another were simply better is not the only reason that there are more people in the world now than ever there was before, so far as we can know.

The number of people in the United States didn’t grow to what it is today because the first settlers were simply prolific in producing children. What actually happened was that when Great Britain claimed the East Coast, Spain and France wanted a share, and began sending shiploads of people to settle the land. The Spanish settled south of the English settlers, and the French settled north of the English folk. China even placed lot of people on the Western Coast, and San Francisco still has a very active Chinese population. The people who came from England were the first that we know of who actually made an effort to make a colony on this continent. However, some of the countries in the Northern part of Europe had ocean going crafts early in the history of tribes and groups of people, and they knew about the northern part of what is now Canada and the United States before any other people discovered it.

There was no doubt that Europe, England, Ireland, France, Spain, and other countries, such as Greece, Italy, and Northern Africa, and certainly, don’t leave out China. All were looking for riches and expansion. Have not all people done that all though history? When ordinary people invented ways to keep a ship or boat on top of the oceans, explorations were made. Explorations led to change. And people who had riches by what ever standard, usually wanted more, and were willing to explore. Then there were people who had nothing but a willingness to work hard because they wanted their lives to be better than they were, and they had no fear of work. There were always problems of some sort where there were lots of people. There was seldom a dearth of willing adventurers who dared to go into places they had never been before. People such as Columbus who took a real leap into history and discovered the edge of half of the earth that the other half had never known existed.

Then Spain, and France, England, and probably some of the Northern most folk tried, and actually crossed the Atlantic. If they kept going, they found either the North, Central, or South America.

the American first, and France claimed the South where New Orleans is located, while other French folk went far into the North, in what was later Eastern Canada. Many of the decedents of those folk still speak French, rather than English. The population of the country of the United States began on the East Coast and the earliest folk were English, and those who came a little later were from all nations around the Mediterranean. The British Islands were prominent, including the Irish and the Scottish people. Spain claimed the Florida area. this country was smaller, and it was not growing with super speed, despite the fact that as the country was already expanding more. From all over the then known world more people were coming to a brand new country—a wonderful place that was advertised as a paradise, when it actually took a great deal of hard work to survive in its earliest days. From the beginning of the nineteenth century life here was improving, but it was never without either some danger, as well as a great deal of hard work. Many folk in Spain, France, Italy, Greece, England, Ireland, Northern Africa, and other parts of the world could imagine a better world away from worn out farming land, and ngland, Europe, and all of the known world hoping to find a better, easier, place to live.

and Europe and other parts of the world . Birthing children, especially if there was only about a year between the children, was very hard on the mother. little space between the children, . Cities and towns were smaller. When my grandparents were young, they were sad when infant children died, and they realized that the price of pregnancy could easily be—and too often actually was—the death of the mother. When women died trying to give birth to a child, and the child survived, the father of that little baby had to find a woman already nursing her own child—or a woman whose recently born child had not lived, or a neighbor woman who could nurse the infant. In those days it was not impossible to raise a child on cow or goat milk, but that , or all the people in a family got sick and died because there was no antidote for their illness. Surgery was terribly chancy. Women were particularly almost always at extreme risk when birthing their children—and if a woman had as many as three children it was almost a miracle if all three lived. However, by the time I was born, there were hospitals available, with hopefully clean and sterile instruments and knowledgeable doctors. However well meaning, not all doctors were as careful as they should have been in trying to help desperately sick patients. Probably about twenty years before my birth my Aunt Helen became ill. Her physician, feeling a tremendous need to help his patient overcome whatever disease she had, gave her a potion that, whether or not it helped overcome the disease, rotted all her teeth, and she was only twenty years old. For the rest of her life Aunt Helen wore false teeth.

Then, as now, Doctors sometimes made bad choices in treatments, when medical training and knowledge was new when someone was dying, a doctor, if he was bold and brave, would simply try something. The patient was already dying. If the medicine helped it would be wonderful. If it didn’t help, at least he tried, and it wasn’t really wrong because the patient was already dying before he ordered the medication. It was certain that doing nothing accomplished nothing. The patient would die anyway. Therefore, why not try? If the patient got better, the doctor would be the hero. If the patient died, he was dying anyway.

I have often wondered how physicians react inside their minds and hearts when they work as hard as possible to save a patient, and then loose the battle. In the early days of medicine most doctors, no matter how dedicated, had few thought often of how awful it would be for a physician to treat folks, and watch them die because he didn’t have any medicines nor did he have information that could help. How wonderful is our medical community now, with both medications and well tried protocols to follow when terrible illnesses occur.

from some concoction and the patient was near death, why not at least take a try at helping when doing nothing meant certain death. Families would beg for help where none was available, so that physicians would try untested experiments in treatments, causing damage to some part of the body. People often died of illnesses in those days—and women were particularly vulnerable because of childbirth. Then there were deaths frequently from diseases that no longer exist. Smallpox spread easily, and once it began it could, and did, devastate communities and towns. In Europe there had been many terrible situations where illness struck a country, a city, a town, a village, or just a family, and all died. Although I haven’t tried to see my vaccination scar in years, before I could enter school I had to have an inoculation to prevent my ever having small pox—a disease that could and did sweep over Europe and which occurred in America, as well. The inoculation would cause my body to make antibodies to the disease, and it would make a scar on my shoulder that would always prove that I had been inoculated and could not then catch the disease, nor could I spread it to others. Small Pox was so terribly contagious, and so terribly deadly to its victims, that in the United States, because of the inoculation requirement in schools, eventually wiped it out completely. After many years the only place you could find Small pox was in some freezer where a “bank” might have been kept by a scientist who worked to extremely contagious. People in a city ran away into some other place from that illness. Towns emptied of everyone who could move or be moved when Small pox was rampant; therefore spreading the deadly disease further and further from its origin. Whole families, or many members of a family, died quickly. Terrified neighbors would try to run away from the danger, oftentimes carrying the illness itself with them so that the area of danger grew ever larger in an attempt to run away from it. Small Pox was a killer. Another terrible illness was Infantile Paralysis which caused muscles, any or all of them, to stop functioning, leaving its victims totally, or sometimes partly, unable to feed or care for themselves. f a person to breathe. The body’s muscles didn’t work. Legs would walk, arms and hands did not hold things, and sometimes even lungs were affected so that the person could not breathe. Those folk would—with their minds still working, they lay like a long, unable to attend to themselves at all, with a machine breathing for them,Most of the inhabitants of entire towns and villages could die from Small Pox because its germs were both powerful and so easily spread. is no more, but once it devastated cities and towns, causing death and spreading from person to person. Children no longer have to be vaccinated for it before they enter school. Chicken pox has disappeared, as had measles. There has not been a case of infantile paralysis since my children were in grammar school. whether or not it helped that patient fight his/her illness.

both our Nation, our States, and our Cities had become sensitive to the spread of communicable illnesses. There were several kinds of such diseases. Some, like Chicken Pox, Mumps, and the three or four types of Measles were common especially among children. The Health Department in Charlotte demanded that these sicknesses be reported, and that the sick person stay in his own house. A man from the Health Department came to the house and posted a warning sign to all who came to the door that someone in that house was suffering from a communicable disease. The purpose was to stop the spread of contagious diseases, therefore reducing the possibilities of wide spread illnesses. Some of the plagues were serious, and all of them were uncomfortable. The sign could come down after a certain number of days. On that day, my mother lifted me off the floor, and let me yank it down. I was very glad that once the sign was gone, I could play outside again.

So far as I remember, the only illness that required its victims to be completely separated from the population was tuberculosis. That was a fatal, debilitating, and highly contagious lung disease. There were no remedies. The only treatment was rest, sunshine, and clean air. It was so contagious that every person who contracted was taken to a hospital from which he was released only if by death, or cure. Since there was no medication, most of the people who entered the TB hospital died there. Occasionally, but depressingly seldom, a person’s own body could defeat the illness, and he or she could return to normal life. a patient’s own bodily fought the disease hthe disease was reported

Of course I was sheltered from the diseases that were rampant among some of the people who lived in our city. Charlotte, after all, was one of the largest towns in the state, and had railroads and highways. At school the playground was shaped mostly like an L. The front of the school faced a thoroughfare. There was a very narrow grassy yard leading to the front door. The brick walls of the school were close the street and close to empty red dirt tprotected from the streets students were protected from a neighborhood behind the schooI can still remember the day I walked away from my playmates on the playground of my school and decided to see what was behind the strong fence along Smith Street. I was probably about ten years old at the time, and what I saw was more than simply frightening. There was a man walking toward my spot behind the fence, and there was something strange about him. He wore ordinary clothing, and a hat. But his face was not normal. There was a bloody sort of mess above his mouth, and his nose was disintegrating—it was almost not there at all. He said something to me, something like, “What are you looking at?” and I didn’t answer him. I couldn’t. I couldn’t turn away, nor could I walk away. The shock of such a face made my stomach feel weird. That night I told my mother about it. She admonished me for wandering off alone from everyone else on the schoolyard, and suggested that I stay with the other students, with a group. Then she told me that there was a dirty kind of illness people could get, and the germs ate their noses. They were not only bad people, they were sort of stupid, too. The name of the disease was syphilis, and he caught it by being dirty and doing wrong things.

the distant edge of the playground that touched the sidewalk of Smith Street. There were houses along it, and I had never noticed it before, and lots of other illnesses that are rarely seen in this country in this day and time, but when I was a child, they happened. There were health rules in the City of Charlotte, especially where communicable diseases were involved. People who were ill were some imes compelled to report the fact to the Health Department of their city or town. If the disease was Tuberculosis, or some other highly communicable and deadly disease, or even something like chicken pox or measles, it had to be reported to the Health Department so that warning signs could prevent people from going to the door risking becoming contagious themselves.

When I had measles, and also when I had Chicken Pox, the Health Department of the City of Charlotte came to our house and nailed a poster beside our door warning people that a Person in our house was ill with a communicable disease. As the sick child I could not go out of my house at all. I still remember that when I was in the third grade the City of Charlotte shortened the school year because when the days became warm there was an outbreak of a disease called Infantile Paralysis some miles from Charlotte, but great portions of our State did not allow children to play with neighbors, or to go to movies, or to visit neighbors. I couldn’t even go to the library. This was long before television was introduced, and the City of Charlotte had a program every day for children who had to stay inside their houses that summer in order to stay away from other children. That was an illness that killed, and that crippled people. It was also called Poliomyelitis. This was the same illness that, though he was an adult, Franklin D. Roosevelt contracted before his election to Presidency of the United States. After that illness President Roosevelt used a wheel chair. It wasn’t only poor folk who contracted these communicable diseases. Sometimes sources of water from streams or creeks or even rivers would carry germs that caused outbreaks of illnesses.

In the homes in Pineville and the outskirts of Charlotte where city water was not available people used wells and springs. In most instances the water was safe to drink—but occasionally chemicals or contaminated water would seep through into a spring or well, and whole families would become ill or even die of the illness.

Medical doctors were not always well trained, though most practitioners used

as well, a quarantine sign was placed on our door so that people who had not already had the diseases would stay away in order not to carry the illness to persons who could be infected. there was a poster about the size of a sheet of notebook paper that with the prominent name of the illness

city or community and there was nothing toavailable. There were few effective medicines before 1940. Sulfa was about the only antibiotic there was, and it was limited because it didn’t work in all circumstances. Doctors knew how to sew up cuts, but they couldn’t keep the cuts from festering and causing rather terrible illnesses and death. orm becoming wasn’t effective for every illness—just some of them. There were doctors, and universities dedicated to medicine.ecine a from the

world in which we are living. present, or how previous situations similar to the events they are facing were handled so that they themselves might avoid repeating difficulties.

It is true that my life has been much easier than my mother’s life. Her life was easier than that of her mother. Today’s differences were wonderfully obvious and effective.
