Of course, people react to circumstances differently and events that are a catastrophe to some folk are a mere slight hitch to others. There are always people who want things to be different. However, it is always true that education and dedication along with clarity of thought, makes a good life for most people. using make the best of education is still important. Attending movie shows and viewing TV had never been the height of ambition. North Carolina had schools. There were City Schools, and then there were Country Schools. Within the cities children could usually walk to school. In the countryside, schools had different rules—at least in North Carolina they did. In cities and large towns schools were usually within walking distance of its pupils. In the Counties of North Carolina schools were also built near housing, however, in the countryside the homes of the pupils were usually too far distant from the schools for the children to walk, and therefore a bus system was put in place with routes covering the area, enabling drivers to bus children to and from school each school day. It has been a very long time since the counties around Charlotte had to arrange their school year to accommodate the children of farmers. It was often necessary for children to help prepare the fields and plant the crops. They also had to hoe weeds out of the fields to keep the weeds from stealing nourishments and water from the crops. Having vegetable gardens is wonderful, but requires lots of work. Preparing the field, sewing the seed, cleaning out weeds, and then doing it all over again until harvest time, and then the work changes to harvesting the fruits, vegetables, or grains of plants, and preserving them to eat or use later. With foods, vegetables must be canned, frozen, or dried to preserve them. The grains must be collected, and the grains themselves separated form the stalks they grew on. Most farmers like to use all parts of a harvest so that the stems of some plants provide hay or straw, and the vegetables and grains provide food and bread for people, and animals. Food animals like beef cattle, pigs, chickens, are unusually kept and fattened until after frost, , . of the plants. roduction of the plants, is as the same Mother Nature who nourishes the vegetables and grains also nourishes the wild grass and weeds. The from planting

and out of the vegetable gardens to keep weeds, which seem to grown much faster and than from out weeds. and so that who were expected to work in the fields of their father’s farms at planting time, and at harvest time. Therefore, the school year for city schools differed from that of country children because most farm children had to begin school after Harvest time, and they had to be available for field work when it was planting time. The school year began in the fall, after harvest, and was in session until Spring, when children had to help plant and work the fields. Autumn after post-pone school until the crops were planted, or later in the year, until the crops were harvested. When I was school age the county schools still arranged their calendars to fit the planting and harvesting of crops, closing the entire school at harvest time. Farming was not easy because it was governed by the time of the year and the weather. There was planting time, and harvest time, and in between there was watching the crop and chopping weeds that wanted to grow in the fields, and there was protection of the crops from bugs and birds, and too much heat with no rain when the fields were watered by barrels carried along by wagons. During that time the rhythm of the farm did not stop where animals were concerned. Animals such as oxen and horses and mules were busy and worked very hard. Because they were not machines, but creatures, it was necessary that they have rest, feed, water, and shelter during inclement weather. The lack of an able animal could ruin crops, just as completely as lack of sunny days or in due course, lack of rain. In those days the farmer walked behind the mule or horse, enduring the summer heat just like the animals. And most of the time if there was a trip to make to into a town, then the farmer had either to walk himself, or to force his already tired horse or mule to carry him—no matter how heavy he was—into town.

In North Carolina there were public schools with knowledgeable teachers in cities and in counties. There were also laws that demanded that children attend school. One of the reasons was that sometimes parents of long ago believed that children belonged so thoroughly to the parents that parents could make their children stay at home to work in the house, in a family business, or on a farm instead of going to school to learn how to read and write. That is one difference between the time my parents were growing up, and the years when I was old enough to attend school. Neither my mother nor my father actually finished twelve grades of school. That did not stop their learning and/or progressing. And their experiences made finishing all of the schooling we could get a priority for my sister and for me.

Children of today may have been told that there was a law that prevented the Mommy and Daddy persons from allowing their little child to skip school because he didn’t like it. It was, instead, a punishable offense if parents did not place their children in school.

More people were literate and more were better educated than their forebears. There were more doctors who were trained in better ways, and our nation as a whole was creating and accepting new inventions that made life easier. Cotton Mills were built to make thread and fabrics and factories were built to make cotton thread into cloth and when machines were being invented to increase the ease of transportation there were more jobs than workers. Then there were the new methods of communication such as the telegraph and telephone. Manufacturing grew as inventers worked to invent machines to do a tremendous variety of difficult and time consuming jobs. Communication became easier with dependable mail deliveries, and , and access to electricity was spread over the country.

, and the growth of manufacturing, specifically the cotton mills, the marvel of electricity for power, the continuing methods of transportation, the birth of the automobile and better methods of paving roads. There was also both State and National interest in roads, and most particularly the extension of train tracks. The by train, and out of manufacturing, as well. There was also the marvel of electricity and the welcome ease of communication because of railroad traffic and the invention of the telegraph and the telephone.

I, myself, was witness to changes that made our city, our county, our state, and our nation a world leader in many areas of importance. I was also a child who was born when our nation was in one of its worst possible positions. I was born in 1931. You may as what I mean about worst positions in the early 1930’s. The fact is that the stock market crash triggered the Depression. And because the heart of the northern states was trade—the buying and selling—the heart of the southern states was agriculture. It took a little longer for the lack of funds to affect the agricultural South. However when cotton mills stopped working because no one in the northern part of the country was buying their product, the mills closed. Without wages and moneythere was no buying, and therefore people with crops of cotton to sell had no buyers, and that made it difficult for folks in the South who couldn’t sell cotton, commerce, andThe Southern farmers couldn’t buy anything from the Northern States because the rest of the Northern country couldn’t buy their products of the ------ was not simultaneous with the fall of the stock market. It followed the crash of the stock market. Now most folks today remember that the Great Depression occurred in 1929. In the Southern part of the country below the Mason Dixon Line the immediate results didn’t hit quite so early. The economy in the South was based on cotton and tobacco, and to some extent also grains and food products. In the North the

telegraphwas improving the lack of roads, and supporting better communication. Rules and laws of decency were enforced, especially in the older communities near the East Coast. Nothing was, or is, perfect. The fact that our country had allowed slavery was difficult to support. However, in the 1860’s slavery was abolished. That didn’t mean the end of the ugliness forced on the people of color. The black race had been treated as less worthy of life and happiness than the white people, and it took a lot of years to change that supposition in the minds of the white folk, though I am not certain that it is completely accomplished even now.

My grandchildren have conveniences and medications that had not yet been discovered when I was their age. I, of course, had conveniences and medications that had not been available to my parents. Time actually does change things, and it sometimes changes in ways that we think are good, and sometimes changes are recognized as being very bad. The good things include the growth of knowledge by physicians, and those marvelous people who see beyond the “way we always did it” to make life more pleasant for everyone. Take dentistry for instance.

Dentists were not seen unless a person had a tooth ache. If there was no dentist, they, or someone else, pulled the bad tooth to relieve the pain. If the entire tooth was removed, the pain usually went away and the gum would, in turn, heal. However there would be a visible gap between teeth. When Aunt Helen lost most of her teeth, it was much simpler to pull all of them and replace them with a full set of false teeth. Partial bridges to replace missing teeth had not yet been invented.

Because my Dad had watched his sister suffer from having her teeth pulled at such an early age, he was determined to help me with my little problem. My lower jaw was not quite as long as my upper jaw and neither jaw was quite long enough to hold all my permanent teeth. When my baby teeth fell out, my permanent teeth grew in, and lapped over each other. My eye teeth looked like the tusks of an elephant sticking out under my upper lip on top of my other teeth. People noticed. I began to hold a hand in front of my mouth, especially when I was in the presence of children, or even adults, I didn’t know well. The only way to hide those weird looking teeth was with my hand over my mouth, and to my mother’s dismay I simply covered my mouth with my hand as if I was ashamed of my own face. I truly was a little girl who kept her mouth shut if at all possible. The problem was that my jaw was too short to hold all my teeth.

Dentistry was not new when I was a child, though filling teeth, and providing false teeth wasn’t all that old, either. There were a number of dentists in Charlotte when I was a child, but there were only two orthodontists. Those were doctors who could put pressure on certain teeth to make them realign themselves by using small wires. When my Dad found out about the possibility of an orthodontist being able to realign my teeth, he asked Mother to take me to see him.

The orthodontist told my mother he would have to pull some perfectly good teeth to make room for the others to be realigned. My Dad, having watched his sister struggle because she had lost so many teeth, said no. The doctor was kind. He tried for close to four years to realign my teeth. They now looked like they were almost ready to burst out of my gums. It had taken four full years. That kind doctor asked my Dad to come to see him, and this time after he talked to the doctor, he agreed that I could have four teeth pulled. Then the entire treatment began again as soon as my gums had healed after having the four teeth removed. This time, though it was not particularly easier than the other, I could at least see the progress. And four years later my teeth were properly spaced, and I finally had the braces removed. That day when I left his office I was so extremely happy that I wept. I decided I couldn’t ride a bus home, though I had an armful of school books. I walked, and smiled, and wept and smiled, and hurried and smiled and finally got home. I still looked normal. I didn’t have braces in my mouth after eight full years of wearing them. I had neither wire nor tusks under my lips. I was normal looking. So I smiled, and smiled, and smiled. And felt happy, and grateful to my parents for doing that for me, and thankful for the doctor who had helped me.

My Dad had been careful, and had not trusted the orthodontist simply because when he was growing up doctors had not really known what they were doing in many instances. Daddy’s little sister, named Stella, died because the Doctor couldn’t help her. Since there were so few effective remedies it probably wasn’t his fault, but it made my Dad place less trust in any doctor because of that experience. There had been no treatment, and no medicine to help his mother who was frail most of my Dad’s life. His sister, Helen, suffered from the treatment offered by her doctor when she was a teenager—all her teeth were ruined, and she was toothless by the time she was twenty years old. My Dad’s older brother was injured, and I was never aware of the circumstances, nor was I told how he was injured. However, afterwards he did not grow taller, and never was as strong as my Dad. Though my Dad was six feet three inches tall, my uncle was only about five feet two inches. Uncle Eddie was not nearly as strong as my Dad, and often asked my Dad to help him with harvest, even after Daddy married and had his own paint business.

The whole time I was growing up my Dad often helped with what he called the “laying by” time. That was the harvest time on the family farm. My Grandfather planted cotton, wheat, corn, melons, and vegetables, and in the flower garden there were a few herbs. There seemed to be few fruit trees, but there were several places along a creek that I saw only once, and there were nut trees near it. Aunt Helen kept chickens for eggs. The pigs turned into smoked meats and fats, and upon occasions the random rooster or pullet provided chicken dinners. Hay to feed the mule and the cows through the winter were harvested, so that very little in the way of food was actually bought from a store. The cows gave milk and butter. Only tea, salt, sugar and coffee, absolutely had to be bought from a store. Fruit pies were usually the desert at meal time, or if pie, or less likely, a cake, was not available, molasses or honey were usually available as a desert, with homemade butter and homemade wheat bread.

At my house as I was growing up, we had a marvelous thing. We had an ice box. It was not a refrigerator since those almost magic boxes made ice, but the ice box was a sort of special cabinet that could retard the melting of block ice, and keep meats from going bad and other food cooler than it would be on an ordinary shelf in the warm kitchen. The ice box slowed but could not actually prevent the ice from melting, and there was a drainage tube that went through the floor to carry away the water as the ice melted. Mother kept her butter, milk, and cooked foods, and uncooked meat in the ice box. In summer we could make iced tea, and our milk didn’t spoil when we kept it in the ice box.
8888888888888888888888888888888888888888888888888888888888888888 My aunts would can or dry what they could, and he , by that uncle was always skin and bones—very small, and not very strong. He was much smaller than my Dad, and far from being as strong as my Dad. He plowed and sowed the fields on their farm, and took care of the mule, the cows, and the pigs. But he certainly was never as strong as my Dad. I understood as a child that Granddaddy Yandle was the real farmer, and Uncle Eddie was his helper. After my Grandfather became too frail to actually do the field work, my Dad helped Uncle Eddie with some of the plowing, and sometimes left his own small business to help with haying, and harvesting, because there was no one else capable of bringing in the crops.

My Dad had because my Aunt Helen who was a teenager at the time, had once been given a medicine to drink that simply melted the outward layer of her teeth, and I don’t know what it did to her stomach. By the time she was twenty years all her teeth had been removed, and she was wearing false teeth. I never heard how long it took—weeks, months, years, for her to get the false teeth, and I never saw her without them. But I do know of a certainty that it took a mighty reason to pry her away from home. During my early childhood she did not go to church, she did not ever go to a store, she never went visiting, and she spent most of her time every day in the kitchen. Her “recreation” was feeding the chickens and feeding her dog, when she had one, and her cats, which lived under the house and kept rats away.

. she taken medicine once when she was only in her teen years, and the result of that was that all her teeth—every smack-dab one of them—had to be pulled, and she thereafter had false teeth. She was not even twenty years old when she lost all her teeth.

A physician had given her the medicine that ruined her teeth. A dentist had pulled her teeth and made her false teeth. Aunt Helen spent almost all of her life at home. She so rarely went away form home. It was true that her mother, my grandmother, needed constant attention because she was both feeble and blind. But Aunt Martha and Aunt Pauline, her sisters, and my Dad, who was her brother, had lives that stretched a long way from that little farm. My Dad was one of five children. He was the youngest boy, and Pauline was the youngest girl. that i

The first time I went to the dentist I was about twelve years old. This particular dentist wasn’t one who fixed cavities, or cleaned teeth. This doctor had a sign on the door of his office that said he was an orthodontist. He was one of two such doctors in Charlotte in the early 1940’s, at least as far as I knew. I had never before been to a dentist when my mother made the appointment. I knew that my Dad had visited a dentist who had pulled one of his teeth, and that made him feel bad for a day or two. This visit was an adventure to me, and though I was eager to improve my appearance, I was a little shy about beginning the treatment that I had heard was painful. I had never seen a person wearing tooth braces. Both my parents were willing to spend hard earned money to correct the way my teeth had grown in after my baby teeth disappeared. My eye teeth came out under my nose, above other teeth.

one of only two such doctors in the City of Charlotte at that time. He was an orthodontist. He realigned the teeth of children when their permanent teen had grown in crookedly, making their smile sometimes I wore braces for several years, young, had braces attached to my teeth. The need was quite visable to to straighten teeth that lapped over each other and grew out like elephant tusks. My mother told me that I formed a habit of covering my mouth with my hand when I laughed, because I was ashamed of the way my teeth had grown out. It bothered both of my parents enough that they sent me to an orthodontist and paid for my teeth to be straightened so that I would look more normal, and less like I was part elephant, with tusks. I was wonderfully grateful for their care. My Dad was particularly proud of the changes he saw when my teeth were eventually straight. I think it pleased him partly because he had an older sister, my Aunt Helen, who had lost all her teeth when she was eighteen years old.

When I was a child I was allowed to listen to most of the radio programs I wanted to hear. In those years broadcasters were subject to strenuous regulations of propriety. Stations—not just programs--could be forced off the air if they did not adhere to ordinary regulations about bad language, cursing, and implications of sexual abuse. Parents could, for the most part, allow their children to listen to radio programs with some assurance that they would not hear cursing, or mentions of explicit sex.

When I first began to watch television the rules of what could be shown were strict, as were the rules for radio. Motion pictures shown in theaters were also carefully monitored for decency. In the early days people wanted to be entertained in a pleasant but extremely “clean” way. If a person was drunk in a motion picture, it was usually meant to be funny, not tragic. Innocent children, that is children not yet informed about cursing and sex and the ugliest situations that too often occur in real life, were not to learn how base people could be when they were just plain mean, drunk, or depraved, and were so proud of it they didn’t care who knew it. Motion Pictures were monitored, and though I’m not sure what rules applied to television, it, too, was mostly carefully watched for crassness and ugliness.

There was one theater in Charlotte that often had Saturday morning specials, hoping to draw children in for the Saturday Matinee. In the evenings they showed provocative movies that “nice” people didn’t watch. The older theaters sometimes opened at ten o’clock or eleven o’clock on 9:00 A.M. with special children’s shows, or just the morning shows. Sometimes the picture changed after six or seven o’clock. Most of the movies shown in theatres were subject to rules of decency. In Charlotte the older theatres were less often filled on Saturdays or in the afternoons. Most theatres didn’t even open in the mornings. Because most people had to work, and most work was done in the daytime, there were few people able to spend time in a theatre. Saturdays were different. Saturdays were movie days for school age people who were out of school on Saturday and Sunday. young people who did not have to go to school. Almost everyone went to The older the theatre, the The filthy movies were usually shown in run down movie houses where the floors and the seats were actually unclean, and where the restrooms were usually filthy. The water fountains even looked dirty. I know because I entered such a theater once when I was about twelve or thirteen to see a popular movie I had missed when it had played months before in another theatre. That was the day I decided to be more careful about where—not so much why—but where I went, especially if I was going alone. That day I learned that entertainment which I had always thought was good fun, wasn’t always either fun or safe. I was certain that shabby was not always evil, nor was evil always shabby.

people too often found themselves involved in. sometimes would not learn bad language or what was then called “the facts of life” without parental consent. **be harmed the was also quite reliable as proper and clean language and portrayals. I can remember once when severe weather was passing through Charlotte that the weather announcer used a phrase on the air that was the punch line of a tawdry joke. Both my husband and I reacted to hearing it, looking at each other in surprise and disgust. The very next day the man was fired. About twenty years later I was up in the wee hours of the night, needing to calm my dismay at the illness of a family member. I thought that if I could sit quietly to watch an old movie it might help me relax so that I could fall asleep. When I switched on the television set hoping to find an interesting old movie, I picked an inopportune moment. To my surprise, on the screen was a similitude of a married couple deeply involved with each other. Granted it was about one o’clock in the morning, and the camera concentrated on their faces, however it was a rather large shot and I decided without hesitation that if that was the current fare offered on late night television I would never again use that medium to soothe my stressfulness. That very night I selected a book from a box I had pulled out from my closet. Then I piled my pillows against the headboard of my bed and read a book that took me away from myself long enough to calm my mind, to allow me to relax into sleep. The old book that did not distress me was much more soothing to the personal distress because of my Mother’s illness.
88888888888888888888888888888888888888888888

Time never stands still, even if it seems to pause. The speed of accomplishments, the quick responses of today, could not have been achieved when I was a child. The equipment did not exist at that time. I realize that life today, right now, is very different from the way almost every American lived it in the 1930’s. Not only has medicine, travel, communications, building, education, and every facet of life changed, time itself seems different. There are more people in the world. There are more people in this country. Moving from one location to another is much easier to do now than when I was a child. Food kept fresh for more than a day was risky when I was a child. Now, storing food safely is much easier. Communications between people some distance apart is now possible.

Mostly because of electricity and the machines and methods of communication we use today, the people of all nations living on the entire planet called Earth can communicate together to solve problems or cope with natural disasters. Much more can be accomplished in a day than was possible when I was a child. The length of the day has not changed, but methods of accomplishing most necessary tasks have improved astronomically.

the rules most folk adhered to when I was young. Some changes are, of course, the most wonderful thing that could happen. Among the most wonderful things were the medicines to fight illness, and the medical procedures that can save lives, the speed with which help can reach vulnerable folk and the marvelous ways that now can warn of foul weather, or dangerous situations. Having been born in 1931 (which makes me seventy-five years old as I write this) there were no antibiotics beyond sulfa until Pennicillin was discovered. Should persons of any age became ill before the 1940’s, they could be sure that one of two things would happen: they would die, or they would survive. If they died, they would have no problems in this world. If they survived, they found themselves in one of at least two situations: they would be either as well as they had ever been, or they would bear some form of discomfort or lack of movement or ability for the rest of their lives.

Judging from the experiences of my grandparents, especially in their younger years, accidents and illnesses often took adult lives. There were lots of people on the earth then—but not nearly as many as there are today. Lives were seldom as long in those days as they are now. , leaving children without parents. Sometimes parents saw their children become ill and die despite their efforts to help them. There were no antibiotics. In the time of my grandparents childbirth was a danger that often took the lives of the mother and the baby, or simply one or the other. If the baby survived, it required milk. If there was no cow or goat milk and if there was no other nursing mother close by who could feed both her own and motherless child, the motherless child usually did not live. In many instances mil from cows or goats was t was not available from cows, goats, or a substitute mother, it, too, would die. both the babies and the mothers. when children became ill, they usually died. There were no antibiotics and few doctors. Communication was generally by horseback, and doctors had no effective medicines to use. Prayer, Bed rest, good food, careful nursing, and a strong physical constitution were the best remedies. It was rare that a really life-threatening disease left no sign of its damages on its victim.
as diminished by the illness and they would have to grin and bear their diminished health for the balance of their lives, or they might not live through the illness andeither got well without medicines, or they died, or they lived the balance of their lives less able to cope with their everyday lives because they were physically maimed by some illness.

towever, thanks to the fact that not all entertainments are dedicated to making life better and more beautiful. In many cases today entertainment is digging into filthiness to be sensational enough to make a lot more money, encouraging people to if it were than a nice production that would simply entertain and please its audiences.

. , because not everything you see on television is even decent nor is it truthful and educational. not available to me

something about me. Actually while I was writing , my husband, and even perhaps our parents. Since I have been trying to find truthful names of old folk I am a little upset that those I once loved and interacted with are fading from my memory, and that there are now no persons I can question to be sure everything is correct. Therefore I won’t tell anyone that everything I shall write is without the occasional error caused by loss of memory, or a muddled remembrance that is not quite accurate. I shall, of course, do my best.
_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _

I suspect every person in the world would like to be remembered by people he or she loved and cared for—such as siblings, cousins, children, grandchildren, and all even folk we met for a limited time but who meant something in my life. the people , but I suspect at least part of my thinking and remembering is a little bit of nostalgia, perhaps a wish to remind my self of some of the exciting times in my life, some of the important times, perhaps times when it was obvious that I was part of something useful, beautiful, happy, or maybe even a little bit wonderful for people other than myself. I, just like almost everybody else, like to know that the world is a better place and the people I love are in better circumstances than they might have been because of something I said, or did, or planned for, or accomplished when our lives touched, no matter how briefly it might have been, or how unimportant it may have seemed at the time.

Actually, when I began to try to remember my early life, I started with scanty memories of my early childhood, and as I progressed down the years I remembered people, and places, events, occurrences, and began to enjoy a walk down memory lane. Often names escaped me, though faces still linger in my mind. That is especially true of the first job I held after I graduated from college. However, I cannot now say, “Oops, I better hit replay and write down the names.” That works only when the past is on tapes and recordings, and I wasn’t using them when I was doing such ordinary things. Time, in and of itself, doesn’t usually give us a lot of second or third chances to relive even beautiful experiences. Anyway—the following is, in the beginning, about me, and later on I wrote down things my husband of fifty some odd years has told me about his childhood and youth, and about himself before I met him. There are also remembrances from our early marriage, our lives together, our children, and now our grandchildren. I hope all the folk who read it enjoy again the lovely times I remember, and the beautiful times I had with all of them. It may be that some experience I write down will prevent their making the same mistakes I made. I hope you will enjoy reading about that period of time, and walking with me down through my past, in years that are now called “long ago.” I did so enjoy the happy times. 

                Iris Jean Yandle

My earliest memories are sketchy, as they are for most people. Babies do not usually remember the first time someone washes their hair, or feeds them, and I suppose all of the necessary and expected events occurred. My only access to my earliest beginnings are memories of what my parents and/or my older sister told me, and though my mother told me lots of little things, my sister didn’t bother, and I couldn’t really blame her for her attitude toward me. Her dislike didn’t come from anything I did or didn’t do. Her dismay at my arrival occurred because in that time it was customary to protect young children from any knowledge of why Mommy had a bigger tummy than she used to have, and the likelihood was good that a little brother or sister would be appearing one day soon so that there would be a new member of the family. That practice, with the best of motives, must have made a lot of problems for a lot of children, and for a while, my sister was one of them.

My sister, at the age of six, had no hint that quite soon the number of persons in her family might increase by at least one person. One morning she found herself taken over to a neighbor’s house. Because she liked the neighbor, named Pauline Funderburk, she had a good time while she was there. Like most six year old children she didn’t demand an explanation about why she stayed overnight with Pauline because the dictum that “children should be seen and not heard” was prevalent at the time. She trusted the grownups to always do the right thing and always take good care of her. Therefore, there were a couple of days she didn’t even see her mother. Of course, her Dad stopped by to make sure that all was well with her, and that Mrs. Funderburk didn’t need anything for Ella Cornelia. It was not actually an ordinary situation as Ella Cornelia had almost always stayed at home. She was not dumb, and she knew the situation was kind of odd, but she was not frightened, nor was she unhappy. She liked Pauline. There had been no hint that events were occurring that would change Ella Cornelia’s home life forever. No one mentioned the possibility that little Ella Cornelia was soon to discover she had a small sister or brother. She was enjoying her stay with Pauline. Her Dad even stopped by to be sure she didn’t need any thing from home. Ella Cornelia had often visited Pauline’s house for short periods, and though she hadn’t spent the night there before, she was having a good time.

Of course, within a day or so she discovered the reason why she was staying with Pauline Funderburk Pauline took little Ella Cornelia home, still not knowing why she had stayed with Pauline in the first place.

Not everyone understands the word surprise. A surprise could be anything from a doll to a new dress or to a scrumptious treat, and during that time (1931) in the South a surprise was usually a joyous experience for a child. My sister was willing to accept whatever it was that was due to her, because it was almost always a fun thing, or a good thing. Maybe it was a new dress, or perhaps some other treat, and therefore she was eager to go home. She had lots of nice expectations, and it was lovely to think about Upon arriving home she went through the door, walked into the room, and sure enough Mother was there and there was a surprise.

The actual surprise was me. And Ella Cornelia was surprised, alright. The other folk there were also surprised. In that day and time parents did not usually tell the children in the family that a new baby was expected. Parents often hid the fact that another child was on the way. Therefore when our Mom came home from the hospital she did have a surprise for Ella Cornelia who had no idea that I was born. She had been six years old for several months, and immediately realized that there was a car in front of her house. When my Ella Cornelia went inside the house, she saw her mother sitting with a baby in her arms. Lots of people were there, though at my tender age at that time I, myself, didn’t recognize any of them. What I know is that when Ella Cornelia learned that she had been sent away to stay with Pauline Funderburk so that Mother could have a baby, and that the surprise was only me, my sister wanted to give me back to the hospital. It took her a lot of years to finally decide that I could stay, after all.

At first, Ella Cornelia’s reaction was that she had been tricked. She really didn’t want a sister. She had been the only child all her life. Now people were visiting me—not my sister. I was the new one. People would come in and say something like “Hello, Ella Cornelia, where is the Baby?” Then they might even have a gift for the newborn, and not for Ella Cornelia.

all the attention. The people in the room weren’t excited about seeing Ella Cornelia. They wanted Ella Cornelia to be excited about the baby. Everyone there was pleased and expecting her to be happy, too. Ella Cornelia did not leave them in suspense over her reaction. She said with all her six year old power, “TAKE IT BACK.”
It took a while to make clear to her that I was non-returnable.

My sister, an intelligent child, had truly enjoyed being an only child, and also reveled in the fact that she was the only Yandle grandchild. Ella Cornelia had also been the first born Parks grandchild, but in that family she was definitely not the only child. Mother’s brother Dennis, a little older than my mother, married a lovely lady named Mary. Uncle Dennis and Aunt Mary married earlier than my Mother and Dad, however Ella Cornelia was also the first born grandchild in my mother’s family. However, after Ella Cornelia’s birth, and before my appearance in our family, Uncle Dennis and Aunt Mary had three children. Dennis, Jr., was the oldest, and then came Patsy, and then Mary Cole.

My mother had two brothers. The oldest one was named Luther. He married a lady who was a true Southern Belle. She owned a house that had belonged to her family for many years, and she and Uncle Luther seemed to be happy, and they spoke as if they really enjoyed living in that historical house. Because they lived so far away from Pineville we saw them less often than we did the kin folk who lived closer to Charlotte. Many years later, when I was old, and Uncle Luther’s wife had passed away, he returned to the Pineville area, and lived with Aunt Ola and her husband Vance Davis, until he died. He brought to each of his nieces a couple of very old, but very nice chairs that had been used in the very old house where Uncle Luther had lived for so long. Uncle Luther went to a lot of trouble to sand and refinish those chairs, and he gave two to all of his nieces. I still have mine.

My sister was an alert child, an active child, a thinking child. She had always been in the very center of the total attention of the family as the only grandchild in the Yandle family, and the first grandchild in the Parks families as well. Of course, she knew about the birth of her three Parks’ cousins, and had seen them when they visited her Parks Grandparents at the same time she did, and they didn’t seem to be a threat. It was different on the Yandle side of the family. She was an only child, and an only grandchild on that side of the family. It always puzzled me that she didn’t mind her three Parks cousins visiting her Parks Grandparents. Somehow those children didn’t seem to be a threat to her. I was different. I was right there, right in her mother’s arms, and in the very center of the other people that were in the house. the middle of her own home.

I was different, however, because I was right there in the middle of her home, in her mother’s arms, and she was told that from now on she was a big sister. For my sister there had been no indication of the expected event, no hint that a baby was coming into the family. In those days, “nice” people didn’t talk about such private things to small children. And therefore, I was an unwelcome surprise to Ella Cornelia. I was, so far as she was concerned, stealing her place as the youngest child. I was definitely the center of attraction. People who came into the house would say a casual hello to her, and then coo over the baby, and say nice things about the new child. She saw it as a defeat for her, and an intrusion on my part. Ella Cornelia had been an only child for a little over six years. I was a blunt, unwelcome addition to the family. She was an intelligent child and she recognized immediately that she had competition. The guests were not looking at her—they were looking at the new baby. It was difficult for her to understand that she had competition where other people were concerned. no longer an only child. She, who had always been the very center of attraction suddenly wasn’t. Everyone wanted to see the new baby. N=Most of the aattention and interest and attention at home and with her Yandle grandparents as well, and since Grandmother Yandle had been very ill, she was visited more often than Grandmother Parks.

She didn’t see her young Parks cousins very often, because in the

. Suddenly, without a thinking child. warning, she had competition. not in any dimension a dumb child. , . She immediately realized my arrival changed everything because she was no longer an only child. She immediately surmised that family and neighbors might begin to “like” the new baby better than they liked her, because all of them were gathered around the new baby, right now! Most of them gave her a nod, but all they were interested in was seeing the new baby, and perhaps noticing her reaction to meeting her baby sister for the first time. Whether or not they were really interested in how she reacted to seeing her sweet baby sister for the first time, and learning that she actually had a sweet little baby sister, it probably had not occurred to them that this was not so much a pleasing present for a small child as it was an unwelcome shock to an barely six year old who had not had even a clue to the manner in which her life was forever changing. She was not stupid. She saw that the people present, every smack-dab one of them, placed all their interest on the new baby. They were expecting pleasure from her, too. , as if it were not a total shock to her, and a fear that the new baby would get all the attention, They girlTherefore, they were not paying much attention to the little person who had hitherto been the only important child. She was completely vulnerable since she had never before had an actual rival where attention was concerned, especially in the Yandle side of the family.

The only other “grandchildren” in the family were the two children of her Uncle Dennis Parks who was her mother’s brother and who lived in Fort Mill, South Carolina. Since they lived about twenty miles away from the Parks Grandparents, they didn’t come to North Carolina often. Uncle Dennis worked six days a week, and was active in their church. The date was after and probably his younger sister who was not yet walking. It was probably a sort of coincidence that Uncle Dennis and Mother didn’t often show up at the same time to visit the Parks Grandparents, and a boy toddler wasn’t much of a threat, even when he had a very small sister who was probably close to two years older than of her Yandle grandparents she was an only child. In the Parks family there was a child just a little bit younger than herself, and though she had played with him a little, she had not found him a rival to her position as the first grandchild in both families. Little Dennis, Junior was about a year and a half younger than her, so that even if there were two grandchildren in that family, she was still the older, which made her the boss. Little Dennis was not really a threat, and visits to the Parks grandparents didn’t seem to be a problem when they were together. Uncle Dennis and Aunt Mary lived in Fort Mill, South Carolina, and he was younger than her, which made her the boss. He didn’t come to visit very often when they were both very young, and the two children seemed to play well together. But Dennis, Junior was not a surprise to a six year old only child. Little baby Jean was a total surprise. Visitors paid attention to the new baby, and came close to ignoring young Ella Cornelia. Shock can breed anger very quickly and sometimes permanently. It took about ten years before my sister could find even one tiny thing about me that she liked. My memory of the turn-around was based on music. She liked to sing. I could carry a tune. Therefore, washing dishes by hand, rinsing them, drying them, putting them away was boring. It went quicker with help. Even a young kid sister could dry dishes. The radio did ot always someone to dry (boring) went quickingand unwelcomeBecause Dennis, Jr. was not a surprise, and he was o.k. to play with because he lived in South Carolina and wasn’t around very much.

However, this baby was not going to be tucked into a car and carried away when it began to be dark. Her parents were going to keep this little baby, right in her own house. Ella Cornelia was not dumb, and she had already discovered that “other” little girls and boys could interrupt the attention lavished on her.

Not only had she not expected so huge a disappointment as a little baby sister, she, who had recently celebrated her n “only” child, an only grandchild, in the Yandle family. In the Parks family she was an “only” child in one family, and she had become accustomed to the fact that she had a slightly younger boy cousin who was the son of her mother’s brother and his wife, and there was even a younger girl baby named Patsy who was Dennis Junior’s little sister. They didn’t visit often since they lived in Fort Mill. . in the other family, because he lived in Fort Mill, South Carolina, and in that day and time, travel wasn’t as easy as it is now, with automobiles one of two grandchildren iand cousin on the Yandle side of the family. Now she had a real “bugger man” in her own house.

As a matter of fact, she disliked me so much she suggested that life would be much better for our parents, and for her, if my mother took me back to the place where she found me, and leave me there. I was unexpected, unwelcome, and a mighty nuisance to my sister from the day I arrived home until I was about ten years old.

When I was born my parents were living in Charlotte, North Carolina. They rented a couple of rooms from my Dad’s Aunt Elizabeth Yandle and her brother Edward. I honestly don’t know how that brother and sister were related to me. They were brother and sister to my Grandfather Yandle. Uncle Edward and Aunt Elizabeth didn’t talk unless they had something to say. That is, they didn’t join in conversations just to wag their tongues. If they had something to say, that politely mentioned it. However they would never have interrupted anyone else who was talking. They never told jokes. They never spoke nonsense. If someone asked a question they would answer it. Had they witnessed a house on fire, they would have waited politely until someone asked them if they had seen it, and then they would have said, “yes.” They were not eager to tell what they knew about anything. They seldom found it necessary to begin a conversation. When they visited, us there was never to jabber about whatever the subject might be

, but they were not , on East Fifth Street. The house numbers were usually three digits, with the first number indicating and the first number assigned to each house was the number of the block. The five hundred block was the fifth block from Tryon Street, and the and the following number or numbers were different for each house. . All the houses in that block had a number that began with five. blocks from either Tryon Street (the north-south streets) or from Trade Street (the east west streets). Though so far as I know the East Fifth Street still exists, none of the houses I remember are still standing. When I was a child I think the Telephone Company—the place where the operators were, and the place to which all the lines in the city were attached was there on that street.

numbers were in the 500’s . I remember that mother told me that when my older sister, Ella Cornelia, was a baby, she and Daddy lived with my Great Aunt Elizabeth and Uncle Edward. I was much older when I realized that they were the sister and brother of my grandfather Yandle. I was very young when I began to remember what they looked like, and how they behaved, and even when I was a very small child, I thought they didn’t match the rest of the family. They lived differently, dressed differently, seemed to have different vocabularies from the rest of my Dad’s family, but also seemed to be extremely welcome when they visited. It wasn’t until I was grown that I realized that they had been born at slightly later date than my Granddaddy, and that their upbringing was different because they had a different mother. Aunt Lizzie and Uncle Edward were kind, but sticklers for “the right way to do things” and had an accent different form ours. I think it their mother must have been more recently British because of the precise way they spoke the King’s English. Both were well educated. I knew very little about them, and saw little of them, though Uncle Edward would stop by our house upon occasion. He was a door to door salesman, who carried a suitcase filled with mentholatum, shoe strings, and other items that people needed every day. I remember his suitcase, and some of the things he sold, and that he didn’t talk exactly like my other uncles. He always wore a suit, and wore a hat out-of-doors. He had a different vocabulary from everybody else I knew. I do remember one day he stopped by our house. I didn’t see either of my Aunt and Uncle very frequently, and I, as a very small child, didn’t really enjoy visiting them at their house, because the house was quite old. Some things about it were interesting—such as the fact that it had not only one way to light the house after dark, but two ways. There were old fashioned gas lights in every room, and there were also electric lights in the house. In their front room there was a settee, and on the other side of the room, there was a pump organ. I had seen pianos in some homes, and I had also seen pump organs. However no one else in our family had either one.

In those times there was a phrase, or maybe it could be called a sentence, I hated to hear put into words, no matter how quietly or discretely. I usually heard it when I was actually or almost the only child in the room, and the grownups were saying very interesting things and using words I didn’t easily recognize. If I was bold enough to ask for clarification, my sister, my parents, or someone who knew me quite well, would lean over and whisper: “Children should be seen and not heard!” That usually meant the end of the conversation until I left the room. I always felt belittled as a person. They didn’t trust me. They didn’t like me. They kept secrets from me when I found their subject interesting. Since I was the youngest child in the family the idea of my growing up, my being savvy of what they were talking about could mean I was no long a baby, but that made them, each and every one of them, older, too. I seemed to be always hearing that at Aunt Lizzie’s house. My biggest worry was whether or not they thought I was trustworthy, and the answer I figured out was no, they didn’t trust me about much of anything. They didn’t even like it if I wanted to bang on the pump organ if I was in the room by myself.

If whatever the adults were talking about had caught my interest that phrase was two things: it always meant “shut-up or you will be in deep trouble”, and it usually reminded any careless adults that a child was present and should not be exposed to whatever was being discussed. If I was intrigued, and wanted a word explained, many times someone told me what I wanted to know, but sometimes I would hear that sentence, and it never failed to cause me genuine dismay. If I didn’t understand the gist of the conversation I felt I deserved a tiny bit of clarification. However, if the grownups were making an effort to talk “above” me, satisfying themselves with knowing looks, but keeping me out of the knowledge of the real meaning I felt diminished and knew they didn’t trust me. It never occurred to me that living a life could hold rules of polite conversation that allowed privacy in sticky situations, or offered protection to people who needed to be sheltered from words.

that they didn’t trust me as a person. They thought I would tell the wrong people. it was not that they were being niceand therefore keep me in ignorance of what they were actually talking about, . I always have liked to talk with other people. we were in a crowd, someone would whisper in my ear seven words I was never proud I didn’t mind visiting Aunt Lizzie and Uncle Edward, though they were different in the way they looked and thought. I could not easily predict what they would say, or what they were thinking. Their accents were different from those of the rest of my family. However, my parents, and my Dad’s parents, my aunts, my uncle, and people I didn’t even know treated him as if he were a valuable friend. Being about five or six years old when I began to make my own judgments about grown-ups, I decided there had to be something about that man that I was too young to understand. made my own When they spoke it was generally in complete sentences. They did not chatter. They were perfectly happy to sit in a room with several people and not say a word. However, Uncle Edward was well educated, and he had what I called a marvelous vocabulary, and when I was older . a lot, I found them strange in some ways. Uncle Ed never spoke unless he had a definite something to say. He never made an effort to wiggle his tongue in “small talk” had no small talk—empty sounds without true merritthem, but they lived very near a railroad track, and the street itself was busy, mostly because Southern Bell had a large building there. old and the houses were old. My mother said the houses in that area were dingy, mostly from train smoke and soot. Probably all had once been owned by the people who lived there, however, time and soot from the trains, and *****but the houses were so old that many occupants had rented space in them after the original folks had died, and their heirs didn’t want to move in.

Most of them were, by the time I was born, rental houses, because their owners had become old and moved out, or they had died and no one in their families wanted to live there. The nearby elementary school had sections that were unsafe for classes, and the students were not allowed in those areas. and most of the houses were a little

them really often. That day he arrived just after we sat down to lunch. Of course, my mother asked him to join us. His reply was that “I have no room.” Since our table was smallish, and the four of us were in our normal places, the old gentleman was correct—there was no place set for him. Therefore my mother hurriedly arose from her chair, made a place for him at the table, then pulled up another chair for Uncle Edward, and asked him again to join us at table. Uncle Edward chuckled, and said, “I meant, in my alimentary canal.” My mother had to explain to me that he meant he had already eaten, and had no room in his tummy for more food.

had be born and educated in England, and that they were children of a second marriage. One Great grandfather married twice. My grandfather was born of his first wife. After her death, Great Grandfather married again, and Uncle Edward and Aunt Elizabeth were the children of the second wife.

Our house had a lovely front porch, my earliest yearslittle bit of trying to recognize important events that I believe are worth recording within written words, and a least a little bit of boredom because I dislike doing nothing. I don’t have any riveting chores, or fascinating errands; therefore I would like to have an important goal, something that will be appreciated by people other than myself. Therefore, I shall type, and I will try to write down how it was in the early 1930’s and how it was for me and to some extent to my family, some of whom none of my Grandchildren ever met. They were strong people, and in many cases very good and noble folk. In my family only my sister remembers some of the things I can remember. She was born in 1925, and at this time is still living in Charlotte. She married Harry May after World War II, and they had five children, who are cousins to my daughter and son. My kids don’t know my sister’s kids very well at all, having seen them only a Christmas or birthdays when they were small. Therefore, once I began the letter to my Grandson who lives all the way across the country in Oregon,

and I have always been long winded. Not only that, I get carried away when I begin to write, and I ramble and digress, and start over again, and then get frustrated and either toss the whole thing, or try to write a whole book. This time it looks like I started a book—and I hope you, and probably the rest of the family will enjoy it. If I can stick to my task I will eventually finish my task. I promise I will certainly try! 

                    ***

When Paw-paw was in high school (he graduated in 1943) he didn’t choose to learn typing as I did. Typewriters of that day and time were mostly manual, not electric, and there were very few male students who wanted to learn typewriting. Their decision was based on an absolutely known fact: Most of the young males in school in those days expected to become boss of something, a superior person in a business. Therefore, he would dictate orders and letters. The females would type them. It was a gender thing.

Paw-paw’s schooling was not very different from mine. He was born in the month October in the year of l925, and was an only child. The plan did not begin with only one child, because when Paw-paw was four or five years old his parents expected another child. Sadly, that child did not live. His umbilical cord circled his neck so tightly during his birth that he never began to breathe. Paw-paw therefore became an only child.

As an infant, Paw-paw and his parents lived in a quiet neighborhood but not a “modern” one. When he was still quite small, perhaps two or quite close to three years old, his parents moved onto a reasonably quiet street not far from Mercy Hospital, where several other young families of their acquaintance already lived. The street was lined with nice, modern houses with a number of young families, including children close to Bobby’s age, who were iving there. Paw-paw, who was called Bobby, was growing up in a spacious house built just like his parents wanted it built. They furnished the house as they wished, and it had a modern kitchen, with a dish washer (yes, they did have them way back then) and their house stood among other modern homes. There were young families nearby, with companions for little Bobby. He enjoyed playing with them, and one child, he discovered, was a cousin.

When Bobby was almost six he enrolled in the first grade at a nearby school. His birthday was October 25, and since school usually began in early September, there was a problem. In the eyes of the City of Charlotte’s School Board, little Bobby Beatty was too young to enroll in the first grade. He was expected to wait until next year. However, his Mama thought he was bright enough to begin school that year, and that a single week, or perhaps two, shouldn’t matter very much, so she made a “mistake” and told the teacher that her little boy was born a little earlier than his actual birth date and little Bobby Beatty became a first grade student. Sometime later, of course, the “error” about his birth date was corrected. Little Bobby attended Elizabeth Grammar School, which was within easy walking distance from his home, and there were other students who lived quite near him who also walked the few blocks to the school. He liked his school, and his teachers, and played nicely with neighbor children. He even decided that he would marry one of the little girls, and couldn’t see why he should not, even though she was a cousin. However, he was only six at the time.

Paw-paw attended the Elizabeth school for several years, but when he was about ten years old, his family moved away from that neighborhood, and that is another part of this story. 

                                                              ********

My maiden name was Yandle. When I was old enough to attend school I discovered that my surname was a bit odd to most people. Even so, there were a few other students in the schools I attended with the same name, pronounced the same way, but usually spelled a little differently. There were several deviations: Yandal, Yandell, Yandel, and Yeandal. Our family spelled it: Yandle. When I was growing up, my Dad would sometimes talk about his family, and I heard stories of his parents, his siblings, and his childhood, along with grandparents, and numerous cousins. He spoke of his Grandfather, for whom my Dad had great respect. Daddy told a story to me when I was very young about the Fiftieth Wedding Anniversary celebration for his grandparents. At the golden anniversary celebration for his grandparents, my Dad who was a boy at the time My Dad had great respect for Milas Milton Yandle, and that event was a milestone that my Dad remembered with some relish, and with a lesson he learned that lasted all of his life.

A Fiftieth Wedding celebration was being held for Grandfather and his wife, and many family members had been invited, and so many had arrived that not all could eat at one time. Therefore, at the appointed time the number of folk who could sit around the table at the same time was then served the meal. When they had eaten their fill, they left the table, and it was prepared again, and again, until all the older folk had been fed. The children, and there were lots of them, had been told to wait until the adults had been fed before they came to the table. That nicety made for some hungry children who had no plan of how to spend all that time until they were called to eat. Therefore the boy children did what boy children always do when they are hungry, and have to wait a long while to be fed—they entertained themselves with a bit of mischief. In the house was a box of cigars, a present to Grandfather on his anniversary. It was a big box, and it had been opened, and several cigars had already been taken from the box.

One brave boy slipped into the room where the cigar box had been placed, and took one—only one—of the cigars and a match to light it, and then rejoined the other boys. Hungry boys who knew each other quite well decided to smoke the cigar while they waited. They went around the barn so as to be out of sight of the house. Once the cigar was lighted they took turns having a puff. It was a new and exciting and thoroughly grown-up experience, though it didn’t take much time to discover that it made them sort of queasy. By the time they were finally called to the table for their meal, the servers, though sort of surprised that the hungry boys did not demand double and triple helpings, didn’t worry about their appetites. The boys hardly ate what was placed on their first plate. The servers were surprised, but were probably grateful that the last table of guests did not prolong the final meal, and without much inquiry about uneaten food, they hurriedly did their clean-up so that they, too, could go join the visitors.

Towards sunset those visitors who had a considerable distance to cover to get home began to say their farewells and thanks and prepared to leave long before dark, as they would be traveling either on, or behind horses or mules. Those the longest distance from home would leave earliest as some, perhaps all, of those families had cows and horses or mules along with pigs and chickens to take care of before they themselves could rest for the night. Morning was always early on a farm. Therefore, the ladies who had served the meal were pleased to sit for a while before seeing their guests out to their buggies and wagons as they left for their trip home. My Dad never said whether or not the servers were surprised at how little of the food was eaten by the boys who had smoked the cigar. He did say that he could eat little of it. However, the tired servers didn’t complain when the youths had finished their meal rather quickly. They finished cleaning the kitchen and tried to find a place to sit down to rest and to enjoy the company, even though the guests were beginning to diminish as they left for home. Almost all of the visitors had, not only a distance to travel by wagon or buggy, but all of them would have also have had their own live stock to feed, cows to milk, and chickens and pigs and the horses or mules to feed and water. No matter how tired the older visitors were when they arrived home, they couldn’t ignore their animals. All of them would arise early the next day to a full workday.

I didn’t hear very much about some of those kin folk who were there for the Fiftieth Anniversary of my Dad’s grandparents. By the time I was born, in 1931, Milas Milton and his wife Sally Elizabeth had been deceased for years. Milas had married Sally Elizabeth Yandle about 1859, and their Golden Wedding Anniversary was celebrated in 1909, when they were both quite elderly. About that time my Dad was a teenager and he would, during World War I, be old enough to serve in the Navy. He had photographs of himself in China, and in other locations as he carried out his enlistment. As a child I was always intrigued by one of the photographs he had carried home. There was a cat on his ship which was named Bugs. My dad had thought enough of the cat to take its picture. I thought pets were wonderful, and I often enjoyed a peek at that photograph, and those of my tall Daddy among other sailors. It is possible that my sister still has those photos, because as the oldest she inherited many of the keepsakes that had been dear to Mother and Daddy.

When I was small it was always amazing to me to think of my strong, tall Dad as a small boy. I wasn’t stupid. I knew that children grew to become adults. But my Dad was so tall and so strong. As for me, it seemed to be taking an extremely long time for me to grow. My Dad’s escapades as a boy seemed to indicate that he was not a small boy—he was a big boy. It puzzled me that I was so very small. I fell easily. I didn’t mean to do it, but I dropped things. When I did I would get fussed at, and when I was small my big sister made it plain that she didn’t like me very much—which is not really unexpected. In those days birthing a child was a hush, hush, matter. And when I was expected no one told my sister. I was a surprise, but not a welcome one so far as she was concerned. She had been an “only” child for seven years, and then suddenly, without any warning, our mother brought home a little baby. People came to see me. When I became the focus of attention instead of the well known child called Ella Cornelia, she was not only unpleased, but actually angry that I even existed. If she had been able to do it, she would have sent me back quickly and permanently.

To think that my Dad ever suffered those same kind of feelings was difficult for a small child. My Dad was the youngest boy in his family, and his sister, Pauline, was the youngest child. My Dad’s older brother, Uncle Eddie, didn’t resemble my Dad very much. He had sustained a mule kick when he was small, and seemed never to grow as strong as his siblings. I was amazed when Uncle Eddie would ask my Dad how to make something work, or how to actually accomplish what he needed to do. He was the older brother, but it he seemed very different from my Dad. My Dad was big and tall. He was not fat—just a big man, well muscled and strong. Uncle Eddie was not taller than his sisters, and he was thinner than his sisters. Uncle Eddie lived at home with his parents and all three of his sisters until Aunt Pauline was married. He wore blue overalls, and I never saw him outside without a cap or a straw hat.

In those days many people who liked tobacco used snuff. Fine ground tobacco was sold in small silvery cans, and all you needed to do to get a “snuff brush” was to find a particular tree, and pick some slender pieces from the end of the limbs. One end of the little round stick would bristle out, sort of like a tiny rough broom, and when it was damp, a touch of the powdered tobacco would stick to the brush, and the user could put it against his or her cheek, and the flavor of the tobacco mixed with saliva would, in most instances, please the user. It could not be swallowed, and eventually the user would have to spit out the dark brown mess being held against their cheek. Usage of Tobacco snuff was not beautiful, because of the spitting. Folks usually used a tin can to spit in. When someone continually used snuff he or she would occasionally miss the can. It splattered where it fell. If cleaned up right away it didn’t leave a dark spot. If some tobacco stuck to the users lips, it looked nasty. If it spilled on their shirts it looked nasty. If a child accidentally kicked a spit can some one had left sitting on the floor close to the leg of a chair—it was a very bad move, and a very messy one. Spilling someone’s tobacco juice made the person who kicked it, and the person who set it down, very, very unhappy.

My uncle Eddie liked to smoke cigarettes better than he liked to use snuff. However, he was the only one in the family who smoked. My Dad, who was six feet three inches tall, always said he was not yet big enough to smoke. No one in my immediate family ever adopted the habit.

Aunt Pauline, my Dad’s baby sister, married Henry Hunnycut, and I don’t remember anything about the wedding. I was probably about five or six years old about then, and knew little about weddings. I liked Uncle Henry, as he smiled often, but didn’t talk much, at least to me. I have a faint remembrance of claiming him as my boyfriend, and arguing with Aunt Pauline whether I, myself, or she, would be marrying him. Most often when we visited Grandmother
.
As a child, I had lots of aunts and uncles, even though none of my Dad’s sisters had married until Aunt Pauline married Uncle Henry when I was about six years old. My Dad, Leroy Yandle, and his sister, my Aunt Pauline Hunnycut (ne. Yandle) were the only ones of that generation to marry until I was about seventeen years old.

There was a family that lived quite close to Aunt Pauline, and his mother was terminally ill. He was upset, and unhappy, and often visited my Grandmother Yandle’s house. The family name was Estridge, and I didn’t know any of them, nor did I ever learn how long they had lived there, or if my aunts and uncles knew the people at all. But one Sunday when I was about sixteen, we visited my grandparents there was a young man in the house, also visiting. I wondered why in the world a young man about twenty years old (or less) would hang around people he didn’t know very well who were much, much older than he was. I learned that his mother had just died, and though he was still in school, he didn’t really like to go home any more, even though he had siblings. So my Aunts made him a cot in the Dining Room of their house, and he was sleeping there, and eating his meals there, and finishing high school in Pineville’s senior high school. I thought he was a real cute boy. I liked him, and we got along o.k. together. I saw him only rarely, when we happened to meet at my Grandmother’s house. He even asked me for a date—though I was very young—and we went to a movie together. It was the only time we had a date. Sometimes on Sundays he would go for a walk with me, and most usually we were certainly not alone.

I saw him often with his arm around my Aunt Martha’s shoulder, and I thought that he was just lonely for his mother, and needed a hug. As time went on, Allen graduated from high school and went to work at a carbon plant. He still slept in the dining room at my Grandparent’s house, and apparently ate all his meals with the family. He was still in High School, and drove a school bus. He ate meals with the family so often I wondered if he ever went home, especially after his mother succumbed to her illness.

When summer came around that year, my mother agreed to go to the beach with Aunt Martha and Allen. My Mother went as a chaperone, because Grandmother Yandle and the others in the house were a little alarmed at the closeness that was building up between my aunt and the very young boy. I was a little bit miffed that I wasn’t invited to go with them. I thought of Allen, traveling with two old ladies, and wondering if he would even have a chance to enjoy the trip. I thought that particular trio was sort of odd group to visit the beach. However, Mother asked me to stay in Charlotte, and run the little paint store that was across the street from our house. My Dad rented the space and Mother served as the salesperson. She answered Daddy’s business telephone, and typed his reports and when folks in our neighborhood needed a bucket of paint, she sold it to them. There weren’t many customers, but the fact that it was an open and active business made it possible for my Dad to buy his paint at wholesale prices, and that was enough of an edge to make the rent of the store worth while. If we sold three cans of paint a day it was a big day. Because we lived only across the street from the store there were often folks knocking on our door in the evening, wanting to buy a small can of paint, and if we were at home, some one of us walked across the street to accommodate the neighbor.

We didn’t have many customers, but I, who had spent many afternoons in the store and learned a lot about what customers usually wanted, and could easily help them decide what they needed. I could type if Daddy needed a letter, or a proposal for a job, and most of our shoppers sort of did a double-take when they saw me, because my mother and I were much alike, except for our ages. Mother had long hair she wore in a bun at the nape of her neck. That summer, I also had long hair which I wore in a bun at the nape of my neck. I didn’t run into any problems that I couldn’t solve, and Mother’s absence didn’t cause Daddy or me any problems.

When the few days of the beach trip were over, Allen and Aunt Martha made an announcement. They had stopped in South Carolina on their way to the beach, and had been legally married to each other. Aunt Martha was Mrs. Estridge. The newly weds did not rush away from the Yandle house where they had been living, but eventually they had a home, and Aunt Martha left the house she had lived in all her life, and left Aunt Helen and Uncle Eddie to run the house, as before. Aunt Martha was very good about visiting her parents, and helped her sister and brother a great deal.

As the years rolled by, Grandfather Yandle went home to be with the Lord, and Grandmother Yandle lived several more years, and she, too, went home to be with the Lord.

When only Aunt Helen and Uncle Eddie were left in the old home place, they were aging, and unable to actually farm the land, nor manage the animals. The animals were sold, the house was sold, and Aunt Helen and Uncle Eddie moved into a house not far from Aunt Pauline’s home. They had electricity, and indoor toilets, central heating in winter, and few chores beyond washing dishes. Uncle Eddie had smoked for most of his life, and he developed emphysema and was not able to work. Aunt Helen kept house, and looked after Uncle Eddie. Aunt Pauline looked after both of them, advising them, and helping them get groceries as neither of them could drive a car. When Uncle Eddie succumbed to emphysema Aunt Pauline, whose husband had died, asked Aunt Helen to come live with her. And so the sisters shared a home until Aunt Helen began to suffer from Alzheimer’s, and then Aunt Pauline helped her with placement in the Methodist Home, as Aunt Pauline was herself quite frail, and no longer able to look after Aunt Helen. Shortly after Aunt Helen was placed in the Methodist Home, Aunt Pauline moved to an assisted living home, and lived there until her death.

.

They had no children, however, Uncle Henry had nieces—two of them who were sisters, and who wanted to work in Charlotte. The two girls lived with Aunt Pauline and Uncle Henry for several years, attending school, and working in Charlotte. Aunt Pauline became a sort of extra mother for them, guiding them, teaching them. They were beautiful girls, and good girls as well. She helped them with schooling, and she advised them as to jobs when they had finished school. It was Aunt Pauline who planned their weddings when they decided to marry. They had beautiful weddings. Both girls treated her as if she were their mother.

When I was about ten or twelve years old, I spent one entire summer unable to go out of my house beyond my own yard, and I was forbidden to have the company of neighboring children or friends. That was the year that Infantile Paralysis was causing illnesses to both adults and children in North Carolina. There were no curatives that could be used to fight that terrible sickness. Another name for it is Poliomyelitis. It was also called Infantile Paralysis because it struck more children than adults. The illness began not far from Charlotte in the mountains of North Carolina. The City of Charlotte proclaimed that children could not attend any presentation that drew a crowd—school, church, movies, parks, play grounds, and any other place where children would come into contact with other children. School ended early that year, and ordinarily school would have resumed ordinarily in early September; however, school was delayed until cooler weather arrived. It was believed that hot weather played some part in the spreading of poliomyelitis, the medical name for the epidemic. My mother and Dad called it infantile paralysis. I couldn’t play with the neighbor children, nor go to Sunday School, nor to the movies, and I couldn’t even go to the Public Library to select books to read. I was by that time wearing braces to straighten my teeth, and I walked to my orthodontic appointments and then walked as quickly as possible back home. Children didn’t go to church, nor to movies, nor did they meet in groups within neighborhoods to play. Instead, children stayed home, and away from other children. In Charlotte there were public parks, and to look after them there was an office for the Department of Recreation—where a designated person was in charge of all the Charlotte Parks and areas of Recreation. That summer they had a thirty minute radio program every week day to suggest ways that children use their time since they could not play with neighbors. The Parks and Recreation Department of the City of Charlotte started a radio show every day with ideas for solitary games, or games siblings could play together. However, most parents did not allow their children to get close enough to other children to actually play with them. It was a lonely summer vacation, and boring. As well as I remember, I was about thirteen at that time. I went up town that summer only twice, and that was to visit my orthodontist. I was wearing braces to rearrange my teeth because my jaw wasn’t large enough to accommodate all the teeth that God gave me. For all the teasing I got for having a big mouth, it wasn’t big enough for all my teeth to sit side by side in comfort. So I had eye-teeth growing out under my nose, and other teeth over-lapped each other. Therefore, I did have the privilege of walking to my dental appointments throughout that summer.

Children were not allowed to wander around on the streets, and they couldn’t visit even next door. They couldn’t play jump rope together, or any type of ball game. Nor could little girls gather to play with their dolls. This was before television, but people did have radios.
