Kids could listen to radio, read books, though they couldn’t go to the library themselves. They couldn’t skate on the streets, nor congregate in a park. They were encouraged not to play with neighbors. Youths over sixteen could attend movies and take summer jobs, but younger children were required to stay at home, playing with brothers and sisters, but not with neighbors. I was isolated in my home, and since I had no siblings except my older sister, I spent that summer alone, listening to the radio and reading books from the library that my sister picked out for me. I did take over a lot of the housekeeping chores, and tried my hand at fixing supper every day for my family. Luckily I could call my mother if I didn’t know how to cook a dish.

Children in North Carolina and elsewhere were crippled by the illness. Sadly, many children contracted the disease and were paralyzed for the rest of their lives. It struck mostly children, but adults were also vulnerable. I could not attend movies. I could not go to church. I could not visit my friends in the neighborhood, nor could they come to play with me. I could not go to the Library to choose my own books to read. I could not run to the café on the corner to get a Popsicle or a chilled soft drink. Poliomyelitis was a crippling disease, and sometimes interfered with the ability to breathe, so that the iron lung, a breathing machine, was invented to help those people to live. It was no respecter of persons. Franklin Delano Roosevelt had suffered from this illness as a young man, but though he was restricted to a wheel chair he was elected President. Antibiotics as we know them today had not yet been discovered. There were no medicines that seemed to help the victims of the illness.

As the summer came to a close and the number of Poliomyelitis declined, schools were eventually opened and life began to go on again. At that time there were no antibiotics that would fight that illness, or any other serious illness.

Epidemic in North Carolin. Schools closed early, and didn’t open on time that year. There were no antibiotics to fight that illness, and those persons both old and young were paralysed. Not only could they not walk, they sometimes couldn’t use their arms, or even breathe without a machine to push air into their lungs. It was a devastating and terrible illness, and it struck children more often than adults—but adults could become victims of the disease also, though they were not as likely to catch it as children. It was a terrible epidemic, and many children in North Carolina were victims. It was in some situations the children died, in others they lost the use of their legs, and in other situations they were paralyzed all over, couldn’t move, and couldn’t even breathe without an iron lung, a contraption that forced oxygen into their lungs. This was the same illness that struck Franklin D. Roosevelt and left him unable to walk. Children died, or were paralyzed for the rest of their lives, and of course, adults were also vulnerable. Schools were closed early, and opened late, as the powers that be thought that the heat of summer, and the conditions under a hot sun had something to do with it. North Carolina had an epidemic. Parents were advised to keep their children away from their playmates, and certainly keep them out of crowds. Therefore, there were no movies for the kids, nor were gatherings such as Birthday Parties, or skating rinks, or swimming pools. I couldn’t even go to the library. My sister had to bring to me any books that I read that summer. She was old enough to be able to go into movie theatres, but I couldn’t go, and she obliged me by telling me the stories of the movies she was able to see. I could listen to the radio, and I could color in color books, and read library books. But I could not “go out to play” with other children.

gatherings of any kind that children were allowed to visit. School closed early, and children could not wander around their neighborhoods, or even go to church.

em were married, except my Dad. Then one day I was advised that Aunt Pauline, My Dad’s youngest sister, did get married. After she married she moved out of her parent’s house, and rented a house only a short walking distance away from the house she grew up in. Her house had a telephone, a radio, electricity, and running water. She also had a refrigerator, and an indoor bath room. It had a kitchen, a living room, a bed room, and an extra room. There was even a driveway beside it. I thought that was very nice—especially the radio. about worked outside the home. My Aunt Helen, for as long as I could remember, had been the cook in that house. She took care of the kitchen, but Aunt Martha helped her. Aunt Helen fed her chickens, her cats, and her dog. Uncle Eddie milked the cow and fed the pigs, and took corn kernels off the cobs so the chickens would grow fat enough to eat, or would lay lots of eggs. Since I was mostly at their house on Sundays, I never saw who took care of the garden where vegetables were grown, nor did I realize who planted or picked the cotton, or harvested the grain. My uncle seemed to be a fragile person, who probably weighed less than any of his sisters. Yet there was always corn in the corn crib, and tools in the tool shed, and the cows got milked, and fed, and so did the chickens and pigs. I was the cotton fields growing, and sometimes the corn field. I saw the water-melon patch. But it was always Sunday when I visited, and I didn’t see Uncle Eddie plowing the fields or reaping his crops. There was a well house, and a well in the back yard, with a pulley with a chain that hung over a wooden box, and if you turned a crank, you could pull up a fresh pail of water. The well house had a cement floor, and was shaded by a couple of trees. It was always cool inside it, and I never found out why, or how they did it, because they didn’t have any ice inside the well house. Despite the lack of electricity that small building was always cooler inside than it was outside. And it was always much, much, cooler than the kitchen, or even my grandmother’s sitting room, which was her bedroom, too.

When Grandmother, who was a tiny little woman, got out of her bed, she would walk about six steps to her rocking chair that had a cushion on the seat and there was also a pad on the back of the chair to make a soft pillow for her back. Grandmother could sit there, next to a window, and she could gently rock her chair, making no sound, and enjoy being out of bed. Often she had company on Sundays, and lots of people came to see her. 88888888888888888888888888888 on her backher cushioned rocking chair. Otherwise the room had a stove, a dresser with four drawers, and a big rocking chair for my Grandfather, and a couple of straight chairs that were just like the cane bottomed chairs that sat under the kitchen table. I still have two of those chairs, because when the house was sold my Dad took the old cane bottom chairs since Aunt Helen didn’t want them.

.than the yard outside. I didn’t even know who canned the fruit and vegetables to preserve them for the winter. But . . I didn’t know who cut and stacked the hay. There was always a cow or two, and Uncle Eddie was the one who milked the cow, but it was Aunt Helen who strained the milk and put it in a large jar. Then it was Uncle Eddie or Aunt Martha who took it to the well house to preserve it. In that house there was no ice box, and no refrigerator. My Yandle grandparents did not have electricity until I was nearly seventeen. They used kerosene lamps that were lit when it was near dark. but they were never lit until it was almost dark.

I don’t know where my Great-grandparents lived. My Dad never mentioned it. They may all have lived in the house where my Grandfather and Grandmother lived, but it , . There is now no one to ask about how those early families lived, and exactly where they lived. I heard stories, of course, that made me think that three generations might have lived together, but I don’t know where. When I sat in my Grandmother’s room and listened to people talk and reminisce I heard lots of stories. There were cousins who had known each other very well, played together, and worked together; however, they were no longer doing so. When I was a child we visited my Dad’s parents almost every Sunday, and often people came to see them to whom I was introduced, and the grownups talked to each other as if they knew each other really well. Most of those folks were cousins and most of them were my Dad’s age or older—but I was very young during that time, and people I saw perhaps only once or perhaps twice in my life didn’t stick forever after in my memory. I do remember that upon entering the house where my Grandparents lived I would often find visitors already in her room—visitors that were old, at least in my childish sight, and through the long afternoons I sat in my Grandmother Yandle’s room carefully listening as the adults rambled about things that had happened long ago, or sharing information about people whom all of them knew who were sick, or going on a trip, or being married, or sometimes having a new baby. I knew changes happened, and I also learned that they knew a lot of people I had never seen, and that they all actually enjoyed their chatter about people I didn’t even know. Sometimes they would mention old friends who were sick, or someone who had indicated that they were coming for a visit, or people whose children were marrying, or having babies, or needed to find jobs. I wished that I could listen to the radio, instead of trying to figure who, or what they were talking about.

I do remember that when electric power became available in that area, my Dad had electricity attached to their house, and from then on they had electric lights in every room. They finally did have a nice radio, but I could never listen to it because it sat in Grandmother’s room. When lots of people had come to talk to Grandmother, they did precisely that. They talked. Since there was only one radio and it was in Grandmother’s room, I missed an awful lot of Gene Autry programs every Sunday evening because the grownups preferred to talk.

Eventually, when I was well up in my teen years, My Dad’s family had a telephone installed in my Grandmother’s house. I don’t ever remember calling them on the phone, nor do I remember ever having a call from that house. As I remember, Pineville’s telephone lines once belonged to a private company, making calls to Pineville from Charlotte “long distance” and therefore expensive. Eventually Southern Bell bought that small company, and included it in the Charlotte area. Until that time Pineville family members rarely telephoned us, nor did we randomly chat with then. After Southern Bell bought the Pineville system, ordinary conversation between us was easier.
When we visited the Yandle house in Pineville, I do remember, from a very early age, that my Mother often encouraged me to remember that I had seen a person, especially if the person was old. Usually that person had not meant much to me—their being old and just sitting in the room with my Grandmother, and just talking, and laughing, about things that happened when they were children. But now I wish I had been wise enough to capture it all in my mind, with clear understanding of who was involved in the many episodes they talked about, and where that particular action occurred. For instance there was a story my Dad told of a neighbor who didn’t like young boys to get too close to his house or his animals, but did have a very tempting recreational object close to his house. He had a large grapevine dangling from a tall tree, enticingly near a creek. He didn’t like boys to come onto his property, and lots of little boys, including my Dad and his friends, liked to swing on that vine and wade in that creek quite near to his house. It was long years before movies and Tarzan stories were shown on the big screen, but children didn’t need to watch movie stories about jungles to realize what fun it would be to swing over the creek on that vine, and jump into the cooling water. Once I heard the story, I wished I knew where that place was so I could swing on it too. But the old gentleman who lived in that house would chase the boys away, and then tell their parents so that they would be punished. Then one day the boys—probably all cousins—wandered by that old man’s house and discovered that he was not at home. So they had a swinging, splashing, good time until the owner returned home, and promptly tattled on them to their parents.

The elderly gentleman lived alone, and apparently liked it that way. However, there was another day when the old man didn’t seem to be at home. The boys came into his yard, and upon finding that he was away, and then the boys decided to “get even” for his meanness. They felt justified, as they were not just “little” kids, and they weren’t hurting anything by swinging on the vine. They only wanted to play on this wonderful vine. On other occasions they had all been frightened by the old fellow’s anger. Because they saw no harm in their vine swinging, they resented the old man’s objection to their play. One day they tried again, and their reconnaissance showed that, indeed, the old gentleman was not at home. The boys talked it over, and planned revenge. That day there were three of them. They each tied strings around both their ankles making the legs of their overalls a sort of bag—and they filled the legs of their overalls with dry sand from the creek bank until it was difficult for them to walk. Then they went through the unlocked door of that old man’s house, and loosed the strings, so that as they moved around the floor within the house they sifted sand onto his floor. All over his house the floor was covered with sand. The boys didn’t take anything, nor break anything. Even so, the old man could figure out who left him such a message. Unfortunately the boys, at least three of them, were immediately suspected as the culprits, so they didn’t get away with it, and the boys got a whipping. However, they didn’t feel ashamed, either, and when my Dad told that story, he laughed, as if their revenge was still sort of satisfactory to him because the old man had run them off when they were having innocent fun swinging over the creek on his grapevine.

Among the stories my mother told were a few that were almost heart-breaking. Mother had a little brother, and when he began to walk she played with him. He became ill, and though his family and the Pineville Doctor did everything they could to help him, he died. My Mother had loved him, and all through her growing years, and after she was married, she kept a small china boy figurine because it had been her little brother’s toy. Today, I have that small china figurine in a cabinet with other keepsakes, and remember a sister’s love for her younger brother, and also I think of the fragility of life, and say a prayer of thanksgiving that today there are medicines, and antibiotics, and trained doctors with great knowledge. That we do not live in a perfect world cannot be disputed, but I am increasingly thankful for the medical profession and their skills that save lives, and help people to stay well and enjoy life and the living of it.

There was a family near the farm of my maternal Grandparents, and when my mother was still only a girl child, she felt sorry for children who had no clothes. One family in particular caught at her heart—for there was a child she particularly pitted because he was always naked. He had no clothes. Mother was probably about eleven or twelve years old. She made clothes for that child, and gave them to him. I don’t know what kind of cloth she used, and she didn’t name the child. However she had cut out the garment and sewed it by hand, and given the clothing to the child. At intervals for some time afterwards she made him clothes to wear.

My mother was the youngest child in her family, with two older brothers and an older sister. When she, herself, had been very young, there had been a younger child, a little brother, who lived to be about three years old. The boy child suffered an illness that took his life. She told me about him when I was a child, and pointed out that in a drawer of her dresser there was a small china figure of a little boy in blue pants with a brown cap on his head. The little figure had been the toy of Mother’s little brother, and she had kept it all of those years as a precious remembrance. When I married she gave the little boy figurine to me, and I have it yet, and cherish it. My Mother had treasured that remembrance of her little brother, and so I treasured it, too. I thought about that very young child who died so very young. It was a reminder to me at an early age that no one is guaranteed a long life. Life, my Dad once said, is never guaranteed. Always, he told me, live it fully every day—we are not promised another day.

Because I was six years younger than my sister we didn’t play together. There were few children my age in our neighborhood, though my sister had always seemed to have lots of playmates. There never seemed to be any who were my age to play with. When I was about three years old there was suddenly a little girl for me to play with, and not only was she my age, she had the same name as me. I had a friend, a neighbor, at last. When we heard a grownup call “Jean” we didn’t know which of us was being called, so our families called us by both first and last names. I hadn’t known before that people could have the same names. It was a novelty, and didn’t disturb either of us. We both enjoyed playing together, and did so every day. Both of us became used to the idea that she was Jean Orr (full name), and I was Jean Yandle (full name) and neither of us saw anything odd about it. I don’t think Jean Orr had anyone else to play with, and my sister had always had two words in her name—she was called Ella Cornelia. I suppose I thought all children had long names.

Our tight friendship endured for a couple of years, then one day she didn’t come out to play, and her Aunt Ponnie told me she had “gone away.” I was very sad. We had both been without other playmates, and we were not only best friends, we were only friends for each other. She had not told me goodbye, or even told me she was going. I asked my mother where she went. My mother said she was sick and when she was well she could come home. But she didn’t come home until both of us had reached twelve or thirteen. So far as I could understand, she just went away, and she didn’t live with her Aunt Ponnie any more. I was very lonely for a while, but life went on.

I explained that we lived in a duplex, and that between our side of the house, and the people who lived in the other half of our house, there was a single wall. When I lived next door to us

We both grew up, of course, and one day someone told me that Jean Orr was living with her Mother only about half a mile away from me. The apartment her mother rented was about a mile away from my house, and to get there I had to walk alone. Her Mother was never at home when I visited her. We usually had a fine time together, but on one visit we, as children do upon a occasions, disagreed. I was quite upset about the disagreement, and went home. When I next wanted to visit her, she and her mother had moved. After her address changed I lost touch with her. I was living in the same house I had lived in almost all of my life, and the back yard of her Aunt Ponnie still adjoined the back yard of my parents, however Jean and I did not meet again for years. Some years later and after my marriage and the birth of our first child, I went shopping in the Sears Roebuck store. I paused for a moment to look at merchandise, a small blond haired clerk spoke to me. She asked me if I was Jean Yandle. I, she said, am Jean Orr. Both of us were married and both had children. The bond that had held us together as very small children made the meeting a lovely moment, but after all the years we had been separated, we had little in common as adults, and were never again as close as we had been as small children.

The reason Jean had been taken away from her Aunt was, to my way of thinking, a terrible and frightening situation. She was not only a very young child, she was a very small little person. How it came about, I never knew, but she was examined by a physician who took an X-ray of her chest, and found a lung anomaly. In those days—the 1930’s—there were no antibiotics at all. In the United States there had been—and still was—a deadly disease that spread easily among family members and among any, and sometimes all, the people with whom the sick person came into contact. The name of the illness was tuberculosis, and was generally called simply TB. People who had the disease could spread it with a cough and most people who contracted the disease never got well, and most of the time any body who spent much time around them also contracted the fatal disease. There were no medicines that could curb it, and not much hope that those afflicted would ever recover. There was always a chance that people they had been in close contact with would also be infected with the disease. Eventually the government required people who contracted TB had to be quarantined in a facility that was like a hospital. However, almost all of the patients had the same disease. They were compelled to stay there until they were either cured, or they died.

Because a chest x-ray showed “something” in her lungs, the powers that be sent her to a tuberculosis hospital, though she didn’t actually have tuberculosis. She was not released for a number of years, and she never did have tuberculosis. She was at least twelve years old when she was allowed to return to Charlotte. She had attended school classes in the TB Sanitorium. But she had been in a sort of hospital for all those years, away from her family. I couldn’t even imagine how lonely and how different that would be. She told me a little bit about her life in that place. I felt terribly sad about what I heard; that anyone could be taken from their home, and could be kept in a sort of prison—at least they couldn’t leave even if they wanted to leave. She had been no more than about four years old when she was placed in that hospital.

Of course there were no antibiotics in those days to “cure” any illness. TB was catching. It was extremely easy to spread that terrible illness form person to person. People died from it. I had never before heard of anyone who had TB that had lived very long after they contracted it. I am not sure when Jean was released. She did not have the disease, she had never had the disease, but she had spent a large part of her childhood cooped up in a hospital with sick people whose illness was of the sort that ended in death more often than in healing. She began to live in the world again when we were about twelve years old. I learned later that she had married, and had a lovely family. We had been very close friends so long ago, long before we were of school age. It was some years before I found another friend with whom I could share so much of my life.

My sister had always seemed to have had five or six “friends” to play with any time she went out of the door. When I was old enough to interact with other children there were none exactly my age. Marian Kanasas, the sister of little Pete, the child who broke the three-center bottle that cut my wrist, was just enough older than me that, for her, interacting with me was to be friends with someone much younger than herself, therefore making her reduce her games and pastimes to my level, since it was probably impossible for me to climb past my own age into her level of maturity. The only children Marian’s age were male, and for me, it was just as it was for Marian—we had no neighborhood friends to with whom we could play.

little boy who broke the bottle that cut my hand When I was five years old I was alert enough quite early in my life to realize that city life differed from the way my grandparents lived just twelve miles away from my house. They didn’t have electric power, or water spigots in their houses, and they didn’t have indoor bathrooms. My Aunt Ola didn’t have a telephone for years after I was married. Their lives didn’t seem to be harmed by these lacks, nor did our lives seem to be terribly enriched by our position.

City blocks in the 1930’s in Charlotte, especially in neighborhoods that had been measured into square blocks with carefully measured streets along which electricity marched enclosed in tightly wrapped electric lines that hung on tall poles that also held telephone lines. that that were all about the same size, however different or however much alike they were. Most of the housing where I grew up was fairly neat, and furnished with running water and sewage pipes, with nominal electricity, and in some cases natural gas lines for stoves and hot . We lived with “modern” type fixtures the architecture were neatly were nice and square, and the houses were fairly close to each other. were two families who lived “next” to our house, if you can count the fact that their back doors opened onto a narrow yard next to a driveway beside my house. I felt well blessed to have one child close to my age as my play mate. However, our relationship was

She even had the same name as me. Then she went away. There I was on a street where there were two little girls just a little younger than me, and another girl who was about three or four years older than me. There weren’t any other kids on the block. The kids closest to my age had almost nothing in common with me. I was older, and had to teach them how to play. They had not learned to “imagine” things. Therefore, I was always the one to make the plans, and lay out the games. They seldom ever disputed me. I had skates, but they didn’t. I had a swing on my porch—but you can be happy swinging only so long. After a while it becomes sort of boring. There were no see-saws, no nice sand piles, no lovely shade trees under which to play dolls, and they didn’t have any nice dolls, anyway. Those years were the late 1930’s and the early 1940’s. Remember that there was no television, and precious little radio that appealed to children. None of us had swings or see-saws in our yard. None of us had either tricycle or bicycle. Then when I was about ten years old I had skates, and they were wonderful—but my younger friends didn’t have skates so I had to skate alone.
88888888888888888888888 Don’t think that times were the same then as now. They weren’t. We were certainly not the only kids in the country who didn’t have a swing in our back yard. The Depression had happened before I was born. I never was hungry, nor did I ever lack good clothes or shoes. I had occasional treats like ice cream on a stick, or a little paper cup full of ice cream, and we lived in a comfortable house. There was a café on the corner of Graham and Eleventh streets, just down the block on which we lived. It was run by a neighbor who was born in Greece, named Mr. Kanasas. He spoke English, with an accent. Greek man sold an interesting drink called “Three Center” which was a poor man’s Coke, as a Coca Cola cost five cents for six ounces, and Three Center had a deceptive bottle that looked as big as a Coke bottle, but was really just thicker, and held about four ounces, and cost three cents.

Sometimes even a nickel was a lot of money tled drink, probably a that came in a thick glass bottle called the “Three Center,” which cost exactly three pennies. It tasted a little bit like a cola. It was sold at the café on the corner of our street. The man who ran the café was born in Greece, though he spoke English with a Greek accent. Dave Kanasas lived on Pine Street with his wife and three children. Their back yard was parallel to our back yard, and my Dad rented a double garage on their property in which to park his truck, and he could use the driveway beside our house to enter the garage.

The Kanasas family had three children, an older boy close to my sister’s age, a girl just a little older that me, but younger than my sister, and a younger boy several months younger than me. The youngest boy was named Pete. Marian sometimes played with me, but not often, as she was several years older than me. I noticed that she seldom played with her little brother, Pete. I didn’t like to play with him either. I was well aware that Pete was sometimes quite mean. I have a scar to prove it.

I was not quite six years old the day Pete invited me to play with him in his yard. He felt lonely, as I did, because there were no other children exactly our ages to play together. The bottom of our back yard touched the side of Pete’s back yard, and his Daddy had a double garage at the bottom of his yard which my Dad rented. My Dad’s business truck—he was a painting contractor—was loaded with valuable drop-cloths, brushes, paint cans, ladders, and other important stuff, and Daddy needed a garage to keep people from steeling from his truck during t 8888888888888888888888888888888888 he night. The Kanasas family had no car, but they had a two car garage, so my Dad rented their garage space. Our back yards touched each other, and my Dad rented the garages at the bottom of the Pete’s back yard . Pete’s house to park his car and his painter’s truck. One spring day Pete invited me to come over to play with him. He had taken one of my Dad’s empty five gallon paint buckets that had been left near the garage, and Pete was using it to play with. He turned it upside down, and then topped the bucket with a wide board that had once been the top of his sister’s play-table. One of the most wonderful toys a child could have was a pretend tea table. Of course children could use it for a writing table or desk—and the tables were usually sold with at least two small chairs for children to sit in. The table top Pete was playing with had no legs. He carefully laid it across the five gallon paint bucket, and invited me to sit with him. I remember that at first I refused, accusing him of trying to trick me so he could make me fall to the ground. He earnestly begged me to join him—him on one end, me on the other, so both of us could sit and talk. He promised to warn me before he jumped off the table. I fell for his plea after he promised, and I sat with him for a short period of time and we talked. Suddenly, Pete jumped off the unbalanced table top, causing me to slide off the other end. My fall would have been aggravating but not really important had there not been another “toy” that Pete had invented just behind our paint can and table top. Several bricks lay on the ground in the same vicinity, and close to them was a discarded soda bottle. Those were the days when the entire United States was still reeling from the Depression. Many people could neither buy groceries nor pay their rent. Six ounce Coca Cola was for sale by the bottle for five cents. But there was also a “look-alike” carbonated drink called a Three-Center—meaning that it cost three cents, and the bottle held less than six ounces and didn’t taste as good as real Coca Cola. Pete’s Dad sold Three Centers. tasty than a Coke, . It was not as tasty as Coca Cola, and there were fewer ounces in its thick glass bottle

not even buy groceries no three-center bottle lay. A small amount of a Coca Cola-type drink was sold for three cents, and was bottled in a similar shaped bottle that was so thick the contents looked much the same, but there were less than six ounces in the Three-Center bottle that held the drink was about the size of a six ounce Coca Cola. The bottle was very thick to make the drink inside appear to be as large as a Coca Cola. twice as thick as the Cola bo worth of a There were several bricks lying on the ground. There was also a Three-Center bottle near by. The Three-Center bottle was like many of the earliest bottles holding colas and beers—they were thick, so that they would look like a very generous cola type drink, but were actually a much smaller amount. It cost only three cents—and that is why it was called a “Three Center”. Just before we both sat on the table top on top of the bucket, Pete had used a brick to whack at a three-center bottle, and had broken it into several thick pieces of glass. Then he sat with me on the table top and we talked a little, and he suddenly, without warning, hopped off and I slid off the tilted table top onto the glass bottle, with one hand thrown out beside me to break my fall. It did, but the patch of ground under my hand was the place where the Three Center bottle had been broken. When I got up, blood was flowing quickly from my left wrist, across my palm, through my fingers, and down onto the ground. It was not a tiny skinned place that shed a few drops—it was a artery through which my fearful heart was pumping blood with terrifying speed. It was pouring off my hand onto the ground, and splashing on my dress. I screamed—and my mother heard me. She rushed into the yard, picked me up and hurried me into the house. She caught up my sister’s clean pajamas to catch the blood, put a rubber band around my wrist as a tourniquet. Somehow she called the doctor who had saved my sister’s life when she was sick, and—believe it or not—he came in his own automobile to get me when he heard that I was bleeding so copiously and my mother had no way to take me to him—therefore he honked, mother carried me out to his car, and he drove less than a mile back to his office. He carried me in, and sewed up my wrist. I remember wearing a bandage, and I remember having to visit the doctor again to have the stitches removed. It has been more than seventy years since then, and I remember every one of those stitches to this day. I also have a puffed scar that has puzzled physicians I have visited, and caused people I went to work for to ask if I had tried to commit suicide. I still have the scar, and I guess people still wonder how I got it. But it was every bit Pete’s fault. And I never trusted him anymore. I was never ugly to him, and I often visited his older sister, but I didn’t play with Pete again for years, and not very often, then. I did wonder if he actually didn’t remember what happened that day, or didn’t think his actions caused me to cut my wrist. I wondered if he ever told his mother what happened. I don’t ever remember actually trusting him ever again, though he did join me and another boy who was about my age with a few games of cowboy and Indian, but I remained wary of Pete. One of our neighbors had a grandson about my age that I played cowboys with, and Pete joined our game once in a while. The three of us had fun together, but I never placed myself in our cowboy game so that Pete could hurt me, or cause me to get hurt. There was an old motto: Once bitten, twice shy.

My full name was Iris Jean, but for years Mother and Daddy usually called me only “Jean”. I thought that a bit strange, since she almost always called my sister Ella Cornelia—the entire name, while I was not called Iris Jean, but just Jean. I never asked the question when I was small, but one day when I was a teenager I asked my Mother why my sister was always called her full name, when I was called simply Jean. She told me that she and Daddy had decided that since my sister was named after both her grandmothers they could not honor one grandmother above the other, so they always called her by both names. I understood that my parents could not “drop” one name making the other Grandmother feel left out. I was probably about eight years old when I asked about why my name had only one syllable and my sister’s had at least five. If I was called Iris Jean, my full name, I would have at least three syllables in my name. I was told that it was easier to call me Jean, and it wouldn’t do to call her by only one of her two names as that would be honoring one Grandparent more than the other. Of course I understood. It was perfectly clear. My sister was worth the extra breath to say her full name. I wasn’t worth the effort, so I remained just plain Jean. Strangely, it didn’t make me bitter, nor did it cause me to dislike my sister. However, I was acutely aware that my sister, and her wants, were more important to my parents than my wants. I realized that If we both needed shoes, she would get hers first. If Mother was making both of us dresses, hers would be finished first. When my sister wanted something—anything—she was quite likely to get it. If I asked for something, it was suggested that I do some extra chores to “earn” whatever it was. Despite the discrepancy, I was never without clothing, or shoes, or any thing else. I was never hungry, nor left out if treats were being served. I felt loved—but I always knew that my sister got first choice, and most of the time was she was first in line when both of us could expect a new dress, or anything else.

There was a day when I had another lesson about who was important in our family. When I was old enough to notice the difference in our names, I suggested to my mother that since my sister was called by her entire name that I, also, should be called Iris Jean—not just Jean, a one syllable word. My Mother explained about the two grandmothers, one of whom would be unhappy if her name was dropped from the double name—the honor was for both of them. Her name could not be shortened. I, of course, understood perfectly. They loved her much more than they loved me. I was, somehow, inferior to my sister. I accepted it, and did what I had heard brave people say: Grin and bear it!

It was very simple. They liked my sister better than me. My sister was already in high school, doing things that were, in my estimation, like “grown-up” things. I wasn’t stupid, and I did have a memory. Easter was quite near, and both of us usually had new shoes just before Easter. I had been saving dimes to pay for my Easter shoes. Our Uncle Eddie, our Dad’s brother, gave me a dime every Sunday, and I had filled a $5.00 dime bank that Mother said could be spent on Easter Shoes. I felt proud that I could help pay for Easter shoes. One day we went shopping. Mother took both me and my sister to Belks Department Store to get new shoes. She bought Ella Cornelia’s shoes in the large shoe department, and I saw her hand my dime bank to the lady to pay for my sister’s shoes. Ella Cornelia now had her Easter shoes. I didn’t mind her having her shoes. I took my shoes off so that I could try on my shoes. My Mother told me we were going to a different store to buy my shoes, so I put my shoes back on, and we went to “Little Belks” which was where they sold items that didn’t sell at regular prices in the “Big” store. My mother picked out some cheap white sandals for me, and those were my Easter shoes. I remember that I didn’t cry. I remember that I resented the fact that my dimes were used on my sister, and I was supposed to be happy with cheap sandals. That was undeniable proof that I was not as lovable as my sister. I didn’t matter very much to anybody—but my sister deserved the best, even if it was my money, and I could always make do with cheap stuff. I said nothing, and I did not cry. I did wonder why I was not as lovable, nor as important as my sister.

. When I was very young my aunts would call me Iris Jean—two names. But that wore off early, and by the time I was five or six everybody called me simply “Jean.” Sometimes my mother even called me “Jimmy.” One day I asked her why. My mother said it was because, had I been a boy my name would have been James. It made me sad to think that I my Mother was sorry that I had not been the boy child she wanted. And I tried hard to be strong—stronger than most girls, and able to do things that, had I been a boy, I could have done with ease. I also tried for most of my childhood to lift the heavy chores onto my shoulders if possible. My sister was often treated as if she was especially fragile. She looked quite healthy, and could boss me around with vigor. However she was subject to short illnesses at times, and my Mother was careful that she did not every overdo any activity she chose to pursue. Mother treated her as

Therefore, I deliberately took on the heavy chores. I carried the coal for the stove into the house, and took out the ashes. I killed the chickens that would be our Sunday dinner. I split the kindling for the fires, and I carried the groceries home from the store. I looked after any pets we had, and mopped the kitchen when it needed it. I did not want to disappoint my mother if she needed someone strong. We were, both of us, satisfied that God didn’t make mistakes, and we were sort of stuck with the fact that I was female. However, while my sister was a girly sort of girl, I was always a tomboy, and half of my playmates after my seventh birthday were male. We played cowboys. And we had “horses” to ride. Since my Dad was a painting contractor, he sometimes had access to barrels. I don’t remember where he got them, but he had two that were in constant use, and a couple more that just sat in the back yard. With a brick on both sides of a barrel to hold it steady as it lay on lengthwise, we had “horses” so we could ride to the rescue of each other. I rode a million miles on my oil drum. Of course, I enjoyed every minute of my many rides. My playmates were mostly Pete Kanasas whose backyard touched our back yard, and an older boy named Bobby who lived across the street from Pete’s house. We three rode countless miles across empty praeries upon our barrel horses, fought bad guys together, and rescued many an Indian who would forever be our friend, and when there was a real race to do good for someone, I was always in front. If we split our trio into both good and bad guys, I usually insisted that I be the “good” guy, and only once in a while did I agree to be the “bad” guy. As the “good” guy I always came in the nick of time to save them from the imaginary bad guys. However, I generously allowed them to “save” me once in a while.

Because I was six years younger than my sister, and there were few children my age in our neighborhood, I had few playmates. My sister had always seemed to have had five or six “friends” to play with. When I was old enough to interact with other children I felt well blessed to have a child close to my age as my play mate. My full name was Iris Jean, but Mother and Daddy usually called me only “Jean”. Strangely, I thought, since she almost always called my sister Ella Cornelia—the entire name—though I was mostly called simply Jean. My aunts would call me Iris Jean—two names. Sometimes my mother even called me “Jimmy.” One day I asked her why. My mother said it was because, had I been a boy my name would have been James. It made me sad to think that I my Mother was sorry that I had not been the boy child she wanted. And I tried hard to be strong—stronger than most girls, and able to do things that, had I been a boy, I could have done with ease.

grandfather suggested that all the Yandles were probably descended from the same family group, however, reading and writing skills were much less precise in those days, and writers were not always actually skilled in making clear letters or using correct spelling. Many of the brave people who left England, or other European countries were bold and courageous, though not usually actual scholars.

My Dad told me that a group of people, brothers, cousins, and their wives and their siblings came from England in the 1800’s. One was brothers with the name Yandle came across the ocean from England along with their families in the first half of the 19th Century. One of them was Milas Milton Yandle There is very little real information about who they were, and where they settled, and exactly and though they didn’t all settle in the South, nor did they all settle in the same towns, most of them settled in the Pineville area

As a child I learned that four Yandle brothers came to the new world which eventually became the United States. Some of them may have gone to the Philadelphia area, and others came into the Carolinas. I do not know for what reason the Yandles decided to leave England, but Milas Milton Yandle was born

but not everyone knew how to read and write in those days, and therefore spelling from one area of the world was generally somewhat different in other areas, even if words sounded the same. Therefore, when in the early days of the 1800’s, many people left Europe, and specifically England, to begin new lives in America, not all the people were well educated.

In the first half of the 1800’s people in England, Ireland, and Scotland, often immigrated to America in large family groups. Some years before the War Between the States there was such a time when two families, with the surnames of Yandle and Johnston, entered America. Not all of them immigrated to the same area of America, and not all of them chose the South to be their home territory. However there was a group of people who crossed the Atlantic from England or Ireland to America and either before they left Ireland, or fairly soon after they landed in America, a bunch of them married each other, though some of them probably married before they left England or Ireland. So there were Yandle families and Johnston families who were brothers and sisters and cousins and who settled within the Carolinas not far from the Catawba River. There were at least Four Yandle families and about that many Johnstons

—there were then new families who’s offspring would be double first cousins. in the early 1800’s with a surname of Johnston, and another bunch who seemed to be members of either a large family of Yandles or a large family of Johnstons, both families with males and females who liked and trusted each other because some were married before they sailed to the New World, and some married pretty soon after they landed. There were at least four grownup Yandle men, and about that many grownup Johnston men, and a bunch of females of marriageable age in both groups. . Some were already married to each other, and some married connected by seemed There was Yandle male who settled in the North with his family, and several of them , part of the new entered at the same time, but all of them They didn’t come all at one time, some into the South, and some into the North. . , along with their children and cousins and in groups of husbands and wives came to America and settled in various parts of the new nation. Some members of the family had come earlier, and were already settled in the Philadelphia area. However, the later group came into the Carolinas. Some scattered beyond the Catawba River into area where the town of Mt Holly was located, and others chose to set up their farms and homes closer to Charlotte, some on North Carolina land, and others on land that eventually became South Carolina. on , and scattered settled on bo Northern part of America in already large cities like Pennsylvania, and a little later another large group of the same people settled in the South.
eneral because at some point in the first half of the 1800’s a bunch of people came to America from England, and a goodly number of them had been Johnstons, and a close to matching number of them were Yandles. Some of the Johnston women were married to Yandle men, and some of the Yandle women were married to Johnston men. There were at least four Yandle brothers. They mostly settled in the Carolinas, but some of them went into settled cities in the North, and at least one member of the family went West, all the way to California. I remember that my Grandmother Yandle, who’s maiden name was Johnston, went with her parents on a very long train ride when she was a child. They crossed the United States from the Pineville area to California in search of her uncle and his family. They had driven across the United States to San Francisco in a covered wagon—parents and children. Letters had come frequently for a time, but after the San Francisco earthquake the family did not hear from the people who had reached San Francisco before the earthquake. The family members were never found—not them, nor any of their possessions. A search was made for their wagon, and the horses that pulled it, as well as for the family members themselves. However no trace of them was every found, and my Grandmother and her parents returned home to North Carolina..

d by the earthquake. that had and The group probably had and brought with them before the War Between the States there were at least four brothers named Yandle who came to America from England. It seemed that the Yandles had very strong ties to another family with the surname Johnston. Johnston men married Yandle women, and Yandle men married Johnston women and a bunch of Yandles and Johnstons who were married to each other came to America about the same time. My grandmother, Ella Johnston, married Amos Yandle, and Amos’ mother was also a Johnston. Amos’s father

father was also a Yandle, and several of the Yandles were married to women named Johnston. some of them married into another strong family with the surname Johnston. The Yandle’s and the Johnston’s intermarried frequently enough that by the time that I was born, in 1931, there were lots of Johnston cousins whose families also had settled not only in Pineville, Charlotte, or Mount Holly, but in the same general area, and many of them settled in small towns near the Catawba River, or at least not far from the great river. women was named Johnston. There were some Johnstons married to Yandle women, but there were a few of the Johnston’s who their cousins, their sistersthe same name, that we were not the only people with that name. There were other students in Bethune School who were Yandles, except they spelled it differently. Most of the Yandles I met were not my exact age, nor did the older ones know anyone in my family. Sometimes they spelled their names differently—such as Yandell, or Yeandal—however none of those seemed to know members of my family.
started to went to school in Charlotte, N.C. that I wasn’t the only Yandle in my school. The name was not as popular as Smith, or Jones, but there were at least three other students with that name attending Harding High School, and though the kinship was especially close, and the spelling was not exactly the same (some were Yandall) I decided that they all came from a well represented bunch of Yandles who migrated from England in the early 1800’s. Not all of them entered the Southern part of the country, as at least one of them was as far away as Philadelphia. However, there were three or four brothers, ( and perhaps a few cousins) who, with their families, crossed the sea at close to the same time, and settled in upper South Carolina, and in North Carolina. They all tried to settle close to where a river flowed, and they were mostly farmers, though one of them was a store-keeper. The store-keeper was my Great-Grandfather—the father of my Grandfather.

Of course, I never knew my Great-Grandfather, but I did hear stories about him. He was a store-keeper, and once he was established, he discovered that even the “new” continent with a “new” kind of government could have troubles, and deep disagreements. He was smack-dab in the middle of the War Between the States. Think how it would be if and the depression caused when the white men went to war to protect their “rights.” The South had lots of people who did not want to free their slave laborers—not because they hated them, nor because they thought them less than human—but because if slaves were free, they could demand wages, and better housing, and better treatment out in the fields. If landowners were forced to accommodate them in order to keep their own way of life, everything would change. Great houses would be too costly, and the easy way of life “rich” families could demand—when they had not been obliged even to comb their own hair—would truly disappear. choress of work their own being part of their everyday lifeThe cheap, rough, inadequate housing they had been allowed as slaves, and the would have to be improved or they would be free to seek jobs elsewhere.

The economy of the South, where cotton was “King” and the constant labor required to plant, nurture, and harvest that crop could not be maintained without the slaves, the entire economy of the area failed. The rich became paupers, the slaves became jobless in large numbers, and their plight—no homes, no jobs, no friends, no food, no hope—most of them were not really better off as free people than they had been as slaves, and many of them did whatever they had to do to stay alive and protect their families. Like all mistreated folk, some of them turned in anger to “paying back” all the punishment they had endured. Many traveled north where they might be able to find real paying jobs, and some few traveled to the west hoping to be able to home-stead. en they demanded clothing, food, and shelter from at they had to do to survive. fields As free men and women they would want more than the clothes on their backs, and furnishing their needs in addition to paying a salary would ruin the land owner, who would no longer be able to afford the upkeep of his house and property. Without huge fields his income would diminish, and if another plantation could afford higher wages, his devastate the land owner’s way of life. As slaves, their workers could be denied more than absolute necessities—and could “make do” with the bareness of their lives. The field workers would, as free men, have a day off, or work only a certain number of hours each day, however, as slaves they were compelled to work from sunrise to dark, six days a week without a real break. Even children could be put to work as soon as they were able to follow directions. Both girl and boy children and all the slave women could be sexually abused by white men without the right to refuse. In almost every instance

their own way of life to be compelled to compensate those who worked in their fields. No one could afford to pay enough workers to sow, work, and pick cotton and the other farm products it took to keep the Southern farmers and their families on the scale they enjoyed at that time? If they were forced to pay enough to support the field hands, even if they did not live as richly as their owners now lived, it would still bankrupt the land-owners. If wages had to be paid the cotton fields would not bring enough money to sustain the plantation.

As a small , and settled into the new continent Not all of them chose the Carolinas, but several did, and several brothers along with their wives and families settled close to Fort Mill, and Pinville. When the Carolinas were separated, there were Yandles in both Carolinas. and —and my paternal ancestors, My Dad, Leroy Samuel Yandle, was born in 1896. My mother, Minnie Parks Yandle, was born in 1902. I was born in 1931, and my husband, Robert Erskine Beatty, was born in 1925.

The Yandle family immigrated to the United States from England, and We have grandchildren who were born near the turn of the century in the late 1990’s, and both Grandchildren, and Great-grandchildren that were born after the year 2000. Of late I have thought about the many dynamic changes that have occurred, both in our family, and in the world in which we live, in the span of the lives of me and my husband. It is staggering to see the differences from the time settlers first arrived in America and the way it was a few years later. They came in small sailing ships—not a lot larger than a fishing boat of today, but without motors. They had only sails, and very little room for privacy. They would travel for weeks to arrive on the new continent. What they found in the earliest days once they had was at first just endless water, waves, wind, and lots of sky. When they arrived in the new world, they found sand, trees, and sometimes a few Indians. Later, when more people had come from England, when homes of a sort had been built, when there was law and order and some settled people who had planted, or even reaped their fields, life became a little easier. This new world was still not inhabited with very many Europeans or English citizens.

People came with almost nothing except the clothes they wore, perhaps a few tools and seeds to plant for their food. Sometimes the clothing they wore was almost all they owned. The earlier efforts were not nearly as well prepared as most of the later arrivals. It is amazing what the earliest folk accomplished with so little in the way of tools and equipment. As more ships came, and more goods were delivered, theactually did were able to achieve. When more ships came, with more goods, and more settlers, A little later there were all those horse drawn wagons that carried people to where they needed to go in the days of my Great-grandfather. Of course, when I was a child, I never dwelled on the circumstances of my forebears, or that my grandparents had once been young, though of course, all of them were. I knew both my grandfathers as men who wore overalls, blue ones. I saw my Yandle Grandfather as someone who didn’t play games with me, not at all. He did not converse with me. He was an old man with white hair, and a white, sticky mustache. He was very hard of hearing, and seldom understood anything I said to him, though he seemed to be trying hard to listen. I saw pictures of him in a suit, with vest and coat, however I, my self, usually saw him in blue shirt, blue overalls, and in the winter, sox and shoes. In summer when he was relaxing on the porch, he was always bare footed. id not see him myself in I never saw dressed in anything except blue shirts and blue overalls, and both with and without shoes and socks—he didn’t wear shoes inside the house in warm weather. When I was small I thought it was un polite to trapse into the house to see Grandmother, and leave him alone with the flies on the porch, so I tried to keep him company, and talk to him. That, of course was a problem all it’s own since he was profoundly deaf. He usually said not a word to me. He sat there, killing flies. He never conversed with me, and I didn’t know what to say to him. If I told him something, he didn’t say anything back. One day he saw me take my mother’s purse out of the car and take a nickel out of it. She had given me permission, and I took only the nickel she said I could have—and he said to me, “I saw you!” Therefore I told him my Mother had given me permission. When we got home that night I told Mother what he said, and she told me that he had gone into the sitting room and had told her what I had done. He was trying to keep me on track—and did not want me to be able to sneak money out of my Mother’s purse. Looking at that occurrence now, I can see that he thought he was doing me a favor, so that I would not learn to steal. I guess I should have been grateful that he cared that much about keeping me straight; however I was a little miffed that he even suspected that I would actually steal from my own Mother. Later that day Mother told me that when I went to the service station to get a popsicle he had told her I took a nickel. She told him I had permission. It annoyed me that he would think I would steal. But Mother said he meant it for good, and I didn’t stay mad at him. Grandfather’s feet sometimes swelled up, especially in the summer, and when they did, he took off his shoes because they hurt his feet. I never saw him wear anything more than overalls, but there were family pictures of him wearing a suit and standing near an automobile. By the time I was old enough to recognize him every time I saw him, his hair was white, and he had a white mustache, wore denim overalls, with blue shirts, and in winter wore black shoes. Most of my life when I visited in Summer-time he sat on the porch on a straight backed kitchen chair, and he always had a fly swatter in his hand, both feet bare and on the floor, and looking for flies—with fly swatter in hand. When he had been there for a while, he would be surrounded by a carpet of dead flies, spreading as far out around his chair as he and the fly swatter could reach. From a distance it would look like he had a black colored rug on the porch floor beneath his feet.

Grandfather Yandle was not talkative. He did have a strong determination about what he should do, or what he simply did not do. When he had something to say, he said it loud and clear. If he had no questions, nor any information to impart, he sat quietly. For the length of Spring, Summer, and early Fall, Grandfather Yandle worked in the fields if he was needed, or he sat on the porch if the weather permitted. It seemed to me that he wished for a little privacy, perhaps even needed quiet time. Therefore he simply stayed out of the way of people when he was not needed to help them. Not necessarily avoiding them, but giving both his wife and children, and himself, a little privacy. Grandfather Yandle did not tease me, or tell me jokes. If I sat with him, even if I talked, he did not always reply, nor did he ask silly questions. I think now, that I enjoyed talking all I wanted to while he listened. At home I had lots of competition since I had an older sister.

eldom though he loved them, and worked hard for them. He differed from my Parks Grandfather in that he no longer attended church. I am convinced that he did not because he didn’t really have a way to get to the church that was about two miles from his house. it would have been very hard for him since only Aunt Pauline had an automobile, and since she was working five days a week, and also needed to spend some time with her invalid mother. He, himself did not have a buggy, and his church was more than a mile and a half away from his house. My father, who lived in Charlotte, had a car, and his sister Pauline Hunnycutt had a car. After Aunt Martha married, she, too had access to a car. Grandmother was unable to leave her home because of her blindness and her frailty, and the only time she went anywhere in an automobile that I learned about was when she was taken to a hospital in Charlotte, briefly.

No one in the family, except my f had no automobile and no buggy, He did have a mule that he used to plow—or rather Uncle Eddie used the mule to plow. He was quite old picked cotton when he was very old, and found it difficult to stay on his feet for any length of time. Therefore, he sat on the ground on a burlap sack, and scooted himself down the cotton rows, and placed his picked cotton bolls into another burlap sack that he pulled along with him. When his sack was full, he stood up, and carried it to the large basket used for collecting the bolls, and then returned to his row, to fill his sack again. The baskets would be hauled away on a wagon. The fields were big, and for the most part, were across Pineville Road from the house.

The home my Grandfather’s family lived in was a two story house, with four rooms and a hall on the first floor, and four rooms and a hall on the second floor. When my Grandmother became blind and was unable to climb stairs, her bed was placed in one of the downstairs room, so that her daughters who had chores in the kitchen could take care of her without climbing the stairs to do it, and so they could hear the tinkle of the bell she used to summon them. Her room was furnished with her bed and dresser, and chairs enough to accommodate the family, and eventually, a large heater in which to build a fire to keep her warm in winter. That room also served as a sitting room. Any visitors to the house would want to visit her, if only to exchange a polite greeting. Grandfather had his bed, and his privacy, upstairs. His early rising to go to work on the farm would not disturb his wife. Also, their daughters, entering the room to take care of their mother would not disturb his privacy.

There were three daughters and two sons in that family, and for many years all of them were at home. My Daddy and his sister Pauline were the youngest, and when I was a child, the only ones who married. When I was five years old, or so, Pauline had a boy friend, and he became my Uncle Henry. Pauline and Henry owned a car, and I don’t remember what Uncle Henry did, but Aunt Pauline went to Charlotte every week-day to her job. I think Uncle Henry had land, and farmed it, but I am not certain. They rented a house just a short walk from the Yandle home place, with only one other house between them. Aunt Pauline could easily walk from her home to the Yandle home place, and did so frequently. %%%%%%%%%%%%%%

The four upstairs rooms were in use, so Grandfather, who wanted a little space, and a little privacy of his own, invented a room for himself. Like many homes of that era, the Yandle house was built with a sort of open sitting room at the top of the stairs. However, my Grandfather claimed it as his bedroom, and secured his privacy by extending what looked to me like a rope from wall to wall, hung what looked like a sheet over it, put a double bed behind it, and called it his bedroom. It served him as a private room the rest of his life.

In mid-summer the Yandle home place, surrounded by tall trees, was shaded very well, but still warm. In winter, there was a stove in the kitchen, of course, and one in my Grandmother’s room. There was a fireplace also in the living room. There was no electricity, no running water, and no toilet. The kitchen was always warm because the wood burning cooking stove kept that part of the house pleasantly warm during the winter, and near to suffocating in summer.

In summer when Grandfather Yandle was tired, or it was Sunday, or there wasn’t much to do in the fields, he would sit on one of the porches with his fly swatter, and kill flies. When the sun was behind his house he sat on the front porch in the swing, and killed flies. When the sun was shining on the front of the house, he sat on the back porch and killed flies. In summer he always held a fly swatter in his hand, and he seldom missed a target. In winter he sat in the warm downstairs room with his wife, or occasionally in the kitchen.

My blind grandmother was an invalid, and kept to her bed all day, every day. She had been in fragile health most of her life, though she birthed at least six children, five of whom lived to adulthood. My Dad often told me stories about his youth, sometimes admitting to having to leave the house in freezing cold to fetch a doctor, or to refill her prescription when his mother was ill. He also said that though he went to school, he had to make his grade in only a few months, since he was needed to plough and plant the fields, and again to harvest them.

I don’t know many stories about my father’s childhood, but there is one he told me one evening as we sat in the living room in our house in Charlotte at 407 West Eleventh Street. My parents had moved there from East Fifth Street when I was about two and a half years old. I have only tiny snatches of fragmentary memories of the first house, but I lived on Eleventh Street in the same house until I married, and my parents stayed there until the City of Charlotte decided to tear down the houses, and build a ramp through that area leading to an Interstate—thereby making it possible to leave the center of town and be on the highway in a matter of about ten minutes.

My parents had lived on Eleventh Street for about twenty-five years. When they realized they would be compelled to leave their current location they decided to return closer to Pineville. So they searched for a convenient place near family members, and found several acres for sale not far from where Mother’s sister Ola Davis and her husband had lived for at least thirty years. There was already a house on the property; however, it was no longer livable. The house had been built so long ago that at one point it was a stage coach station. It was very small, though it was two stories tall, and had only four rooms. There had once been a separate building that was its kitchen; however, like many kitchens of that era, it burned down. There was a story that during the Revolutionary War the British were in the area and camped on that land. One of their soldiers deserted from that camp, but he was captured and hung on a tree that still sheltered an area where my dad built a storage shed. That land had a very old history, and my Dad had roamed over a large part of that area as a boy. They, of course, built a house my mother designed herself, and they had a lovely place with a large basement, and pleasant yard. There was room for a horse, named Patsy, and a few chickens—the king of the chickens had a name: “Chick-Chick” and it lived for years. He was an indoor chicken, though he was allowed outside, and he ate tidbits from the table, and crowed at my mother to awaken her each morning. He lived in kingly solitude in the basement of that house at night. When Chick-chick died of old age, my parents buried him with a ceremony.

My mother loved having her sister so close, and they had great times together during that time. Her husband, Uncle Vance, helped to build the house, and contributed greatly to the way it turned out. Not every “self” built house was truly livable, but that house was close to perfect. It saddened my parents and us when, about ten years later, someone really important decided to build a huge building that would need more than the corner property—in fact all of the land my parents owned as well as that of their neighbors.

Therefore, Mother and Daddy found a nice farm on the other side of Charlotte that already had both a small lake and a good sized brick house on it, with plenty of space for a garden. It also had a second house which was rented to a nice family, with three children, on the back of the property.

Because my parents grew up close to Pineville I was sorry they had to leave their house there. Mother’s sister and brother-in-law had been only across the road from them in the house they built themselves. Mother’s parents had died some years earlier, and my Dads parents had died a few years later. Pineville is a small town that was once about fifteen miles (give or take a little because it is a guess) from Charlotte. Charlotte was not as large then as it is now, and neither was Pineville. When I first began to notice familiarities along the road, I would ask questions. To my surprise, my Dad, or my Mother, knew a lot about the buildings we passed, and even the spaces that were open fields with jimson grass growing on it, or places where there were stands of tall pine trees for along the way. Occasionally

Because Charlotte has spread beyond its early boundaries there is now less distance between Charlotte and Pineville. My early first memories of the trips to Pineville began from our house, through Charlotte’s Square, and down South Tryon Street. There was a little ziz-zag around corners, and then we went down East Boulevard, past the Lance Packing Company, the Street-Car Barn, and a corner where people hitching a ride south usually stood. Then we were on Pineville Road, and there were fewer houses, and some businesses. About seven or eight miles down the road toward Pineville we came to curve. If you guided your automobile sort of straight, ignoring the curve of the road, you would find a level crossing of the railroad track, and on the other side of the railroad was a very old road. The old road was wide, but it was paved on only one side. The other side was covered in fine gravel, for horses. . . That was where Pineville Road was re-routed to prevent having the road cross the railroad track twice in the space of about two or three miles. with the road, and not curving, you came to a railroad crossing. If you crossed the railroad you found yourself on what folks called “Old Pineville Road. Now, I don’t know which came first—the muddy path that was the beginning of the road, or the railroad track from Pineville to Charlotte. But however it was, the railroad dug a valley through the middle of a hill, and kept right on chugging. The Road said, well, My Daddy told me that when the government was paving the road, making it safer for wagons and cars, they didn’t want to build a bridge over the railroad track, also laid between Charlotte and Pineville, because just a little way down the railroad track from where we were, the land dropped down, and the train track was way down in low place, avoiding a hill. Well, the folks who made the road just made a little wooden bridge that arched over the narrow width of the track. This was a place where the first Pineville Road that was just a few ruts in the muddy dirt,

but some buildings where there were businessesWhere are road to Pineville from Charlotte is of a wide cement road with dirt shoulders on both sides of it where Queen Ann’s Lace plants would grow in summer. My Dad usually drove out South Boulevard onto Pineville Road, stopping only at our planned destination. Sometimes we left the highway roughly three miles before we reached Pineville, and crossed the railroad tracks to a streach of . Early in my life, once we , and then we drove Road now is a wide thoroughfare that extends well into the city of Charlotte. I believe that the Road was probably marked out long before trains or paved roads came to Mecklenburg County. I don’t realilroad between Pineville and Charlotte

When his family was living very close to the old hump backed bridge on Old Pineville Road, one that no longer exists, that once leaped high over the train track o

Once my Dad told me a story that I have always treasured and I will write it down. In the days before the family moved to the location I was familiar with . . In hi

As a small child (five years old up to fifteen years) I didn’t really like to sit still and keep quiet while the grown folks congregated in a stuffy room and talked to my Grandmother. We usually arrived there about two o’clock in the afternoon, and stayed there until about seven, or even eight o’clock in the evening. The adults usually had a chair, even if it was only a straight chair, but I rarely had a comfortable one. The room had two rocking chairs—one for my grandfather, and one for my grandmother, and a couple of chairs just like those in the kitchen that would, when I was small and wearing a short dress, mark my legs in an image of the cane strips that made the seat of the chair.

Another reason I liked to go to my Grandmother’s house was that there were some young people near my sister’s age who lived about two houses down the road, and she enjoyed playing with them. Perhaps by the time I was ten or so, they were not exactly playing together, but swapping information about being teenagers. It didn’t bother me that I was not invited, I didn’t know them, and my sister didn’t want me around, and that left me with several pleasing options. Almost always there were cats, or kittens, or both, around the porch. There was a dog there—and usually the animals “belonged” to Aunt Helen. Oodles of chickens strutted in the back yard. The milk cow and the mule were in a pasture behind the well house, and the barn was about twenty feet from the gate that was just behind the well house. If I wanted to take a walk, I had several options. There was a gas station with a little store inside it next door

I could walk up a seldom used red dirt road, and choose whether I wanted to walk all the way to the train track and throw a few rocks because the track had lots of rocks in its middle between the cross-ties, and both between and beside the tracks were wonderful white or gray rocks one could toss.

I didn’t mind sneaking to a small building beside the well, but beneath the limbs of a sheltering tree. The building had a concrete floor and there was usually water from the well several inches deep on the floor. Most of the time the well house was cool—or perhaps just cooler than—the rest of the yard. Because there was no refrigerator in the house, the milk was stored in the well house, along with any other perishables, such as butter. As a very small child I accepted as a fact that the well house was cool, without much curiosity about how it worked. I think, well trained child that I was, that the older folk in that house, such as my Uncle and my three Aunts, as well as both my Grand Parents, were indelibly marked in my head as people to whom small children were simply an aggravation. I don’t recall that I was unhappy about not having a playmate. My sister was enough older than me that she that on any occasion. I do remember that I worked hard not to “bother” them, mostly by keeping my mouth shut, staying outside, if possible. My Aunt Hellen loved cats, and there was a dog there. My Aunt Pauline also had a dog—a huge critter named Bo, who looked like it could easily eat me. When I was outside, I tried to have either my Aunt Helen’s dog, or Bo, with me when I was outside alone. When a or, when I became nine or ten years old, walking over to my Aunt Pauline’s house while she was visiting at her mother’s house, and listening to her radio. I also had permission to wear one of her housecoats that I thought was as beautiful as any evening gown I had ever seen in any movie. I would put it on, take off my shoes, and dance in her living room to radio music. I always thought of My Uncle Eddie, Aunt Helen, and Aunt Martha as folk who, without doubt, didn’t want to be bothered with the questions of little kids.

The

To top all that, the property where the house stood had been sold, the house torn down, and a hardware store built on the site.

bother the horse or the cow, and didn’t like the pigs, and stayed away from the chickens because I didn’t like the deposits they left behind them. That left me time to play with the dogs, and when I was ten or so I had the freedom to walk across the yard to a house where very interesting people lived, who were always polite to me.

to visit the house very near where some extremely interesting people lived. I was old enough to know a little bit about black people and that some years before they had been slaves.

I might explain that dear little dimpled Shirley Temple was making movies—marvelous, and new, and never-before-anything-like-it-movies. She was cute, pretty, talented, a dancer, a singer, a precious little actress who inspired every woman who viewed her movies whether or not she had a girl child that age, to want a girl child that age because she was smart and was a movie star with cute dimples. I actually had a child sized paper doll of Shirley, nearly as tall as I was, with about six paper dresses so that she could change to suit the imaginary situation. About that time I loved to p’like. You don’t know what that means? Oh! I’ll spell it. PLAY LIKE. You know—Let’s p’like I’m Shirley Temple and you are Jane Withers and we have a horse.

Every mother in the entire United States immediately cut all the hems off all the dresses their little darlings wore so that if her child bent over she would reveal that her little panties matched her very short dresses, just like Shirley Temple. Of course, because of the Depression, some children couldn’t have a bought dress—but if her mommy could sew, she could make one.

’s sitting room. mtin a dim room and talked. The only lights were kerosene lamps, and they were not—repeat—NOT burned in the day time, despite however dim it was in Grandmother’s room. Since she was blind, it was assumed that no one else had a right to bright light, either. So we all sat in dimness.
