There were two windows in her room, both of which should have provided some brightness, however, one of them opened onto the back porch with a wide and shady roof, and from the other we could see a bunch of leaves very close to the glass from a tall as well as large bush that kept out bright light. One did not wriggle around in a comfortable chair inside that room, either. There were only two “good” chairs. One was a pillowed rocker with a high back that would allow grandmother to lay her head against it, and the other was a large and sturdy rocker complete with cushions and pillows, which would accommodate my Grandfather. Uncle Eddie sat on a kitchen chair, and so did all other visitors. If the room had enough people in it to use up all the chairs that were normally there, I was elected to sit on a small foot-stool that was in reach of Grandmother’s feet, should there not be a chair for me. If more persons came to visit, chairs without cushions were brought from around the kitchen table that were so old that the legs of the chairs looked as if they had been sand-papered to shorten their length. Of course it was because they had been pushed up to, and away from the table for probably more than fifty, or even seventy five or more years, against a rough floor. The shortening of the legs was not on purpose, but simply the result of their use for three meals of each day for long years by more than one generation. We actually have a couple of those chairs at our table, today, and they have cushions that lift the person who sits on it a little higher. The legs of those chairs are quite short. The cane strips that are woven front to back and side to side to provide the seat of the chairs will, if you sit on them long enough and are wearing shorts or a short skirt, leave your legs with its imprint, making your legs seem to be of woven wood.

Granddaddy Yandle, had a special chair, big enough to hold him, with soft cushions and arms If there were other people who needed to sit, they did so on kitchen chairs.

On summer afternoons when we visited my Dad’s family Grandfather Yandle was almost always on either the front porch, or the back porch, according to which porch was toward the sun. In summer he was never without a fly swatter. Usually at the end of the day both porches would be covered with dead flies. **d of the day, the porch deck was literally covered with dead flies. I was small enough at that time to remember a fairy tale about a man who killed seven flies with one swat, and in an effort to make himself seem fierce he made a sign that said “I killed seven with one blow” without defining who his victims were. I thought my Grandfather should certainly have a better sign than that, as I was unable to count all the flies he left on the porch deck.

I must confess that I am seventy-five years old. My husband, Robert Erskine Beatty, is eighty years old. My youngest grandchild is about eight years old; however I have great-grandchildren that are still infancy. My father sometimes spoke of his childhood, mentioning his Grandfather Yandle who ran a grocery store near Pineville. That Great Grandfather and his wife came to the United States before the Civil War, but they had been born and raised in England. He brought with him two younger people—a man and a woman—and I have been unable to determine exactly who they were, or what exact kin they were to me. I called them Uncle Ed, and Aunt Lizzie. I am still confused about which of the generations of my forebears they fit into. They were brother and sister, and they lived in Charlotte when I was very small. Aunt Lizzie called my grandmother Yandle “Sissy” as if they were sisters, however, my Grandmother Yandle was not born in England. they were not blood kin. However my grandmother was not blood kin to them. My grandfather definitely did not have an English accent, though he didn’t talk to me very much, and seldom had very much to say when the family was sitting around the stove on Sunday afternoons in the winter. I, myself, liked to be outside when I was there if the weather was nice. In winter I sat in the room with the grownups and listened to their conversations. and around. My Uncle Ed sort of did have an accent that was not a southern brogue.

  • brother and sister, whom I knew simply as Uncle Edward, and Aunt Lizzie. When I was a child, I simply didn’t understand how they were connected to the rest of our family—but I was certain there was a connection somewhere, or they would not be my “Aunt” or my “Uncle”. My English Great Grandfather, whom I never saw because he died long before my birth, owned a store, and the two of his family that I knew well were extremely well educated, and had vocabularies that differed from that of us Southerners. I always marveled at why they were treated with such obvious courtesy. I understood that they were not like everyone else, and that we always treated them as if we were honoring their presence—when I, as a small child, always thought of them as a nuisance—especially as I was warned to be on my best behavior when they were visiting. as if they were much better, nicer, and worthy of courtesies than other folk. They, themselves seemed to think they were entitled to deference. As a little child, I just—well my grandchildren of today would say that I was just “going with the flow,” however, I couldn’t see why those people “deserved” more courtesy than my own parents. as a small child I didn’t know why they were different, nor that they had once lived in England. I realized their manners and their opinions were sometimes radically different from those held by my parents, but I didn’t discover much about them until I was studying a family tree. Their house had always had running water. They had gas lights in their house, as well as electricity. since it came from a well, knew my Great Uncle Edward, and my Great Aunt Elizabeth, who was called “Lizzie”. I realized then that they spoke a little differently than most folks, but I didn’t know why. For instance, their house had electric lights; however, they also had gas lights in their home. They did not have a complete “Southern Drawl” and no one every mentioned that they had been raised by people who had lived in England. I knew without doubt that they were somehow different from my Mother’s people whose ancestors had come earlier to what is now The United States. My childish explanation was that they were just a little odd, and that sometimes people simply turned out that way. I also believed Great Aunt Elizabeth, and Great Uncle Edward were just a bit snooty, believing themselves a bit better than anyone else. just theythoughthat in some ways they were “different” from people who had a southern drawl. I just thought they were a little bit (not really very much) sort of “dotty”. That means I thought they were not quite “with it” as more any more recent teenager might explain it. as a because they were and because I knew them when I was very young, I thought they were verand his wife came to this country from England, much earlier, and established a home in either Pineville, or Charlotte. I never learned exactly where he lived. He owned a store. I don’t know exactly what kind of store it was, but food was one part of its wares. The name of this ancestor was Samuel Yandle. That much I know, because his wife, in extreme old age, repeated a poem, a verse, or a little song about him. I never met the gentleman, however, my mother helped to nurse his widowed wife when she was close to a hundred years old, and told me, and showed me, how she rocked, slapping her feet softly onto the floor with her feet matching the rhythm of her rocker, in strict cadence of the sing-song poem. Over and over again the tiny lady would rock and sing. Then my mother told me that if she, herself, was careless and walked close to that chair, a small hand, but still strong one, would pinch her severely, leaving a bruise, so that my Mother took great care not to fall prey to her little idiosyncrasy. , all day, as she rocked in her rocking chair, and since my mother helped take care of her she told me about that old lady who, though a little crazy, could still sing when she was near a hundred years old. My mother helped take care of her for a while, and she recited the sang the song for me. It went like this, to the squeak of her rocking chair, and the tap of her shoes against the wooden floor:
            Samuel Yandle is my name,
        And England is my nation.
        The Bible is the Book of God,
        And Christ is my Salvation!

His name wasIt might seem strange, but I don’t know his name.

know that quite often time flies so quickly you can’t it doesn’t make much of a splash in your thinking. For instance, every little girl who lived when a child Movie star named Shirley Temple played in kids movies suddenly found herself in dresses that barely covered her privates. That, my dears, was STYLE! That style marked a sweet, intelligent, pretty, and modern little girl. I know. I was one of those little girls who wore short dresses; however, my mother always made me a pair of underpants that matched the dress so it wouldn’t be too noticeable—she wanted me to be fashionable, but lady-like, too. Who cares that dresses were (short or long) when it was (ten or twenty or only five) years ago? Change is inevitable in almost every facet of life, and the living of it. Change often depends on new discoveries is And now I am looking back to the time when I was very young. Life really is different for people born years apart. Sometimes the length of time matters, sometimes changes come quickly, and leave just as quick, that they are just a “notion” or a “quirk” that stirs folks for a short while. Sometimes However, changes come, and they go also. Knowledge usually increases, however in huge and then increases more, and more. Something new is invented, discovered, or it arrives accidentally, buts sticks, and becomes part of our culture. Then that some urgent change could be called . But when you think of it, and measure changes, it seems to be much, much, more important.

My Father, Leroy Samuel Yandle,

itself, and then think about the differences twenty years can make, it is almost stunning. different twenty or more years can be--when people lived, and how they lived, things we have learned from the pages of our Geography books and History books come alive. The United States had been a nation—not just a colony—for about one hundred fifty years when Paw-paw was born in 1925. . Many new citizens arrived by ship from all over the world, beginning at the time the rest of the world heard about the new continent. Actually, it hasn’t stopped yet. *l today. simply because this was a “new” country, and there was lots of room, and the people who came were usually sort of running from some unpleasant situation in the country they were born in. whatever situation they had found themcame to the New World In the late 1800’s and the early 1900’s. For one thing, travel became easier as time passed. lots of people from all over the world came to this new nation to make a new start in how they lived their lives. Our country was still relatively young, but we were growing. There had been many changes in the country since its beginnings. The Civil War in the mid 1860’s had taken a toll on the South, but in the Twentieth Century most of the people in Southern states had begun to recover from the effects of that war, and jobs were again available, and prosperity could be found in many parts of the South. Mills and factories were built in the South, and railroads crossed the land. Cities were growing, jobs were available, and the children of Negro citizens were not accepted in white schools, nor were they welcomed into the houses of white people except as servants. Often in large cities persons of color were unwelcome. I can remember that in Charlotte, North Carolina, Negroes who ventured into the up town areas could not use the same rest rooms that white people used. There were two fountains from which to drink—and one of them was for Negroes. often able to send their children to school, though most of them, especially in the South, were restricted to certain areas of a town or city, and few of them were taught in schools.

had The late 1920’s were not halcyon years. There had been a boom of good fortune in the early 1900’s because the damage of the Civil War and its aftermath was beginning to wane. Jobs were plentiful, homes . was being overcome, and the late 1800’s, after the close of the Civil War, earlier, gold had been found in California and Alaska. The nation was growing, buildings were erected in towns, homes were built, jobs were plentiful, railroads were extended, airplanes were invented and put to work, a war was fought in Europe and our troops won, though the price—the loss of lives—was devastating. there was still a frontier, however, that wild frontier was rapidly being tamed. However we were still a relatively new country, and all over the world things inventions were changing the methods of farming, of . e of the most important ones was that we were not afraid of new things—and in our country machines replaced horses, buggies, and horse or mule pulled plows. We, as a nation, were using machines instead of horses and mules. Many kinds of motors were coming into use. Instead of horses Engines pulled trainsof many kind were appearing in homes. Things like dish washers, electric stoves or gas stoves instead of wood burning stoves were available in towns and cities. not afraid nearly two hundred years when Paw-paw was born

In the mid to late 1920’s and the early 1930’s Charlotte was becoming a large city—not just a town—and rules of conduct where children were concerned was changing. There were many states that had no rules about child labor, but when farmers, or mill owners, needed simple tasks, they could hire small children, pay them almost nothing, and keep them on the floor of a mill with a broom for ten hours. That was a fact.

Paw-paw was blessed, as I was blessed, by our parents. Our folks did not require their small children to work when they were so young. However when Paw-paw’s parents, and my parents were growing up, things were different.

Here is a short story about life and the living of it in the late 1800’s, and the early 1900’s, events that could, and did happen, when our parents were young. My Dad had a neighbor, who was kin to his family. There were several children in that family, among them a four year old girl. It was quite legal to hire children in mills to sweep the floors of lint from the cotton. In this instance, the child’s father took her to the mill, and they put her to work sweeping lint from the floor of the mill, right in the middle of the huge machines that made cotton cloth. The normal shift for the mill was at least ten, and possibly twelve, hours for each shift. It was against the rules for a worker to sit down during the work day. Therefore, the little girl could not sit down during her day’s work. However a kind overseer allowed the child to lean against a pillar holding up the roof, and so long as she didn’t sit down, she could rest or even go to sleep standing up. Her day was not limited to eight hours—but was at least ten hours, or possibly even twelve hours because there were no rules or laws to prevent such demands by the mill owners. The child worked in that mill until she was twelve years old, at which time a young boy, who was about fourteen years old, came to work in the mill. Each day he saw the girl, and learned that she could not spend any of her wages, as they were paid to her father. They ate their lunches which were brought from home, together, and talked to each other for some weeks. The boy admired the girl for her strength and for her sweetness. He thought her father was mean, and that the girl deserved to be treated better.

There were no laws that would protect her, and she would “belong” to her parents until she was married, or until she was twenty-one years old—twelve more years without going to school, twelve more years without being able to spend a penny of the money she earned. Her only hope of leaving her work at the mill was to get married. However, how would she ever meet s person to marry when she worked twelve hours a day?

The young man’s last name was Crump, and he was not much older than the girl, but there were few rules about how old a person had to be to get married. And one day he asked the girl to marry him, and told her that as his wife she would not have to work in the mill. She did not hesitate. The license was purchased, the preacher was talked into marrying them, and the girl was free from her father.

Except for the anger of her father who could not now snatch her wages from her, the marriage worked just fine. She left the mill and became a house wife. Her young husband realized that she had done little except work in the mill all of her life. She had never played games with other children, nor did she go to school. She knew that some children did play, and that they pretended to have “houses” that were simple lines drawn in dirt to indicate rooms and walls. Of course, she knew how to do household chores, because she had done them at home. She did not work in the mill on Sunday, so she had home chores on that day.

Alone in a small house with her young husband the young girl was busy keeping house, and cooking meals. During the part of the year when they first married it was still daylight when her husband came home from work, she would serve him supper, and then if it was still light outside, he would go out into the yard with her, and they would draw lines in the dirt, outlining the rooms of a house, naming the rooms, and then pretend to furnish them. It was play. It was pretending. She had never before done that.

When I saw the couple they were middle-aged. She was tall and slender and very pretty. He was well filled out—but not at all fat. He had been to school and become a preacher, and was serving a church not too far from Pineville. She had educated herself, and was a slender and quite beautiful lady. The only time I saw them was the day they visited my Grandmother Yandle who was blind. They stopped in that Sunday afternoon to visit, and they had a happy time talking with each other, and with my parents. They prayed with us before they left my Grandmother’s room. I watched the Preacher help her into their car, and then enter the car himself. That was the first time I had ever noticed that men did that.

After we went home that evening, my father told me a tiny sequel to the story of Pastor Crump and his child bride. He told me how terribly angry her father was when the marriage took place without his consent. My Dad also explained that what her father disliked most was that she would not be giving him her pay check any more. Not long after that marriage the father of the young wife was in Pineville with a younger daughter named Sophie. As they walked down the street the father saw the brother of the Crump boy who had married his older daughter, and he was still so angry that he shouted to his little girl: “Run, Sophie, run. Here comes another Crump, and he’ll have you and gone with you!” My dad thought the old man’s anger was funny, and laughed. I, too, smiled when he told the story. However, I have always wondered about the other children in that family, and how they were treated. If a parent was mean to one child, would the others be treated differently? I was grateful that I was never made to do chores too difficult for me—and though I disliked “kitchen duty” it had not been my parents who demanded that I “learn” how to wash dishes—that was my sister, who when she was near seven years old was suddenly, and without the slightest hint of change or of what to expect, introduced to a tiny sister who cried a lot, had stinky diapers that she was compelled to help wash on a scrub board in a tin tub set on two chairs in the kitchen, and then she was expected to hang them out in a freezing cold back yard since it was February when I was born, and usually quite cold. Ella Cornelia resented me totally. She had not been told that a child was on its way. My mother was definitely expecting, but my sister had no clue that change was on the way before it actually arrived. All she knew was that one day Pauline Funderburk drove up to our house, took her mother away, and left her with Aunt Martha. I was a surprise, but not a welcome one. She had been the only child of my parents. She was the only Yandle grandchild, the only child in our family, and didn’t have much competition in my mother’s family either, as the other Parks grandchildren lived in South Carolina and were not constant visitors to their grandparents. Ella Cornelia was the center of attention every where she went—that is until I came along.

No sensitive person could blame her for being a little upset to discover—without warning—that she had competition who was the center of every visit, and moreover, had become the most important person in the house, also, with the neighbors, and then to everyone who came through the front door. They all came to “see” that dratted baby, and scarcely said hello to her, and most of them wanted to know how she “liked” that little interloper. Well—to be honest—she didn’t. Didn’t like me I mean. She didn’t like it when visitors came in and said hello, Ella Cornelia, where is baby Iris Jean? THAT did it!! Ella Cornelia had been the only child in the Yandle family for seven years. She had not been told I was on the way, so that I was a terrible shock. My father was, at that period, the only one in his immediate family who was married. His brother and one of his sisters never married, and two of his sisters eventually married, however, neither of them had children. My sister and I were the only Yandle grandchildren. My Uncle Eddie, my father’s only brother, was never married.

When Ella Cornelia was born she was the only grandchild on the Yandle side of our family.
She, therefore, had close to seven years as the only important child in Charlotte or Pineville. She was the total center of attention to her blind grandmother, her grandfather, her Aunt Helen who was usually in the kitchen, her Aunt Martha who had some training as a nurse and looked after our blind grandmother. Then, there was Aunt Pauline who no longer lived in the house with her parents because she had married Uncle Henry. They had rented a house only a three minute walk away from the farm where she had lived until she married. She was close enough to come to see her family everyday.

Since Ella Cornelia had been very ill when I was about three years old, I, with my apparent health, received less attention from my Yandle Aunts and Uncles. I was an unwelcome chore when I visited them—too young to be of any help, and a nuisance to take care of. However my sister was the first grandchild, and doted on. Because she was the first grandchild, and then had been so grievously ill, and now needed careful nursing, she became even more the important grandchild. She was so important that I was sort of invisible when I was around, unless Aunt Martha wanted to “play” with me. Her favorite game was to snatch my small panties down and pinch my fanny. She would follow me from the kitchen down the hall, through the dining room and into the kitchen again with me moving as fast as my small legs would carry me to stay out of her reach. However, she was right behind me pinching my fanny, and laughing.

I was too young at the time to remember how long I stayed in the house where Aunt Martha lived, but I do know that for several months I lived with my mother’s sister, Ola, who had no children of her own. I had not seen much of my Aunt Ola, but she was kind to me, and took good care of me. She was, however, somewhat of a stranger.

Aunt Ola was a bit older than my mother. She and Uncle Vance had no children. Aunt Ola had not had as much “schooling” as my Mother, who was the younger. Aunt Ola was a wonderful, intelligent, and gifted person. I seldom saw her sitting down except late in the evening or on Sundays. *. , willing to help people who needed help. She was intelligent, a hard worker, she loved my mother and she loved and took care of her parents, taking both of them into her own home after her mother became too old to cope on her own. had a heart attackwhen her mother was no longer able to but she had not been around small children very much, and I was just a frightened young child being handed from here to there because my sister was ill. and the constant sicknesses in the household of my Grandmother Yandle had often made any visits to her short. So much so that I was sort of invisible when I was around. also because of her illness, was the very center of attention. Eventually I was sent to my mother’s sister, my Aunt Ola, and Ella Cornelia stayed with Aunt Martha and her family. Aunt Martha was already nursing Grandmother Yandle who was bedridden, and blind. By that time my grandmother was bedridden and blind, and when I was about two, going on three, my sister was seriously ill, and was not allowed to walk for a full year. Once she was out of the danger of dying any minute, but was still extremely fragile. During her training Aunt Martha had become ill, and she did not finish her training. Her skills came in quite handily when my sister was sent to , she was sent to Pineville to be nursed by her Aunt Martha who had studied to be a nurse, though she had been unable to complete her studies. Mother would never have allowed her to go except for one thing. The Depression had occurred, and money to pay doctors, and buy medicines had to be earned, and as Daddy was working as hard as he could to put food on the table and rent a roof over our heads, Mother went to work to buy medicine. , andBecause my mother had to go to work to pay the hospital and doctor bills, Ella Cornelia, who was still not allowed to stand or walk, she was sent to her Yandle grandparents, aunts and uncle to stay neither of them could get up and walk. My sister had to use a wheelchair for a full year after she was released form the hospital. She was not allowed to “do” anything. I was too young to be of help, and therefore I was a little nuisance, and often sent to stay a while with my Aunt Ola, or someone else. Aunt Ola was my Mother’s sister, and she offered me her attention and love, tried very hard to take good care of me. However, she had never had a child of her own, and though she tried very hard to take good care of me, I think I may have been a little bit afraid of her. Years later she told me that I had been difficult to look after, and that one day when she washed my hair, she had a tough time calming me afterwards. She said I kicked and screamed, and kept saying, “You went and wet my hair!” I think it took a while to calm me, and on the occasions some years later when I spent a few days with her, I remember that I tried very hard not make problems for her. I had, during that long ago visit, given her enough grief to last the rest of my life. Therefore, I owed it to her to be “good as gold” when I visited. She was always kind to me, and during the time my sister was so terribly ill, Aunt Ola kept me at her house, doing the best she could to look after me, when she had no child of her own, and had never before had the opportunity to learn how to take care of a little child.

My Daddy’s sister, Aunt Martha, was both tall and hefty, and loved to tease me. I’m not sure why she thought it was funny to pull down my diaper, or later, my underpants and pinch my butt, however that was one of her funniest tricks. She would walk behind me as I tried to out run her down the hall of her house, and she would walk behind me, laughing, and reach down to jerk down my panties, and pinch me. I was too small to keep enough distance between us to prevent it, but I tried hard to run faster than she could walk. I never won the race. She always reached me, and then was unhappy with me because I cried. Usually when I was included in a visit with my Yandle Aunts and Uncle, I was careful to stay out of reach if I could. My parents never understood why I wasn’t in a hurry to hug and kiss my Dad’s sisters. I was wary of everyone except Uncle Eddie, who gave me dimes for my bank, but never aggravated me.

My Grandmother and Grandfather Yandle, and my Daddy’s sisters, all seemed to love Ella Cornelia but they also seemed to dislike me. I could not understand it, and wondered if it was because Ella Cornelia was named after both her grandmothers: Ella for Grandmother Yandle, and Cornelia for Grandmother Parks. I thought both names were nice. I was named by my sister—only she didn’t know she was naming a real person. She had a pretend playmate she called Iris Jean, when she was quite young. That turned out to be my name. However I answered to “Jimmy”, and anything else anyone wanted to call me. However, my sister was always called her full name: Ella (for Grandmother Ella Yandle) and Cornelia (for Grandmother Parks). There could be no preference since both ladies were alive and well aware of her name, and the importance of it. I, of course, was named by my sister. It seems that she had an invisible playmate when she was young, and its name was “Iris Jean”. Of course when I was old enough to understand that Ella Cornelia had furnished my name, I was not only surprised, but a little angry. She didn’t even LIKE me, much less love me. And she certainly was not famous for doing nice things for me—she was more likely play a trick that would end with me in tears, or ready to knock her to kingdom come. I wasn’t named after real person. I was named after a make believe person—and she was invented by my sister, who didn’t have a kind word to say about me when we were young..

I, of course, was a little angel—and never gave trouble. I couldn’t have been more than three when Ella Cornelia contracted an illness that could have taken her life. There were lots of children who lived on East Fifth Street at that time, and a bunch of them enjoyed playing jump rope. One hot summer day when my sister was about ten years old she played jump rope with a large group of neighbor children. Jump Rope took a team to be really interesting. There were rules. Two players were chosen to be the turners of the rope. The other children were jumpers, and usually there were two teams of jumpers. I’m not sure how my sister played the game, but she was a jumper. Two others turned the rope, and a bunch of kids started jumping the same rope. If a jumper landed on the rope, or touched it, that jumper was out of the game. When only one jumper was left, that person had the opportunity to jump ten turns of the rope, and if no mistake was made, she had won a second try for her team, and the game started all over again. Well, on that day my sister was the jumper who was the last one still jumping, and she kept right on jumping until she had jumped ten times without touching the rope. Then her friends rejoined her, and they all jumped again until there was, again, only one jumper left, and that was my sister, again, and again she jumped ten turns of the rope without touching it, and again her team returned to the rope, still turning in a distinct rhythm again, and again her team mates joined her, and again they all, eventually, touched the rope—all except my sister. This happened ten times. Ella Cornelia was excited with her triumph. She bragged to our parents that she had done it. She had been the one who was still in the game and who kept on jumping ten turns of the rope so that her playmates could join her again.

It was a mighty victory, but like all battles, there was a toll. And my poor sister, pleased with her stamina, contracted pleurisy and fevers. Her physician, a dear man named John Ashe, put her in the hospital. Her condition worsened. Three consulting physicians said she would die. Dr. Ashe said she would live. Mother and Daddy put their trust in God, and in Dr. Ashe. And Ella Cornelia did live. However it was not an easy victory. When the surgery was over, and she had been in the hospital for a long time, she was no longer the strong jump rope jumper. She was not allowed to walk for a year because her heart was damaged. During that year my mother asked her sister, Ola, to keep me. Aunt Ola was, first and foremost, a person who had been born on a farm, and had lived on a farm all of her life. She had gone to school, just as my mother had. Aunt Ola was married to Uncle Vance, a gentle sort of man, who was intelligent, and a hard worker. He had built their house on what was called “Old” Pineville Road. There was also a railroad track that passed through both Pineville and Charlotte

Charlotte was an old city. Pineville was about the same age, but much smaller. Charlotte became a very large city, extending it’s boundaries until Pineville was only about ten miles from the city limits of Charlotte. I am certain that a paved road has existed between the two for at least seventy-five years, because I don’t have a memory of a dirt road, or a black-top road along that route. Pineville Road was at some point, definitely, a trail, because parts of the trail were still in use when I was a child. Some years before the road between Charlotte and Pineville, that was, probably about fifteen miles distanta steep hill. The front of his house lay on high ground, and to step onto his front porch was one, and only one, short step. If one walked to the back of his house, he would find it slightly downhill all the way, and at the rear of his house were tall steps, easily climbed to a nice wide platform carefully fenced to avoid an accidental fall to the ground. The stairs had a banister. where a door opened into his screened back porch. straight up to his back door that led into a screened in porch

long the side of his house to the rear, one would walk down hill, and find that there was a considerable basement workshop beneath the house. Wide, tall stairs went up to a square porch, with shelf-like banisters on two sides, an entrance to the house on the other. However how to attend to chickens, cows, and probably horses, and both her father and her husand kept horses. She had probably cooked most of her life, because she was the oldest girl in her family (while my mother was the youngest). Aunt Ola had no children, but she looked after several children at least for a while, during her life, and I was one of them. She was kind to me. When My mother’s brothers were nice men. One, Dennis, married a wife named Mary, and they had three children: Dennis, Jr., Patsy, the oldest girl, and Mary Cole, the youngest. Uncle Luther also married, however his wife could have no children. 

 no children.  She had not been around children very much.  But when my sister became ill, Aunt Ola took me into her house.  Mother and Daddy were watching over my sister in the hospital.  Now she was a woman who had no children,  though shehad younger brothers, two of them, and one younger sister.   watched her own little sister, my mother, grow up, that had been a long time ago.  She was eventually allowed to come home, and finally in a chair for a full year before the doctor decided she could walk again, and go to school again.

*wheelchair for at least a year, and she was never really as healthy as she had been before her illness. She had four physicians, and three of them said she would not live because of her illness. Dear Dr. John Ashe said, yes, she will. And he was correct.

That didn’t rope and had to leave the game. and she did it ten times, jumping all the while Therefore, all her team mates could return to the game. When she had , and when her entire team except for herself had touched the rope, she alone was still jumping so she jumped ten turns of the rope, and earned a second chance for her team and so the others rejoined her, and eventually with several folks jumping the same rope her buddies eventually touched the rope, and were out of the game until she jumped ten perfect jumps again. Then without resting, the game went on. That evening she reported that she had jumped ten games, and each time she was the one left in the game, and she jumped ten perfect jumps ten times. edjumped with a group, and when everyone except her was out, she jumped ten perfect jumps, and her team was in the game again. She was clever, and strong, but she did not listen to her body, nor rest, nor drink water, and she jumped until her several team members were all out, then she jumped ten turns of the rope, and got them all back in the game again. until it started over again. When there was only one jumper left who had not touched the rope, that jumper could jump correctly ten turns of the rope, and her team could return to the game.

Well, my sister was a good jumper. And on a warm day she jumped for a long time, until she was the only jumper left, and then she jumped ten turns of the rope without touching it, and her team could rejoin her and jump until there was only one jumper left. Remember that this was a summer day. My sister jumped ten full games of jump rope, and was the last one on the team still jumping so that it was she who jumped ten turns of the rope without touching it, and therefore she had not had a rest, nor water, and was worn out at the end of the game. That night she spiked a fever. She went to the doctor. She was sent to the hospital. She grew worse, and it is difficult to understand that at that time there were no antibiotics. People who were sick mostly either got well or they died. Of course there were medicines, but nothing like penicillin had been discovered. She had fever, her lungs were filling with fluid, she was going to drown in her own fluids. Then her doctor drained out the liquid from her lungs, but she was very ill. There were at least four, maybe five physicians attending her. Four of them said that the kindest thing was to make her as comfortable as possible until she died—they had no hope. One doctor, said treat her, and she can live. He won.

I mentioned that there were no medicines that could truly kill germs. Persons who suffered from contagious illnesses such as tuberculosis were whisked off to a special hospital for people with that disease. That solved the problem of a contagious illness spreading all over a hospital, and therefore all over a city, ruining everyone exposed to the disease. There were no—repeat no—curatives for illnesses of that nature. Because tuberculosis and leprosy had no cures, people stricken needed hospitalization. But they could not mingle with healthy people because the diseases were so easy to contract, and epidemics with vast consequences had to be avoided. Sometimes flu, or typhoid, or many other known diseases could strike a community and hundreds of people could die. It happened. It happened in the United States. It happened when I was a child. I saw the damage Poliomyelitis could spread in a city, in a state. It happened in the mountains of North Carolina. Hundreds of people contracted the disease and none of the powerful antibiotics we have today were yet discovered. People became ill, and they either died, or were crippled for the rest of their lives. Some lost only the use of their legs, others lost almost all control of their bodies, and those whose lungs were affected lived only with an apparatus to breathe for them.

Some physician somewhere discovered that our bodies could tolerate and defend themselves if only a tiny bit of some illness were injected into the arms of patients. Therefore, injections of small doses of severe illnesses were given to perfectly well people, and it caused their bodies to create antibodies to fight it, so that those people would never be sick with that disease. used to help our own immune systems fight them should children come in contact with the disease.

injected could result in our own bodies building an army of anti-bodies within us, and with a tiny little shot, people could become immune to the illness. That was when shots began to be given in tiny doses to small children, so that they would never contract the disease. Their bodies could easily fight off a terrible illness by making antibodies to fight it.

In the 1930’s all children had to be inoculated to prevent small pox, a disease that killed half the people wherever it became an epidemic. Typhoid feva enough yphoid was like that. Some of the children’s diseases such as measles could turn into sort of plague, and there were debilitating illnesses that could devastate a community if the illnesses could not be controlled. that jumped from one person to aa cause that could be and not aiding , because if they were kept in an ordinary hospital they could give their nurses and doctors the disease, and spread it to everyone they came in contact with—including other patients. Therefore, tuberculosis patients were sent to hospitals that accepted only tuberculosis patients. where there were people sick with other illnesses, they could also become ill from those illnesses.. or other

surgery. She had pleurisy and another complication also. the game began again. without , and that one had not touched the rope, the last jumper in the group could, by jumping the turned rope ten times, begin the jumping session again, with all those in the group jumping usually at high speed, she could then invite her teammates to return and jump with her. . When I was in school years later, there were two teams in that game., and they were divided into two teams.

she was still compelled to use a wheelchair. She was whining one day, wanting something, and Mother was doing about three things at one time. I think she was scrubbing our laundry by hand on a metal “wash board” to get the dirt and stains out, and making a lunch at the same time. Ella Cornelia was being impatient, and saying things that would cue mother to “build up her ego and make her feel good” so my mother was trying to soothe her temper tantrum, when, all of a sudden, I helped her out. I told my loving sister I agreed with her, I let her know I was sympathetic. I sang a little song for her. It went like this: “Poor Ugly Cornelia, poor ugly Cornelia.” Young as I was, it didn’t surprise me that she didn’t appreciate it, and when she threw her shoe at me, I dodged it.

When my sister became ill, there were five or maybe six doctors who examined her, and consulted on her treatment. Four of them said she was so very sick that she would not live through her sickness. If she did pull through, she would be an invalid. There was one doctor, Dr. John R. Ashe, who said she would live. Dr. Ashe was not only Ella Cornelia’s doctor, he was also mine. He was the one doctor who did not give up on my sister. He treated her as well as he could in that time when there were no antibiotics, precious little, too. It was always Ella Cornelia should be watched over, and pampered. I, of course, was healthy, and strong. I could always wait for “next time” or I was too young to realize that she always got first dibs on anything, and if there was something she wanted, she got her desire much quicker than I did, and if I finally got something, it often cost less than hers, and showed it. I was young, but I wasn’t deaf, and I wasn’t so dumb that I didn’t know the difference. I also didn’t realize that my parents were trying to give her as much of what she wanted as they could possibly afford simply because she might not live a long life. They didn’t want to remember that she desired those shoes, or that dress, or anything else, and died before she could enjoy her choice. Therefore, they decided I would never know the difference if they spent more money on her than they did on me.

Now spending any amount of money was serious business. This was the time when the South felt the terrible weight and helplessness caused by the Depression. It was in the early 1930’s. Homes had been lost, jobs had been lost, investments had been lost. Rich people who lost money, and all their investments had jumped out of tall buildings, shot themselves, or drank themselves to death because they could not face being less than wealthy. But when the big important people lost “everything” a lot of working people, like my Daddy, lost their livelihood too. Not because they were too bold, or too secure that they didn’t see the disaster coming. My Daddy had invested in two houses. He bought them, then allowed them to pay in installments. Our family was sort of “living” on not only my father’s income from his job in a lumber yard, but he was also earning from houses he rented out—the rent was “profit” to my Daddy, and to my grandfather, too. Daddy had also bought two lovely houses, planning to move into one of them after a while, and in the meantime, using the rent money he received to pay the loans on the house. Of course the Depression caused the renters to be unable to pay rent, thus my Dad couldn’t pay the mortgages, and he lost the houses, and everything he had invested into them. . He also lost his job, because he was working for a lumber yard and nobody—but nobody—was building anything. Everybody was scratching to at least keep what they had, if possible. Sadly, it was rarely possible to hold on. There were no jobs. Without jobs, there was no money to spend. With no money no debts could be paid, and thus there were more failures. People who could grow their food on their farms were at least able to eat—if they had seed to plant. Houses could be, literally, given away in some instances, but most folks in this country were flat broke, with no jobs available, and no hope that things would change any time soon. Knowing people, or being kin to people who had farms usually meant you had some food. During that time, and for some years afterward there were people who wandered around towns, and cities, and farms, and anywhere they could beg a meal. Mostly those people were men. They had no “place” and they didn’t have clean clothes. Most had only worn out shoes and little in the way of suitable clothing. In summer they might wear long sleeved outing shirts, simply because they didn’t have any other shirts. In winter, some had only an old sweater, or a threadbare jacket. It seemed strange to me that most of the bums were white. I asked my Dad about that, and he said, the Negro people usually took care of their own. They, he told me, would share. I don’t mean that because they were willing to share with each other they didn’t suffer. They did.

My Grandfather and my Dad, long years before that time, had purchased some houses already built in an area where only Black people lived. Within Southern cities at that time, there were definite areas where Negroes could live, and other areas where White people lived. The differences were very easy to discern. Most of the black people lived on muddy roads, in dingy old housing without indoor toilets, and with maybe one spigot in the middle of an area where every one got water. The houses were not insulated, and none had a way to warm them except perhaps a fire place or a stove. Their roofs were not always in good repair, and most had an out-house somewhere in the neighborhood—not toilets or bathrooms. It was a miserable sort of life, but they were usually as clean as soap and water could make them, and somewhere near there would be a spigot of running water available. Most of the time the houses were quite close together. This, of course, made very small yards. Therefore, owners could squeeze more small houses in an area. Many white people made money on building houses and renting them to Black people. My father and his father did that. However, my Dad kept the houses he and his father rented out in good repair, and painted them often enough to keep them clean looking. The wife of one of the men that rented one of the houses sometimes did work for us, cleaning the house, washing the clothes, then ironing them when they were dry. That was a period of time that was long away from drip dry clothing, or machines that could dry wet clothes that, when hung up immediately didn’t need ironing. Those days were some years in the future. Almost all cottons had to be ironed before they could be worn.

Ardie would wash and hang out our clothes to dry, then clean up the kitchen (wipe off the stove, wash the dishes, mop the floor) and if the clothes were dry, she would bring them in, fold the linens, and iron the clothes. My Dad rented one of his houses to Ardie’s family, and helped any of them if he could. And my mother paid Ardie for her work in our house, never cheating her, or short changing her.

Those days were long before Negroes were recognized as equal to white people. My parents never took advantage of them. When so many people were out of work during the Depression, my parents lived East Fifth Street, one block from a Negro area. There was an old lady named Georgina who lived in that area, and she had no way to heat her house. In the winter my mother invited her to come to our house, because it was warm. Georgina was elderly, but she could and did wash dishes for us, and she helped my mother in other small ways, especially while my sister was so ill.

didn’t even try to go to school. They would work all day for a meal. themselves.called “bums” who had no home, no food, no jobs, and no hope. ThMost of the time it didn’t turn out to be possible. My Dad lost two houses, partially paid for, and nothing gained from that effort. He lost his job at the lumber yard, and therefore couldn’t even pay the rent on the house he was renting. This was a terrible time for him to lose his job because that was the time when my sister was sick. 1lost “everything” except their lives. It touch

. Of course, at my age I didn’t realize that was what moved my parents, so I simply thought that I was not “nice” enough to have those things. My sister took better care of her things than I did, therefore she could have nicer things than I was allowed to have. long enough to anything I needed, after all, I was healthy. My sister really needed help and constant care. I was sort of an imposition, no matter where I was.

Of course, no one, especially my mother, really considered me a nuisance. Not ever did she dislike me, or wish I wasn’t there. She always did her best for me. She made me dresses, I had a new doll each Christmas, she bought me shoes when I needed them, and I never thought I was unloved. I always understood; however, that I was in second place. Ella Cornelia was always first. I was only five years old when that fact was actually proven. . It came about because almost every time I went to see my grandparents, my Uncle Eddieone of my uncles gave me a coin. Mostly it was dimes. That was awesome. There was a filling station practically “next door” to my Grandparents house. My sister was also given a dime, and she promptly went to the filling station and bought a treat. My mother always opened her pocket book and placed my dime into “my” bank, which was “safe” in her purse. I wasn’t one to fret or fuss about decisions since I was told

I always knew that my sister’s needs, and sometimes her “wants” were more often than not, met. I didn’t understand that my parents thought she might die any day. Her life could be ended by any small illness on top of the sickness that still plagued her.

However, there was enough of that frequent momentary thought during my sister’s illness that gave me a cue that she was loved more, and was far more valuable than me—simplly because everyone thought she might die young, and therefore, since I had “plenty” of time, she always and had first dibs. I was the baby, but she always got first choice, and no one wanted that to happen. However, if it did, no one wanted a memory of a time when she had to wait for a treat, a new dress, a special item, a pair of shoes, or almost anything that she wished she had, if it was possible, she got that item, if it was at all possible.

that wasn’t cheaprubbed off on me to make me believe that I was much, much less important than my sister.

I know less about my maternal grandparents than I do of my paternal grandparents, simply because my Grandmother Parks died when I was about ten years old, and my Grandfather Parks was killed by a train about two years later. My Grandmother Yandle was an invalid most of my life, and though I saw her often, she was either in bed, or sitting in her rocking chair by a window all the time. I never saw her outside her house except once, when my Dad and Uncle Eddie carried her across her own yard, and a few feet further into her daughter’s house because my Dad was painting her room, and fixing things that weren’t working correctly. She was only out of her house for an afternoon, during which I kept her company.

I knew less about my Parks Grandparents becauseand my graneight, very young, so that I saw less of them than of my father’s parents. My Yandle grandparents lived until I was very close to adult-hood. paternal grandparents My mother’s parents lived on twhere my mother and her siblings grew up. My mother was the youngest surviving child in her family. Her parents, whose surname was Parks, lived on their own farm near the South Carolina line—not far from Pineville. I think a shopping mall was built on part of the Parks home place. I have very little memory of that home because I was about five years old when I last saw it, and don’t remember much about that house. On the front porch there was a hump-toped trunk, and I do remember that that day it rained, so that I could not go into the yard. I sat on the hump of the trunk, and watched the rain drops bounce on the edge of the porch. I did not realize that inside the house my mother was helping, and planning, a major change in the lives of her parents. My Grandmother Parks, my mother’s mother, had heart trouble, and my Grandfather Parks was old, and found it difficult to run their farm. , except there was a hump-backed trunk on the front porch, and because the grown-ups were talking inside the house, I watched . **a great number of actually there is a shopping mall, built a little before the year 2,000, which probably covers the farm my grandfather Parks owned. of our Parks grandparents, there was only one uncle who had children, and they lived in Fort Mill, South Carolina. It was easy for them to visit Uncle Dennis’s parents because they lived quite near the South Carolina line. If you are familiar with the geography of Charlotte, you may know where a mall was built on the southern edge of Charlotte—and I think that mall was built either on, or very near where my Grandfather Parks farmed when my mother was young.

When they visited our Parks grandparents they went to the farmin the Yandle family, and one of only three other grandchildren in the Parks family. Those Parks grandchildren lived in Fort Mill, South Carolina. In those days when they came to North Carolina they visited Uncle Dennis’ parents, my grandparents, who lived on their farm below Pineville. Uncle Dennis drove a 1925 Ford automobile, so his entire family, his wife, Aunt Mary, and their son, Dennis, Jr., and his sisters, Patsy, and Mary Cole. They usually came with him every time he visited his parents, or his sister Ola, and her husband Vance. Those cousins were not a problem to Ella Cornelia. She liked Dennis, Junior, and enjoyed playing with him. . We had only three first cousins, and they lived in Fort Mill. , and only three first cousins.

My mother had one brother, Dennis, who lived in Fort Mill, worked as a barber (he had his own barber shop) and his wife Mary ran a beauty shop next door to his barber shop. They had children—three of them—one boy and two girls. Her other brother, Luther, married, however had no children. My mother’s sister married a man named Vance Davis, but she was unable to have children. and her other brother did not have children. Of my father’s siblings only one sister was married when I was a child. Aunt Pauline married Henry, however they had no children. Uncle Eddie, Aunt Martha, and Aunt Helen still lived at home with my grandmother and grandfather. Uncle Eddie plowed the fields, planted and harvested every year, and looked after the mule and the cows. Aunt Helen fed the chickens, and Aunt Martha looked after her mother who was an invalid, and blind. , or very near it. when I was small, and she had no children. When A

aware that small children should not be forced to work((((((((((((((((((in jobs outside the family until they were sixteen. of that Mrs. Crump’s family, because if he could be mean to one child, he would be mean to all of them.

I felt blessed to be living in a more reasonable world—and a family that did not demand such labor from me. one that didn’t demand child labor. because the older Crump boy had at the along with another of his girl children. When he spotted the husband of his twelve year old daughter he began to . When her father spied the younger brother of the Crump boy who married his older dauaghte saw behind him the brother of the young Crump boy who had married his daughter, he yelled to a younger daughter who was with him, yelling “Run Sophie, run! Here comes another Crump, and he’ll have you and gone with you!” in Pineville with his younger daughter who was named Sophie. Sophie was probably ten or so, and Mr. Crump’s younger brother was walking down the street in Pineville On the sidewalk he spied the brother of Mr. Crump. He was still so angry , and he was walking with a younger sister On the pastreet Mr. *Crump was a minister then, having put himself through school. His wife, too, had learned to read and write, “Run, Sophie, Run! Here comes another crump, and he’ll have you and gone with you!” 8888888888888888888888888888888 When she was only twelve the two of them talked at length to each other, and one day the young man thought of a way out for the girl. If she was married, even at that age, she would no longer belong to her father—she would be a married woman. There was no ban on young marriages, so the boy bought a license, married the girl, and with his earnings rented a house for them to live in. The young husband continued to do a man’s work at the mill. When they married the girl, for the first time in her life, had a little free time. Since she had never “played” in her life, she wanted the experience. When her husband came home to her in the summer, when it was still light, she fed him supper, and then they would go outside, and the girl would draw lines in the dirt, and lay out a “dream” house, and “play like” the lines drawn in the dirt were walls of their home, and then pretend to furnish it with marvelous furniture that was really an down-turned bucket or a tree stump. ***house in the dirt of their back yard, and mark with a line drawn by a stick the rooms of her pretend house. Then they would sit on boxes and have a pretend tea party, and The girl was not compelled to work, but she kept house for her young husband. , no matter what her age. and take a nap, standing up. , children were often sent into factories, especially mills, when they were quite young. This young girl went to work in a cotton mill when she was four years old. Her father collected her pay, which was a very small amount. A problem in the cotton mill was the lint that fell on the floors. Therefore, young children could, and did, sweep up the lint. that lint from the Her duty was to sweep up lint from the floor of the mill, which was a problem. whose father was mean—and she was sent to work in a cotton mill when she was four or five years old. She pushed a broom to keep the floor free of lint, and she did it for twelve hours every work day, six days a week. When she grew tired the overseer in charge of the mill would allow her to lean against one of the pillars that held up the roof of the mill, and she could lean back against that pillar and go to sleep standing up. He could not allow her sit down, or lie down—that was against the rules—but he could allow her to rest against a pillar, and he did. That story has an end, and I shall tell it to you now: The girl worked there until she was twelve years old. Another child worked there, too, a boy, who was about fourteen or fifteen years old. He admired that girl child and thought it was not fair that her father would not give her any of the money she earned, not even for shoes. In those days, a child’s pay for any work belonged to his, or her parents. That boy began to pity, and then to love, the little girl. In those days, when a girl married, her father could no longer take from her the money she earned while working. A wife’s money could be used by her husband—but her father could no longer take it. So that young man of about fourteen married the twelve year old girl, and she was free to leave both her parent’s home, and the mill. Her father was more than a little angry because she married so quickly that he had no chance to forbid it. It also meant her father could no longer force her to work, nor take her wages if she did work. He could not demand anything of her any more since she was a married woman—no longer was she his child.

I, myself, talked with that lady when she was older than my mother by a year or two. She had never actually “played” during her childhood, and she had always wanted to play as other children did. Therefore, after their marriage, in the evenings when her husband came home from work and after they had eaten supper, he agreed to go into the yard with her, and play “house” like other children, especially in the summer when it was still light. She would do, as I did when I was a child. In the back yard where there was no grass, she drew lines in smooth dirt, marking out the rooms of her “house” and making mud pies for the pretended “supper.” They sat on bits of tree stumps, and pretended they were on beautiful stuffed chairs with lovely pillows.

Playing “House” was something that almost all children did in that day and time. It was a game my mother played when she was very small. My sister, seven years older than I, also played it with her friend, though never with me. I must admit that my sister had a difficult time acknowledging that I was part of the family. A child seven years old—the only child—has every reason to feel special. Then one day my father’s sister, my Aunt Martha who could drive a car, came into Charlotte from Pineville, and scarcely spoke to my sister, already seven years old, and then, without much discussion, left my sister, Ella Cornelia, with a neighbor, not even telling her where they were going, or when they would be back. Ella Cornelia felt as if she had been In addition, though Aunt Martha came back to the house, Mother did not!! Ella Cornelia didn’t know, nor was she told, where mother went, why mother went, or when she would return home. At seven years old, she was frightened and more than a little dismayed by the situation. Then after several days Aunt Martha came back, bringing mother back again, however there was a change: when mother came home, she brought a crying baby girl—tiny little thing—that a lot of who had, all of her life, been of considerable importance, especially to family members. Now, family and friends were eager to see the “little baby”! Therefore, they didn’t pay much attention to Ella Cornelia when they came. Actually, it was a fact that they all sort of ignored Ella Cornelia, but excitedly wanted was to see the “new baby”. The one that cried, and soiled diapers—and that was a bummer, with a capital “B”. One of the worse parts was that Mother seemed to feel sort of weak or not quite well; therefore, Ella Cornelia had to help hand wash that stinky little baby’s nasty diapers and dresses, as our family didn’t have a washing machine. Ella Cornelia desired with all her heart, and for a very long time, that she could talk mother into returning that baby girl to wherever it came from!

I, myself, loved everybody when I was little—but young though I was, I was wary of my sister, and realized that she did not like me much at all. When Ella Cornelia turned ten years old, I was—give or take a month or two, just about three years old. It was summer, and on a warm day Ella Cornelia played jump rope with a number of friends.

In that day and time, the game of jump rope could be played as a group game. There were, of course, rules to the game, some of which varied because of the age and gender of the jumpers, or the . The game my sister played was that two or three jumpers would jump at the same time. If a jumper touched the rope, or the rope touched one of them, the girl who was touched was out of the game, leaving the others to continue. Usually only two or three jumpers could jump at the same time because with a larger crowd there was insufficient room to maneuver. , and lots of people would be touched by the rope. . If the rope touched a jumper, she was out, and became a spectator. If it was a group game and three or four people jumped at the beginning of the game, it was the last one who had not been touched by the rope who could “save the day” by jumping ten jumps (while the rope turners would try to vary the rhythm so that it would not be easy) lots of different rules Two people would turn the rope. All the others would be in a group of four or five, and as the rope was turned, the jumpers would jump as a group. Of course it was hard for a large group to jump together, and if the rope touched a jumper, she was out of the game, and became a watcher. The rope turners were usually pretty steady, but were free to change the speed of their turns, making the judging of the rhythm difficult. When the several jumpers were removed, leaving only one member of the “team” still jumping, the jumpers had another chance—because of the last jumper from the game one by one because each had been touched by the rope, it was possible for the team to a jumper had touched the rope,to make the jumping more difficult. did not stop turning If a jumper touched the rope, she was out, and became a watcher while the other members of her team continued to jump. When only one jumper was left, she could try to redeem her group’s chances of entering the game again by jumping alone ten turns of the rope without touching it, but those ten turns could be fast, and difficult to keep up with. If the last jumper actually jumped the ten fast turns of the rope, her team could run in one by one and join her again. The rope did not stop turning so long as one jumper was still jumping, unless the turners were too tired to turn. Usually there were enough when the jumpers began to be tired, they made more mistakes, and when no one could jump the ten redeeming jumps for her team, the rope turners were relieved, and the rope turners changed to former jumpers, and the turners were then free to be jumpers. by When the last jumper was alone, and had(or if) the jumpers returned, If a jumper was touched by the rope, she was out, and she would become one of the turners of the rope, and the others would begin a new game. . y two, or maybe three on a single team. Two would turn the rope. The first “team” of three, or perhaps four, would begin to jump. It didn’t usually take long for at least one person to step on the rope. That person was out. When there was only one person left jumping who had not touched the rope, and that person could jump ten turns of the rope without mishap, her team could join her again, one at a time, by running in to join the one who had jumped ten clean jumps and saved the “team” from taking over the turning of the rope. and jumping without stopping the turning rope to without touching the rope, counting the jumps was important. If the only team member could jump ten turns of the rope without touching it, her entire team was still in the game.

That meant that if one person could jump ten more perfect jumps she and her team-mates were still in the game. Being tired had something to do with the wrong timing of a jump, but kids with good health and agility could do very well for their team, and that is what my sister did that day. She played ten games, never touched the . It was played like this: one day she played a very active game of jump rope with a group of her friends, probably six or more girls, who divided themselves into two ”sides.” One team turned the rope, and the other group jumped, all at one time. Only two or three could jump at one time. When only one had not failed to jump so that she was touched by the rope, she was “out” of the game. When only one of the team was left, if she jumped ten jumps without touching the rope, her team could return to jump another game, and the rope turners had to keep turning the rope. When all of the jumping a jumper, she was out. If only one “jumper” correctly (it was tiring”, the other side jumped, together. When the rope touched a girl, she had to sit out of the game. That day there was a group of girls playing, divided into two teams. One team turned the rope, and the other team would jump it. Ella Cornelia was an excellent jumper. Her team was the first to jump, while the other team turned the rope—and that meant that all of that team jumped until at least one had touched the rope—and that jumper was “out” of the game, but not permanently. When only one member of a team was left to jump, if that one person could jump successfully ten times, the others could re-join her team, again and the team that was turning the rope had to continue turning the rope. When all the team members were jumping the rope at the same time, it was easy for a jumper to touch the rope. When a jumper touched the rope, she was temporally “out” of the game until only one jumper was left. If that single jumper jumped the rope ten times without touching the fast moving rope, her team of at least three jumpers, could return. If the ‘ten” jumper missed, the other team would become the jumpers, and the loosing team became the rope turners. , and it could be turned fast as a challenge to the single jumper, that team could still ie out of the gameWhen most of the team had touched the rope and only two were left, it was easier for the jumpers to keep right on jumping. When there was only one jumper, if that jumper was able to stay there for ten fast jumps, without touching the rope, her team could enter the game again because that one jumper had jumped ten quick turns of the rope without touching it. However, the one who had jumped ten times had to stay in the group. team could come there were several team members jumping at the same time, it usually didn’t take long for some one to be touched by the rope, but with only one jumper, it was easier tojumpers three jumpers could rejoin her since she had jumped ten times without touching the rope. On that day, Ella Cornelia played ten games. She did not touch the rope—but each time she was left alone, it was she who jumped the extra ten times so that her team mates could re-enter the game. She arrived at home wet with perspiration, and very tired. The next day she was ill.

Ella Cornelia’s illness occurred well after 1931—the year I was born. I know, because I was I am told I was about three years old when she became ill. Remember that there were no antibiotics. Her illness was so severe four doctors pronounced her incurable—but one insisted she would live, and that was Dear, wonderful, Dr. John R. Ashe.

Much later in my life my mother told me that

born in 1931, and I was two or perhaps closer to three when she became ill. Those were the years of the depression, even though the date was a several years past 1929. The depression shattered thousands of lives because when banks failed every person patronizing that bank lost whatever he had put there—whether the deposit was small, minimum, or large, it was gone. If you owed money on a large item like a home, or furniture, and you had paid some fraction of its worth already, the entire balance of its cost remained unpaid, and because banks went broke, whatever you had saved against a rainy day was gone—and, yes, almost every person, business, and bank was affected. Your savings, your bank account, eventually anything that had not been fully paid for, was gone. People were angry, terrified, terribly upset because the bottom of commerce just fell away, and the walls came tumbling down. Businesses didn’t just have a hard time—they crashed along with the banks. have beenwhen the banks failed and you couldn’t retrieve your savings, or even what was in your checking account, with a loan almost anywhere—home, automobile, or business—lost not just the hope of fully owning whatever they were buying, but they lost what they had already invested. If you could not completely pay for your car, house, building, furniture—or any item you had promised to pay for in small increments—were no longer yours, even is you had only a few more payments since you had not completely paid for it. You failed to complete your bargain, and deserved no part of what you had already paid . Bank failures meant there was nothing to borrow. Businesses that had debts lost in the same manner. Banks closed, because they had no money. Businesses could not pay their employees because the banks had closed. People who did not receive their pay checks couldn’t pay their bills, either. Folks who were paying down a mortgage paid, as well as the opportunity to own whatever they were buyinghad his loan called in—pay up or hand over whatever you were buying. most people were out of work when the companies that had hired them collapsed because the companies had borrowed money to expand, and when the cause of the depression was shattering lives and fortunes. Within a few days Ella Cornelia was placed in a hospital (in a time frame when there were no insurance plans to help with illnesses) and she was desperately ill with Pleurisy, along with another illness which affected her heart, had a name I have forgotten. There were four doctors in Charlotte who said she would die because her illness was so severe that she would not recover. Remember that there were at that time no antibiotics. No medicines that could help her. There was, however, one doctor who said, don’t give up—she will live. His name was John Ashe. And he was correct—she did live, though it was a difficult battle, both in expenses and in her struggle to be well again. It did not come easily. She was fragile, restricted to bed rest at first, and later was told not to do some of the things she had earnestly enjoyed. She spent a long time in bed, and a longer time in a wheel chair or on restricted movements. This was the child who loved to dance, and jump rope. This was the active child who had numerous friends with whom she actively joined in physically active games. This was my sister, and I was a true hindrance to her, mostly because I was so young that I needed constant care, at a time when our mother needed to give both diligent and constant care to my sister.

My memories of that time are few, as I was about three years old. I was talking fairly well. I was told that while my sister was in the hospital, and perhaps the first few days, or even weeks, Ella Cornelia was at home. She needed a great deal of nursing and was not allowed to walk on her own for at least a full year. I was too small to remember the timing—or recall how long I lived with my mother’s sister, Ola. went to live with my mother’s sister, Aunt Ola, and Uncle Vance. And that was a very different environment. My mother’s sister had no children, and lived a couple of miles from Pineville. That meant that she lived about ten miles from Charlotte, in an area that did not have electricity, or running water. She had no children, and had not played nursemaid to very many babies, She and my mother had two brothers who lived in South Carolina, one too far away to be helpful in an emergency. **although her brother Dennis also had three children. Dennis and his wife Mary lived in Fort Mill, about ten or so miles away from Pineville. In those days automobiles were available, but not everyone had a car. as did Mary’s sister. too. Dennis, his wife Mary, and their three children at that time. Uncle Dennis lived in Fort Mill, one, or possibly two children. She lived out in the country, and at that time the houses in that area had no indoor toilets, nor any electricity, nor did they have running water in the house. All water was carried up a substantial hill from a spring. There were no electric lights, only kerosene lamps. She did not do any household chore exactly as my mother did. She was not my mother. Her husband wore blue overalls, not white ones like my Dad. At night it was dark! In the yard there was a dog. I didn’t like it—and besides she wet my hair, and I truly disliked that! I told her: “you went and wet my hair!”

If even one of her team mates could jump ten turns of the rope without touching it, her entire team could rein. jumper—and the entire team jumped at one time. When the rope touched one of the jumpers, that person had to drop out. When all except one had been called “out” the one jumper still in the game could jump ten jumps, and her team could return to jump again. leave the team.One team turned the rope and the other team jumped. When all the jumpers save one had touched the rope and been called “out”, the one remaining jumper could, by jumping ten more times without touching the rope, win another try for her team. My swift, athletic sister kept her team “in” the jumping for ten full games, and though her other team members touched the rope and were called “out” she had been the last one still in for her team, and each time she jumped ten times without touching the rope. from jumping, the last jumper could jump ten times, and if there was no miss-step by touching the rope, the entire team could come back in, and jump another turn. Her team game, and each time my sister’s group had only one jumper left in the game it was my sister. Then she jumped alone the required ten jumps that would put her team back

number of perfect jumps that put her entire team back to jump again, instead of turning the rope.There were lots of girls playing, and it was a group game. They Thereafter Ella Cornelia, in one word, disliked that little interloper, for whom there were times when she had to be quiet, and stop doing what she wanted to do—fun things such as tap dancing, or playing with friends. , or other fun things that suddenly were not acceptable Not only found that girl baby a nuisance, but almost everybody our family visited and

wasn’t ther where she was, nor why she left home, nor did she know when mother would come back. , or even why, she didn’t come back home. That was, as one would say today, a bummer

Not only that, Aunt Martha did not bring Mother back home.

, and my sister, seven years older than me, also played it, though never with me (I was a nuisance to her until I was thirteen). It was simple, and required only a stick of some kind, and bits and pieces of discards from the house, and considerable imagination. It was called “playing house”. Of course, there was no grass in my backyard, except along the bottom edge of a wire fence that separated our yard from the neighbors. We drew rectangles in black dirt, and named them living room and kitchen, and we found things lying around in the nearby yards that could be seats, or tables, or perhaps jar lids that we called plates, and jars that were tumblers for our “tables” that rarely resembled a real one. In my back yard they were often empty up-side-down paint buckets, as my father was a painting contractor.
