I never had a swing (except on the front porch) or a see-saw that wasn’t “spur of the moment” and not quite satisfactory. I never even had a sand pile until I was close to the age of finding sand piles too “childish”.

we picked up lines in rectangles along with neighbor children. “Rooms” were laid out and furnished with imagination and the handy bits and pieces of whatever was near to make furniture by me, and all of the girl children I knew while growing up. also played in make-believe rooms, drawn by sticks on bare earth. However, my “chairs” were up-side down empty paint buckets because my father was a painting contractor. The visit by the couple who had married so very young was the only time I ever saw them, but I have remembered them all these years. It was a lesson on how cruel people could be to their own family members, and how blessed I was to belong to my family. I remembered how tenderly he cared for her as they left the house occupied by my grandparents. As they descended the steps he held her elbow, and he didn’t leave her to enter the car alone—he handed her into her seat in the car, closed her door, and then walked to his own side of the car, and climbed into his seat. I thought that was very nice of him. And I believed that it meant he loved her very much.

That story has a really happy ending. The youth and his child bride settled down to married life, and when he was older he went to school, and eventually became a preacher. She became a good wife, and helped him as he studied, and as he began to preach, and eventually to pastor churches. I met them one Sunday when they visited my blind grandmother, and at that time I was probably about twelve years old, and they were probably in their forties—or perhaps a bit younger or even older. I thought they were both fine looking people, and I was in the room as they were leaving at the end of their visit with my grandmother and the other members of the family, and the preacher paused a moment, and said a prayer, which I thought was a very good prayer—I remember, young though I was, that I approved of him. Though I don’t remember exactly what he said in his prayer, I decided that I would like to hear him preach, since I had learned of his background, but I don’t remember ever seeing them again. Life is like that sometimes. You see and understand a little more about life, and the living of it, but you have only the one chance to take in a lesson, or learn a truth, and it is good if you can remember it, and use it as an experience that is meant to teach you something, because the opportunity is rarely offered a second time.

There are lots of true stories that are actually entertaining. Of course, not every story is as riveting as the one about the girl who married at twelve years old. I heard that story when I was about twelve, and I met the people at my grandmother’s house. But then, I heard lots of stories about how people lived, loved, and had children who were worthy of admiration. I would like to share some of those events with you.

There was another part of that story that I learned when I mentioned those folk to my Daddy one evening. He told me that Pineville was a small village in those days—not as large as it was when I was growing up. The father of that twelve year old wife was very angry because of her marriage. He was angry at that boy, because he knew that if he had not married his young daughter she would have had to work in the mill until she was twenty-one years old, and she could not have kept even a penny of her wages until she was twenty-one years old. The man was angry that he could no longer collect her earnings. He had another girl child, named Sophie, who was about eight years old. The father and Sophie were walking down the street in Pineville when he saw a youth walking toward him. The old man yelled out at the child who was with him: “Run, Sophie, run! Here comes another Crump, and if he sees you, he’ll have you and gone with you!”

I was delighted with the story—the lady had escaped from a “bad” father. However, it taught me that not all fathers were nice—and that probably meant that not all mothers were nice, either. I remember that I was glad my parents were good to me. It told me that I should appreciate them more, and try with honest diligence to make life good for them, as well as myself.

As years passed, State, and Federal laws prohibited hiring small children for jobs. Even the motion picture makers could not have babies or very young children on sets for hours on end. And sometimes the motion picture makers hired twin babies, so that their camera time with the baby could be doubled. States and our Federal Government passed laws that prevented companies from hiring small children to do a full day’s work. There were age limits that would prevent children who had reached their teen age years from having an job without parental agreement. Furthermore, some part of local stat or city government had to , and the Federal Government made rules about child labor, so that little children could not be hired out at early ages. I don’t remember what the ages were way back then, but when I was growing up, children of less than sixteen could apply for jobs only if they had a special license from the government to do so. It was against the law to keep a child from going to school in order to work at a job.

, rules were laid out demanding that children could you now. Mng up. North Carolina, and many other states, was becoming strict about the schooling of children because uneducated people were troublesome folk. Therefore the state government had set up rules so that parents were compelled to send their children to school when they reached the age of six years. It was no longer possible for parents to send their small children into a mill to sweep the floors, or to any other duty. Before schooling became a rule, parents could push four or five year old children to work, and that child would have to do whatever he or she was told to do, instead of allowing schooling, or even not schooling children, was not a parental option any more—it was a law. becoming had lots of rules where school was concerned, and when it was time for him to enroll in the first grade, the schools were fairly strict about the ages of the children. First Graders were accepted only if they turned six by a specific date. Past that date by only one day—and the child had to wait until next year to start.

Well! Loraine Beatty was a petite person, and not just a “female” but was genuinely a lady, as well as a mother. However, she did not want her son to twiddle his thumbs for a year because he lacked a few days of being all of six years old—so she didn’t wait, and he didn’t wait, because she altered his date of birth by about 30 days, and enrolled him in the first grade.

September was normally the month in which school began, and so little Bobby Beatty enrolled at Dilworth School and began his school career as a student. Destined to finish high school at the end of the twelth school year, Bobby settled into his work in twelve years. Bobby was an intelligent child, and did well at school. He got on well with his teachers, and his school friends, but he did not actually complete his sixth grade classes at that school. When he was about ten years and unexpected event changes a lot of things in his young life.

Bobby’s paternal grandfather, William Beatty, was a policeman. One Sunday evening Grandfather William Beatty worked late. His wife, Hattie, had been at home most of the day, enjoying fixing a meal and sharing it with their married daughter, Virginia and her husband, Marvin, and their children. Late that afternoon Grandmother Hattie became anxious when her husband didn’t arrive home when he was expected. Grandmother had telephoned his office, but there was no answer. As the evening lengthened, she asked her visiting son-in-law, Marvin, if he would drive down to his father-in-law’s office to see what was delaying him. He had not answered his telephone when his wife had called him, and he was not often this late returning home. When Marvin arrived at Courthouse office, he found his Father-in-law still at his desk, but no longer alive. It was a very sad thing. His wife, and his grown-up children, and their children, were devastated, as were his co-workers. Grandfather Beatty was widely respected by his superiors and his fellow officers on the Police Force, and well loved by his family, his daughter and her husband and their children, and his two sons and their wives and their children. Grandfather Beatty had many friends, and a large family. He was dearly loved, and sadly grieved by many. And his death changed a lot of thing for his family.

At her husband’s death Grandmother Hattie had to rearrange things in her house to make room for her oldest son’s young family who were moving into her house to help her. The move meant that Paw-paw would have to change schools, and life would certainly be different.

Hattie Beatty was an older woman—but she was tough just the same. She and her husband had owned their house since early in their marriage. He had been a policeman for years, but he was also an excellent wood-worker, and made furniture in his basement. I still have a table that he gave to his oldest son’s wife, who was my mother-in-law. I have kept that table for more than fifty years, myself, and it is in use in my house now. The house where the Beatty’s lived was large. It was the house their two sons and one daughter had grown up in, and it was a center for all of them, as they were frequent visitors.

The basement of their house was large and well used because it served as a laundry, a woodworking shop, a storage for home canned foods, a wine cellar, and a play place for numerous grandchildren who visited frequently. On one side of the house was a glassed in place where plants lived in winter, and just outside was a miniature glass

room, but it was also a wood-working shop, and it served as the space where many of Grandfather Beatty’s projects made. Her husband had been a wood-worker, and had machinery in the basement so that he could make furniture. He was a “man of all work” and stayed busy most of the time he was not working as a policeman for the City of Charlotte. Since the house was located precisely across the street from Lance Packing Company, the famous company that makes those little packages of cheese crackers and potato chips that are still in demand today. Hattie, with the large house just across the street, had taken in boarders who worked for Lance Packing Grandmother Beatty had taken in boarders for years—most of whom were drivers for either Lance Packing, or the street cars that provided public transportation in Charlotte. or the Lance trucks that delivered potato chips and crackers all over the city of Charlotte. nd now that would be difficult, but not impossible, even though her son, his wife, and their little boy were moving in and a great deal would change. Little Bobby was in school, and would have to continue to go school each morning. Some of the regular boarders might have to find other accomodations, and return each afternoon. The house of his grandmother had taken in boarders for years.
routines for sending a child to school from that location. Because Hattie had been in total control of her home for many years, it was difficult, actually close to impossible, for her to ask her daughter-in-law if the recent arrangements made by Hattie were suitable to her. It was hard on Bobby’s mother, too. She was no longer the only mistress of the house she lived in, nor did she now have the “last word” about changes. Despite difficulties, new arrangements eventually became ordinary. If the two ladies were not in total agreement, time rubbed away most of the dismay.

Changing from one school to another for young Bobby was accomplished, and didn’t seem to bother him. Grandmother Hattie kept on running her boarding house, and Bobby’s mother, took a job uptown in Ivey’s Department Store.

Life is ever changing, and time kept right on ticking in the house on South Boulevard. The newness of the situation wiped itself off into a matter of routine. By becoming not quite so new due to the passage of time and the true desire to keep peace among all the folk involved, the situation became ordinary, and expected, and the newness sort of wore off in routine. Everyone seemed to slide into the now ordinary and expected every-day routines as time passed. The rough moments smoothed into that routine, and the three generations accepted the changes.

Bobby had no difficulty changing schools. His mother had not worked outside her house before the move. She had always been at home after school let out. Now she was at work when her son returned from school, and Bobby had a different pattern in his after-school situation. Of course in the summer he enjoyed a real bonus when his three cousins came with their mother (his Aunt Virginia) to visit Nan-naw, which is what all the children called his Grandmother. Bobby’s uncle Erskine lived near by, also, but his only child was a quite young little girl, so the boys didn’t see her as often as they saw each other.

Another new adventure was Bobby’s discovery of the Boy Scouts. There was a Boy Scout troop meeting in a church not far from his grandmother’s home. He joined the troop, and began to earn badges. He doesn’t remember exactly how old he was when he ventured into the Boy Scout experience. He does remember that the group met in a nearby church, and he was encouraged to earn badges for specific accomplishments as a Scout. Scouts were expected to “earn” badges to sew on their uniforms. Among the challenging projects that ended with a badge to display was a long hike of fourteen miles—that is, seven miles away from the starting point, and seven miles back. Bobby wanted to earn that badge. However, he had no fellow scout to share his hike. Of course his mother didn’t want him to walk fourteen miles alone. In fact, she said no! Not alone! When there didn’t seem to be any one who could conveniently accompany him on his hike his mother did what most mothers would have done—she herself went with him, walking seven miles away from home base, and seven miles—each and every one of them—all the way back home. In due time, Paw-paw received his Boy Scout Badge for a fourteen mile hike.
Paw-paw enjoyed Boy Scouts, and when he was about twelve he went on a Boy Scout camping trip. But when he changed schools the next fall, he joined the school band, and doesn’t remember going to scout meetings after that.

Time, people, animals, and cities, no matter how beautiful The City of Charlotte found itself growing. Some of the older school buildings were growing so old they were no longer totally safe for use. One of those buildings was a school with a grand name: Alexander Graham School, with a grand location just off

was close to the great Catawba River, and from early childhood Paw-Paw and his parents, and lots of other family members often went to the river for a refreshing weekend. however, when he started to Junior High School he didn’t attend the meetings he decided, while still in grammar school, that he wanted to play the cornet—sometimes call a trumpet—and between the ending of his sixth grade class and the beginning of the seventh grade he took lessons throughout the summer so that he could play cornet in the band. When school began in September he attended his first Band practice, and was quite disappointed when his director announced that the band already had all the cornets it needed. What , and when school started he joined the band. Things did not work out exactly how he planned it, though, because when school he thought about playing an instrument in the school band. He wanted to play a cornet, and wanted to take music. When he left the Sixth Grade, and was changing from

Across town, while Pawpaw was growing up, riding his bike to school, and riding it back home again. When he entered While he was delivering newspapers everyday, and attending school, the rest of the world became restless, with events occurring in other countries that were not only troubling, but downright frightening.

The citizens of the United States, for the most part, spoke English, though many people could speak more than one language because their parents, or their grandparents who had come to this country in the early 1900’s, still spoke the language of their European childhood, even if they also spoke English. It was usual that people who spoke the same languages would dwell close together if possible, and in many of the larger cities there would be sections in which at least two languages were spoken. The older folk usually treasured the language they grew up with, and couldn’t discard it. The younger ones became fluent in both languages, and used English at school, and with neighbors, but at home spoke the language of their grandparents.

In today’s world, especially in the United States, almost everyone has at least one television set, and I can tell you that in my house there are three—our private TV located in our sitting room, the larger family one in the living room, and another private one in Jessica’s bedroom, that received only local stations.

The living room T.V. set is used almost exclusively by Jessica and Matthew, or their five siblings who live just across the street. Of course there is a TV across the street, too, but often there is a conflict of interest in the available broadcasts, that means either one or more of the children are disappointed in the choice of stations. Therefore, they often visit us—or rather our living room television—especially when there is a difference of opinion about which of the available programs will be watched at home. *When father, mother, or other siblings wish view a particular program then difficulties arise when it is discovered that someone else has first choice, and when it is time for some other broadcast that is dear to another member of the family. when someone (like a Mother or a Daddy) insists on watching a specific program when one other person (or maybe a bunch of other persons) desire to watch a different station. want to watch something else.

Jessica and Matthew have private rooms, but both are small, with little room to spare once there is a bed, a chair and perhaps a table or desk in the room. When the young people invite company, or just want to relax, they use the nicely furnished living room that has two sofas, lamp tables, a coffee table, a piano and a couple of unusual chairs that have seats and backs, but no legs. The floor chairs are great for playing video games since they can be used quite close to the screen of the TV. The leg-less chairs place the sitting person about six inches off the floor, just opposite the TV screen, and within easy reach of the controls for the game. The padded backs of the strange close-to-the-floor rockers are sturdy and comfortable, and the controls for the game easily are easily used.

The large living room is open to the dining room—actually not a separate room, but a separate area at one end of the kitchen. Our table is not far from the threshold, and will seat eight people if they are good friends. If any of the people are touchy about being too close to each other, the table will seat only six folks. The kitchen is wonderful, with sink, counters, pantry, lots of shelf space for dishes, and in the middle, a large work table that has storage space beneath it. In one corner of the kitchen is a small pantry with lots of shelves. Cabinets with doors line the walls of the kitchen. Most of the living room opens into the dining room/kitchen area. I love the kitchen-dining room set-up. The eating area is visible from the living room, and in the wall beyond the table is a double sliding door overlooking our back yard, letting in light and sunshine and the vision of a stand of forest—not especially planted for our enjoyment—but an untamed forest of various trees, that have lived not very far from a lake for long years. A little of the forest is on our land, and was not removed when the house was being built. Between our house and the lake there are unsold lots, a road, and an embankment that surrounds a huge lake—the one that supplies water to a very large area. The lake has water, fish, and banks—with a few small animals that frequent lake-sides. Fishing is allowed, but no boats of any sort.

Our house is not actually on the lake, but since there are no houses on the road that runs between us and the lake we can see the lake surface during the winter when the trees have no leaves. In summer the view is of green leafed trees that any slight wind turns into a moving, swaying wall of differently shaped trees, and nearer to us, honeysuckle and vines that that blend in with the leafy trees to produce a massive wall of natural beauty. In winter, we can see snatches of the lake between the bare branches.

Can you believe that when Paw-paw and I were young there was no—absolutely no—television? Some folks had radio. Our family had one because one Christmas Daddy bought one as a family Christmas present. During the day, and for the most part, during the work week, the radio sat on the kitchen table. Sometimes on Sunday we moved it into the living room. Then one summer day when I was about twelve years old, Daddy had an opportunity to buy another radio, which took its place in our living room. It took up lots of room, and was a wonderful machine because, in order to hear records, we didn’t have to wind up a turntable with a crank. The click of a knob turned on the radio, which could pick-up broadcasts from several local stations, and a few distant ones. If you owned a record either ten or twelve inches in diameter, you could place a it on a turn table with an upright spike through the hole in its center, and listen to the music etched on the ten inch, or twelve inch, disc. The discs were called records. Our marvelous player had an automatic device could drop a stack of records on the turntable and play them one by one, without having to manually change the disc. Awesome!

There were four or five movie houses in the up-town area, and to my complete surprise, one day we drove on a busy road near Presbyterian Hospital, and discovered that a new movie theater had been built along the street. There were several buildings in the area, and most of them had doctor’s offices in them. Then smack dab in the middle of all those serious buildings was a fun thing—a motion picture theatre. It stayed there for years, and may be there yet—however I don’t live in Charlotte any more, and I don’t know.

There had always been grocery stores, and drug stores close to areas where there were homes. Most of the department stores were “up town” in the business center. Charlotte, when it began to grow, and houtime the stores were drugstores built near small grocery stores, or other convenient shops. malls, though they had not yet come to be call “malls” as the shops were usually small and limited in their products. a couple on heavily traveled streets well traveled streets There had been movies in theaters for a long time—at least it seemed long to me. for, and movies that were shown in theaters; but not television. Television may have already been a hope or dream in someone’s mind, but it was not in the market, nor was it talked about in the early years of World War II. Radio was useful to soldiers who used that medium to stay in contact with leaders, especially when troops were stretched out over a wide area, and certainly when enemy soldiers were near any part of their location. Scientists in both America and the countries we were fighting were working on ways to intercept messages, and methods to secretly provide information to their armies without the enemy intercepting the same information. Civilians, adults and children alike, were considered much less important than soldiers. There were shortages of food in grocery stores, shortages of clothing and shoes in department stores, shortages of automobiles and trucks for ordinary businesses, and shortages of doctors and nurses because they were on the front lines of the war. There were shortages of people to work in offices, and sometime churches had no pastor because their preacher had enrolled in the military to serve as chaplain wherever he was needed—on army training bases, or with fighting men on the battleground.

Fruits and vegetables that had once been canned began to appear in jars—much more fragile than cans. However, metal was scarce because vehicles and guns and planes were being produced, therefore ordinary items were simply not manufactured because of the lack of supplies.

People were scarce, too. Many manufactured items were necessary to the war effort, and if they were necessary for the ordinary home use of civilians, they quickly became scarce and hard to find. Since the government had first choice on all items, the civilians began to suffer from lack. Ladies could not buy the stockings they liked best, clothing of all sorts was hard to find, especially shoes. Men in important necessary jobs were drafted into the military, and there were no others men available to take their places.

Until that time women rarely worked outside the home except in a few cotton mills, or perhaps in a department store, or doing what women had always done, care for the sick as a hospital nurse, or perhaps some other acceptable, lady-like occupation. That factor changed quickly. Women began to step into offices, banks, stores of all kinds, and when the need arose, into factories where before the war began only men had been hired. Women learned to drive, as soon as their father’s or brothers, or husbands went into service. Women began to clerk in grocery stores, in department stores, in restaurants, and most important of all, in factories making war materials like guns, airplanes, boats, ships, and cars. Gender no longer mattered, because Many factories had to build a new room or two because now they needed restrooms for women, too.

Young girls past their sixteenth or seventeenth birthdays went to work in hospitals as Nurses Aids. That title was, to my knowledge, brand new. *

, women stepped into jobs formerly always filled by men. The sudden change in the gender of workers was extremely notable. Women appeared in offices, yes—but also in factories, in hospitals, in stores, in areas where women had never before worked. Ladies who were far too feminine and delicate to do anything outside their homes, were suddenly working in factories, in offices, in areas that would have caused a “scandal” had the need been less prominent A popular song in those days was about Rosie, the riveter, who, though dainty and feminine, worked right in the factory with the strong and rough men who riveted war tanks and war ships together for use during the war. With so many men, and some women going into the army open left many important jobs without workers, and the demand for workers made gender walls tumble down, and women began taking jobs only men had sought before the war.

. opportunities , or doctors, nurses, and preachers volunteering to accompany the into and iron and steel Children my age sometimes were drafted to do necessary, but simple chores that helped civilians—such as placing a stamp in ration books so that the person who received that ration book could buy gasoline for a car or truck, or food for family or himself. I think I must have rubber stamped a thousand ration stamp books in one afternoon when a large number of students from my age to twelfth graders. We had all volunteered to help the leaders of the City of Charlotte because beginning on a certain date no one could buy meat, canned foods, and scarce food-stuffs and some clothing without a “stamp” which was about the same size of a postal stamp. The book of stamps was about the size of a dollar bill, and was made of paper much like that which newspapers were printed on, but closely resembling the shape and size of a book of

postage stamps, with little perforations so that they could be easily torn out of the book along with money to buy things that were in short supply—such as meat for the table, and shoes, and gasoline for automobiles. Hording was frowned on, and boot-legging the rationed items were punishable. . that was printed on paper that looked like newspaper sheets, and were easily torn. Upon a certain day in the near future stores and gasoline stations could not sell certain items without a stamp as well as the cost of the item. and needed help to rubber stamp one ration booklet with little stamps that could be torn out. Every person, infant to elderly, needed a book of stamps to buy items that were in short supply—like canned goods, gasoline, shoes, and other necessary items. Each person living in Charlotte, no matter how old or how young, had to have one of those stamp booklets. My memory of what they were used for is a little dim, but gasoline was rationed, meats and other canned foods, and some clothing as well, particularly shoes. other foods were rationed, as were shoes. These items could not be bought without a ration ticket. There was a great number of ordinary items, such as canned goods, and meats, that were sold only when the buyer had not only money, but also ration tickets. There was an old joke that had made the rounds in Charlotte while I was very young, and the punch line from that ancient joke began to be a by-word. The joke was about a Chinese laundry which I can’t remember, and I can’t remember the funny part, but the gag line was something about a Chinese man in a laundry who refused to release a man’s clean shirts by saying, “No tickee, No shirty” that

leaders at a huge auditorium in Charlotte. The auditorium was used for a large variety of productions: wrestling matches, orchestra concerts, a production of Handel’s “Messiah” by a traveling choir, occasional operas, exciting teams playing special basket ball games, dances when the expected crowd was large, and even lectures by well known speakers or a series city-wide worship with publicly well-preachers. city-wide worship Christian presentation by one or more famous preachers, or a local production of Handel’s Messiah.

*888888

were held, and an occasional concert, as well as city-wide worship services, or the presentation of operas that were presented by traveling musicians. held on specific specials, n, or some other such as me at that time helped. went to a large building —and one of my memories of that period of

hospitals, stores, and lots of other ordinary things that could not be done So much so that soldiers got food, shoes, tents, bedding, uniforms, motorized machines and ammunition and other supplies even if the civilian population was not supplied with shoes, clothing, some foods, or trucks and cars. To replace worn out or messed up items.

Among the urgent priorities was the need for doctors and nurses to travel as closely as possible with the front-line participants who were going into harms way. Suddenly, physicians were scarce ose Doctors who remained in their practices were often overwhelmed with “new” patients. e doctors who stayed home were inundated with new patients whose were

For the duration of the war there was an array of items that could not easily be bought, for any amount of money. One thing was automobiles, which were not being manufactured at all for civilians (that means any and every one who was not attached to the armed services) no matter what their age. Foods from other nations were either no longer sold, or in short supply, such as sugar, bananas, or other items no grown in the United States. Meat was sometimes not available because a great amount of meat, either already butchered or still on the hoof was being changed into meals for people who recently joined the armed services. Among the items that were in short supply was sugar, at that time coming mostly from Cuba. Then there were other items such as coffee, tropical fruits, vegetables, meats, fish, pork beef, fish, even cigarettes, were in short supply for civilians. , or any other fruit, vegetable, or meat Americans had been buying outside the country. not being manufactured, or bought from other nations are these: Stockings leather shoes men’s apparel sugar including shoes, stockings, some clothing that required elastic, many foods imported or shipped across country, , many foods, especially sugar, which mostly came from Cuba, and many other items. Winter clothing Where clothing was concerned, shoes were scarce, and for the most part, only rayon stockings (for females) were available—no longer could ladies get silk stockings from China. Rayon stockings were disliked because they twisted and wrinkled easily. New clothing was hard to find—that is—the kind of clothing you wanted was usually in short supply. Shoes were a problem. Why all the shortages? Suddenly—really suddenly—an army of thousands had been inducted into the armed services, and **A huge army of men for whom there were no uniforms or standard boots had to be clothed. the same problem with shoes, they were scarce, too. Sweaters were hard to find, and women with nimble fingers found knitting them was easier than trying to find colors and styles that suited them. Food—yes, food, was scarce. Most of the reasons had to do with transportation, or the source of the product. Items that came from Europe or South America or even all the way across America (from California when you lived on the Atlantic Coast) could be blamed on lack of transportation. Transportation was busier than it had ever been; however, any chore needed by the military came first—and civilian shipments were usually carried when it was convenient to do so.

Shoes were scarce because available leather was being used for footwear for the armed services. Radios were hard to find in stores because airplanes, ships, and armed services had first dibs on radios. Because of the war ordinary citizens who had no radios wanted to buy one, and those who had only a large radio that was difficult to shift from room to room, wanted a portable. This was not selfish. In winter most homes were still using stoves and fire places for warmth. There were many that had furnaces that could heat an entire house—but fuel—from wood to special coal, was scarce. The men-folk who cut the wood were in service, coal was very scarce, and oil, which came across the sea, was rationed. Most families, mine included, closed off most of the rooms, and used only their kitchen, if it could serve as a sitting room, too. That’s what my family did. Instead of the living room’s comfortable stuffed furniture, our family sat on kitchen chairs near the stove, and didn’t complain. Currently housing is built with open areas instead of actual separate rooms. It would be difficult to hole up in one smaller place in those houses. We didn’t have that problem in the 1940’s. Presently homes , most houses have more than one TV in a house. **** Television

in almost every home. But if you wanted to wee but if you wanted to see a something that seemed real, you had to go to the movies. Long before television became available to homes, Radios were the source of news, entertainment, music of various kinds, comedies, dramas, and programs called “soap” operas. a no for nonelong, long, before Television appeared. Radios were handy, but many homes were dependent on newspapers for daily information and news. Because Bobby’s Grandfather sold newspapers uptown on the northwest corner of the square, he enjoyed helping him to sell newspapers and magazines. When Bobby could manage it, he would help his Grandfather as tenants of the nearby buildings stopped to pick up their evening papers. The Ivey’s store was known for its elegance, and as a fact they did have quite beautiful clothing, but Ivey’s was not a store that bragged about low prices. Since Bobby’s mother worked there she usually bought her clothes there, too, as she got a small discount. Sometimes my mother looked at their clothes, then made me a dress that looked a lot like the ones on the Ivey’s racks. The store where his Mother worked was one block away, and then the two of them would go home together. helped him sell papers as often as he could. Sometimes he sold papers until time to meet his Mother When it was time for the stores to close **8888** Sometimes he He also walked to Ivey’s to meet his mother and go home with her. occasionally offered his grandfather help with selling the papers. he had heard a lot about selling newspapers. And as he grew older and more confident walking to school, he often walked to the business district of Charlotte, which most people simply called “up town”. His mother was working about a block from the square at Ivey’s and she left work around 5:00. If Bobby was early for his mother to leave work, he often stopped at the kiosk from which his Grandfather Beatty sold newspapers and magazines. Sometimes he helped his grandfather sell the papers before he walked a block down the street to meet his mother who was leaving the store at closing time. . y, and our country. Events that were newsworthy from Europe and Africa were mentioned if they were significant. There was another way to hear news, however. Radios had been in use for some years, but in Charlotte most people could not afford to buy radios, and they were extremely cautious about using electricity when it wasn’t absolutely necessary. There were two radio broadcasting stations in Charlotte: WBT and WSOC. WBT was first, and that company built a tall tower that was visible from a stretch of Pineville Road a little distant south of Charlotte. The road itself passed close to the small city of Pineville, through which both the railroad and a highway passed. When my Dad drove down Pineville Road to visit his parents or my mother’s sister, we watched for that tall tower which had little red lights on it that blinked off and on all day, as well as all night. Some years later WBT erected two other towers so that there are three of them, now. Radios were a new and quite marvelous thing, but they were not free. If you bought a radio, and could pay for the electricity it took to listen to it, you could hear everything WBT broadcasted, from about 6:00 AM to about 11:00 PM, when they stopped broadcasting. Because everybody with a daytime job went to bed by 11:00 o’clock, there was no one awake to listen to the radio, so there was no reason to keep on broadcasting.

Since the Depression was still affecting what people bought and also how much electricity they used, most people did not yet own a radio, simply because they could not afford to buy one. Sometimes people who owned a radio would invite neighbors to visit just for their pleasure of listening to the entertainment, or the news the radio could provide. Another reason folks did not buy a radio, was that it used electricity. Most people who had electricity were careful how many, and how often, lights were turned on in their houses. If you were alone in a room, and left the room for more that a minute, you clicked off the light to save the cost of electric power. North Carolina, as well as most of the nation, was still recuperating from the Depression in the early 1940’s. I was very young when the Depression struck our country. Studying history in school was required, but I never clearly understood why everybody went broke at one time. I was absolutely certain that it had happened, because my parents told me that Daddy was buying three houses as an investment. Since he couldn’t make the expected payment because he lost his job, he lost those houses, and didn’t get any of his money back. Without a job, he did not get paid. He lost his job because his boss couldn’t pay him anymore since his business wasn’t making any money. However it happened. My Dad lost his job because his boss couldn’t pay him for his work. Companies couldn’t pay workers because the people who had not been paid couldn’t buy whatever the company produced, so since nobody was buying, the companies didn’t make any money. The banks, which should have been rich because people had given them money for safe keeping, either didn’t have any, or not enough, of money when people tried to withdraw it. The banks closed, and no one made deposits any more. the banks which kept their money had lost it. Since Companies could not get their money out of banks, people did not get paid. Because people weren’t paid they couldn’t pay their rent or buy groceries. When people could not pay rent or their loans on their houses, they had to leave their homes. Bosses couldn’t pay workers. Workers couldn’t buy food or pay liens because their bosses couldn’t

n to the people who had deposited it. I studied history, but I have never really been able to reason out why there was suddenly no dispense to people who had money. Most of the banks in the United States suddenly had no actual money. was caused by the failure of almost every bank in the country. The losses that followed the failure of banks caused great hardships in the United States. When banks closed, companies could not pay their workers. Workers who didn’t get paid for their work, and could not remove their savings from a closed bank could not buy food, or pay their debts. provide sor who had lost their jobs because their workplace had simply closed, had no money to pay for food, housing, or medical care. Mortgages went unpaid, and people were forced to leave their homes because they could not continue to pay People who lost their jobs could not continue to pay on mortgages, and those folk could not continue to live in a house with a mortgage that could not be paid. . People who were renting houses, could not continue to do so when they lost their jobs, and therefore would eventually have to move out. , or even rent. People who were buying homes could not sell them, as no one had money to buy them and the banks could not offer a loan. continue to pay each month, and lost their homes—they couldn’t sell their homes to retrieve their investment in it, as no one had the money to pay for it. People lost their equity in the house because they had no money to continue paying their loan. to recoop because no one had money—and so they lost what was already invested in their homes. Because they could not make regular payments they were evicted from their homes. Many businesses failed simply because no one had money to buy their products. It was a sad time.

, and could no longer continue living there. papying stil, causing people to loose their homes, as well as their jobs, and the failure of the banks left them with not much more than the clothes they were wearing. People really did go hungry, and if they were sick, they really couldn’t buy medicine. . His Grandfather Bates was becoming famous in the center of Charlotte because he had placed a kiosk in the center of the “uptown” area known as the Square, and from his chosen corner he sold newspapers and magazines to people who passed that busy corner. That opportunity occurred to himimes required an adult to witness the sometimes . He delivered news papers. He went to school. He played more often with his cousins than he had when he lived further away from them

Charlotte, in the late 1930’s and early 1940’s, was not a “rich” city—nor was it poor. In the 1860’s and for a long time afterward, the South suffered from the Civil War, and the changes that followed the emancipation of all the slaves. Farms and the lack of money and jobs caused by the depression, and people sometimes went without shelter or food. I can remember vividly that there were “bums” in our neighborhood. Bums could usually find some sort of shelter near railroad tracks, mostly because ordinary people within the city tried diligently to avoid the noise of the trains which were compelled to blow whistles each time the railroad crossed a city street. Since traffic rolled on the streets day and night, there was no time the city was without train whistles for any length of time. If the trains did not howl, the mills did. to warn traffic to get off the rails where streets crossed the tracks. or roads crossefor the were laid through the city there was often a section of housing that could not shut out train whistles, nor could they avoid knocks on their back doors from bums. Bumswere people who had no home, no family willing to take them in, no clean clothes, and no food. Their homes were in camps, usually near a railroad track where tax money was concerned.

Bobby completed grammar school, and then attended Alexander Graham Junior High School for three years. The number of schools in Charlotte were increasingly inadequate. students who lived in When he entered the tenth grade at Central High School he could ride his bike to school. He had small jobs, like many young boys at that time. He carried newspapers to homes not far from his own neighborhood. The delivery of newspapers was usually the job of young boys, and Bobby had a route.

Bobby’s paper route was not the only place he had sold papers. He had begun selling papers quite early because his Grandfather Bates, his mother’s father, had a kiosk right on the Square in the middle of town where he sold both morning and evening papers, as well as magazines.

Though Bobby’s paternal grandfather had died when he was nine or ten years old, his maternal grandfather was not only alive, he was well known by a great number of people in the city of Charlotte, because he sold newspapers and magazines.

The columnists at The Observer, Charlotte’s morning newspaper, often wrote about him. Many important people—as well as ordinary workers in that area—depended on him to furnish them with newspapers or magazines that were likely to sell quickly. One of the people who liked him was a Charlotte Observer columnist, who sometimes wrote about Grandfather Bates in his column. Grandfather Bates was small in stature, but he was a very fine person.

well liked by man, b

Observer columnists, and was often mentioned in his column. Since by the 1950’s Grandfather Beatty Many people depended on him to set aside special issues of magazines or newspapers when the demand for them was high. He was small of stature, and neat in his appearance.

Both he and his wife were members of Calvary Methodist Church. Bobby’s Grandmother Bates, was a special person, too. She was the daughter of , and was often mentioned in the morning paper, The Charlotte Observer, by one of the columnists. Grandfather Bates owned a kiosk on the Square in the heart of the business district where he sold newspapers and magazines right on the sidewalk. Bobby enjoyed helping his Grandfather Bates sell papers and magazines, and when he wasn’t in school, he loved to stand on the square with would help his selthe sometimes helped him by is morning because of his business—he sold newspapers and magazines from a kiosk very close to the Square on West Trade Street. As a child, Bobby often delightfully helped him sell his papers and magazines after School. often had been Loraine Bates before her marriage. Her father owned and ran a newspaper stand up town right on the Square, He sold newspapers and magazines on a very busy corner where West Trade crossed North Tryon Street. pm the SqHis mother’s , and sometimes he worked for his maternal Grandfather,

rest of Bobby’s school years up to his graduation from high school, he and his family lived on East Boulevard in the home of his Grandmother Hattie Beatty, on South Boulevard. the rest of Bobby’s school years, he and his parents lived in the home of his Grandmother on South Boulevard, across the street from Lance Packing. He attended Central High School, and graduated in June of 1943. Life and the living of it often steps completely out of the ordinary. And that happened to a lot of people on December 7, 1941.

Grandmother Beatty’s house became ordinary. Each year the Charlotte schools closed for at least two weeks during the Christmas season. When he was in the eleventh grade at Central High School, a great many things changed—not just in Charlotte, North Carolina, but in all across the world.

Hattie and her family had not lived in Charlotte since her marriage to William Beatty.

Adolph Hitler, head of the government of Germany, attacked almost all the European countries, and England, as well. Most of the world was affected. Italy allied itself with Germany. There were battles in North Africa. The United States declined to enter the European War, on the other side of the world. Japan had, for some time, been invading China.

Then one Sunday in December of 1941, Japan’s Air Force attacked United States Naval ships anchored at Pearl Harbor, which was an act of War against the United States.

That was a day that changed the lives of most of the people living in America, and much of the entire world.

The United States declared war on Japan, and on Germany and Italy as well.

Across town from where the Beatty’s lived, there was another Charlotte family—that of Leroy and Minnie Yandle, and their two daughters. Leroy and Minnie lived on West Eleventh Street, and had lived there for not quite ten years. At the beginning of their marriage Leroy had rented a room from his Aunt Lizzie and Uncle Edward Yandle.

, his father’s sister, wYandle had grown up in Pineville, North Carolina, as had his wife, Minnie. When they married, Leroy had a job in Charlotte, so the young couple rented a room in the home of Leroy’s Uncle Edward Yandle, his father’s brother. who was a bachelor, and shared a home with his sister, Lizzie. Edward’s family had lived in Pineville whfamily lived for a while on East Fifth Street with his Leroy’s Uncle Edward, who shared a house with his sister, Lizzie. Aunt Lizzie kept house for Uncle Eddie, and since they had an empty room in their house, Leroy rented space from them, married Minnie Parksa couple of rooms there, and after the December wedding, moved the and his sister, Aunt Lizzie. .

but our country began to This war was a change that affected most of the world. Germany declared war on most of Europe, and on England. Radios had been available for several years, and most people had at least one. events up rooted, not only his life, but the lives of thousands of young men and women. In Europe, Adolph Hitler, who had taken over the government of Germany, started a war in Europe. After that conflict was raging in Europe, the Japanese, half a world away from the United States, but already at war with China, decided to destroy the navy of the United States to prevent the our country from interfering in the Pacific battles.

The Japanese sent their air force to drop bombs on the American ships anchored and stationed in Hawaii, and they tried to destroy the planes of the Army Air Force stationed in Hawaii, as well. Their surprise attack was, from the Japanese viewpoint, quite successful. They sank the navy ships in the harbor, and bombed the airfield and U.S. navy ships at anchor in the harbor. It was a highly successful attack from their view-point. Japan “won” their unexpected attack, and though they had not declared war before they tried to sink our entire naval fleet anchored at Pearl Harbor, that was only the beginning of World War II. It huge attack. . TThey made their position our country being able to keep them from hen he was a

Paw-paw, who was called “Bobby” at that point of his life, had to change schools. Grandmother had to assign permanent space the Paw-paw’s family, the children called “Nan-naw,” was still preparing lunches for Lance Packing Company employees, and I think she was also providing beds for some of them, as well—like a boardingThe family also had to make changes weathered the problems that arose, and the sacrifices that were necessary. Grandmother Beatty kept right on making lunches for the people who worked for Lance Packing Company, and Bobby Beatty changed schools, and settled down in his new situation. Living there, he did get to see his cousins a little more often than previously. His Aunt Virginia had three sons, one a bit older, the others younger than young Bobby Beatty. He now saw his cousins more often.

y family moved into Grandmother Beatty’s house. The recently widowed Hattie had taken in “boarders” for

many years. Right across the street was a Lance Packing Company. This was the manufacturer of snacks such as plain as well as cheesy crackers spread with peanut butter and wrapped in small packages for nibbling at lunch. That company also made potato chips in small bags that were favorites of young students who carried lunch bags to school—or grown up folks who lunched on sandwiches and apples at mid-day. These items were vended from behind counters, and also from machines that, when fed nickels or dimes, would release tasty crackers or chips for hungry folk. Trucks bearing the Lance logo drove to countless spots within Charlotte where machines tucked in corners of hallways and basements were a relief to busy workers, students, or unprepared visitors who were hungry, with no restaurant nearby. Each Christmas the Lance Company put up lights and scenes of Santa and a manger in a stable scene with loud music that included carols and happy songs about the Christ Child, as well as Santa. Lance made the display interesting enough that families with small children usually had to pass the scene more than once before their small children were satisfied that they had not missed any part of the display. Lance used easily recognized trucks driven usually by young men who faithfully delivered snacks to snack bars as well as wonderful modern machines which, when fed a nickel, would push out crackers or chips. Now that—my friends—that was a marvel. There had never before been such a thing—a machine that, for a nickel, would slide out a package of crackers. That was amazing!

The young men who kept the vending machines filled with Lance products, and delivered their products to vendors—small, large, and in-between hired young men to drive their trucks, refilling vending machines and re-stocking shelves at all the large and small outlets where the product was sold. Many of those young men were single, and actually from out of town. They would spend Monday through Saturday delivering snacks on a specific route, go home on Saturday evening, and return on Monday morning.

In those earliest days of public transportation trains were sometimes a mixed chain of passenger and freight cars. As railroads grew more plentiful, and movement of both goods and people became more frequent, trains in the West, as well as in the East, tended to be either passenger or freight, but not actually both. The use of automobiles increased fairly rapidly when they were introduced all over the country. At first only the daring that were also wealthy drove an automobile. The usefulness of horseless carriages was immediately visible. It was easier to pour gasoline into a tank than to water, feed, and shelter several horses—and automobiles did not require cleaning the smelly floor of the garage as horse barns did. Automobiles were introduced early in the twentieth century, and there were a few used in the previous century. However, in the early days of Charlotte, petroleum products were not available in large quantities in most areas of the United States, and the majority of the roads that connected cities distant from each other were still unpaved and rough. Even within towns pavement was not usual. For instance, in early days the center of Charlotte where Trade Street crossed Tryon Street, and which was called the Square, could be approached on fairly level ground from the north, south, and west, however, the eastern approach of Trade Street was a steep hill, and when it rained, slippery mud was a problem for heavily loaded wagons and for automobiles. Busy streets where horse-drawn traffic was heavy were usually quite nasty to walk across in either rain or sunshine.

In the early 1900’s the streets in the South, including the city of Charlotte, were often simply dirt roads, which turned to mud and slush on rainy days, making all transportation difficult. Cement was a wonderful invention, as was asphalt. I know that not all of Charlotte’s streets were paved when I was a child, because I saw them. My parents first lived on East Fifth Street Our first home was a rental on East Fifth StreetMy parents first lived on East Fifth Street, but then moved to West Eleventh Street when I was about three years old. I have only tiny fragments of memories of the Fifth Street house, but memories of Eleventh Street are vivid. d with my family on West Eleventh Street until I was married. I witnessed many changes in the uptown of Charlotte, as we lived less than as they occurred on that street. Most of the streets I was familiar with were black-tops. We lived on West Eleventh Street which Of course most of the streets were paved by the time I was ten, but there were still new areas being opened up, and . Occasionally brick or stone would cover heavily used streets. Many towns along rivers or the sea , and along the coasts would arrive empty to take on ship-loads of goods to be delivered elsewhere. , and this was very true of towns all over our country. Towns and cities near the sea, or along deep rivers where ocean going ships travel, sometimes had one small advantage where road-building was concerned. Sailing ships without When sailing ships emptied their holds they hoped to find rarely returned left their anchorage empty—but them turned around to return home without loading their holds reached their designation and emptied their holds, they could not go to sea again without ballast—a fancy name that meant in most instances, heavy rocks. abt

or near a river. Ships which had delivered the products they had transported could not simply sail away empty, with no weights in the hull, lest they overturn. Upon occasion they off-loaded the necessary rock ballast materials in their hull in order to replace them with shipping crates. Towns made quick use of them by using the ballast stones to pave roads—thus cobble stone streets were born. Cement was used more often, and a little later Tar became the less expensive covering for muddy streets and roads. Because I was so very young when automobiles became the norm rather than a sensational rarity, I don’t remember when paved streets came to be expected rather a happy surprise in Charlotte. I know—because I walked them—that there were still unpaved streets in Charlotte when I was a teenager. At that time, especially in the South, most cities were divided into “sections”. There was “up-town” which was usually the business and shopping district, and “Mid-town” which often was a business area, with stores, offices, and sometimes government, buildings. Then there were areas where the very poor whites or the Negro people lived. Shamefully, people with money to invest would build poorly put together dwellings, most of which did not have piped water (thence no bathrooms and no water in the kitchen). In most of those neighborhoods there would be one spigot on a pipe somewhere in the area where water could be drawn into cups or buckets. The unbeautiful and sometimes pitiful area where colored people lived rarely had pavement, and in some places there was still a water pipe—the only source of clean water—at the intersections within that neighborhood. I know, because I saw it, and knew Negro people who lived in such a place. I was too young to know why or how we knew them, but we did know the Mason family, Ardie and her husband Gary, and most of their children, and eventually a few of their grand-children.

I remember hearing about another black lady who helped my mother during a time when I was very small, and my sister was not expected to live. Her name was Georgiana. I’ve been told that I loved and trusted her, and that she took care of me when I was an infant—in exchange for a warm place to be in the winter, and at least one meal each day. My mother did not take advantage of her situation to get work without pay—Georgiana had no way to heat her house and it was winter. She was short of food, and we fed her. She was elderly, and she could sit down when she was weary. She lived very close to our house on East Fifth Street. It was in a period of hardship for nearly everyone during the depression. I have little or no real memory of that time. I do know that my Daddy lost his job at a lumber yard because no one was buying lumber, and few had the money to build anything.

This was a time of which I have almost no real memory. The crash of Wall Street didn’t actually bother our family, and we had no large deposits in Wall Street. However, when Wall Street failed, businesses began to shut down, and rich people became quite poor. People who were in debt, or buying anything (automobiles, houses, furniture, or such) they suddenly had no jobs, no money, and not much hope that even nominal jobs would be available any time soon. People who had lost their jobs or their homes were devastated—which doesn’t mean they were just upset! Devastated means they were forced to leave the homes on which a mortgage was owed –and it was pitiful, but true that anything they had paid into the cost of houses, automobiles, furniture, and such, was now lost. The lien holders did not give back that portion which was paid. Lost was a heavy word. Lost meant all gone. Almost paid didn’t matter.

Lenders who were even briefly “merciful” to debtors were losers, too.

My Daddy was working for a lumber store, and invested in buying two houses, rented them out, and used the rent to pay installment on the houses. When tenants lost their jobs, they couldn’t pay rent to my Daddy, resulting in his inability to make payments on the lien against the houses he was buying as an investment. Therefore he lost not only the property, but the entire amount he had invested in them. With so many empty houses available, no one needed building materials, causing the Lumber yard where he worked to fail, and he no longer had a job.

Investors stopped building houses because there were lots of vacant ones abandoned when people couldn’t pay their rent. Jobs all over the country disappeared when businesses failed. The lumber yard couldn’t sell its lumber, as no one was building anything. Any person who had a debt found it difficult or impossible to actually pay it. Banks failed, and those who had placed money in failed banks bank to peopl. Some housing that had only begun to be built was abandoned because the owner could not complete the job, nor sell it unfinished. Mr. Hodges’ lumber yard was losing money because housing could not be completed and sold. —and the wood would not be paid for because the house couldn’t be sold. were vacant because would-be owners couldn’t keep up the payments, but there was no money to build brand new houses, either. people couldn’t Not only those belonging to folk who could no longer make payments on either the houses they were buying, nor the ones they were renting

houses. as no one was building houses he eventually lost his job because the owner was not able to sell his product. . of. As an adult I was told that my parents were living with my Dad’s Aunt Lizzie on East Fifth Street, and when the Depression The business where he worked eventually went broke. a time of which I have no real memory. I do remember very little about her, except that I trusted her, and she was often in our house. Georgiana was elderly. She and , and had neither food, coal, or wood in her house. She was both cold and hungry, and my mother invited her to our house. During that year and for several years later, my sister was not well. She had suffered an illness that included pleurisy and fever, and three our doctors in Charlotte saiShe would help mother who was trying to keep my sister alive, and keep me from getting sick during that winter. I was probably two or three years old the summer and winter of the last year we were on Fifth Street—probably 1934. During that time, my sister, Ella Cornelia, was very ill. She was in Presbyterian Hospital, had at least four doctors who were trying to keep her alive. My parents were warned that she would probably die, and that if she did, it might be a blessing.

She came to our house to help my mother, especially when my sister was born, and again when I was born.

muddy when it rained, poor, in some with a shas barns did. much cleaner, too. available in the early 1920’s, were in use, of course, but young people rarely owned one, and most families who could afford an automobile had one. Strangely, in most places there were not many women drivers. I can remember that I was actually shocked when the lady across the street from us learned to drive, and would drive away from her house with complete ease. My surprise was that she could find herself back at home, because a person could get lost on unfamiliar streets.

—not one for each driver—but one for the family. It was usually the father who used the automobile, and the rest of the family walked or rode the bus. I, myself, walked more than a mile every school day to the high school I attended, as did my sister before me. When I enrolled at Queens Collage the distance was too great for walking, and I rode a city bus about five or so miles across Charlotte every school day.

. The could go home to spend Sunday with their families. They needed a bed to sleep in during the week, and hat meant they had to have a place to sleep during the week. Many people who had an extra room would rent it out to * and lots of those young men were not married, but they also did not have family in Charlotte. Therefore, they needed a place to eat and sleep during the week while they were working for Lance Packing Company. In those days, there were lots of boarding houses.

A boarding house was an ordinary house, which had extra bedrooms, and some member of the family who could cook at least two meals, but more often three meals each weekday. These homes were called boarding houses. They were ordinary homes that were

Working people who didn’t have a house, or apartment could usually search for and find a home where there was an extra room, or several extra rooms, where the boarder could live, and eat two, or more likely three, meals each day. The boarders usually at a set time each morning and each evening. A few, if they worked near their boarding house, could go there and eat lunch, too.

for boarders, usually went home on the week-end, these were unmarried men for the most part, who worked for Lance Packing Company, and were not married. It was quite usual from time to time, allowed some of the young, unmarried men who drove trucks for There were still a one or two ver Beatty, along with his wife and ten year old son, Bobby Beatty, moved into the house with her. Life is always changing, and Robert E. Beatty (Paw-paw) saw a lot of changes. He now attended a different school. He had fewer playmates, but few dull moments, as he more often saw his cousins Now that was a change and had families. During that time Loraine Beatty, her husband Fred Beatty, and young Bobby Beatty left their home and moved across town into the large house on South Boulevard so that Hattie Beatty would not be alone.

South Boulevard was an extremely busy street, and was a major highway carrying traffic into South Carolina, or traffic moving from the south into North Carolina. Just across the street from Grandmother Beatty’s house was a very large garage where the city busses were parked every night, and where the same busses which traveled throughout Charlotte filled with passengers going to work, or home from work, or to town to shop or to physicians or dentists, or on Sunday, riding to church—and in almost every ride in whatever direction—later in the day those same people would have to go home again, riding the bus to get there.

Next to that garage was Lance Packing Company, the maker of thousands of packages of cheese crackers, and plain peanut butter crackers and potato chips, salted peanuts and other snacks. The street was always busy. because across the street from Grandmother Beatty’s house was a large bakery where Lance Crackers were made, along with other snacks. Grandmother Beatty had, for some long years, served a sort of boarding house lunch to employees of Lance Packing Company. One or two of the drivers lived with her, and a bunch of them ate their lunch at her table. Of course they paid her, as they would have had to pay for lunch eaten at a restaurant.

Now just about everything was changed in Grandmother Beatty’s house. One of the big thing was that

and Your Paw-paw Beatty was at this time about eight or nine years old. His family was living in a lovely house on Greenway Avenue, a street in Charlotte not far from Presbyterian Hospital. OnHis Beatty Grandparents were still living in the house his Father, Fred Oliver Beatty, had grown up in, located on South Boulevard which was a wide and quite busy street. Fred Oliver Beatty lived in his house on Grandfather Beattyparents had fairly recently moved into Please recall that your Paw-paw was about ten or eleven years old. Upon a summer evening Paw-paw’s Grandfather Grandfather, a City of Charlotte policeman, failed to return home when expected. Later that evening his son-in-law, Marvin (who was married to Paw-paws Aunt Virginia),went to Grandfather Beatty’s office, and discovered that he had died, sitting behind his office desk located in the Mecklenburg County Courthouse.

That unexpected sadness changed things for Paw-paw. His parents moved into the large house on South Boulevard—a very busy street—and just across that street was the car barn for the trolley cars which traveled on tracks all over Charlotte. Trolley’s allowed people to pay a minimum amount of money to ride across town to their jobs, or to keep appointments, or to go to a movie. It surely did beat walking for miles since not everyone had either a horse or a car. The move meant Paw-paw had to change schools, teachers, and playmates. The room he now called his was tiny, with little space for any sort of toys. He had to change schools, and at the new school he didn’t know anyone, and had a new teacher. At home the front yard was very small, and there was a fence in the back yard. No children lived on either side of his house, and the back yard opened on an alley (which was like an unpaved private street). All day, and all night there was noisy traffic along the street in front of his house, and it didn’t stop until late at night. This street, though it had houses on it, also had businesses, and right across the street was a huge garage, and people had dubbed it “the car barn” because every morning the streetcars left their garage and carried passengers from place to place all day, and then at night came back to their barn to be cleaned, and if needed, repaired, for the next day’s business.

A little below the huge garage that was called the “car barn” was a manufacturing plant for snacks like cheese crackers and potato chips and several other popular treats which sold for five cents in grocery stores and many other places that sold drinks and snacks wrapped in cellophane. Lance Packing Company made all sorts of treats, like peanuts, and cookies and crackers packaged in small amounts at low prices, and sold in a myriad of stores all over the city.

Paw-paw lived in the house owned by his Grandmother Beatty on that busy street that connected Pineville and points South to and actually through Charlotte to many parts of this continent. So we can leave information about the Yandle family from the age of ten until he was drafted into the military. When he returned, he again lived in that house, until the City of Charlotte decided to take all the land in that area for its own use—and cities and states and the Federal Government can actually do that—simply decide what the house and land are worth, pay the owners what they decide is fair, and make them move away whether or not they want to move. And that is the beginning of another part of the story.

The central streets in the heart of Charlotte were carefully laid out into a precise grid early in its history. One area was set aside to serve as a Court House, which would be where the town was governed. Many of the large cities of England and other countries in Europe had an important government center often called a Square. Charlotte also had a Square, which, when the city was founded, was set up in the very center of the town. In that spot a small wooden Courthouse was erected. From that point crude unpaved streets were laid out, running either east to west, or north to south from the Courthouse in the very center of the town.

The people who settled in the new town were generally from England, or some other European country. They were true pioneers. They made a town called Charlotte, and a state called North Carolina. They laid out farms, and planted them, and harvested There had been nothing there except trees when the people first arrived, mostly from Europe, other parts of the world, or from settlements further north on the Atlantic coast. The moving of people from England and Europe to this new country was not truly swift, nor was it ever easy to travel. However, settlements in this new world where only savages lived pushed Indians away from the Atlantic Coast, . I have heard stories of the way life was lived when my parents were growing up. I have heard a few stories of how my grandparents grew up. I was told stories about my great-grandparents. My Great Grandfather Yandle owned a grocery store. During the Civil War there were a fairly large number of women whose husbands had gone to war, leaving them without funds. If there were no family ties to come to their aid, my Great Grandfather Yandle would see starving women with young children, and help them by giving them food. Of course his store lost revenue. He kept on doing it as long as possible, until he could no longer pay his bills. His brother, Edward Yandle, helped him with the legal aspects of being unable to pay his suppliers.

Although I never saw Great Grandfather, or his wife, I heard stories about them both. My mother helped take care of his tiny wife after Great Grandfather died. She told me that the when someone passed her as she rocked in her small chair, she would pinch them—hard. It was always uncomfortable to be pinched by boney fingers that didn’t want to release their prey.
If she wasn’t pinching someone, or having a meal, she would chant a little rhyme:

            Samuel Yandle is my name,
            And England is my nation.
            The Bible is the book of God,
            And Christ is my Salvation.

I think I still have, somewhere, the black silk dress she wore at her Fiftieth Wedding Anniversary party. My Dad remembered that he was quite young, and had snitched a cigar from the box that had been a present to his grandfather on the occasion. He and his cousins took their cigar out behind the barn, lit it and made them selves sick by taking turns smoking the cigar. There was a crowd there, and the adults—family, visitors, and quite elderly couple who had been married fifty years. The boys smoked, and to their dismay, had no appetite for the wonderful meal set out by the time they were called to the table.

My childish view of my bachelor Great Uncle Ed Yandle was that he was absolutely and totally strange. He was well educated, and had a fabulous vocabulary—and though I didn’t realize it, he spoke like an Englishman because his parents had been English before they became Americans. My father held Uncle Edward in high respect. However, he was always using big words I didn’t understand. I remember one of his visits when I was about five years old. We were just sitting down to lunch when he came into the house. Mother invited him to eat with us. He said, “I don’t have room.” It was a fact that our small table, at that moment, didn’t have space for another chair. My mother immediately stood up, crowded my five year old self against my sister’s chair at one end of the table, and quickly brought an extra chair to the table. Within seconds she had placed a clean plate, silverware, and a glass of water onto the table, and asked Uncle Ed to sit at the table. He came to the table, sat, and chuckled. “I didn’t mean there was no place to sit” he admitted, “I meant I didn’t have room in my alimentary canal.”

Uncle Edward lived in a house on East Fifth Street which he shared with his sister, Lizzie. The house, itself, intrigued me because instead of having one way to have light after the sun went down, that house had two ways of producing light. One was, of course, electricity. And it didn’t show me any surprises. The other method used narrow gold colored pipes, and had tiny, very fragile white globes above tiny pipes on each side of the mantels. There was one in every room, and if you turned a little lever you could hear a hiss, and then if you struck a match, a gas flame began to burn. Unlike a kerosene lamp, you couldn’t move these, and you could not touch the fragile white netting above the small pipe, where the flame danced when the valves were open so the gas could hiss out into the white netting. If you even touched that white netting, even if it was by accident, it would crumble away, and the light wouldn’t work anymore. I didn’t realize why my Great Aunt Lizzie, and her brother, Great Uncle Edward, would want two separate ways to have light in their home. In my old age I realized that gas was probably used when they lived in England in their early youth, and they were accustomed to the use of gas lights. When they came here from England they quite naturally wanted the same kind of lighting in their home. However, when electricity was available, it was superior to the gas lights. They took advantage of the better lighting furnished by electricity, but did not discard the gas light source, and when there were power outages, they still would have light.

Aunt Lizzie was a spinster, and shared a house with her brother, Uncle Edward; however, some years previously there had been a young niece living there also. Aunt Lizzie had raised her sister’s daughter when her sister was unable to look after her. I never saw that girl, but I was told she was particularly beautiful, as well as intelligent. She had learned from a teacher how to play an organ, and her organ still sat in Aunt Lizzie’s front room when I was a child. Sadly, the young girl Aunt Lizzie loved and cared for so carefully contracted an illness, and died at the age of about eighteen. Aunt Lizzie, unmarried and childless, had raised the girl. It was a delight to Aunt Lizzy that the girl was beautiful, obedient, every inch a lady, and a well trained organist. She was also described a lovely and talented girl. Aunt Lizzie never truly recovered from her grief. She could not, or would not, say the dead girl’s name, or discuss anything about the child she, herself, raised. In her old age Aunt Lizzie stayed for several months at our house, and had to share a room with me, though we had separate beds. Aunt Lizzie did not complain, nor did I, We had different daily and nightly schedules. You might guess that I didn’t enjoy that period because she was peculiar in her habits. She would never touch a door knob with her bare hands, but always put a corner of her apron between her hand and the doorknob. There were foods she would not eat.
