She was particular about her laundry and her clothing—her underwear could not be hung outside on the line to dry for fear someone outside the family would see them. Her fragile health prevented her from helping with the household chores, but it didn’t stop her from lecturing me on how to do it.

and children without support. My Great GrandfatherYandle would ran a store, in Pineville I think. When the wives and children of Confederate soldiers had no food, he gave them goods out of his store anyway. The town grew. Of course it took time, but children were born, and new people eventually arrived, adding to the population. Stores were built, goods were offered for sale. Churches were started. More people came to the new continent. Places and areas were given names, and Carolina was born. Settlers of many persuasions and divers beliefs came, some speaking divers of languages. The first group of people who came into what is now North Carolina simply disappeared, and no one has ever discovered what happened to them. People who kept coming to the shores of what is now Virginia, and also what is now North Carolina had huge problems, and many did not survive. The hearty ones reveled in the work of staying alive in a strange part of the world. Once here in America the settlers sometimes had really difficult times. First, they brought very little with them. Second, there were tribes of Indians already living here, and some of them were hostile. Being unfamiliar with the terrain a well as the weather was difficult. The new people were not sure of what they could eat, or what it would be better to avoid. Most of them had never built houses, or chosen locations for a house, nor did they have an infinite amount of supplies for their survival. Their ammunition was scarce, they had no horses, they did not have copious amounts of food, clothing,, or other necessities. They couldn’t go back to England, But they did know how to work—and they did.

Europe, especially England, was crowded. People were fairly eager to try the new world. There were more people than there were houses, and all wooden Courthouse in the center of a busy square that was proudly named Independence Square. In the earliest days in the center of that Square there was a small Court House. Streets leading to and from the Square were laid out in precise North-South or East-West directions, *****making a neat grid across the growing town. The North-South road that went through the Square was called Tryon Street. The East-West road was called Trade Street. At precise intervals perpendicular streets were laid out in blocks. There was a “first” street, and a “second” street, and the roads that pointed north or south were given names, too. Some were named for Governers or army officers, or for the usage of that street, like the one that was named Trade Street because it had so many stores along it. at first streets going east to west, (or vice versa) given numbers, and those when they ran North or South, they had names, though of course there were exceptions to that pattern. east or west, and names when they ran North or South. There were four numbered streets on one side of the Court House, but the count was interrupted when the centraand as years passed, there were at least thirty six streets that were numbered. in precise squares, with named streets running north or south, and numbered streets running east or west, but the numbering went from First Street north to Second Street. By the time that the . Of course there were not many streets laid out at the beginning. As the city grew the numbered streets were expanded, and I think they rose as high as Thirty-Sixth Street before other names were used, however, the town expanded eastward, as well as westward, and the eastward streets began with “First” and couldn’t go any lower, so the new streets eastward also had names rather than numbers. Before my parents married they both lived in the area of Pineville, a small town that was, in my youth, about ten miles from the Charlotte City Limits. As the seventy-five years of my life unfolded, the distance between Pineville and Charlotte diminished, until today it is less easy to tell the difference. When I was a child most of the land near Pineville that stretched in any direction was farm land. Pineville was a little more than ten miles from Charlotte. My Yandle—grandparents lived less than a mile from Pineville if they walked to the town along the railroad track. , as well as my Parks grandparents lived near Pineville, but not within the town. They were farmers, growing their own food crops for both animals and themselves, and earned money by selling some of their produce.

My Daddy parents family lived on West Eleventh Street, Charlotte was quite small when it began, and the authorities who named the streets started, of course must have picked a place to begin the numbered streets, and counted upward. Strang, with First Street which was extended to either the East or to the West. The streets extending North or South from the central Square had names. people who laid out the streets began decided to number the East to West streets, and name the North to South streets, but there had to be a starting place. the numbered streets began with First Street, which ran East and West. A measured block away Second Street was laid out, and a system was in place. Whoever and the dividing point was the position of the Square, which was literally smack-dab in the middle of the town. Beyond the Square, the names of the street counted upward—except that as the city grew, there was a lot more space for counting on the western side of the square, and though I never searched for the highest number I know it went as far as Thirty-Sixth Street. . nleaving space for houses or buildings and from it there were two roads—Tryon Street, and Trade Street—both of which were extended in straight lines away from the Square. Trade Street ran East and West, and Tryon Street ran North and South. Stores and places of trade eventually lined the streets close to the Court House. Eventually other streets were laid out. crossed. That intersection was large because a small building serving as the Court House Charlotte sat in the middle of it. At some point that Square was given a name: Independence Square. It was declared the center of the town. Of course, stores and houses were built along the streets. Eventually the streets were all named, and all paved. Streets leading away from the Square specifically led either North-South, or East-West. The Square was the center of the town. Streets already in use to the east of the square fffff had a Square that was named Independence Square, and in its center , too, had a Square, whi—where The place where the courthouse stood streets leading to the Courthouse, in the very center of the town, were wide, and spread away from the center in precise directions: North-South, and East-West. The divider was the Courthouse, which sat in the very middle of a square, dividing North from South, and East from West. The East-West streets were numbered, and the North-South streets were named in those early days. From First Street to Fourth Street the numbered streets stretched east of the Square. Beyond the Square the numbered streets expanded as the city grew. Though I don’t know precisely how many streets were actually numbered, I do know that Thirty-sixth street existed, but don’t remember if the numbers grew any larger. Some of the North-South streets that were named in the blocks close to Eleventh Street were given names such as Pine, and Popular, and then Church, * , the to the west the numbered streets began with were west—and therefore the fifth when the town expanded The streets that ran square from which the north-south directions were divided. that were straight, and exact, carefully running either east-west, or aligned exactly north-south, depending on the direction you needed to go. The center of the city was called “the square” , which was a It was divided into square sections of mostly the same exact size that were called “blocks” on which housing appeared, with small yards before the house, and another small yard behind it, as well. The east-west streets were numbered. The north-south streets were named.

Our house was on the other side of town. We were only eleven blocks from the center of uptown Charlotte, on West Eleventh Street. Eleventh Street was comparatively wider than most of the other numbered streets between Eleventh and the to many other numbered streets which also ran west to east (or vice versa), and it the other numbered strIt was probably about 1935 or 1936 that the City of Charlotte made a big change in the public transportation. In the middle of the street that went by our house on West Eleventh Street there was a track—smaller than, but resembling, a train track. Along that track trolleys rolled, one at a time. The trolley , and stop at intersections for people to get on, or get off. It was a funny sort of car, because both ends of it were the front. it a single trolley would offered to the public. Until then there were trolly cars, much like the ones you see pictured in San Francisco, which pull power from lines overhead to run the cars, and carry people from where they are, to where they want to go. *which traveled on rails sort of like trains, except that there were cables high above the tracks, and on top of the trolly cars was a small device that touched the electrical lines and ran on electricity.

ne building just across the street was called “the car barn”It was a fairly large house, and Paw-paw’s Grandmother

Shortly after the family moved in with his grandparents, his Grandfather Beatty, a City of Charlotte policeman, died suddenly of a heart attack while at his desk in the City Hall. After that sad occurrence Paw-paw’s parents did not leave his grandmother alone in her house, but lived there for a long time. The Beatty family was still living on South Boulevard in 1941.

In Europe and in Japan there was trouble—not just some small misunderstanding between nations, but two highly dangerous world-wide troubles. German Leaders decided to take over all of Europe, claiming they were superior people, who deserved to take over all the other countries on that continent. On a group of relatively small islands in the Pacific, another country decided that every part of the Pacific Ocean and the islands and continents within or surrounded by it should allow the Japanese to rule over them. Other nations disagreed, and War was declared in both Europe and the Pacific Islands. Germany, and it’s ally Italy, along with Japan, had armies, navies, and air forces to attack the cities and homes, and the myriad armed forces headquarters scattered around the world where there were military basses and materials. There were also ships there which could be called war ships—simply because they had the capability of protecting themselves and any ships they were escorting across the sea from attack by pirates or by any other source. A fleet of United States Navy ships were in the harbor of one of the Hawaiian Islands, along Army Air Force planes. They were there to defend the Islands. The Japanese didn’t want America to have the capability of ***They planned to steal whole countries by invading them quickly and without mercy—killing, destroying, and taking over other countries and its citizens. They killed not only soldiers, airmen, sailors, marines, and civilians, but they also decided that if they simply destroyed the governments and the homes of ordinary people in the countries they wanted to steal. isimply steal and destroy claim every inch of the land they prepared for . and the Japanese . Germany decided to take over Europe and the world, and the Japanese, feeling very cramped in their small country, decided to destroy every nation they could—China, and the United States, in particular, so that they could rule their part of the World. On December 7, 1941, they attacked the United States Navy as well as the Air Force without warning, and sank ships, and bombed military posts in Pearl Harbor, Hawaii take over every nation they could were living there in 1941 when the war began. Because it became a law that as soon as able bodied young men became eighteen years old they were eligible for the draft, and if they were able bodied, and not mentally incompetent they were trained as a soldier. Young men who wanted fervently to choose which service they would serve could join before they were drafted, and actually report for duty after graduation from high school. Paw-paw was one of the men who made that choice. He enlisted in the Army Air Force before he graduated from high school, and was therefore not called to duty until after he graduated that spring. Shortly after that date he received instructions about where and when he was to report, and he was sent to a hotel on the Atlantic Beach for his first training.

men who enlisted before they were called could choose their service. because that way he couto prevent his being drafted into which ever service wanted him—without his consent. If he enlisted, he could pick his choice of service. Therefore, he enlisted in the Army The year Paw-paw graduated from High School he was already eighteen years old, and he would have been drafted as soon as he graduated. . He wanted to choose which service he would serve in, and settled on the Army Air Force was finishing his last year in high school. After December 7, 1941 Paw-paw had one more year of school, and th

My sister was six full years plus a few months older than me. When Harding High School opened its doors for the first time Ella Cornelia was a seventh grader. Hers was the first class to complete six full years at Harding. The earlier graduation classes had transferred to Harding after attending other schools. The year after Ella Cornelia graduated, I entered seventh grade at Harding. This was my first opportunity to choose the subjects or classes I took. I was much impressed at the idea of having such wonderful choices, and I was a little dismayed when I discovered that the seventh graders didn’t have many choices since the classes for seventh grade students were almost all mandatory, with few possible alternate classes. All seventh graders had the same subjects, except that boys were not required to take home economics.

It was a great relief when I discovered that I could re-arrange my schedule so that I could play violin in the school orchestra, however, to do so I had to give up my “free” period that the school named “study hall”. I truly loved the practice with the school orchestra, and I was glad when the orchestra played before all the students during an “assembly” or upon the rare occasion when we played at a PTA meeting, or special event. Once each year the Junior Choir would present an operetta for which the orchestra provided accompaniment, so I played my violin in all six of the operettas while I was at Harding. These were high points for me. Unfortunately Queens College did not have an orchestra, so I didn’t use my violin there, nor did I practice after I left college. So I “lost” my ability to play.
When I enrolled at Queens I discovered that some of the high school courses my parents demanded that I study were not a fortunate choice after all. Since my mother insisted I take Home Economics for three years I didn’t have an opportunity to take chemistry, earth sciences, or geometry. There wasn’t room in my schedule. There was only one year of the six high school years that I didn’t have classes all day without the relief of a study hall. My classes were so packed there was no room for me to take high school geometry either. And there was a conflict the year I would have had science (the class where students cut up a dead frog). Therefore, when I went to college I was compelled to take a couple of subjects I could have avoided had I been able to take them in High School. However, I was glad that when I married I could cook, with three years of home economics behind me. And when my children were born, I could sew clothes for them. However, studying all the things my parents had chosen for me, and sticking to my choice to stay in the orchestra, I discovered I lacked studies in science that were mandatory for graduation from Queens College. I had to take a couple of remedial classes, and spent one summer taking the only math subject being offered—Trigonometry. That course was a trial for me, not because I am dumb, but because I had not had geometry—normally a prerequisite for Trigonometry. However, I braved it out, achieving my goal—I had the hours, and I passed the subject of Trigonometry. When the fall semester began I was ready for it, and joyfully continued with my last year in college.

My sister, Ella Cornelia, graduated from Harding in June of 1941. That same June I finished sixth grade, and would be attending Seventh Grade at Harding High School in that Fall. My sister was elated to be out of school, and was eager to jump into the experience of working for a living. Family friends operated a small office for a major insurance company, and they offered Ella Cornelia, a job. She took the proffered job, and worked happily there for a while. However, she truly believed she wanted to go to college, and in the fall of 1941 she enrolled at a college in the mountains of North Carolina. She had earned a little over the summer, and Mother and Daddy were helping her with tuition, so she trotted off to the mountains to college. I’m not sure what Ella Cornelia thought college would be like, but whatever she expected she didn’t find it. Her roommate was from a well-to-do family of German extraction, and the ordinary courses that freshmen take when they enroll in any college did not fascinate either of them. In that small mountain town there were few, if any, exciting places to visit. The campus was small, and though the views were quite lovely in hill country they don’t change very much from day to day. The relatively small community was a small mountain town—not offering very much in the way of entertainment such as Charlotte could provide. The studies were just that—and not riveting. Ella Cornelia had never loved the unexciting every day lessons of school. She didn’t have even one exciting friend in her new location, and the only person she really knew was her room mate who didn’t like the school either. Ella Cornelia stuck it out until Christmas Vacation. Then she decide she didn’t like college well enough to stick it out. So she and her room mate packed their clothes and accoutrements and took a bus to Charlotte. Her former roommate came with her, and stayed at our house a day or two, then left for her own home.

On the About a week later The year was December of 1941. It was almost Christmas. So my sister and her room mate decided to dump the whole idea. When, and came home for Christmas with no plans to return to college. Mother and Daddy regretted her decision, but didn’t try to change her mind. My sister quickly found a new job as secretary to a two man insurance agency with some old friends of my parents, and she was a working woman again.

I had been eager to become a “high school” student. In many communities seventh grade was not high school. It could be “Middle School,” or a Junior High School, but not a Senior High School. Harding High school was sort of unique in our city because it incorporated six grades—Grades seven to twelve, and could not be called less than High School because then the senior high students would have been more than a little upset, so it was called Harding High School from the beginning, even though Junior High students also attended there.

My seventh grade studies began in September, and I was pleased with my teachers, extremely happy with my elective class which was orchestra. I found friends I had known in sixth grade with whom I could walk to school. I had mostly new clothes to start the school year because I was growing tall, and I was—well, I thought I was at least o.k. looking, even if I was a little chubby. I had been both sorry and glad that I needed all new clothes because I had grown taller as well as maturing so that most of my blouses sort of strained across my chest. I had also grown taller during the summer causing few of the clothes I had worn in sixth grade were wearable for my seventh grade year. Since my sister had planned to go to college and needed new clothes that fall, my mother had delayed sewing for me—after all, I wasn’t really going anywhere. I wasn’t pleased with the situation, but I accepted it, and didn’t complain. Then there was a sudden chill in the air, and there was frost on the ground one morning. I put on my last winter’s coat, and I couldn’t button it. It had become too short. My arms were too long for the sleeves. I had outgrown it. The real problem was that I really didn’t have a coat I could wear and it really was cold that morning. So I wore my too tight coat.

I didn’t enjoy making a problem for my mother. There I was, with almost no winter clothes to wear, and no coat. Since my mother was a seamstress she always made my clothes. I suddenly needed “everything” and in her sweet pleasure for my sister’s decision to go to college which began much earlier than my school year, she had not yet made me new clothes. I had outgrown my winter coat. My winter clothes were all too small for me. And now the weather, which had been very mild up until that moment—had turned cold.

I had nothing to wear to school, so mother made me put on a sweater that would close over my chest, and helped me squeeze into my coat

In one short period of ten minutes or so, I ruined my mother’s day, and became a problem where my clothing was concerned.

New clothes for me were indicated, and Mother quickly lengthened skirts and let out seams until I had winter clothes to wear. It wasn’t an error that I had made, so I wasn’t upset, but I did feel that somehow I had let my mother down by making her work late into the night for several days so that I could have clothes to wear to school.

I was happy to begin my first year of high school. I made a friend named Sue the very first day. I liked my classes. I loved orchestra. I walked a mile to and from school carrying an armload of books and my violin. I loved walking home with Sue, and often walked several blocks beyond the intersection where I would part from Sue and walk one more block to home.

I knew that I had chores to do when I arrived at home after school at about 3:25 every day. When the weather was cool it was my chore to bring in coal and light a fire in the stove. I also was to wash any soiled plates and glasses left from breakfast. If mother had told me what to fix for supper I would begin to prepare the meal. I almost always made the biscuits, and cooked the vegetables. Actually we didn’t eat a lot of meat.

When I arrived home in cold weather my first chore was to make a fire in the laundry heater to warm the kitchen, and bring in enough coal to keep it going as long as it would be needed. Then I could do my homework. If I wasn’t finished with my school work by four-thirty I had to put my books away and start making supper. I rarely had real “from scratch”cooking to do. I could make slaw, and biscuits, and warm home canned food from the pantry, and I could wash green vegetables and put them in a pot for cooking. if I had homework, my parents expected me to finish it before bed time. If there were soiled dishes I was to wash them. If mother had given me instructions for supper I was to complete them. However if I had no homework, I had the afternoon for reading, and I did love to read. I was one of the best customers the library had, and I was rarely without a book if I was alone in the house.

Mother usually arrived between five-thirty and six o’clock, but I didn’t expect Daddy until just before dark. When he arrived he had chores to do before he could eat—he had to put away his painting supplies and wash out his brushes, and sometimes he laid out the paints and drop cloths and brushes for the next day. Only then would he be free to come into the house for his supper.

When I could sit down in the kitchen, I loved listening to the radio, and sometimes I turned it on when I was washing dishes. Since Mother was working I had

esoe if I was working in the house, or if I had a book to read I was happy. I hadn’t yet read I loved to readWe had radio, and I loved to read. I also had lessons to There were some radio programs that I enjoyed, and I often turned on our radio when I was alone in the kitchen. There were only three stations in Charlotte, and if there was nothing on the radio I wanted to listen to, I could always read a book—because I loved to read. I was rarely uneasy if I was alone. I usually kept the doors locked because we lived in a neighborhood near when I was alonenever lonely nor did I feel frightened when I was alone. I could lock my front door, and the back door was locked before I left home that morning.left me a note about supper, I had to fix part of the meal , I had toIt I had two or three breakfast dishes to wash, and if it was cold outside I had to bring in coal and make a fire in the kitchen stove. Mother would make supper when she came home, unless she had left me instructions to cook something. I had the house to myself for about two hours. I could and usually did listen to the radio My mother was still working at the sewing shop, my Daddy had plenty of work as a paint contractor, and I liked my new friend named with whom I walked to school. In the afternoons I usually walked halfway to Sue’s house with her, then retraced about four blocks to my own home, because Sue didn’t like to walk alone. who lived a little more than half a mile up the street from my house. I had a bed room to myself, and my little world was rosy. My sister was still away in college when my school year began. and that made me a sort of “only” child since I was the only one at home, which I relished.

month before my matriculation at Harding, our lives were changed by circumstances neither we, nor our families, had control over. Japanese air planes dropped bomb on and American Naval Station in Hawaii and the United States declared war on Japan, and on Germany and Italy as well.

Charlotte’s schools always had Christmas vacations—about ten days or so—before school resumed. Early in December it was dark before six o’clock, and that Sunday evening

ess than six months before I began my seventh grade studies, the Japanese attacked Pearl Harbor on December 7, 1941, and the United States entered the war almost immediately. Though there had been peace in our country for some years, the armed services still existed in our country, but I had never actually seen a soldier in all of my life until after December 7, 1941. My Dad had been in the Merchant Marines near the time of the First World War. When his ship docked in foreign places he usually bought small souvenirs to take home, and there were some photographs of him in his sailor’s uniform with some of his buddies. He bought a small shellacked box in China, and for all of his life it sat in the middle of the Dresser in his room, holding a few mementos of his voyages, and some small trinkets he bought while abroad. There were pictures of himself in uniform in China, and other places where he made landfall. He had not been in battles, but he had seen a lot of the world when he returned home. I was very grateful that he did not have to go into the armed services again. He was over forty years old at that time, and not eligible for service.

I remember how glad I was that my Daddy didn’t have to go to war. There was a family living across the street from our house. The father worked, the mother stayed home, and their two grown children lived with them. Their son joined the Air Force soon after Pearl Harbor was bombed, and after his training he was assigned to duty in Europe. When he first joined the Air Force his mother bought a small flag with a blue star in its center to hang in her living room window. It was something families did when someone in their family went to war, so that everyone who saw it knew someone from that home was in service. One day his mother replaced the blue star with a gold one. Her son’s plane had gone down over Europe, and he was buried there.

Suddenly, the Depression that had caused hardships for almost every person in our country was over. Instead of out of work persons begging for jobs, jobs were begging for people to do them. Factories that made war materials discovered that most young men were in the military, and there were not enough workers to do the job of building ships and airplanes and munitions—so women were hired to build ships and planes, and to make munitions. There was a popular song about Rosie the Riveter that was played with pride on radio stations. Women became ambulance drivers and factory workers, and they filled many jobs that only men had previously held.

We, (my parents, my sister, and I) resided in Charlotte on West Eleventh Street, a location which does not now exist as it has been incorporated into a ramp leading to an interstate highway. My Dad’s parents, along with his only brother and two unmarried sisters, lived on the family farm near Pineville. His sister Pauline, the youngest daughter, was married. She and her husband rented a house only about three minute walk from the family farm. My Dad’s mother was blind and an invalid, but his father still helped Uncle Eddie with the farm chores. Two of my Dad’s sisters were “old maids” when the war began, and they, too, were still living at home. The Yandle home place was a little bit more than a mile from the town of Pineville. When my Uncle Eddie wanted or needed to walk to Pineville where there were stores, he usually followed the railroad tracks because it was the shorter distance by about half a mile, and in addition was safer than dodging fast moving automobiles on the highway. W

My Mother’s parents lived on several acres of farm land not far from the South Carolina border, and only a little more than a mile from my Dad’s parents. I have only a vague and shadowed memory of their home place, mostly because I was only about five years old when they decided to abandon their own home and move in with my Aunt Ola and Uncle Vance. Grandmother Parks had suffered a heart attack, and Grand-daddy Parks was getting too old to till his fields or care for his stock. For all of his life Grand-daddy and Grandmother Parks had attended Flint Hill Baptist church not far from their home and easily reached by horse and buggy.

They made the decision to move into werehat house to live with my Aunt Ola when I was about five years old. I do have a faint memory of that house because on the last Sunday my mother’s parents would be in their own home built on their own farm, I had a wonderful treat.

They had moved from their When I was about five years old they left their own home on their farm and moved in with their oldest daughter, my Aunt Ola, and her husband Vance Davis, who had no children. to the home of their oldest daughter, my Aunt Ola. Uncle Vance, her husbandhouseThey, too, were living with one of their children—my Aunt Ola, and her husband, Vance Davis. other had one sister, Ola Davis, who lived near Pineville, and two brothers. One living with his family in Fort Mill, South Carolina, and the other living with his wife a little further away, also South Carolina. We saw Aunt Ola and her husband, Uncle Vance quite often. Uncle Vance was a farmer, the son of a farmer. He was also a man of all work. There was a forge in his back yard, a workshop in his “basement” A convenient distance from his back door there was an “out-house toilet” along a shady path an and a little beyond that there was a large building that served at least two or three major needs: One, was that it was a chicken house, and like most other chicken houses it was usually ankle deep in chicken droppings. However, in neat boxes along both sides of the building there were boxes for the large number of hens to lay eggs in. Like most farmers who kept lots of chickens, their droppings were used for fertilizer. Aunt Ola sold the eggs or used them, but she also “saved” some of them in large jars, and I never discovered how they tasted, or why she did it, or even how she did it. I did see large glass containers that would hold at least three gallons, filled with some sort of clear gel, with eggs suspended within it, not touching each other. Aunt Ola was, to me, a wonder woman. She did not have running water in her house until I was a teenager. She did not have electricity in her house until World War II ended. She used a pedal sewing machine, and I often saw her make quilts.

Aunt Ola never threw away bits of cloth sturdy enough to become part of a quilt. She always kept a “rag” bag in which to store scraps of cloth culled from the “good” pieces of worn out or torn clothing or bits and pieces left over from making new clothing. Her quilts most often had a carefully cut pattern of pieces of cloth sewn together to make a colorful and pleasant coverlet. The coverlet could serve as a quilt, and also as a pleasant “spread” through out the day. The filling of the quilts—what was sandwiched between the fabric of the top and bottom of the quilt—was combed cotton. Cotton bolls straight from the field were relieved of their seeds, and combed between two the fabric on the bottom of the was carefully placed and “quilted” with hundreds of small stitches so that the cotton between the top and bottom of a quilt would stay in place, and provide warmth for a number of years.

Quilts had two surfaces, and between them Aunt Ola would lay evenly carded cotton battens, which she carded herself from cotton straight from her own fields. This was a tedious sort of operation. Aunt Ola would have to remove the seeds from the cotton, then put wads of cotton balls on one batten and use the battens (like a really stiff hair brush, only it was made with thin nails the field had cotton seeds buried in the balls of white cotton. These were picked out, and the soft cotton balls placed between two paddles with handles. The paddles were like a slender piece of wood with thin nails sticking out from one side in careful rows. It took two paddles to find the seeds. tapped Since quilts had two surfaces between which were cotton battens (Aunt Ola’s battens were home made on wooden paddles with sturdy teeth that would comb the cotton seeds from the cotton balls that had been harvested from her own fields) that were from “combs” with which she for warmth, Aunt Ola would buy new material to make borders between the blocks she had so carefully designed

, and then making other square the same size, with the same colors if possible, or with squares that would compliment each other. Then she would purchase cloth that would serve as the “back” of the quilt, and use some of it to “frame” the squares she had sewn so carefully. she had put together. similar to the first one The other square

and from it she would design and sew together patterns of small bits of cloth until it was a “block” about ten inches square. Then she would fit the blocks together, usually separating them by placing a strips of “bought” cloth that would frame the blocks both vertically and horizontally, making a “quilt top”. More often than not, the other side of the quilt was of bought fabric, sewn together and stretch onto her quilt frame. Upon the lted bl strips of cloth, so that the dividersblocks of

a quilt stretched on a wooden frame as wide and as long as a quilt so she could stitch the cotton batting between the that could be hoisted up to the ceiling when she was not using itin her “sitting room” so that whenever she had the opportunity she could work on er. , or some way “saved” them (I did not ever figure out how that worked) but she put them in some sort of gel in jars that would hold about three gallons of the jell, and lots of eggs suspended in the jell. of held lots and lots of eggs in a whitish colored jell. I never ate any of them that I know of, but I was aware that there were lots of large glass jars easy Now the front of his house was one easily managed step up onto his front porch. The rear of his house was about ten feet off the ground.

He fashioned a machine that would saw lumber from trees, and became and Aunt Ola

Less often we saw Uncle Dennis, his wife Mary, and their three children, Dennis, Jr., Patsy, and Mary Cole; because they . Uncle Dennis lived in Fort Mill, only a few miles from Pineville, and since they had an automobile we saw them at least once a month. However Uncle Luther and his wife, who had no children, lived further away and though they also owned an automobile we saw them mostly on special occasions such as birthday celebrations or Christmas. shop on the main street of a small town named Fort Mill. Dennis was married and had three children, his oldest was named for his father, Dennis, Junior, and was mostly called simply “Junior”. The girls were the youngest, and were named Patsy and Mary Cole. Uncle Luther married _____, who had been a school teacher. They had no children.

who lived with her husband Vance Davis on their farm about a mile When the war began my Dad, mom, sister, and I, were living in Charlotte in a rented house on West Eleventh Street. One of his sisters was married, and lived within five minutes walking distance of her parent’s house, and her two sisa small distance within walking distance of the Two of his three sisters still lived at home, and took care of their parents along with his only brother. The other sister was married, and lived with her husband in a house about a block away from her parent’s house. Pauline, the married one, worked in Charlotte. In that day and time she was the unusual one—she drove her own automobile to her job in Charlotte, and back again in the evening. The rest of my father’s siblings still lived at home with their elderly parents. My grandmother was bedridden, and blind. **and drove her own car to work each day. I had never seen my Aunt Helen anywhere except at home, where she took care of her invalid mother (my grandmother) and cooked for her parents, and her brother and sister. Uncle Eddie took care of the fields and their livestock my Grandparents , daddy, my Uncle Eddie, who took care of their livestock, and worked their fields. My Aunt Martha had once studied as a nurse, but became ill, and was unable to complete her training. She took care of my grandmother who was blind. But Aunt Martha, whom I had never seen in any garment except a dress, put on coveralls, and went to work a secret place that was called simply, the shell plant. I never saw it, and I never knew exactly where it was. The people who worked there never talked about what they did, nor did they mention where it was located. They worked there until the plant closed after the war ended. All during that time my Aunt Ola picked up my Aunt Martha every day, and those two ladies worked at the shell plant until the war was over. in my grandparents house. two of them away from their home. The youngest one, Aunt Pauline, had gone to college and worked in Charlotte, though she lived in Pineville. They had no transportation of their own. My mother’s sister Ola could drive a car, and she and her farmer husband owned a 1929 Ford. A building that I never saw was built in a place I never heard named, but it could be reached by an automobile. My Aunt Ola was whom I had never seen at

Two of my aunts made weapons in a secret plant located somewhere between Pineville and Charlotte, North Carolina. I was a curious child, but they never told me exactly what they did when they were at work. These were women who had never in their lives worn men’s clothing—but now they wore overalls because it was required. One of these aunts was an old maid, and I had seen her away from her house only once or twice in my life. She so rarely went anywhere it was a shock to me to see her away from home. My other aunt had a 1929 Ford car, but she, too, had never worked outside her house. I had never known her to go anywhere except to church. I don’t remember that she had ever even been to Charlotte to visit her only sister—my mother. But during the war my Aunt Ola Davis drove to the house of my Grandmother Yandle to pick up my Aunt Martha, and the two of them went to work at a secret place that was built after the war began to make something secret to be used to fight the war. Neither Aunt would tell me what the

had never worked at a job outside her home, and didn’t have a car. My other aunt lived about a mile from her house, and I had never in all my ten or eleven years of life seen the two of them together. They recognized each other, but I had never seen them together. When the war began there were so many needs that jobs were plentiful, and skilled people were excused form service in the military if they were already doing something important, such as making ammunition, or army uniforms, or building airplanes. Salaries in the armed forces were small—but the men were clothed, housed, trained, and they paid for none of that training. and until war began was still affecting wages, prices, investments, building, and therefore keeping the economy from growing was completely over. The government was spending money building Army Posts, Marine stations, Air Force bases, as well as purchasing weapons, building factories to make bombs and uniforms and boots and guns. Housing was needed for the service men, so contractors were rushed to complete new naval, marine, army, and air force locations, and mills along with factories were making shoes, caps, uniforms, blankets, and other items for use by the armed forces.

, as well as the houses people lived in and the jobs available to those who wanted to work, was over. The government was eager to build up an army, a navy, and marines. There was a need for air plane pilots, and places to train them. There were demands for motorized vehicles, from tanks to smaller vehicles to drive, not only within training camps, but on battlegrounds. The Jeep was born, and produced quickly. In December of 1941 when the Japanese attack occurred there were still pockets of our nation that had remained devastated by the Financial Depression. The Depression was over when factories were opened to make war materials. Men left their civilian jobs to join the services. Women, too, were able to join the women’s branch of both Army and Navy, and I think women could also join the Air Force. When men suddenly dropped their jobs to join the military there was a change in the United States. Instead of a depressed economy, the people who had jobs were begging women to come to work because so many men had enlisted—now there weren’t enough men to fill all the positions that were open and begging to be filled. Nurses and Doctors left their civilian practices to become physicians within the services. Nurses followed them into battle areas. People died. Wherever there were battles there were casualties. The German attacks in Europe devastated most of those countries. The Germans attacked the Russians, France, England, and other nations in Europe. The Japanese wanted to rule the countries surrounded by the Pacific Ocean. They were fighting China, and many of the islands in the Pacific. Germany had an ally in Italy and was fighting France and Poland, and many other small countries in that part of the world. Airplanes were used to drop bombs, destroying the cities, interrupting transportation, and the ability to and Italy, in Europe and Japan in the East were attacking their neighbors. Japan wanted to destroy the United States particularly.

The United States began to fight back; however, they were not actually Existing military men and drove the people from their homes. were driven from their homes and either froze to death or were killed by invaders. The French were invaded by Germans Not only did people in Europe and the Far East, and the Islands of the Pacific , and women, too, leaving jobs without workers, and . Demands for the instruments of war—guns, airplanes, ships, trucks, cars, gasoline to run them, tanks, weapons, uniforms, tents, cots, blankets, boots, and then there was need for forts with toilets, showers and spaces for beds for the soldiers to sleep in. , s, forts in which to train young volunteers and young men who were compelled to register for service. Most of the camps that had been busy places during the First World War were no longer suitable for the more modern army. and the houses peopin , a few months after the Japanese bombed Pearl Harbor. I graduated from the same school in 1949, and spent the next four years at Queens College, graduating with an AB degree in 1953. In the years of my schooling there was a World War—the second one for our country.

Strangely, Ella Cornelia and I took nearly the same subjects in High School. She found a job quickly, and worked for a while in an insurance office. This was not particularly fascinating. So she enrolled at Lees McRae College, up in the mountains of North Carolina. With the war going full blast college was less and less fulfilling. Ella Cornelia had worked in an office in town, and had worked in her teens in a five and dime store. She left school at the Christmas Holiday, and did not return. She found a job, and volunteered at Memorial Hospital as a Nurses Aid. A little later she worked as a secretary in a physician’s office, and some years later she worked at Memorial Hospital in the X-ray Department, typing up reports on the X-rays of patients. She was working there when World War II ended.

When I was old enough to notice how our city was put together because I had to walk to school, and after school walk almost a mile to the Quite early in the history of Charlotte the city streets were laid out, The city streets of Charlotte were laid out years in precise squares, and eventually the streets were paved, as well as side walks on both sides of the road. ago, Our neighborhood streets were laid out in even sized blocks. The corner houses faced only one street, though along one of their houses there was another street. Our house was the first one on that block of West Eleventh Street, but it was not on a corner. The first house on Pine Street was the corner house, with its back door opening on Eleventh Street, beside the front of our house. Our two story house was a duplex, with two front doors and two back doors, and one central wall between the two dwellings. Each side was a mirror image of the layout of the other. There was one roof for both houses. There were porches at the back as well as the front of the house. At the back, the porches were latticed and had screen wire on the inside to keep out flies and mosquitoes. It was divided evenly, with a solid wall between the two porches, presumably for privacy. Both front porches, and the rooms within each side of the duplex, were mirror images of each other, with a common center wall and no access from one house to the other. When the people who lived next door were friends, the stay-at-home wives could bang on the kitchen wall, and yell, “come over for coffee (or iced tea)” and the ladies could share a brief rest from their household chores, along with a friendly chat. My mother was delighted that when I was about five years old we acquired new neighbors who had a little girl close to my age. She was a bit bigger than me, but my same age. Children my age were scarce on our street, and at first it seemed wonderful to have a playmate my own age. However, my pleasure was short lived. That little girl rarely came outside without her older brother who was already in his teens. He, I discovered, had a mean streak, and thoroughly enjoyed tormenting me, since he was forbidden by his parents to torment his sister. He was not allowed to trip, or push, or hit his sister. He well knew his parents would not tolerate that—but I didn’t count, and he showed his sister how much fun it could be if the two of them finagled me into a trap where I could—and did—bet hurt. They both seemed to enjoy that. They caught me twice in their little jokes, and she dropped my only baby doll and broke it. We were compelled to walk to school together in first and

could, and did, urge her to help him trap me so that both of them could have a laugh at my expense. I clearly remember one of the last tricks he played on me: He was playing with a rope, tying his sister’s feet, or her hands, and then letting her go. I was the spectator. Then he made a circle of his rope, and invited his sister to jump in and out of the rope circle while he held one end of the rope. She held the rope several times while he, himself jumped in and out. He invited me to do it, and I said no. He and his sister pretended to be having a wonderful time jumping into and out of the rope that lay quietly on the ground. Then he coaxed me to take turns with his sister and since she was doing it with me, I thought I was probably safe. me to jump in and out of the circle. When we were both playing I didn’t mind doing it. But then the little Betty wanted to do it by herself, indicating that we could do it in turns. However when I jumped into the small circle the big brother jerked the loop and tied my feet together then jerked it so that I fell hard on the ground, scraping my elbow. I was—if you want to know—not amused in the least, because my elbow was skinned, the rope put a burn on my ankles, and my dress had red dirt on it where that big boy had pulled me on the dirt. I never did trust either one of them again. been . The brother and sister laughed like hyenas. . For a long time there had been no children my age for me to play with. There were no other children really close to my age in the neighborhood, at least not close to us, though my sister had found one close friend and several other acquaintances to grow up with. When my mother let me play the new neighbor’s child, I was not delighted. She was larger than me, a few months older than me, and bossy. Besides that, she had an older brother that was mean as a snake. She liked that brother, and both of them delighted in what they called teasing me. The boy liked to hurt me. The girl delighted in helping him trick me in a game so that so that he could make me fall or otherwise hurt myself. The girl was rough with toys, and she liked to play with the few I possessed because her toys were broken. Soon mine were broken, too, if she was able to “play” with them. In the first summer they lived next door to us neither I nor the neighbor child, had yet gone to school. In the fall my mother was thrilled that I didn’t need to walk to and from school alone since the neighbor’s aggravating little girl could walk with me so that we could be some small protection to each other. That was a hard for me, too, but it lasted through the beginning days of the first grade because my Mother took a job.

A former neighbor was a partner in a sewing shop, located very near the Square which was an intersection in the middle of the city of Charlotte. Originally it was a cross road of Trade Street, which went east and west, and Tryon Street which went north and south. In the center of that crossing stood a small wooden Court House where many important decisions about our town were made. As the town grew, the court house became increasingly inadequate, and it was decided to build a new one with more grandeur and space. The location of the existing building was called “The Square”. Two roads met there—Trade Street which extended beyond the square in an easterly direction on one side and a westerly direction on the opposite one, as well as Tryon Street on which traffic moving either north or south could travel. In the meantime, other buildings had been built near the square, and there was no longer space for a spacious City Hall without pulling down those recently completed large buildings. It was decided to choose a different location, and so a spacious Courthouse as well as a City Hall were built on East Trade Street a few city blocks from the original wooden building. The intersection of the two original roads in the town crossed each other, and where the first Court House was located. Eventually the Court House required more space and it was relocated about half a mile away on East Trade Street. The name the town citizens had given the area stuck, and that intersection was still called “The Square.” was . Rather suddenly my situation did change. I insisted that I needed to walk to school alone each morning, and my afternoon walk now turned in a journey to my mother sewing shop—a different path, and I was forbidden even to go into my empty house when I was released from school. Instead, I left school and walked eleven city blocks to the Sewing Shop and stayed there until Mother’s shop closed when we could walk home together.

Once I was in school my mother took a job as a seamstress. A former neighbor whom I called Mrs. King had set up a sewing shop with another lady as her partner. They had a nice shop and a clientele. Mrs. King’s partner wanted to retire, and so my mother became her partner, and the sign on the window of the room where they worked read: King and Yandle Sewing Shop. I was six and a half years old, and

The Southern States had suffered from the Depression which began in 1929. The Northern sections of America had grown in population, and in industry, much faster than the Southern sections. The South was mostly farming country, with few Cities, while the North seemed bigger as well as more heavily populated than in the South, with factories and mills, as well as farms. The South had a bunch of cotton gins, but their population had suffered greatly from the War Between the States. The Plantations and their fields were where the riches lay, and after the War there were no workers to plant, and harvest those fields. The former Confederacy was shattered when there were no slaves to work their fields. Many farms and estates had been mortgaged to fund the Civil War and furnish their army with uniforms and arms. These homes and plantations were lost when the battles were lost. Former slaves, who were freed by the government had no jobs, no shelter, and rarely had a change of clothing. The worst problem for them came at once—no food or shelter. Young, old, sick or well, they were on their own, without extra clothing, food, or homes.

These were very sad times

In the South there was little, if any, actual help from the government. Hungry, frightened, without shelter, what had seemed to be a wonderful victory, and a wonderful release for them became a nightmare with no shelter, no food, only the clothes they were wearing, , except for the real facts. They had no jobs, no homes, no food, no clothes, no shoes, no education, no medical treatment, and no hope. Former owners were, in their position, to be avoided, and they had no place to live, no food to eat. If their clothing was torn there was no replacement, most of them were barefooted. They could pillage the plantations, but once their first effort to fill their needs was done, there was very little left, either for them or for their former owners. could not or would no help them. The former slaves, old or young, well or sick, hungry more than likely, and angry about the situation, had no homes, no source of food, . As slave sit all who were now despised by their former owners, and angry themselves at being homeless and without money . Set free without jobs or homes, without food or shelter, without protectors, , and because they had themselves financed the war, there was very little value in their large plantations—they no longer had slaves to work the land, and since they had financed the war themselves, no money to pay workers. There were hungry and angry former slaves running free, and taking what they wanted or needed wherever they could find it. farms. use without slaves there was no one to work the land. Therefore there was no cotton, nor any other produce to sell. many plantations and farms did not —financially, as well as, and though there had been rich landowners before the conflict, there were few who were not devastated by the outcome of the war. , and the way of life in the South was devastated in some areas, less so in other sections. There were fewer people in the South who had steady income and large farms. There were fewer cities with factories in the South, which had been thrive , and there were larger cities in the North than in the . There were fewer people in the South, and fewer mills and factories in the South than in the North. , and a great many more farmers. Small farms were not usually a money making business, but it was a sturdy way of life, producing food in their fields, and eggs and ham and bacon as well as beef from their animals. Farming was not generally a way to get rich, but it was a pleasant life when no droughts or bugs ruined the fields and no diseases struck the livestock. needing more houses, more automobiles, more food, more towns, more transportation, I was born in 1931. The South was mostly farming country, with scattered towns and few real cities, and that was a time when

was going to have a playmate—except that when she was little she was mean, and helped her older brother torment me. We played together, mostly because there were no other children exactly our age (five or six years old) living near us. , who had two children, a boy and a girl who was my age, We were still living in that house when my sister married Harry May. There was a house just across the street from ours that had been divided into two “apartments.” Harry and Ella Cornelia rented the smaller space, and lived there for about five years before they bought their own dwelling. They had privacy, but they also had family very close. This was a time when World War II was over, an age one of them a sort of My family was still living in that house when I married. My sister had married several years before, and And had kitchens, staircases, and hall walls back to back, and three rooms (Living Room, Dining Room and closet, tiny hall, and kitchen, at the back of the house. Between dining room and living room) though thebanister on both back and front of the house. The back porchesThere was a thin wall between the two, and lattices lined with screen wire around them. The front porches shared one roof, but there was a little gap between them. Each had its own entrance. The front yards were tiny, mostly covered with bushes. For years—once I was old enough to take on chores—I cut the grass in our front yard with the only tool available to me—a butcher knife.* entrances were separated by two porches, each with its own banisters, and a little gap between the. . only a wall separated the porches. In the front, however the two porches were divided by banisters surrounding each; however, the roof was not divided, and covered a three foot gap between the porches. the same, and , and a little ; however there was only one porch roofwas a porch The porch roof also covered both sides of the duplex, but the porches had a gap between them, emphasizing the , like the rest of the house, were covered with the same roof and surrounded by banisters, and though onwere banisters and a four foot gap between the porches. however, the porches were railed, and there was a gap between themdid not connect. OThe banisters of our porches were the separated by a gap . The rooms of our side of the house was a mirror image of the was made of sqst house on that block facing Eleventh Street. The first house on Pine Street was the “corner” house, its back door opening on a driveway that opened The back door of the , but we were not “on the corner”. It was an old neighborhood, with some houses stilled owned by its occupants, and a sprinkling of renters, as well. Our house was the first house on the block facing Eleventh Street. But there was a house above ours, facing Pine Street, so that our house was not on the Between our house and the corner was Above us was a corner house, facing Pine Street. The length of the side of that house, front to back, was on Eleventh streeetOn that day I walked alone a little further than one city block to our neighborhood church where the evening services were being held. It was nearly dark when I walked home.Like most Americans I listened to the radio news about the attack on Pearl Harbor. I had been listening to reports from England about the bombing of England and the fighting in Europe. I was frightened, of course, and I remember asking if bombers were going to drop bombs on Charlotte. My father assured me that we would have plenty of notice if such a thing was going to happen, and it probably wouldn’t happen at all. After Christmas when we went back to school my teacher handed out letters to parents of their students, and they asked parents to indicate whether or not they could house children from the Atlantic Coastal area in the event that area would be attacked by enemy bombers. My mother said yes—we could take six.

After my graduation from high school I went to Queens College, and graduated in four years. School was in session about nine months out of the twelve, and I worked every summer to earn pocket money for the next school year. Ella Cornelia embarked on her “adult” life straight out of High School. Remember that World War II had just begun. Physicians and nurses were in demand on military posts all over the country. This was a real dilemma for hospitals all over the country. Nurses were suddenly in demand at the local hospitals all over the country. The quickest solution was volunteers who could take over some of the menial tasks, like delivering meals to patients, holding bed pans, and filling water glasses. There were often, I am sure, eventually more important duties for the quite wonderful young people who took special training and then regularly put on their pale blue denim sleeveless uniforms worn over white blouses with Red Cross patches to serve as helpers to the nurses who were over-worked. The young volunteers were unpaid, but greatly appreciated.

Though Ella Cornelia did try Lees McCrae College from September through December in 1942, she didn’t like it. Somehow, with the war escalating, going back to school seemed unimportant to her. The world was at war, and she had been doing highly worthwhile things as a Nurses Aid. Spending her time reading text books seemed useless under these circumstances. She came home at Christmas, and didn’t go back to school.

job in a doctor’s office shortly after she put her college education aside. Later she worked for at least two physicians, and eventually went to work in the X-ray department of Memorial Hospital. She was working there when she got married.

She graduated in 1942—just months after the beginning of World War II. I think one reason she didn’t like college was that almost as soon as World War II began the entire United States changed what it was doing, and how it was doing it. The last time a full army was needed was in 1918. During the peaceful interlude between those wars there was a nominal army, a nominal navy, and a nominal marine corp. They were not very visible. At the age of six or seven I had never seen a soldier, though I knew my Dad had served as a sailor about the time of the First World War, however, he was not on a battleship.

When I started college I was fascinated at what I was learning. and embarked on her “adult” life before I was out of high school. She helped me in countless ways as I was growing up. Ella Cornelia was old enough in 1942 to take a course at Memorial Hospital that made her a volunteer Nurses Aide. A great number of nurses went into the armed services, leaving many hospitals all over the country short of nurses, and young women volunteers pitched in to help with the menial duties of nursing in the Charlotte hospitals so that trained nurses could handle those duties that could mean, quite literally, life or death for patients who needed such care. The Nurses Aids were volunteers, and scantly trained, and they received no salaries.

I envied her the opportunity to help with the war effort. I wanted to help, too, but the most important thing I could do was to make sure that any empty tin can was rinsed and flattened, and taken to school to be put into a special box to be recycled. Food tins were so difficult to get that many food manufacturers began to sell “canned” foods in glass jars. I remember that my mother “spent” some of our precious food ration stamps to buy a jar of fruit cocktail for a special meal. A street near our home had recently been repaved, but it had been roughly done because of shortages of materials. As she crossed that street she stumped her toe on an uneven space of the new pavement and dropped her large double armful of groceries, breaking the glass jar that held the fruit cocktail. That, of course, was the end of that! I remember that she wept, not because she fell and bruised and scraped her knees on the rough new pavement, and not because she ruined her nylon stockings, but because she had lost the fruit cocktail which could not be replaced.

Even though the “Great Depression” was ten or more years behind us when World War II began, there was the fact that a lot of people still found it difficult to feed their families. The depression had been the beginning of folks loosing their jobs, and ten years after that fact there were many families still struggling to put food on their table. Movies were popular and I remember “Snow White” with the little dwarfs, and the happy song they sang: “Hi Ho, Hi Ho, It’s off to work we go” and I remembered how people would laugh and cheerfully borrow their tune to sing “I owe, I owe, so off to work I go” and though they smiled, they meant to imply that it was not always pleasant.

The Depression had lingered in parts of the United States—but the Depression was over when the War began. Suddenly well paying jobs were available. The armed forces were inducting young men and young women as well, aged eighteen and older for training. After the close of the First World War many military posts were abandoned. Now they were building new, modern posts for all the services: Army, Navy, Marine, and Air Force training stations were being built or refurbished as most of the existing military or navel posts were in disrepair or simply too out of date to be effective. Immediate housing was needed to shelter the new recruits who were enlisting across all of America. Forts and Naval bases that were abandoned after the 1918 war were inadequate and out of date. Airfields and Naval bases had to be reopened or built from scratch. Forts for training had to be built. The newly inducted servicemen needed uniforms, beds, weapons, and daily meals as well as shelter. Factories were overwhelmed with orders to supply these demands. Munitions factories became busy. Clothing factories made uniforms. Shoes, boots, and other footwear were being made. Workers in factories making munitions, or uniforms were suddenly working over-time. Contractors who were building new military bases were working overtime to complete their jobs.*** Some recreation sites such as lots of hotels along a beach were forts filled with barracks to house thousands of young men training for training soldiers, building ships, submarines, air planes and making munitions provided lots of jobs. It was Boom time. Mills were busy making uniforms and tents. Factories were making uniforms and shoes for the armed services, and beds, lockers. Barracks had to be built then there were larger needed to make uniforms and boots, as well as tents and beds and lockers for soldiers, and there manufacturers were needed to build air planes, battle tanks, weapons, and other hardware used by soldiers and sailors and marines. There were not enough Military Posts to train the great number of soldiers that would be required. Someone had to build new army posts. Young men had to train as soldiers. Therefore new ones had to be built, and old ones refurbished. Hotels built for tourists at beaches could offer both space for training and beds for sleeping and so they were put to that use. Builders were needed to build, and painters were needed to paint the new buildings. Manufacturers had orders for their products. Young men and women were called into the army, navy and air force, and that meant there were fewer replacements for retirees and huge market for workers who enlisted in the services. To the surprise of many, old people took up menial jobs so that the stronger ones could work in more demanding jobs. The losses of the depression years were definitely over.

The energy and the efforts poured into preparing for war brought significant changes. The tools of war were weapons, machines, tanks, air planes, guns, trucks, jeeps, weapons, tents, and not the least—food for the troops, and utensils for them to eat with. In the civilian world clothing, shoes, and food was less plentiful. *. When the war ceased and the enlisted men and women came home time itself seemed to change. Peace was not actually peaceful in the beginning. There were too many empty chairs, waiting for family members to return home from military service. There were those who lost their lives, and would never return. There were wounded men who Not only because there were empty chairs in many homes—but because the needs and requirements of mounting a war had revealed gaps in knowledge that bright inventors and scientists worked hard to fill. Medicines called antibiotics were discovered and used, new gadgets were invented making work easier, and a burgeoning economy and communication breakthroughs made spreading ideas from coast to coast much easier. Electricity which before the war was available only in large cities had spread over the United States, and all over the world. Then machines that were scarce during the war and used for the military or for other specific uses suddenly could be bought for home use. They were welcomed, bought, and used. Work, especially tedious work began to be easier in a great many situations. Soldiers came home and found jobs. There had been many inventions developed during the years of the war that had been used only by the Military, however, now they time that were time and effort savers were released for use by all ** ade work easier for people were invented and used, and improved, and enlarged. People whose parents had reasoned that since the country was in recession they would do without things discovered that they had raised children who thought very differently. Before World War II there were great numbers of citizens who did not yet have electricity in their homes. There were still families who had no access to telephones unless they went to a neighbor’s house. Small businesses still used ink and ledger books to keep track of their transactions. Now suddenly there were new inventions that had saved time, energy, and effort that had been used solely by the government or by the military. Now these devices began to pop up for use everywhere—in medicine, in machinery, in improvements of household chores, and families began to buy refrigerators to replace ice boxes. Gas or electric kitchen stoves were being bought, instead of smoking kerosene or wood stoves. Telephones for both business and home use were now available, and people had them installed. Items that had been scarce were now plentiful, and affordable. Businesses which had made materials useful to the armed services found new and eager buyers for their products. Clothing styles changed, The styles of clothing began to change when only war materials could sometimes merely , and then there were telephones were home telephones now available,re were lots of other devices. Some devices such as radios and telephones were not actually new, but more towns they were now Telephones, radios, record players, cooking stoves, floor cleaners, automatic dish washers, and other devices, most of which took only the punch of a button or the movement of a leaver to go into operation to solve one of life’s small aggravations. There were and the new sorts of machines available—such as a device that other home furnaces in homes, in transportation, and in entertainment. The devastation that was the result of the war in Europe and the Pacific had not touched the United States. Europe and Eastern countries had been devastated by the destruction of caused by bombs and the loss of lives during the conflict. Though America did not suffer all of the losses of Africa, Europe, Japan or the Islands of the Pacific, there were losses that no relief could alter: the loss of the lives of the brave young men and women who did not return from their service in military. the armed services. could never bethe loss of young and promising men and women, our homes were not destroyed nor our cities leveled by bombs. Our loss was in the lives of those young men and women who were killed in action. Our homes were not destroyed by bombs, our cities were not devastated, and we did not need to rebuild our factories or replace our streets, nor was it required that we rebuild and refurnish our homes. We were not compelled to re-invent our government, nor submit to demands of foreign governments. Our losses were mostly in the category of people—young men and women who were now gone forever, and the costs of weapons and the wages and upkeep of the armed services and but of course we some of whom left no children, and had not had time to add their ideas and inventions or their particular dreams to the future. This was the greatest lost for our country. In Europe their cities had been destroyed, and many of their promising youth perished in the conflicts. Their cities had been bombed and their infrastructure destroyed. Water sources and sources of electricity were destroyed. The devastation of their cities was not the largest problem, though it took years to rebuild. Their governments had been destroyed as well, and in many countries no one was really in charge until the victors arrived to take that responsibility. The cities where government had once ruled were often damaged or destroyed. It would take not only time, but huge amounts of money to repair the damage of the war, and replace the streets, the electricity system, the water system, transportation, and such things as post offices, hospitals, police. France, Germany, Italy, and England had been torn and ravaged by the war. Like the United States, many of the strong young men and women who fought their battles did not come home. **young men and women had been killed or wounded in many cities homes had been destroyed and sewage systems electricity, and clean-up of destroyed buildings and homes. ad been bombed and homes destructed, and many of their young and the strong had perished in battles, while most of America had suffered only from the loss of soldiers. The money spent on new inventions was no earning .

for inventors and . The small gold stars that were hung in the windows of homes which would never see their soldier again began to disappear as Peace lengthened. The economy was growing, medicines helped to bring sick people back into health, automobiles were being manufactured again for civilian use, telephones were being installed in every house, clothing was available in stores, and shoes were no longer rationed. Food was plentiful, and marvelous new THINGS were being offered in markets all over the country—things like electric typewriters, and newly designed radios, electric record players, along with sturdy new records that brought music into houses. Civilians could buy automobiles again. Food was plentiful. The instruments that had guided ships and airplanes could be used for peaceful enjoyments, so that television was invented and travel was much easier whether your journey was across town or across the world. One of the most marvelous new inventions was penicillin which could cure illnesses. But the practice of medicine had grown astronomically, offering cures and procedures that had never before been available. and booming, new ideas and new inventions and newly developed medicines were available making health care disappeared, but the grief did not go awayere gold star Peace did not at first seem to make up for those hardships, especially when the horrors of war were people a lot of people who had not really recovered from the depression. There was very little to spend on frivolities, not only people who might be called “poor,” but for people The working man or woman had little money to use on frivolities.**** Radio’s were wonderful. In those days there were many people who had very little money. The radio was the source of most breaking war news. Small radios were purchased and turned on especially at the hours that news of the war was broadcast. I can remember that I actually shivered sometimes when I heard a man named Edward R. Murrow broadcast news from London. He always began by saying: “This (small pause) is London.” The German air planes were bombing London and other targets in England. Most of the news in the early days of the war was bad. It became quite terrifying when the United States entered the war. I had seen enough news reels from Europe to realize that civilians were not safe, and though my parents tried to tell me that Charlotte was not going to be bombed, I was skeptical because our school had asked it’s students to distribute letters in our neighborhoods that asked if we, or any of our neighbors, would be willing to take in children living on or near the Atlantic coast if—and that if was a frightening word—if our enemies began to bomb the cities and towns on the coast, especially where there were ship building facilities, or naval bases. The printed notice also asked families to indicate the number of children who would be welcome in their homes. When I saw that note I knew we were already crowded. There were four of us, and we lived in three rooms. We had two beds—one for Mother and Daddy, and one for me and my sister. I took my paper back to school with a note that we could take six children into our home if the need should arise. I asked her where they would sleep, and she said, “We will find a way!” She meant it, too. We had a divan (a couch) that would make a bed for two, and my mother had quilts to make pallets. Had children been compelled to vacate their homes on the coast my mother would have found a way to care for, feed, and bed down those children as if they were her own.

The only other real information about the war in both the Pacific and in Europe, since television was still only a dream in someone’s head, was from the radio. There were two stations in Charlotte, but there were reporters who were scattered all over the world who reported by radio from places over the seas. We could hear them on our radio in Charlotte. The nightly news was sacred, and no one spoke aloud during the short minutes of over-sea reports. One that we tried never to miss was the broadcast of Edward R. Murrow who was stationed in England. London was suffering a daily and nightly bombardment on London and other locations in England. German bombers flew over England destroying buildings, factories and homes, and sometimes bombs were aimed at landmarks that had stood for over a hundred years, destroying churches and famous landmarks in London and other cities.
