Mr. Murrow opened his report on international radio with three words: “This,” he said, in a proud and loyal, and extremely brave tone, “is London!” Then he would give his report of the damages done to London to the people of the United States.

My Dad had bought a radio as a family “Christmas Present” the year before the war began. We listened to reports in our kitchen, because that room was warm from the cooking fire. We burned coal in our heater, and kerosene in our cooking stove. The radio was placed on the kitchen table so we could all listen to the news. We had also been asked to conserve electricity, as well as fuel used to produce warmth for the winter. During most of the war we sort of lived in the kitchen, especially in the winter. We used electricity only when we needed it, and if we left a room, we clicked off the light, even if we planed to return in a few minutes. Within a few months there were civic “drills” to make sure the city could be blacked out to avoid the genuine possibility that enemy bombers could attack and accurately bomb and devastate Charlotte.

Because of the needs of the armed forces and factories that made war materials, both coal and oil became scarce. Petroleum products were rationed for automobiles, and neighbors began to form car pools and to use the bus system to reach their jobs. Every part of our lives were changed because our country was at war. There were shortages of everything.

Ration books with stamps were issued for every person in the country. Even small children had ration books allowing the purchase of foods in precise portions. The purchase of shoes required ration stamps. If a child grew out of his shoes before the allotted time for new ones it was just too bad. Gasoline was paid for by the gallon, and measured out at the pump—but you had better have the right number of ration stamps along with the price of the gas. ee, and all other foods that were imported were scarce, and sometimes difficult to find. Meat was scarce, and vegetables or other foods that were not grown in North Carolina were expensive since shipping was now more restricted because of the shortage of gasoline for transport, and the shortages caused because the military had first dibs on food, and other items needed by soldiers. shipped , and in another booklet there were Food stamps for meats, coffee, and sugar, and other items that had to be brought in by boat. Fresh vegetables were usually procured from local farmers—but foods that grew in distant places were not easy to find. Clothing that ordinarily came from overseas or had to be shipped across the country were available less often. Leather shoes were hard to get because most shoe makers were making boots for soldiers, and manufacturers of clothing were making uniforms and other necessary products for soldiers, sailors and airmen. Some items were scarce simply because the Armed Forces had first dibs—on foods, and on clothing, and automobiles, and trucks, and airplanes, and the ability to ship items from here to there. Mills stopped making pretty patterned cottons for spring dress and made uniforms, boots, coats, and bedding for soldiers. Shoes were hard to find in stores because soldiers needed boots. New cars could not be bought because the army needed Jeeps and trucks and tanks and submarines as well as boats and airplanes. New training bases were built, and because battles began immediately there was a huge need for military hospitals.
There is one occasion that I remember vividly, but it needs a little bit of “setting up the scene” before it makes sense today. Once upon a time—way back in the late 1920’s and early 1930’s there was a problem in the United States. Not all, but many of the banks failed—that is they went broke. They could not return invested monies to those who had banked their savings for safe keeping. Businesses couldn’t get bank money to pay workers, and workers couldn’t pay rent, and families couldn’t buy groceries or visit doctors because they couldn’t pay for food or medications. Homes financed through banks were lost, salaries could not be paid by the businesses which couldn’t get their own money out of banks, and everybody was broke. Everybody was desperate. People who couldn’t pay their workers had to dismiss them. Businesses failed, banks failed, homes were lost, foreclosures were made, and there were very few people who were not affected by the disaster.

was broke because the banks went broke. rent for their went broke. Doctors couldn’t be paid People had no jobs, the banks could neither lend or refund invested monies, and so things were in a royal mess. left most people without jobs, money, or hope. Jobs were scarce. Groceries and needed clothing could not be paid for, and people with debts were delinquent because they had neither jobs nor money. People were turned out of their room for failure to pay rent, and ebts were was a problem in America. Our national government recognized that problem, and made a decision that liquor and were problems drunkards caused terrible troubles. They couldn’t hold a job, they beat their children and helpless wives, fought café waiters who refuled to sell them any more. Most couldn’t keep a job, beat each other, their wives, and their children. They could not hold a job, drove cars into terrible wrecks, and generally played havoc wherever they were or whatever they were doing.
J No jobs, beating each other and helpless wives, children, and uninvolved persons simply because they were present when a drunkard went ballistic. Drunkards were driving cars, wandering in front of train engines, beating their wives and children, beating the owners of cafés who refused to sell more beer because of the drunkard’s condition, and demanding free liquor at gun point while drunk. It was epidemic. The federal government decided that America didn’t need all those drunks, and they banned the making of wine and beer. Of course that didn’t stop people who really wanted it. It was bootlegged, stolen, made at home, and brought in from places where it was legal. The bootleggers didn’t really go out of business—they just got more secretive. They made wine and alcoholic drinks and sold them because the use of whiskey, beer, and wines so frequently had caused countless wrecks, fights, accidents, beatings, and other ugly things, like murd When the war began it was illegal** —as I was an eye witness—the day a soldier beat up the manager of our grocery store, and then opened his storage room, picked up a sack of sugar, dropped the correct amount of money and the coupon on the check-out counter, and left before the policemen who were summoned by telephone could arrive. Later the police visited the young soldier, but they didn’t arrest him—as the manager had hoarded—meaning he had not planned to sell the sugar to ordinary customers. He planned to sell the sugar it to bootleggers to make beer and wine. Sugar was not only scarce, but stores were to collect ration stamps as well as the cost of sugar when it was sold. That manager was going to sell all his sugar to bootleggers so they could make liquor or beer out of it. In those days it was against federal to sell alcoholic beverages. This was a national law, because in the 1920’s drunkenness was spreading like wildfire, wrecking marriages and harming children who’s father could not support the family because he was a drunk. to prevent our entire population from being turned into a bunch of drunks. to sell for a lot of money to bootleggers because Sugar was scarce, and foods that require sugar eventually became scarce, too.

During the winter we built fires in We still slept in our bedrooms, but we “lived” in only the kitchen in the winter, to diminish our use of coal, oil, and electricity. We needed fires for warmth, but we would go to bed early and listen to the radio or read a book, so we wouldn’t have to “waste” our coal or kerosene when it was not necessary. in the winter, however, both coal and oil became scarce. The Christmas before that December ere on the battle lines, and they spoke from their locations, and some were able to film battles or events during battles that could be shown in movie theaters, bringing first hand information to theaters. When I saw Jewish children and their parents being crowded into Germany’s prisons, I wept. The results of German bombing of England was also filmed, and there were moving pictures of battles on islands in the Pacific with names which I had not heard before, and I would weep when I saw the fighting, and I prayed for the soldiers. I only a little girl and I didn’t really understand the war or the reason for it. I wept when my neighbor’s only son who was in the Air Force that I had never be which showed news reels of the bombing in England, and occasional pictures taken on the battle fields of Europe, North Africa, and the Pacific Islands. The War news was usually shown before the film of the latest Hollywood offering. Fairly early in the conflict “war movies” began to show up about enlisted men and battles and dare-devils who saved the day, and improbable replays of things that had really happened. By 1942 I was old enough to go to the movies by myself or with school mates. There was one movie that had no war theme. It was the Wizard of Oz, and my mother let me go see it at the Carolina Theatre one afternoon. I liked it so well I stayed in my seat and saw it twice. When I came out of the theatre my mother was leaning against the wall—she had waited for me through that whole extra movie, because it was dark and she didn’t want me to walk home alone.

learning either as a volunteer at a local hospital during World War II, or at a job by the time I was old enough to take typing lessons, which I did in ninth grade. I also took lessons in shorthand, which was a method of writing symb Most of the girls who took typing also learned shorthand (, and studied business math. and—a way for secretaries to keep up with dictation by using symbols instead of the actual alphabet to write words. I started to school when I was six—in the year 1937. Those were years in which, in the city of Charlotte, almost all children walked to school. unless they road school buses. Most schools were built in neighborhoods where parents of young children were likely to live. Schools were built in communities where families lived. Schools where grades one through six were taught were called primary schools. I knew of only one school taught that I am sure of that taught only grades seven through nine, and that was called a “middle” school. Most of the schools therefore, in Charlotte, there were few if any school buses. School was quite different from in those days than it is now. Higher education—such as college—was often too expensive for most families. It was not until the end of World War II that there great emphasis was placed in college educations. Most colleges of pre-war were young people who were eager for college educations, and those who had served in any of the services were offered aid to achieve diplomas. Another wonderful thing that cropped up about that time was night schools that offered college classes, especially to men and women who served in the military during the war, at tuitions that were manageable, and classes that were taught in the evening as well as daytime classes, which meant that the students could work during the day, and study one or two subjects each evening.

he GI Bill which offered aid to men and women who served in the armed forces to complete college educations

When World War II began Paw-paw was certain—without doubt—that as soon as he graduated he would go into the military. That was happening all over America with every young man who was nearly 18 years old. Women were not required to enlist though many of them did. They were generally posted where they could serve behind a desk, and not often in areas where real battles would be fought.

Young men were subject to the draft soon after they became eighteen years of age. If they were still in high school they wouldn’t be called to enlist until they graduated. Many young men who knew they had no choice in the matter, and had an interest in a particular branch of service had a The tough battles in the European Theater had, for the most part, been won, but the Pacific war was far from over. Though at the time he reported for duty the battle in Europe was close to being won, the Pacific was still a deadly, active and aggressive war area, with Japan still dropping bombs on Islands, shooting down American airplanes, and engaging American soldiers into face to face fighting on some of the Pacific islands. Instead of learning how to type in high school, Paw-paw went into the Army Air Force.

Basic training was a process that forever changed the lives of most of the young men and women who entered the armed services during World War II—both men and women who served will tell you that joining on their own or being “called” to service and immediately “taught” how to be a soldier was often rough, ugly, impatient, and run by rough talking unsympathetic sergeants, many of whom seemed to have hearts and minds made of ugly concrete, especially during the early enlistments. Those who had to teach (train) all the inexperienced young men and women how to obey whether or not they wanted to obey, and to do whatever task they were given, no matter how sore their muscles were, or how brutal the task, or how dangerous it might be. One of the things they had to do was to make sure the men and women in the army didn’t think for themselves—but simply followed orders, and were particularly careful to do so, even if they were in danger from the enemy.

One college schoolmate of mine told me that when she finally had her first leave she rode the bus into a town, and then stood on a corner, staring at the bustle around her, without a single thought of what she would do next. For long weeks of training she had been told what to do, and how to do it, and on that street corner there was no one to order her to do anything. She found she no longer knew how to make decisions for herself. But this was war, with no time to waste on niceties. The enemy soldiers were already marching across borders in Europe and in China and on the islands of the sea near Japan. During a war soldiers are always in harms way. Whether or not they want to fight, they do it—they shoot, or drop bombs, or sink ships, and they obey orders. In 1942 the government simply needed able bodies—and they drafted men from every state. Some were single, fresh from high school graduation, and others were college students or working men who left jobs and families to serve in the armed services. Many enlisted immediately because Pearl Harbor was bombed by Japan. Others registered because they were required to do so, and were notified to report for duty. From every corner of the country—men who were both young and single enlisted, but mature men, married, or single, with or without children, wise or dumb, familiar with fire arms or never having touched one before—were called to report to the nearest Army Training Post. It mattered not whether the men were eager, or just willing to serve, nor did it matter if they were unwilling to serve. When the draft notification arrived it was not like the invitation to a picnic—it was a summons, and failure to appear at the appointed time could have serious consequences such as imprisonment. The number of soldiers ready for active duty increased as training progressed. However, the draft continued for the duration of the hostilities. Young men who were at least eighteen and in good health were required to register for the draft. Enlisted men who had fought actual battles were sent home as quickly as possible. Those who were not on the front lines were utilized for replacements for soldiers who had served outside the United States. over-seas who were being sent home. ement soldiersthose who registered were called to service. Some young men had medical problems that excused them from service, with a military grade of Four-F which meant that the military didn’t want that person because of that applicant’s lack of health or clear vision. Soldiers, sailors, or airmen were in good health with sound minds—it didn’t matter whether or not they wanted to enlist. Enlistment was a requirement which, if neglected, had serious consequences—like jail time. Boys of sixteen and some who were a bit younger were allowed to enlist with parental agreement, or less often, the agreement of their parole officer. . Most of the very young who were accepted into military training had non-existant homes—that is—they were delinquent or without family or headed for disaster because of situations they were helpleshome situations that were leading to were not promising because of circumstances they could not change were often allowed to in life were sad or non-existent for some reason, could enlist with parental agreement, and begin a totally different sort of life wething as ordinary as bad vision without spectacles could result in a make a man have littlee age of eighteen were expected to enlistrose quickly, the army was made up of people, and though there were a few “bad apples” in every crowd the enlisted men did a wonderful, brave job, and there were a great number of mostly young men who lost their lives doing their brave job though for a great number of men it cost them their lives. There was a larger number of young soldiers who returned home to take up their interrupted plans for life; however, they also discovered their outlook had changed by their experiences and training, and their aims and confidence in achieving was also different. They had left home as youths, but returned as adults with a plan and the perseverance to make it happen. Returning soldiers who needed training to get a well-paying job were eager to make use of higher education offered by what was called the GI Bill, which offered help with tuition for college educations. Colleges were crowded. Many of the larger cities had community colleges—schools that offered evening classes as well as daytime classes to accommodate those who worked during the day and studied at night. Trained people were needed in most jobs because the war had brought wonderful new ideas and new tools (new knowledge, new inventions), and a “boom” occurred during and after the war itself. Women had worked in factories, replacing men who were drafted into the military, and now there were quite wonderful machines to use in farming, in hauling materials from factories to markets, airplanes offered a new way to move about the world. New inventions and new processes that were useful in the war could be used for civilian needs.
8888888888888888 , such a microwave cooking, could be manufactured and used all over the nation—not just in on a military base. education Most of them made use of the education and schooling that the GI Bill offered. Some young men and women didn’t change much, and were still like their younger selves, but now they had goals, and reached them.

I was far too young (about ten years old) when the war began, to realize what the word “war” meant. Of course, as events occurred, I learned that men and women who went to war did not always return. The families of young men who entered any of the services placed little flags of blue and white with a star in the center. This indicated that a member of that family had gone to war. When the soldier was lost in action the family would replace the blue and white flag with a gold star. The family home directly across the street from our house placed a gold flag in their window when their son’s plane went down over France.

In the United States there were shortages of gasoline, food, automobiles, and coal during the years of World War II. Everyone had a “ration book,” even children. Scarce items could be bought—canned food, meats, shoes, some clothing, only if you had ration coupons. Women could no longer expect to find silk stockings (from China) to be available. Another item that was scarce was sugar (from Cuba). Meat for the table became not only expensive, it was often unavailable. Suddenly there were no new automobiles—the factories were making military vehicles. There were few new shoes—the shoemakers were making military boots. Doctors and nurses left their “safe” offices in towns and cities to be close to soldiers wounded in battles. Most citizens were glad they were where they could help wounded soldiers—but the parents of babies or young children were appalled because doctors were suddenly in short supply as they too went to war. Near the battlefields of Europe or on Pacific Islands or naval vessels the doctors and nurses set up hospitals near battlegrounds to care for the wounded and dieing, usually very close to the fighting. The sacrifices made by the doctors and nurses who served so close to the battle areas was not only unselfish, but placed them in unsafe areas. Within the United States their departure from the hospitals at home left some areas of the country extremely short of competent physicians—a hardship for everyone. Gasoline—then as now mostly coming from the Eastern part of the planet—was rationed, reducing the ability to drive automobiles. The “carpool” was invented of necessity. People walked to work if possible, or rode busses or streetcars; however if there was no public transportation, neighbors “car pooled” which meant that they took turns driving, and neighbors rode to work, taking turns being the chauffeur of the neighborhood. Those who had no car walked or rode a bus.

All items that came in on trains or trucks were at times difficult to find in stores. There were fewer goods in the major department stores. In grocery stores there was some lack of fresh foods, particularly meats. The very scarcity of food made prices rise. Because railroads and truck traffic was being heavily used by the armed services even transportation of civilian goods was often sparse. Manufactured goods such as clothing, shoes, and furniture were difficult to find. One small point was the silk stockings from China that almost all women wore as their “best” garb. During the war they were extremely scarce or non existent. Rayon stockings were not endeared by most women for they would bag around their ankles, and the seam that should be straight on the back of their legs would shift into crookedness. One of the greatest boons when the war ended was that a new kind of fabric, called nylon, had been invented to make parachutes for the soldiers. It was only after the war that the material could be for used for stockings==thus the nylon hosery was born. they could be used for stockings. There were no new automobiles for civilians, but if there had been, there was no gas to run them because gas was very scarce, and rationed. Auto owners had to surrender coupons in order to buy gas. No coupons—no gas.

My Dad had access to fuel stamps because our home was in Charlotte, though his jobs were often on the coast, and also because most painting contractors did not have the very special equipment to paint the tanks—which my Dad “invented” in order to paint the tanks. He and the men who worked for him usually found a rooming house—a house which furnished a bed and meals—near his jobs in the distant towns where he worked. He and his helpers worked long hours, and had few days off—often working even on Sunday. Some years before the war began workers in coal mines and other large industries began to form unions, and threatened to simply stop coming to work to force owners of the industries to offer safer work places, and decent wages. The United States government had laid down rules meant to protect workers from being obliged to work for ten or twelve long hours without increased pay—rules that did not exist when mills and other modern manufacturers first appeared. When cotton mills were first built children as young as five years old worked for ten of twelve hours for six days a week sweeping the floors of the mills. I know this is true because one of my Daddy’s cousins, only about fourteen years old, married a ten year old girl who had worked in a mill since she was five. He gallantly married her at the age of ten, and I met that couple myself when they visited my grandmother a week or so after celebrating their fortieth wedding anniversary.

My Daddy, born in 1896, saw great changes in our nation and in industries. He saw the growth of the use of automobiles rather than horse drawn conveyances, and he saw train tracks laid down and the huge engines that pulled the trains, he saw roads improved and paved, and he was aware that airplanes were being built and flown. He became an automobile mechanic before he learned to drive a car. He, with the help of his father and uncle bought rental houses so that the family could receive the rent money to help his parents, his brother, and two sisters. My grandmother was in fragile health and was blind, and during my childhood I saw the strength of my grandfather dwindle and fade until he could no longer work his fields. Uncle Eddie, my father’s only brother, suffered an injury as a youth, and was not strong, but was the only one to work the farm, as his two sisters were also frail. They owned their farm, kept chickens, cows, and a mule. Uncle Eddie did the plowing with a mule, milked the cows, chopped the wood for the stove, and brought in the buckets of water from the well. His sisters fed the chickens and picked up the eggs, kept the house, prepared the meals, and nursed their mother (my grandmother, who was blind and bed-ridden).

That was an era of the growing mechanization of our culture—with trains, automobiles, airplanes, the beginning of automobiles, the spread in the early years of modern manufacturing required ten or more hours each day for very little pay. Long hours were allowed during the war, but only if they were paid for—because people were willing to work in order to bring the soldiers from their own families home from the war.

Daddy came home only if he needed supplies available only in Charlotte. Daddy designed his special equipment himself, and it worked well for him. Of course he had a “crew” who had also worked for him when he was a house painter. . and which, without frequent painting, would rust, and spew petroleum products out on the ground. Leaks not only wasted the product, but were unsafe—risking huge fires. The use for automobiles for simply driving one person to work was not a wise use of oil. Therefo ree pleasure such as vacations was

The demand for petroleum products was so great, and its sources mostly in northern Africa difficult to transport because of its vulnerability to submarine attacks made petroleum , and would make the area around it extremely flammable in areas so that they would not rust, spring a leak, and thereby waste gasoline. He invented a contraption that could go around and around the tanks, and up and down from top to bottom so that the tanks could be painted quickly and thoroughly to protect them from the weather. My Daddy engineered his own tackle and boards to reach all *Many of the “tank farms” were on the coast, available to tank ships from northern Africa. Unpainted they were subject to leaks, and the waste of gasoline. Raw fuel splashing into the air and covering the ground were fire hazards. Daddy painted tanks in Charlotte, of course, but he also would spend weeks on the coast where sea-going tankers would deliver gasoline, or in other towns where fuel oil was stored. A military base was built from the ground up in a city east of Charlotte, and Daddy painted those new barracks there—it was called Camp Butler.

My sister, Ella Cornelia, was in high school. She took a special course at our local hospital, and then worked as a nurse’s aid in local hospitals because so many nurses had joined doctors and other medical personnel on ships and near battlefields to give quick and effective help to wounded soldiers. However, hospitals at home in the United States sometimes were without enough trained nurses because so many nurses had volunteered to serve overseas, or in military hospitals elsewhere.

The war did come to a close. And nurses came home when the casualties diminished.

but at Queens College I met a number of men and women who had been in the Armed Services during the war and who were now taking classes at Queens College under the GI Bill at the same time I was there. A few of the students who were enrolled while I was there were women who had also served during the war. One or two had served overseas as Army nurses, and several had been in the Women’s Army or Navy. All of these young women were eligible for assistance with their additional education, and made use of that help by enrolling in classes at Queens and many other colleges all over the country.

When I was fifteen—or maybe sixteen—I learned after the end of World War II that during the War in Europe German soldiers were captured, and there were no handy American prisons in war-torn Europe to confine the captured warriors. They were usually kept in Stockades as far away from the battlefields as they could send them. It was an awkward situation, and the American government sometimes transferred the captured soldiers to the United States and loaned them out to farmers or factories, giving them jobs to occupy their time, and providing only food and shelter in exchange for their work, plus a very small stipend for cigarettes and toiletries. In those days there was a lot of land in North Carolina used to grow both vegetables and grains and food animals for people—and many farmers were shorthanded because so many young men were in the armed forces. In some areas the captured German soldier “farmers” were assigned to farm work, and had to be guarded to prevent their escape and prevent their causing any action that would hinder the war efforts. My sister, Ella Cornelia, married one of the guards that watched over captured German soldiers. Of course, when the war ended the German soldiers were allowed to return home.

Ella Cornelia met Harry at the home of Rusty and Margaret, who had a farm almost within the City of Charlotte. The story of their farm home was important in our lives.

Long after the German Soldiers who had been placed on a farm in Charlotte were allowed to return to Germany, the Army Sergeant who had guarded them while they worked on Rusty’s farm had become a firm friend of Rusty and his family. The Sergeant was, by that time, stationed in Pennsylvania, since the war was over. In the late summer of that year Sergeant Harry came back to Charlotte to visit Rusty and his family. And thereby hangs another tale, and another story. To tell it, I must digress a bit.

During the World War II My family, (Mother, Daddy, Sister, Me) had attended a small church for some years, and Rusty and his family discovered our little church, and began to attend there, too. Rusty had a nice voice, and joined the choir; however, he did not read music, and he needed extra practice to learn the base notes of the music. Since both Ella Cornelia and I were in the choir, we invited Rusty and his wife and son to our house for a meal, and as the evening progressed, spent a little time at the piano teaching Rusty the base notes of next Sunday’s music. It worked so well, and we liked the company of the young family, and set up a regular practice every Friday night at our house. My mother and Daddy enjoyed it, too, and sometimes sang as we practiced, though they did not join the choir.

My sister and I had sung together for years, practicing mostly to sing to our blind grandmother who could no longer go to church. Our everyday chore of washing dishes at our house was boring, so we passed the time by practicing hymns in two part harmony to sing to our grandmother, and learning popular songs from the radio, too. It made the work pass quicker if we concentrated on the music. We usually had a hymn book handy, and we learned as many songs as we could, she singing soprano, and me singing alto.

Another short digression: Shortly before World War II began a new church was born on Monroe Road. It was started in a partially finished building just because an old woman wanted a Methodist Church near her house—and she had a large, three going on four generation family. There were some neighbors and a number of friends who shared her vision. I never met the lady, as she died before my family joined that church, but I knew her son and daughter-in-law, their children, and their grandchildren as well. Because of the Grandmother’s insistence, a church was born. Of course it wasn’t easy. The building was not finished well enough to serve as a meeting place, but the Waddell family helped the Great Grandmother who asked a retired Preacher to serve as the first pastor. They had prayer meetings as a beginning. Somehow floors were built, windows were installed at frequent intervals along the side walls, a platform was built, complete with pulpit, and behind the pulpit was space for a choir. Ceiling lights were was a piano, and soon the men of the church gathered to unload a piano someone had donated. before Sunday someone had donated a piano. the call to gather in sanctuary for several days as someone bought a bunch of seats from a defunct movie house. These were rows of attached chair backs complete with armrests and seats. The seats themselves could be pushed upright to allow more room for audiences to move in and out of the rows of chairs—just like a movie theatre. Because they were discards the cushions were of different colors, and were dirty and torn, however, the handy efforts of the women of the church who stretched new brown fabric hung, and the ladies of the church gathered together to clean, paint, and re-cover chairs that had once served in a now defunct movie theatre, Once the chairs were in place all that was lacking over the refurbished cushions and repainted the wooden backs of the seats, making them comfortable, clean, and new looking, the building looked more like the inside of a church everyday. Someone donated a piano, and someone else agreed to play that piano. Other people agreed to teach Sunday school, and a new church, called St. Johns Methodist Church was born, dedicated, and began to grow. Members who could sing made a small choir. A young preacher who had Graduated from College that June was appointed to the pulpit, and St. John’s Methodist Church was no longer just the dream of an old lady, but a new and growing church in a quiet neighborhood on Monroe Road. Very soon an addition was made to the church itself, and a Sunday School was born. , with a Sunday School, a small choir, a pianist, a preacher, and a growing congregation. There were two girls, sisters, who sang in the choir. would do “special music” from time to time. Their names were Ella Cornelia and Jean Yandle. ing class of that year from The Methodist Church and student at a Methodist theocollege who planned to be a minister agreed to pastor the church. a The ladies of the church found a leather-like material to cover the cushions, and matching paint to brush onto the wooden backs. Once fastened onto the floor they were as good as new, and made clean and comfortable seats. Someone had a piano in good condition that would fit into the choir loft. The retired minister who had agreed to hold the first few meetings continued to hold services until the Methodist Church assigned a newly graduated young man to this new pulpit. And so Saint John’s Methodist Church was born.

uest ministers send an appointed preacher Methodist Then one day someone so an auditorium was born. to be down the row with comfort—just like a movie theater. moveable seatswith backs that were for a pulpitfound a retired preacher to floored, windowed, electrified, painted inside and out. A retired preacher was talked into serving a short term as pastor, and someone bought a bunch of theater seats that had come out of defunct movie house. TIt was eventually named St. John’s Methodist, but it started as a non-denominational church in a ramshackle building that already stood beside Monroe Road, which had, I think, been built to protect building supplies and other construction materials. The building was constructed for usefulness—not for either beauty or convenience. There was no electricity, no running water, and no method for either heating or cooling the interior. I’m not even sure it had complete flooring to begin with, but it had walls and a roof. The building was longer than it was wide, and it had never been painted.

T. had a wood floor, lots of openings along both sides, and that it was longer than it was wide. I don’t know why it was first built, but I do know that it was quite long, and suitably wide, with winbut no running water, and not much in the way of electricity. It had a roof and walls. The old lady’s son was a builder, but he had a large family and no extra money to build his mother a church. So they made the best of things. The first few meetings were held there, and soon they were able to repair some things and put in chairs. There was no money for benches; however an old movie house was refurbishing their chairs—the same design as the ones in theaters today—but these needed reupholstering. So the women in the church bought brown plastic material and replaced the old covers on the theater chairs and the church had seats. That first summer it did not have water, nor a great many light fixtures, but eventually they had a wooden floor and a large stove in the middle of the sanctuary, as winter was on its way. Someone gave a piano, and someone built a pulpit, and an altar rail.

S omeone built a podium and acquired a pulpit, and fashioned a small choir loft. Someone donated a piano, and a bunch of people found a movie theater that was replacing its chairs—the kind that shares arm rests, just like the auditorium seats today. The women of the church put new covers on the seats, and People from the neighborhood came to worship there. In the beginning it was a small group. However the homes in the neighborhood supported the church, and many neighbors joined together to get things started. Of course they invited their friends and families.

I

My Dad was a painting contractor, and he had painted some of the buildings Mr. Waddell’s company had erected. He learned about the church on Monroe Road, and one Sunday we all went to worship there. jobs. family practiced several different songs nearly every week to sing to her. Ella Cornelia also was in a church choir every Sunday morning.

Because my sister, Ella CorneliaRusty and his family had been friends of my family for several months, and because Rusty had a barn full of milk cows that he milked with machines, She met him when the farmer who ran his farm with German labor brought him to church along with his

IN the wrong place******

There was a young family farming on rented land very close to where the first coliseum was built on Independence Boulevard. Actually the farm was there long before the Coliseum was built, and Rusty, Margaret, and their small son lived on that farm, and raised beef cattle and sold milk from their fifteen or twenty cows. They also raised pigs, and planted fields of food for the cattle and the pigs. In a small field near their house they also had a garden for food for their own table. They grew tomatoes and beans and squash and other vegetables. The young family worshiped at a Methodist Church that was

, and it was what farmers didSince Charlotte was surrounded by areas where they were sent to the United States and placed on farms or in factories doing jobs that, in peacetime, had been done by the soldiers who were overseas fighting the war. Therefore, the farms that needed workers could have German soldiers to do the work.

and placed on farms with nominal guards. Many American farmers had gone to war, too, causing food and labor shortages. I don’t know how candidates were chosen, but captured German soldiers were sometimes assigned to farms in the United States, and usually there were American soldiers who were the guards who made sure they did what they were told. I know about this because Usually there was a member of the United States Army who made sure the German men stayed where they were placed, and worked as they had been told to do. One of the American soldiers who became such an overseer for captives was named Harry May. He had placed German helpers on a small dairy farm just outside of Charlotte, North Carolina. Rusty and his wife, Margaret, and their small son could do more with their fields if there was help, so German prisoners of war lived and worked on his farm. Sergeant May was the overseer.

It seems that Rusty was also a member of a small church in Charlotte, where he and his wife worshiped every Sunday, and where their small son attended Sunday school. Rusty had a wonderful bass voice, and made friends with a couple of young people who also sang in the choir. Their names were Ella Cornelia and Jean Yandle, daughters of Leroy, and Minnie. The Yandle girls sang in the choir, and so did Rusty. Friendships were made, and Jean and Ella were agreed to help Rusty, who didn’t read music, learn the bass parts of the special music the choir sang each Sunday. Therefore Rusty and his wife and child were invited to dinner on Friday evenings with a special sort of private choir practice afterwards. It was fun, and greatly enhanced the rendition of the music on Sunday Morning. Friendships were formed of course. Over several months friendships grew deeper, and then the war ended, and the German farmers were allowed to go home. Nevertheless, Sergeant May still came to see Rusty and Margaret.

Thereby develops another part of the story of our family’s life. Because Sergeant May had to oversee the German workers, he often visited Rusty and Margaret, even after the German prisoners were released. On one of those days, a teenage girl had agreed to help with the farm work during school vacation. She was there when Sergeant May came. Because it was one of the nights Rusty and his family usually visited the Yandle home. It was usual, too, that Rusty and Ella Cornelia and Jean had a short lesson on the music to be sung in Church on Sunday.

ty, his wife, and small son lived just outside Charlotte, and raised cattle and corn, and wheat, and

and that left their fields, badly needed to grow food in the United Statesin Europe was near it’s end, German prisoner’s of war were being returned from the U.S. to their own homeland. As for American soldiers, Congress had offered them education, after their enlistment. As soldiers returned home they were able to enter colleges and a great many of them took advantage of the opportunity. When I went to college at Queens in Charlotte, there were several young men who were day students (not living on campus) who were taking classes at Queens. The GI Bill was in action, and many of the students at Queens had taken advantage of the government’s offer to help returning soldiers by offering to pay a part of the cost of their tuition. About that time Queens College, previously an “all girl” school, began taking day students (meaning they didn’t have dormitory rooms on the college property). One of the students who was a “day” student, as I was, had been in the Women’s Army Corp (WAC). Men could also enroll as day students, and many returned servicemen did precisely that. I often sat and talked with the former WAC who was using the GI Bill (a law that offered education to men and women who had served in the Military). That young woman and I talked a good bit. She told me that she had been a WAC during the war. I asked her about her service, and about her courses at Queens. She told me that her army experience was, at first, the most terrible experience of her life. Apparently these young women had to be taught not to think—but to follow orders. She told me that her trainers had insisted she not think—just obey. The process was brutal, and she literally forgot how to be herself. Soldiers were needed so badly on the battle lines that they had to learn to advance against bullets—whether or not they thought it would be safe.
On her first leave she went into a nearby town, and discovered she was shivering. Obedience to orders had ruled her days, her hours, and her minutes, since her enlistment. The need to obey and not “think” and been so ruggedly taught that when she stood alone on a city street she felt abandoned, and actually frightened. Bereft of orders, she was alone and lost. Actually that experience was the beginning of her “comeback” to having confidence in herself.

Parents could not prevent their eighteen year old children being sent away from home and into a war. Most folks accepted it as fact that it had to be done. Many of the fathers and uncles or even grandparents of the young draftees had fought in World War I, and knew what it would be like.

In the First World War the loss of life was tremendous. The people in our country knew that the casualty rate would be high—death or loss of limbs was very possible for foot soldiers. Families who had a son, daughter, husband or father in service often put a small flag in their front window that indicated a soldier, sailor, marine, or airman from their family was in service and in danger. The Houser family across the street from our house had a son in the Air Force. Mrs. Houser had a blue star in her front window. One day the blue star was taken away and replaced by a Gold star. Her son’s plane had gone down over Europe, and his body had not been recovered. The Gold star stayed in her window for years after the War had ended.

Boys graduating from High School knew they would get a summons to appear at some army fort, or navel station, or where Marines trained, or perhaps an Air Force landing field. Soon after Paw-paw graduated from high school he was called into the Army Air Force. Young men who “signed up” to enter a service could choose which service. Those who were drafted usually went into the army.

Because Charlotte had an airfield with available land around it, Charlotte had facilities for flight training. The wide area around the airfield was suddenly covered with housing—and became an Air Base. Only people who already lived in that area were welcome on the roads that lead to buildings and houses and barracks that popped up around the base. Where there was open ground one day, on the next workers would be erecting buildings for the men, and extending runways to accommodate the huge increase in activity on the landing strips.

After the war ended my Dad did some work near the air field in Charlotte, and in the summer when our house (without air-conditioning) was extremely warm, he would ask us (Mother, Ella Cornelia, and me) if we wanted to go for a ride. If we had enough gas, Daddy would drive us out to the air port where we could watch the planes come in and take off. It was on a graveled road near the end of one of the landing strips. The planes would come in over us to land, and they would take off over us to climb into the sky and fly away to some far away location. Daddy had painted the little wooden building that served as the airport and he knew the neighborhood pretty well. We would sit there with an evening breeze blowing through our windows and listen to the roar of motors, and see the planes take off almost directly over the roof of our car, and think that it was a great privilege to be able to watch them. The only drawback there was that we sometimes had to fight mosquitoes. And my mother would always say a short prayer for the ones that lifted into the sky over the muddy little spot where we watched. She especially said prayers as the participation of America in the European War became more active

Years before the spot where we could see planes take off and land had been a sort of “Lovers Lane, where automobiles with a couple (boy and girl) would park there. Now lots of people drove out in the evenings to watch planes take off and land. It was a cool place in the evenings, as there were few trees or houses to interrupt the evening breeze.

On Weekends (both Saturday and Sunday) many of the young airmen could leave the airbase, or soldiers from other close at hand army posts would come to Charlotte, and go into the center of town hunting movies, restaurants, and other attractions, including girls to date, and take to a movie. Most of them didn’t have automobiles, so they came in busses and went back in busses, and ambled around town and ate in restaurants, attended church on Sundays, and watched movies when they could. There were a number of families who unselfishly had the money and the time to make sure that no Air Force person would have “no place to go” when they were off duty. They invited the young men to their homes for a meal, and sometimes the Airmen would stay overnight with them. There was a family on our street—Mr. and Mrs. Brady—who did that for the soldiers. They would see the young men meandering around the uptown of Charlotte, and invite them to supper, as many as three or four. Sometimes they stayed overnight, at their house, ate breakfast the next day, and went to church at Tenth Avenue Presbyterian, which was my church, too. It was just a block from my house, and the young men who ate lunches with her would often accompany the Brady’s to church. My sister was old enough to date, and when one of the young men who came to the Brady’s house asked her Daddy allowed her to go with them to a movie. I thought that was unfair—I liked movies, too, and if I couldn’t go, how did she get that privilege? The fact that she was seven years older than me didn’t really occur to me at the time. Actually, there were a number of families who would drive into town on Saturday or Sunday to look for soldiers of any service who were on leave for the week-end, and take a few of them back home with them to offer meals and “family-type” week-ends in their homes. with

Young men, still “wet behind the ears” were rushed through their training and sent to Europe to engage in ground and air fights with German forces—taking back the countries Germany or Italy had swallowed. Very large Army Air Force at bases popped up in or near cities where airfields already existed, and also in the West where the terrain was mostly flat, and not heavily occupied by towns. Florida’s hotels were used by the government to house Air Force enrollees. There were not enough Army bases to accommodate all those who enrolled in the Armed Forces. When Paw-paw was called into service after his graduation he was sent to Florida, housed in a hotel, and he went through basic training there.

He was sent to several parts of the United States, learning first one, then another part of the skill he needed. When his training was finishsed, Paw-paw was assigned, with his crew to duty on an island in the Pacific that I don’t know how to spell. When he arrived there he and his crew dug trenches as shelters, and put up tents to live in. He had been promised a new “stripe” on his uniform to go along with his first flight over enemy territory. Then he learned that the U.S had dropped atom bombs on Japan, and the war was over.

Pawpaw had been through all his training, traveled far from home into strange places, had eaten in messes where he hated the food, taken orders from people who could actually punish him if he didn’t do what they told him. He dug ditches to protect himself from natural problems, like storms and wind, and the possibility of being shot or blown up by the enemies of his country. He was an airman in the war zone. Then, after all the discomforts that young fellow had endured, the day before his crew would fly over Japan and drop bombs on the enemy the war ended. Remember that Paw-paw was still quite young. It was sort of like working very hard to clean up your room, and when it was spotless, shining, clean, and smelling good, the company came, but no one even peaked into your room—you had done all that for nothing. Paw-paw had marched, learned how to fly, wore a uniform that had to be washed and taken care of, and worn precisely perfectly, and now, the war was over. There would, therefore, not be any more increases in pay—the danger was gone. Any journeys would be about peace—he would e shooting down enemies. It was done. Paw-paw had left home when he didn’t want to leave, he had lived in places he didn’t want to be in, he had traveled half way across the world, been eaten by mosquitoes, helped take his airplane anywhere his superior officers told him to go, slept in uncomfortable beds, eaten food he didn’t like because there wasn’t anything better, washed his own clothes, and now, just as he would have gotten a raise in pay, and the experience of bombing Japan—the country that had bombed Pearl Harbor—the war was over. No more war. So Paw-paw thought his “luck” was great, but if the Japanese had waited one more day to surrender, Paw-paw would have gotten a raise in pay. So far as the young boy who grew up to be your Paw-paw was concerned, young as he was, that was a bummer.

A day or so later Paw-paw stood on that Pacific island with the name I can’t spell, and witnessed at a distance the landing of a Japanese plane. The men who had flown in it were transferred to an American plane that would shortly land on an American Carrier not far away. Once there, those men would sign the documents that would end the war—they would surrender to General McArthur. The war was over.

Paw-paw was a little miffed because he had been looking forward to a raise in both rank and pay as soon as he made his first mission over Japan. Suddenly, the fight was over—no more war. Therefore no raise in pay, and no raise in rank. Only a sort of “clean-up” crew was needed. To one so young, so far from home, it was a dismal climax to all the time he had spent away from home, learning things he would not ordinarily have had to learn, and it was all for nothing. They hadn’t really needed him. But he was stuck on that island, and had to go to Japan and do whatever somebody told him to do, but most of it was not particularly important so it was a let-down. It seemed unfair that the timing of the end of the war also prevented his pay raise and status—he would not be promoted, and he would not get a raise.

There were adventures, and travel, and a boat trip home during a typhoon, and at last he was mustered out of service. There was a train ride, then a taxi ride, and he was at home. Of course his family realized he was being released from service; however they didn’t know when, or how, or where, so the return of the Airman was a surprise. The members of the family had done that day what they did every weekday, involved with their jobs and routine. The wonderful part was that he did come home. He was there, all in one piece.

Life was very different after the close of the war. The entire world had been turning in its place, and changes had occurred. Transportation was different. Food was different. Frozen dinners had been invented. Refrigerators had improved tremendously, with most having freezers, to make their own ice. Ideas were popping up everywhere, different, exciting—food could be heated in an electric microwave, and it didn’t take hours to cook stuff—it could be done in minutes. And wonders upon wonders: there was, at last, an actual medicine that would help heal skin injuries and other illnesses. At first, only sulfur was in use on the battlefields, but then a new medicine was found, called penicillin which could prevent infections. Of course it was used on the battlefield, in field hospitals, and when production was greater than the need of the armed forces, even civilian hospitals were able to use this wonderful medicine. People new to Charlotte could, in the weeks following, finally have their telephones installed. Repairs could be made now, that were delayed because of either the scarcity of materials or the lack of people to do the work since so many young men were in the military. But the greatest difference was that all of the servicemen had seen a lot more of their own country than ever before, and most of them thought that living as if they were still in Horse and Buggy days was totally unsatisfactory. They wanted machines to do the great heavy chores. Medicine had improved by leaps and bounds—not just a tiny bit every twenty years or so. Surgery by physicians who had been on the battlefield was different, and for the most part, greatly improved. Need was the beginning, and successful tries by physicians and inventers paved the way into a very different sort of life.

Suddenly, houses without telephones had one installed. Radios were in nearly every house. Electricity was spreading quickly into areas like Pineville and other small areas around Charlotte, and other large cities, too. Even farmers who were not in a tight community could have phones. And most already had radios. Running water, instead of hiking to the spring to fetch a bucket of water, was prevalent. Few city houses were not without power. Cars and trucks that had been restricted to government use were now available for ordinary people who could pay for them. The young men and women who returned from active service wanted automobiles, too. Because some areas of the country had better plans for education than others, the areas that were behind began to catch up with areas of our country that were ahead of them. Efforts began to be made to teach every child how to read and write. Because the armed services had needed lots of nurses and doctors, there seemed to be more of them than most cities had seen before the war. The skills that had saved lives on the battlefield were brought back home and hospitals could and did do more than they had been able to accomplish before the war. Air planes were no longer “two little boards way up in the air making all that noise” but useful machines to make long journeys quickly and easily. Because train engines had been manufactured to carry war materials there were more trains, and they had more places to travel, and more travelers to carry, and more freight than they had ever expected to cart across the country and deliver.

The young men who had gone to war were a mixture of city and country and mountain and valley and lake and desert people. They saw wonders—radios, airplanes, bulldozers, tanks, weapons, and they saw dumb ideas and smart ideas, and most of them decided that the clever ideas were better. Somehow, while they were winning a war, aircraft improved, and so did automobiles, They saw wonders—radios, airplanes, bulldozers, tanks, clever plans that prevented deaths, perseverance when victory seemed impossible but wasn’t. Most of them had seen other parts of the world, and the way other people lived. Miracles had been achieved by using new weapons, new ideas, new inventions, and using or improving on ideas for new and wonderful inventions. Telephones were a marvelous way to spread information, and they were now being installed in most homes in the towns and cities. Before the war only the very rich had owned telephones. New equipment that saved time, energy, and effort had been put in place so that most homes and businesses could have telephones. The manufacture of goods for use in homes as well as automobiles could now be made instead of warplanes and ships. Young men who had once lived “down on a farm, or out in the country” had seen foreign cities, and many parts of the world, including much of the United States. Many young people had traveled the world, had seen and experienced things they would never have known about had they not gone to other countries during their service in the armed services.

Another wonderful thing was that young men who had served in the armed services could go to school, and have help from the government to pay for attending college. The need for quick ways to disperse information about the battles by radio caused local radio stations with “News Reports” to open “World News” as well as local information. Machines like air planes and radio and special vehicles or heavy equipment that could change terrain had been invented and put to use. To help the war effort there had been many inventions, and people were trained to use them. Need is the mother of invention, and scientists had found antibiotic medicines that helped wounded people heal. Physicians had gone to war also, and learned more than had ever before been known about saving lives. . , and . More young men had seen more of the world than they would have seen in fifty years had they not traveled. ****** . or introduced to different ways of life, and opportunities to “go to college” under the GI Bill, to which they were entitled to go to schoolequipment. . surroundings, always obeying persons who didn’t care whether he liked them or not. He had learned how to shoot at enemies, and drop bombs on their country. All the sweat and loneliness and food he didn’t like, and people who yelled orders to him, was for nothing. Not only that, but if he had made only one “run” against the enemy, he would have had a raise in pay, and another stripe. Since the Japanese had surrendered, he didn’t get to make that flight, and henceforth missed a rise in pay. He had been looking forward to having that raise in pay—so he was a bit ambivalent about the surrender.

He was, of course, still quite young. All the training he had received was still his. But he wouldn’t get his rise in pay….and he couldn’t go home—yet.

He was stationed in Japan for a while, living in barracks built for Japanese soldiers, or perhaps their pilots, until he accrued enough “points” to earn his discharge. He saw the devastation the atom bombs left behind them, and in his free time he went sight-seeing to some degree, but since there was no war anymore, all he really wanted to do was to go home. As soon as possible, he did. Even so, his journey home wasn’t easy, as he went by boat across the sea (during a typhoon) and then by train across America. Released from service he took a train to Charlotte—and since little was known about the procedure of leaving the service, and telephones were scarce, he didn’t tell his family he was on the way. One day he simply got on a train, and when it arrived in Charlotte, he got off. He rode a taxi to his house, and walked in, as if he had never been away. He was not the boy he had been when he left Charlotte—and he still wasn’t sure what he wanted to do with his life. But he was at home, now. He had not yet decided what to do with the rest of his life—but his Mother, Father, and Grandmother Beatty were there, and he was there and that night he slept in his own bed.

Of course, he was now a grown man—but he wasn’t a man with a plan. He had not had an option about enlisting—and life itself was not a promise during that period of history. A hideously large number of soldiers lost their lives in that war.

Paw-paw had no set plan for what he was going to “do” so far as jobs or education were concerned. He wanted—I don’t think he knew what he wanted—beyond a sort of a longing or a wistful desire to have a wife and family, a good paying job, a nice home, and perhaps a career as a pilot since air travel was rapidly growing. He had only his high school education along with some military training to rely on—but no college degree. Paw-paw had never loved school. He had held some sort of teenage job early in his youth—paper boy, and currier by bicycle—but those were “youth” jobs while in school.

The Second World War brought this old world, and especially our country, into a totally different era. Instead of horse and buggy we were pushed into futuristic air travel and special new machines that could do much more than a man with a mule. Though new tools, and engines and new ideas were not “free,” still more people did more different jobs and more people had better tools, mass produced for the most part, and available to folk who had steady jobs with nice salaries—working people. One of the most appreciated and marvelously welcomed was the jump physicians had made in dealing with wounds and injuries, and the fact that science and medicine had a great and wonderful boost when they finally found medicines that were antibiotics. Penicillin and great and wondrous protocols were invented—needs and necessities are always the mother of invention—so that medicines and protocols were invented to be used with injuries and illnesses at a time when the government was footing the bill. Science discovered antibiotics, and physicians stumbled on new protocols out of desperation when they worked on the battlefield. There were new and wonderful medical advances, mostly because the tools and medicines were improved. Once a small child wanted a toy that didn’t exist—and drew a plan of the toy—then said he had made it out of “think”. I believe that the doctors who treated the wounded were sort of like that—they were intelligent and compassionate and because the wounded were dying anyway, they were willing to risk treatments that had never before been tried. During that time, great wide leaps in medicine occurred. And once begun, they continued to a certain extent through today, when new meds and new procedures and new machines that help with human health are frequently invented.

In general, the way of life before World War II was widely and particularly different from the life we live today. The city of Charlotte had sewage lines, and water lines that came into neighborhood houses—but there were sections of Charlotte where people still drew their water from community spigots and used out-houses. Few ordinary families had telephones. When World War II began hardly anyone in our neighborhood even had a radio—most didn’t have telephones. Few bothered to walk into to town to see a “movie” and most people walked to church each Sunday. There were very few radios in homes on our street. Most of the homes I had been in did not have telephones. Rural areas such as Pineville had no electricity, and most had no running water in the house, therefore, no indoor toilets. Ice was sold by the pound from horse-drawn roofed wagons, and trolley cars were laid in the center of certain streets for public transportation. Of course, Charlotte had telephones—but only “rich” people or businesses actually had them—and of course we didn’t. There was no phone in our house at the beginning of World War II; however, soon after the war started, Daddy had a phone put in at our house. I was about eight years old. In the Pineville in 1941 most of the homes had out-houses for toilets, and bathed from a basin filled with warm water from a kettle. Many farm homes did not have electricity—neither my maternal nor my paternal grandparents had toilets or running water in their homes. How did people cope? For the evening and night time, there were chamber-pots under most beds for convenience. One of the first early morning chore in those homes was their emptying. The wicks and chimneys of kerosene lamps had to be cleaned (from soot) so they could be used when darkness fell again. Water had to be brought by the bucket full from springs or wells outside the house, and was usually used very carefully to prevent unnecessary trips to the well or spring—water is heavy, and “Jack and Jill” in the nursery rhyme who fell down and spilled out the water was not, I repeat, not, funny to folk who had to lug bucket after bucket into their homes in order to have water when it was needed. Another thing was automobiles. Automobiles were invented in the late 1800’s, but for the most part people who lived in Charlotte didn’t really have a car for every family. When I was a child our family lived on West Eleventh Street. We moved there when I was about two years old, and my parents still lived there when I was married. My Mother and Dad didn’t move away from that house until your Mother was about two years old (but that is another story). In those days the houses along our street sometimes had “driveways” beside them—but not many people on our street had an automobile. There was no parking along our street anyway, probably because in the times before automobiles were in front of nearly every house in town, people walked to work, and to neighborhood stores, or if they went into “town” near the square, they took a trolley car.

The up-town of Charlotte had five and dime stores, clothing stores, and department stores, and most of them were within a couple of blocks of the square—where Tryon and Trade streets crossed. The government buildings—the Post Office, the City Hall, and the Court House, were on Trade Street. Upon occasion in parts of Charlotte that were several miles from the Square there would be five and dime stores,—a sort of variety store where prices were low, or drug stores, which generally sold about the same kind of merchandise that most of them sell today. But the large stores, such as department stores and what we called “five and dime” stores, shoe stores, hat stores, and most of the better department stores were located within two blocks of the square, with show windows along Trade or Tryon streets.

Before my seventh birthday there were trolly tracks down the middle of Eleventh Street. There were driveways beside several of the nearby houses, and a few garages in some of the back yards, but people in our neighborhood seldom owned vehicles. They either rode a bus or walked to their jobs. We lived in a duplex—which meant that our house was like Siamese twins—our kitchen, hall, and upstairs bedroom shared a wall with their kitchen, hall, and upstairs bedroom. The house next door was a “mirrow image” of our house.******

next door had what Mother called “an alley” beside our house. Alleys usually had openings at both ends, and driveways usually ended at a garage door, or at least a fence. Until after the War our neighborhood had few vehicles parked, either in front of, or beside of, the houses on our street. The We walked if the distance was only a mile or a mile and a half. We took the bus if it was dark, or the path was through a dangerous area, or was more than two miles long. I walked to school. I walked to Church when we attended those in our neighborhood.

My mother, when I was in First Grade, began a new “career”. She had always made the clothes my sister and I wore, as well as her own. She had known how to sew from the age of eight, when she made shirts and pants for a neighbor child who had no clothes of his own, and wanted to go to school. When I was about six years old she actually went to work for a company that recovered (as in replacing worn out fabric with new covers) furniture. I was so young that I don’t remember much about that period, but I may have been in Kindergarten while Mother was at work. Ella Cornelia had been very, very ill, and for a time no one except Mother and dear old Doctor Ashe thought she would live. There were no antibiotics. People who suffered that illness became invalids. Mother was told that if she lived, she would have heart trouble and weak lungs the rest of her life, which would be short. Minnie Parks Yandle did not give up or become slack in her concern. Mother was determined that she would live and be healthy. The only suggestion the physicians had was simply keeping her comfortable and praying—so mother did that. It was dear Dr. Ashe who drew fluid from her lungs, and offered such palliatives as were available. She also did not accept that her first born would die at about ten years old. NO!

The Garr Auditorium was a young church at that time, and was probably Pentecostal. My Dad was working at a lumber yard. The owner’s wife was a staunch believer in praying for healing. So prayers from Pineville Methodist (where the Yandle’s worshiped), and Flint Hill Baptist Church (where Aunt Ola worshiped) and Garr Auditorium, (where Daddy’s boss and his family worshipped), and folks who listened to the daily fifteen minute devotional on WBT radio lead by Mrs. Garr were asked to pray. Physicians warned that if she survived she would be an invalid.
Mother said NO! But she took great and steady and prayerful care of Ella Cornelia, who did not walk or move very much for over a year. Any strain on her heart was avoided. She used a wheel chair, or was carried to the table for meals.

Ella Cornelia had suffered a terribly high temperature, and her hair had been haggled off while she was in the hospital. She was thin and weak and not allowed to walk or do anything that took more than a little energy. Water was carried to her—she didn’t get her own. She was not allowed to use her own energy to go to the table for meals—she was carried. She had lost weight so that she was skin and bones, mostly. She would look into a mirror and cry, saying something like, “I am so ugly”. Mother, of course, always encouraged her by saying “you are not ugly—stop saying that!” I thought, being a “good” sister, she might be less aggravating if I didn’t argue with her if I could help it., and so I decided it would be a good thing to sympathize with her one day when she had not been home from the hospital very long and was using a wheel chair as she was not allowed to strain her heart by walking. One day she whined about her looks since most of her hair had been chopped off unevenly while she had such high fevers. I sang her a little song which had a chorus that said, over and over again, “Poor Ugly Cornelia.” It liked it so much I sang it over and over again. She wanted to hit me, perhaps to mash me. Since she was chair-bound (forbidden to walk) she couldn’t chase me. Mother told me to stop saying that. I was possibly about four years old at the time, and since she was always the center of attention, the one everyone cared about, and I was the small person who didn’t NEED attention, even though I was as small and needy of attention as any other child, anyone could see why I didn’t like her very much.

Since I was healthy—and no one was afraid I would perish before I grew up—guess who got most or all of the adult attention. Daddy would come in, wanting to know right away how Ella Cornelia was doing. Kin folk would come to see her, sometimes bringing a small gift—but they didn’t need to see me, and there was no reason to give me a gift. I was three or four when she got sick—and she was never, in all of my childhood—pronounced as well.

Ella Cornelia was slender, pretty, had nice (even if they were home-made) clothes. She had any pair of shoes she wanted—even if Mother had to take the money for them from MY small $5.00 dime bank, and I was old enough to realize that my money was used for her pretty shoes while my cheap sandals were bought from a store my mother called “Little Belks” which was in a grungy old building on College Street where anything that wouldn’t actually sell in the main store could be sold at low prices to people who couldn’t afford to shop in “Big” Belks. That meant that somehow I wasn’t worth much in my family. Ella Cornelia was important. Jean was truly unimportant. Fortunately for us all I managed to keep my sorrow and disappointment to myself, even though the partiality, though it diminished somewhat as she recovered, never went away.

No one could say that about Ella Cornelia—her frailness was visible. I was old enough to realize that no one ever actually punished her if she said something ugly. If both of us needed “help” at the same time, I was the one who had to wait. If she wanted an ice cream cone somehow she got one; but I was “too little” to have one. For several months I was “farmed out” with kinfolk I didn’t know very well—one of them my Aunt Martha (an old maid) who delighted in following a toddling little child, jerking down my home-made panties, and pinching my butt. That was a “playtime” that really got to me, and though I couldn’t have been more than four years old, I remember it to this day. I got over being mad at her all the time, but I never did appreciate her as I did for my other aunts and uncles. During Ella Cornelia’s illness members of the family had been keeping me so Mother could be at the hospital. Most of the time someone else had been keeping me. My while she was hospitalized. and at home people told me to go play in another room.

or Ella Cornelia. The man my Dad It was a church that leaned more than a little toward believing in healing through prayer, and the pastor and his wife had a fifteen minute spot on WBT radio. Our family did not attend or even go there, but that church would pray for healing for anyone who called them—and the . People phoned them for prayer requests, and the wife of the man my dad worked for was a member of that church. re was more to her illness than that. Most of them had lung problems, and few could lead an ordinary life after that illness. Ella Cornelia had pleurisy, which involves lungs, I did attend Kindergarten when I was too young to go into the first grade. —when the chair or sofa was worn out and needed new fabric covers. would have to be re-upholstered or discarded because of tears and broken springs. like settees or divans and easy chairs. I remember that she She learned a lot there, and soon after that we had a divan in our living room (someone had ordered it recovered and then couldn’t pay for it so Mother bought it from the upholstery store.) She had stayed home with me until I started school. But when I was in first grade, she went to work in a rented room in a building on East Trade Street, owned by an old lady who was a living reminder of how life was lived fifty or more years before, and very near the square, which was the name given to the intersection at which Trade Street crossed Tryon Street. Today the Performing Arts auditorium is standing in the space where that old building stood. Across East Trade Street there was once a hotel, but it had closed and small businesses had rented a building that had become a in the place of the old Hotel that had become an office building which was the view I saw as a first grade student, there is now a rather spectacular hotel, with a fountain in a courtyard now stands). She became partners with Mrs. King who was running an established sewing shop with a partner who decided to retire. Mrs. King, who had been our neighbor at one time, offed my mother the position. The shop acquired a new seamstress, and a new name: King and Yandle Sewing Shop. That title was painted the window that looked over East Trade Street,It was painted on the window which opened on East Trade Street, in the same block that had the two major streets crossing each other: Trade Street and Tryon Street in the middle of Town. That crossing was called the Square. I had just started first grade, too young to spend the afternoon alone in an otherwise empty house on West Eleventh Street, especially since the front door lock didn’t work. Young though I was, I knew the way to the Square where the sewing shop was located, so every afternoon I left school, walked past my house (I wasn’t allowed go into our house when no one else was there), so I then followed the familiar streets to the square where Miss Sallie Davidson’s owned an old brick building on East Trade Street next to Belk’s Department Store. There I spent the afternoon in my mother’s sewing shop, making “people” of the myriad spools of thread she had collected and stored on a homemade spool holder.
**88 I went there every day as soon as school was out, and all day during the summer when there was no school.
