There was no one at home to watch over me, and my mother didn’t think leaving me alone in a house which did not even have a front door lock. When the school year was over in the spring of the year in which I completed the third grade a terrible contagious illness began to spread from the mountains of North Carolina, and in other locations in the South. I remember that it began a few weeks before the actual planned closing of the schools for the summer—and it lasted all through the summer, because school was late opening that fall. The illness was a terrible disease called poliomyelitis. It caused its victims to become paralyzed, and some of them could not even breathe on their own because their muscles didn’t work any more. Sometimes it was only legs that were involved, and about that time Franklin Delano Roosevelt was President, and despite his handicap he had been elected President, though he used a wheel chair. The disease struck babies, children, youths, adults, and old people, and they either died, or were to some extent crippled. Some patients could no longer breathe on their own, and were stuck into a device known as an iron lung—a huge tank with a motor that helped helplessly paralyzed persons inhale and exhale. That summer was a terrible time in North Carolina.

This was an era before antibiotics. The only thing that could be used was sulfa and that didn’t help with Poliomyelitis. Remember that there were no real antibiotic medicines. An epidemic of Infantile Paralysis broke out in the mountains of North Carolina. It spread—and maimed children and sometimes adults—for most of that summer. The horror of new victims of the disease did not actually stop until cold weather began. Charlotte City officials banned children from anything that drew a crowd. No church—no movies—no parades—no gatherings—and even things like family get-togethers were canceled. Next door neighbors wouldn’t let their children play together. The disease was devastating, and there was no cure. People who had the disease either died or walked on crutches for the rest of their lives, or lay in a machine that would breathe for them since they couldn’t breathe for themselves—that was the year that iron lungs became famous. I didn’t go to the library, or to church, and entered the up-town area only when I went to the doctor, and that was as seldom as possible. My parents had learned about orthodontists—dentists who straightened and aligned teen for children whose teeth grew in crooked and out of place. I was having my teeth straightened, and I had to visit the doctor’s office about once a month. For that appointment I walked about a mile to the office, and then returned home, without going into any other store, and I was forbidden the pleasure of stopping and chatting with any friend I might come in contact with. I wasn’t allowed to ride the bus by my parents, as that would have meant sitting close to other passengers. It was about that time that my family had sent me to a dentist who would straighten my teeth. I had “tusks” sticking out under my upper lip. If I felt like laughing at anything funny I would put my hand over my mouth, because I looked like a vampire with teeth sticking out like tusks. That summer, my trips to the Orthodontist were the only times I went uptown. I couldn’t even go to the library to select books, however, Ella Cornelia could, and she chose books for me, and when I had read them she would return those and find other books she thought I would like to read.

888888***

Here in the South we had not only trains and motorized equipment, but we had world wide radio for the first time. We had aviation rather than covered wagons—and in most places in this country the burgeoning of production and new larger and better everything changed our lives in a hurry. For instance, before and during the war we had in our kitchen area an ice-box. Some few of our neighbors had electric refrigerators, but most of the folk on our street, like my family, had ice boxes—simple cabinets with good insulation and a drain pipe to accommodate the water from the melted ice. An elderly black man our family, with respect, called “Dad” brought us a block of ice about three times a week. Now this old gentleman lived alone, , “Dad” with much respect, brought

The job market had changed. Many young soldiers had completed college before entering the services. Many had gained brand new and/or quite modern skills, and could step right into the changed life-style of towns, cities, businesses, factories, cities, farms, and offices where intelligent people and accepted all the new inventions that came out of World War II—like airplanes, caring for injured people, different ways of caring for sick folk—for instance the medical community now had medicines and serums and diagnosis tools that had never before been in use. Penicillin had been born, as well as other wonderful methods of treatment for injured people. Computers were certainly not like they are today, but the first machines that were forerunners of the computers of today were being installed in both government and business offices. Simple well thought out methods of doing many things—from making a garden, or a field, yield more of whatever had been planted, and travel as well as shipping had improved so that new protocols were being used in almost every phase of everyday life. new vessels, tru or using machines, called computers usint A great number of young men had learned needed skills while in service. Some had even1 finished college before enrolling, and those young men **Jobs were scarce, simply because when almost all able-bodied me went into the military, there wasn’t enough labor to achieve much of anything in factories. . Farm boys, every male student over eighteen, every nurse who opted to volunteer to nurse the wounded and other skilled women who excitement and professional men, physicians, businessmen who had dealt with processing food, shipping food or boxes of other important and useful items, who were “able bodied” went into service. , some of whom knew precisely how to handle women had entered markets they had never ventured into before there were so few men to take up slack because of the needs of the armed services. ***

He didn’t really like the idea of school, but he enrolled at a college, not because he had chosen it, but because a pretty girl he had known for several years was enthusiastically enrolled there. Though a good student in High School, his effort to tackle a college education miles from home, with unfamiliar teachers and students, subjects he mostly didn’t see a specific reason for, with schoolmates he had never seen before, and knowing only the one girl who joyfully immersed herself in the variations of college life on a campus that was not actually “near” home, made life difficult for him. His venture into higher education didn’t last. and he decided to go there because a girl friend was also enrolled there. After his military service which had not been either avoidable nor changeable, he didn’t expect to find unbreakable rules, or or completely where he had no choice about where he was stationed, Paw-paw discovered that he disliked being away from home; and also that he was not in a “mood” to delve into the courses he was required to master as a college student. Most of them were required subjects he had avoided in High School—and in those days students did not always have the privilege of simply choosing their curriculum. Paw-paw quickly discovered that, for him, college wasn’t pleasant. He was taking courses he didn’t like, didn’t think he would need to use in the future, didn’t see a reason for, and besides, he had an argument with his girlfriend (from Charlotte) who was also enrolled there. he didn’t want to be a college student anymore.

His father was treasurer for a long haul trucking company, and eventually Paw-paw went to work there as a “step and fetch” person for parts for truck engine repairs, and other necessary errands. Eventually he moved into the office though he didn’t really love desk work. He was working there when we met.

Over a hundred years ago Paw-Paw’s maternal Great-Grandfather Shuman had, as a young husband and father, along with other young families in his neighborhood, had a desire to establish a Methodist Church in their neighborhood on Mint Street. The Shuman’s house had a nice front porch, and neighbors who shared Grandpa and Grandma Shuman’s desire for a church in that its vision of establishing a churchso they found a retired Baptist preacher, invited neighbors to attend an impromptu church on the Shuman front porch in order to establish, and a new church was born. The group grew, a building was found to house the church, and soon a Methodist preacher was appointed to lead the new congregation.
A building suitable for meeting was found while the group attending grew until it was necessary to build a new church. After that move into a larger building more years passed, and more people came to the church, and eventually Mint Street became so busy and so well traveled (with a railroad right down the center of it) that parking along the street was forbidden, and there was no space available for a parking lot. That’s when Grandfather Shuman and his fellow members decided to build a new church, further down on Mint Street. The years passed, and again it outgrew its building and parking lot. So they moved the church to East Boulevard. The church building was only about a year old when they decided enlarge their staff to include a parttime secretary who could also function as a director of Christian Education. That person turned out to be me.

*88888888**

in Charlotte. It was a nice neighborhood, but there was no nearby church. Their first steps toward their goal was to find a preacher, a place to meet, and a group of equally determined folk who would help the church grow. The place they needed turned out to be Grandfather Shuman’s front porch, and the preacher was a retired Baptist who agreed to lead the services. Neighbors and friends were the congregation, and so began a new Methodist Church in Charlotte. Grandfather Shuman, his wife and family, and his friends and neighbors persevered until

Paw-paw was young, and had not found a particular or wonderful pathway for the rest of his life, partially because he had not seen a challenge that appealed strongly to him as a career, and he was certain that he would spend at least two, if not more, years in the Air Force as soon as he left high school. World War II was in full swing, and all able bodied young men were required to register for the Draft. Paw-paw wanted to join the Army Air Force, and signed up to go as soon as he graduated from High School.

Robert Erskine Beatty did enter the Army Air Force, as it was named at that time. Shortly after he graduated from High School he was called into service. He can explain better than I how things went from that event, as I don’t accurately remember all that happened. He was in the Pacific, but never participated in bombing Japan. The day before his first bombing mission, the Japanese surrendered. Eventually he was sent to Japan, and served there for the required length of time before he was eligible for discharge.

High School students had to register as soon as they graduated from High School, or if they chose, enlist before they were drafted, which allowed some choice in choosing Marine, Navy, Air Force, or Army. in full unsure of what he wanted to do, and tried college, but left before the first semester was complete. He went to school to learn how to service and repair airplanes, but discovered that a lot of returning soldiers and done the same thing. Actually jobs were not easily found, because a lot of returning service men had been wonderful soldiers, but didn’t have educations to enter the different job market that existed after World War II ended.

Paw-paw tried attending the same college as his best girl friend, but events didn’t pan out the way he expected, so he came home, took flying lessons, drove a taxi, and even took a course so that he could become an air-plane mechanic, but nothing seemed to be the perfect answer, so he finally went to work in the office of Johnson Motor Lines where his father was Treasurer of the company.

By that time his family was attending Calvary Methodist Church. And the mention of the church opens another avenue of information. The church had been formed by a group of Christians who wanted a Methodist Church in their Charlotte neighborhood. Those folks found a retired Baptist preacher, who agreed to hold services on the front porch of a man named Jake Shuman.

The church eventually grew, received a Methodist pastor, and either bought or built a small church on Church Street in Charlotte. Jake Shuman and his wife and children, as well as a number of other folk, worked until they had a well run and growing church. The area where there once was a large community of homes became a victim of the growth of Charlotte as a city. The area changed, businesses grew along the street causing more traffic and noise, and less parking space. The increase of traffic and use of automobiles d, along with the bustle of business, and eventually the city demanded that there be no parking on the street. The church suffered because of the diminished parking space, and the attendance had become larger than the sanctuary, so building had become too small to hold all the members at one time. and it was beginning to feel cramped because of the increase in the number of members. Therefore, Calvary Methodist moved into a building built expressly for them, not far from the first building. Years passed, the congregation grew, and the church itself prospered, however, the bustling area again became too “busy” for comfort, with only inconvenient parking, and was again too small to hold all the members. Another location was found, and a larger building, with large Sunday School rooms, and a nice parking area was built on West Boulevard. There was a old but decent neighborhood around it the property, and near a bus line. The street was wide and well traveled. The nearby neighborhood seemed stable and well cared for. However, the actual street on which the church would stand was quite busy, as it eventually lead to the Airport.

*****this time near an older, settled neighborhood, though on a street that was rapidly becoming a major thoroughfare. The new church was built, and the congregation increased now that parking was the people moved away from the that was close to the first church building didn’t like the business area that their

, Baptist Preacher who agreed to hold services, but there was no building, so the had services on the front porch of a man named Jake Shuman. He and his family along with a large number of neighbors worked at creating a Methodist Church, even though their first preacher had been a retired Baptist. The group met on the and on _____Street. The group consisted of men and women who tried college, and a course at a special school to learn how to service and repair airplanes, took flying lessons, and in the meantime things at home changed.

His grandfather, who was a City of Charlotte policeman, died, which changed the home set-up completely. Eventually re he went to work for Johnson Motor Lines, the same trucking line where his father was Treasurer of the company. Among his first duties was to pick up materials ordered to repair the giant trucks and trailers that carried materials all up and down the Eastern Seaboard. He bought from local dealers the parts to repair the big trucks and other equipment, but eventually he worked in the office, and it must have been with a pencil because he didn’t know how to type.

****He was living in a garage apartment behind a house his parents had bought. They had been living on South Boulevard in a two story house with a large basement that had once belonged to Paw-paw’s grandparents. Paw-paw’s grandfather died, and his grandmother aged to the place

Paw-paw was still living at home, and his parents had just purchased a home in a very special neighborhood along a street called Dilworth Road. Mama and Papa Beatty had lived for years in the same house as Papa Beatty’s mother, Paw-paw’s grandmother. . She had been widowed for some years, and Papa Beatty and Mama, as well as your Paw-paw, had lived in the house with her for a number of years. Grandmother Beatty’s house was on South Boulevard, just across the street from where Lance Packing Company had made crackers and chips for many years. Lance was going to move, and the neighborhood was quite old. Changes were being made from many directions, and so the Beattys moved into a nicer and much quieter neighborhood. It was not a “main” street, it was a street of expensive housing, and the people who lived there seemed to have good incomes. The mother of a movie star named Randolph Scott lived in the house on the corner.

They were members of Calvary Methodist Church, as was Paw-paw, and “Mama” moved into a “new”

When I graduated from

worked in Johnson Motor Lines after the war, as that is where his father worked. His was a desk job, and there came a time when he needed to use a typewriter. Since he couldn’t type, it was a problem.

Therefore, I dug into a box of books I had accumulated, and pulled out a manual for beginning typists. Just before I graduated from Harding High School I visited some of the teachers who had helped me earn my diploma, and my typing teacher was discarding all the typing manuals which my class used. She offered one to me, and I packed it with my other books when I moved to Paw-paw’s apartment after we were married. I think Fred was an infant at the time, and Louise was a toddler. However, each evening for a while we had typing lessons—just as my teacher taught me—on a rented electric typewriter. I was the teacher—remembering how my teacher guided me—and Paw-paw was an excellent pupil. In about three weeks he could type without looking at the keys, and so the lessons stopped, he began his new position at work, and at last there was time to play with the babies again after he came home from work.

Paw-paw used that skill until Louise was about ten years old, give or take a year or two, and then he changed jobs, and began to drive an armored car for Wells Fargo. During that time there was no need for him to use a typewriter; and therefore the skill diminished until he can’t “do” typing now. That was the early age for computers, and most of them were still key-punch machines, which were welcomed in the marketplace, but letters and such were still done with typewriters.

When Paw-paw went to work at Wells Fargo it offered several options that appealed to him. First, he could drive (and he loved to drive) almost all day. Also he went to other cities, and he had always liked to move around the countryside. Most of his day was just driving, with stops at banks along his path, both delivering and receiving scads of valuable money, guarding it’s safety, and taking valuables to the safety of a vault. He was in and out of banks all over North and South Carolina, and several times went to other states to drive new armored trucks back to Charlotte, or transporting money to someplace outside of North or South Carolina.
When he left Wells Fargo he did a lot of “Guard” jobs. One was to prevent uninvited or unexpected folk from going into a place where steel bars were made—a hot, noisy, and uncomfortable place. He also worked as a guard at new building sites to protect the tools and as yet unused materials which were apt to “walk” away if unguarded. He also worked in a factory where clothing was sewn for shipment to department stores. The pay for the women who ran the machines was low, and the owners didn’t trust them. The items they sewed were sometimes small enough to be squeezed into a handbag, and Paw-paw had to look into their purses to be sure they were not carrying either finished or unfinished underwear home with them. He disliked that job so much that he finally quit it. However, the women who worked there often spent their short lunch period outside the building, and would upon occasion feed a cat or two from their lunch boxes. We got a lot of cats at our house like that. Paw-paw couldn’t stand seeing the hungry animals begging for food, so he brought home with him several cats he “discovered” who had no home. About that time we found ourselves with bunches of cats. People would drive by, see a bunch of cats, and add their unwanted cats to the number. At the end, we had thirty or forty animals to feed, keep safe, and sometimes take to the vet. Paw-paw left that place, and I thought the cat population would not continue to grow, especially after he worked at the place where they made steel rods and other steel items. However, a cat he discovered at that location apparently got too near liquid steel, and burned all the skin off her tail, leaving only the bones. She had nearly grown kittens, but her injury had to be quite painful. So we “borrowed” the cat long enough to have her tail removed by the vet, and gave her antibiotics for a while, and then returned her to her young brood. When Paw-paw left that job the cat was still running around, minus her tail, but seemed happy with her situation. I think the men who worked there fed them from their lunch pails.

His job there was sort of like a guard job, and when he decided he had enjoyed that job enough, and sought another one, he continued as a guard.
or other valuable paper from one place to another He drove over North Carolina and South Carolina to large cities and small towns or to wide places along the road where there was a bank. He carried a weapon, and the only time he was present when one was fired while he was on the job (apart from practice on the firing range) was in a small mountain town in North Carolina. The “guard” who was holding a shotgun while Paw-paw placed money in the armored car, was a little tense. He, by accident, pulled the trigger—thankfully the barrel was pointed up—and both of them quickly locked up their truck, jumped inside of it, and left the scene. No one was hurt, but that year Paw-paw, who was “in charge” of that particular three man team, didn’t get his “perfect” bonus because that moment of carelessness by his co-worker was reported to his boss. Paw-paw didn’t pull the trigger, but he was “in charge” of that run, so he also suffered from that moment of carelessness.
When he left Wells Fargo he did a lot of “Guard” jobs. One was to prevent uninvited or unexpected folk from going into a place where steel bars were made—a hot, noisy, and uncomfortable place. He also worked as a guard at new building sites to protect the tools and as yet unused materials which were apt to “walk” away if unguarded. He also worked in a factory where clothing was sewn for shipment to department stores. The pay for the women who ran the machines was low, and the owners didn’t trust them. The items they sewed were sometimes small enough to be squeezed into a handbag, and Paw-paw had to look into their purses to be sure they were not carrying either finished or unfinished underwear home with them. He disliked that job so much that he finally quit it. However, the women who worked there often spent their short lunch period outside the building, and would upon occasion feed a cat or two from their lunch boxes. We got a lot of cats at our house like that. Paw-paw couldn’t stand seeing the hungry animals begging for food, so he brought home with him several cats he “discovered” who had no home. About that time we found ourselves with bunches of cats. People would drive by, see a bunch of cats, and add their unwanted cats to the number. At the end, we had thirty or forty animals to feed, keep safe, and sometimes take to the vet. Paw-paw left that place, and I thought the cat population would not continue to grow, especially after he worked at the place where they made steel rods and other steel items. However, a cat he discovered at that location apparently got too near liquid steel, and burned all the skin off her tail, leaving only the bones. She had nearly grown kittens, but her injury had to be quite painful. So we “borrowed” the cat long enough to have her tail removed by the vet, and gave her antibiotics for a while, and then returned her to her young brood. When Paw-paw left that job the cat was still running around, minus her tail, but seemed happy with her situation. I think the men who worked there fed them from their lunch pails.

Paw-paw, at the age of 80 often writes notes but he doesn’t write letters now-a-days. When a response of any sort is either necessary or just courteous, he either writes a short one or two line reply, or He takes advantage of the fact that I still use the computer, and therefore I have become the “communicator” person. Once we were married, he seldom wrote anything that I could type for him. There was one period of time in Paw-paw’s life when he wrote frequent letters, and that was when he was about eighteen or nineteen, and was in the Army Air Force (as it was called then). He wrote short but frequent letters to his mother and father during his training in the U.S. and also while he was overseas. His mother kept the letters, and they still exist somewhere around here. He was on a Pacific island while serving in the Air Force when the Atomic Bomb was dropped on Japan. After he came home from the war I don’t think he wrote more than a half-dozen real letters to anyone—in all those years. He is very good at handling our bills, and he keeps track of birthdays. He makes notes about events we need remember, and always reminds me of our appointments or important dates. He is a handy person to have around—but he doesn’t do letters.

We speak to Fred and his family nearly every evening by telephone. This is possible because our cell phone does not cost us for use after about 6:00 P.M. over a large area that includes Charlotte. Unfortunately, Oregon is not one of the areas that are included in the “free” zone.

Paw-paw turned 80 years old last October. I am seventy-five. We have been married for more than fifty years. It doesn’t seem real that time has passed so quickly—wasn’t it just the other day we met and got married? However, we both feel our physical age. We are both hard of hearing and less agile than we once were, but we are blessed with general good health for the most part. As you know, Paw-Paw has no siblings, and I have but one sister. I spoke to Ella Cornelia by telephone yesterday and to Becky (her daughter) and David (her son) as well. Ella Cornelia is a little more than six years older than me. She is still in her own home, though if she feels “poorly” she spends time with Becky (her daughter) at Becky’s house. Becky is living in the fairly small house that Ella Cornelia and Harry (her husband) bought when they had only one child. Since Becky is in Charlotte she usually visits Ella Cornelia every day when she is at home. You may remember that Becky has that huge dog named Pearl. Pearl is already more than seven or eight years old. Her chin has gray in it now. Becky takes really good care of her, and when she leaves her house she always takes Pearl if possible. Pearl is a frequent visitor to Ella Cornelia on most days.

Paw-paw and I don’t get to Charlotte very often. For us, the drive itself drains our energy. Even so, we recently spent most of a day visiting in Charlotte—just for the day. We hope to do it again soon. First we arrived mid-morning at Fred’s house, and stayed there until nearly four in the afternoon. I used most of my time playing with Chrystal’s youngest child, baby Jonathan, who is walking now, or with……well, I started to finish the sentence by saying I was talking with young Rebecca, however, one does not exactly carry on a conversation with Rebecca. One LISTENS to Rebecca. She arrived home from school, and at once she became very busy, both physically with toys and so forth, but also with a strong desire to lead all conversations. She talks a lot. Though Fred was on vacation from Sonitrol for the occasion, he was baby-sitting little Jonathan. Paul was not at home as he is spending some time at a special summer teaching place—not so much a camp as it is a campus —and I think it is in Western North Carolina, or the edge of Virginia. He seems to be doing well. Thomas and Stewart were at home, and Fred was there all day as he is on vacation for the week. However Sheryl, for some reason, though she, too, was on vacation and knew we were coming to visit, had to go to work that day. I think, she simply didn’t want to be there when we came, though I would never say such a thing to Fred Lee. She was afflicted with a disease called “The in-laws are coming and I am going.” She always manages to either be away all together, or to have an “errand” that cannot be delayed even is she has company.

We enjoyed seeing and interacting with baby Jonathan and Rebecca, Fred Lee’s kitty cats, and Fred, too. Summer and her husband and son came by, and they volunteered to go the Wendy’s and bring home food for all for lunch. They brought back plenty to eat, and we did have a great time. Fred’s cats even enjoyed it.

We left Fred’s house early enough to have a short visit with Ella Cornelia before we returned home. Since Paw-paw is eighty years old he gets tired while driving, and we didn’t want to be on the highway after dark. Age does take its toll, whether or not we like it. We didn’t stay very late in Charlotte as we both prefer to arrive home before complete dark. We also have a chore that must be done before dark because we have no electricity in our shed as yet, and our kitty-cats (the three of them) have to be fed each evening

Like most old people, Paw-paw and I have fallen into a pattern for our week, which rarely varies. Though we do not have outside jobs anymore, we do have chores. We have our three cats to take care of, and our own housework to do. I water the flowers that are planted in the front and back yards. We go to the Grocery store several times each month, and to church regularly on Sunday and Wednesday evenings. When we first arrived in Inman we went to church twice (morning and evening) each Sunday, but there came a time when it was extremely difficult to arrive on time for morning services (simply old age); however we do try to go to the evening services. We also attend a Bible study on Wednesday evenings taught by Bill Decken. Bill is not only our teacher, he is also our chiropractor, and we visit him once a week for an adjustment—me particularly. My spine gets out of alignment which causes discomfort and difficulty in movements—so I see Bill every week. He is a busy man, as he is a teacher at Sherman College which educates persons who want to become Chiropractors. In the afternoons Bill opens the office where he, himself, practices chiropractic adjustments. He is quite involved in our church (Bethel) and teaches Bible on Wednesday evenings—a class Paw-paw and I often attend. Bill is also an elected official in the church. He is married to a lovely lady who was born and raised in the Philippines, and they have three or four daughters.

Apart from Church and Bible Study, our doctor’s appointments, and our grocery shopping, we have very little to occupy our time except taking care of our house, the cats, and the task of watering plants your Mom and Dad graciously planted among our green bushes in the front yard, as well as a small plot I started last year in the back yard. Another chore that we have every day is looking after our three cats. We still have Brownboy, who came with us from Charlotte, and Grayboy—the one who made friends with Loren while he was on the front porch, and our black kitty, Little-bit-o-cat, who was so named because she was so small when someone dropped her off in our yard at 2190. They seem to be happy together, and in the winter they often curl up together to stay warm.

Our only real neighbors are your family. The small number of folks on the street where we live have been either noticeably unsocial, or noticeably the sort of people we wished would move away, and quickly. It may be that most (or some) of them actually rented on the nearby properties only until other housing became available. A few months after we settled in we watched a young couple move in below us, and the wife was expecting a child. I thought that at last we would have nice new neighbors—but it didn’t turn out that way. The young wife disliked me from the first moment. Somehow I must have angered her without realizing it—or she plain doesn’t like fat old ladies.

On the uphill side of our house there came a day when I knocked on the door to speak to the grandmother, whom I had seen on the porch occasionally. She was part of a three generation family. There was Grandma, a couple, and two children a little older than Ashley. When the Grandma open her door I was literally shocked because the nicotine smell of the house was so prominent it literally took my breath away—my allergies do not allow me to be around tobacco smoke. That was the end of that attempt to be neighborly, though I did apologize for my abruptness, and explained why I could not come in for a visit. The only critter that welcomed us in our neighborhood was the black cat that lived in the house with the smokers. It likes to be petted, but not picked up, and it meows to me.

Despite the lack of friendly neighbors except for our own kin, we have found our house very comfortable. True, two of the bedrooms are small, and Matt and Jessica don’t have much free space in their private rooms. However, the living room is there for their use, and kitchen areas are great, Jessica and Matt have full use of them. Since Paw-paw and I have our own “den” we seldom use the living room. That gives Matt and Jess a little privacy, too. They can watch what they want to see on Television, and lounge on the couch as much as they want. Jessica can play the piano whenever she wishes, and Dylan loves to come over to use the play-station.

At this time of year, of course, your mother’s home school is on vacation for the summer. During the last school year I had the privilege of reading the Little House Books to Ashley and Dylan. Many times I could enlarge on or add a description to augment the printed word. Laura Ingalls Wilder began to publish her books when I was in grammar school—I remember my third grade teacher reading those same stories to us. When I was young my parents often visited their parents in the country. I knew a lot about how people who lived on farms around Pineville. Pineville and environs was mostly a farming community, and in the first half of the Twentieth Century that area was mostly farmers. Both Pineville and Fort Mill were familiar to me since we had kinfolk living there. There were lots of differences between those towns and the city of Charlotte. Farm life, even close to Charlotte was quite “old fashioned.” None of the people I knew in Pineville or near it actually had running water or electricity in their houses. There were few tractors, as they mostly used mules to pull the plows and other equipment. I was quite old enough to know how wonderful it was when the houses my grandparents lived in were wired for electricity, and installed indoor plumbing.

Though Radio was available when I was quite young, the first radio in our house was the Christmas I was in the First Grade. I was six years old. My Mother had somehow found time to work for an upholstery company while I was at school, and she had bought a divan and an easy chair (second hand, of course, but newly re-covered with new fabric). The couch and chairs were for all of us, and she had also borrowed a radio that belonged to our upstairs neighbors who were away for Christmas, so they let us use it. The radio was plugged in and ready to entertain all of us when Ella Cornelia brought me home from a movie (which was a rare treat all by itself). Mother and Daddy had spent the time we (my sister and I) were away hauling two end tables, with matching lamps to provide light, a sofa and a chair into an empty room, and setting up things so that they would look pretty—along with a Christmas tree already lighted and decorated. That was a very special Christmas.

Charlotte was, of course, a “big” city even then, but ice was delivered in horse drawn wagons, and lots of nearby “country” folks were still coming to town in buggies and wagons. There were trucks and cars also, of course. In those days there were no bus lines—only trolly cars—that ran on rails. One evening my mother hurried me to “get ready” to go out. The next day was the first day that Charlotte would have motorized busses for transportation instead of trollys. And though it was dark outside, it was time for the last trip of the trolly that passed our house. She told me to remember—and never forget—that I rode on the last trolly car that passed our house before Charlotte began to use busses. And so we did ride out Eleventh Street to Graham to the end of the line, turned around, and came back home. It seems strange now to remember how very important the change in our city appeared to my Mother, and my Father. They both insisted that I remember this step into the future. It seems strange to me now that anyone would even be interested in this day and time that the City made such a grand hop into the future when I was about four or five years old. There was no television—few telephones in homes—and only “rich” people had automobiles and radios. Mostly we walked to places we needed to go. Airplanes were such a novelty that when we heard the motor of a plane we all ran outside to search the sky for a glimpse. I have seen great and marvelous changes in the way people live. The daily newspapers were more important than they seem to be now, because that was the method that ordinary people learned what was happening in the world, in our state, and in our city. I even remember that when the Japanese bombed Pearl Harbor there were neighborhood kids—those who carried News Papers in the area—who went up and down the streets yelling “Extra-Extra” with huge headlines about Pearl Harbor. In those days there were telephones and telegrams which police, fire houses, and businesses used when it was necessary to communicate quickly, but most households in our neighborhood did not have telephones. Even radios were not in every house. My grandparents in Pineville, and my aunts and uncles did not have electricity or running water in their homes. My uncle Vance had chrystal set, with headphones, but he could get only WBT, and only through the headphones. Telephones had been invented, of course, and businesses and governments had them, and rich people. But few folks who worked for a living had either an automobile or a telephone. If you wanted to advise people in other cities and states, mail or telegram was the usual way information was exchanged.

Once when I was about five years old I actually rode from my Grandfather Park’s house near Pineville to Flint Hill Baptist Church in a black topped buggy—just me and my Granddaddy Parks. It was a wonderful treat—especially since no one, not even my sister Ella Cornelia—was going to ride with us. It was just me and Granddaddy Parks all the way from his house to Flint Hill Baptist Church in a black buggy pulled by a horse named Pink. My dress was pink and my shoes were black patent leather. I had a wonderful experience that day, and treasured it. Because I was only about five years old a lot of the detail of that wonderful experience has faded from my memory. I don’t recall why Ella Cornelia didn’t come with us. When she was ten years old she was very ill, and it is possible she was not well enough for such an outing.

My grandparents were old, and unable to cope with living on their own farm, and were going to move from the home they had built themselves, with only the help of my mother, who was the only child still at home. They had lived in that house for at least fifteen or twenty years, and Grandmother had “heart trouble” and Granddaddy couldn’t cope with everything by himself. My grandparents were invited to move into the home of my mother’s sister Ola, and her husband, Vance Davis, who had no children. They lived a little more than a mile from the town of Pineville on a short stretch of Old Pineville Road that was still a dirt road in the early 1930’s. Both the Pineville Road of today and the railroad track leading into Charlotte passed near the front of Aunt Ola and Uncle Vance’s property, however their home and farm was not actually on the Highway as it is today. There was an unpaved stretch of “Old” Pineville Road **Their farm was located on a stretch of “Old Pineville Road” that had two strikes against its location when the State paved the highway. There were two rail crossings within less than two miles along that section. The solution to the problem was to re-route the highway to avoid both the bridge and the crossing at one end there was a wooden bridge, and at the other end there was a level crossing. which was , as well a short part of Old Pineville Road. Before the road was paved it waved a little to and fro as it stretched out toward Charlotte. A section of the original road bed was chopped off and rerouted to avoid building a bridge over the railroad track at one place, and also eliminating a level crossing about a mile from the bridge. I haven’t seen that location in about twenty years so I am not sure what it is like today. The original pathways of both train and horse drawn traffic, and later the more carefully laid out and paved Pineville Road that exists today, all go the same way in the same area. There are still sections of “Old Pineville Road” in use—which are paved now of course—however the section near Uncle Vance’s house has become a sort of cul de sac as part of the road was interrupted when the bridge over the railroad tracks became unsafe and was destroyed.
The entry to that bit of Old Pineville Road has been changed, and I’m not sure how it is situated now, but I think the level crossing of the railroad track still exists.
8*** a few of them are still called “Old Pineville Road”. there several times in that ten miles from Pineville to Charlotte. Old Pineville Road was the original pathway of the highway, and it was the road crossed the rails in several places between Pineville and Charlotte. a mile long stretch of Old Pineville Road was also in front of their house. That section was the original route when the traffic was horse-drawn vehicles. When the road of paved the roadbed was moved to avoid both a building a new bridge over the railroad track and also a second crossing of the railroad at a level crossing within about another mile of the road. Pineville Road—the one laid out when only horses or horse drawn vehicles were using it. When we left Charlotte to live in South Carolina traveled mile long stretch of Old Pineville Road—and was not paved when I was quite young. Later, as I was growing up, half of that road was black-topped, because it was often used by horse drawn wagons and buggies. along the highway leading to Charlotte. . I didn’t realize that Granddaddy might be a little sad since this would be his last journey by buggy from his very own home to his church. Next Sunday he would go to church in a 1929 Ford automobile driven by Uncle Vance. From that time on Granddaddy and Grandmother would ride with them every Sunday. My mother explained so that I almost realized and sort of understood that Granddaddy and Grandmother were giving up their independence, and would not be “in charge” anymore. Aunt Ola and Uncle Vance would be good to them—but it still would not be living on their own in their familiar home which they had built together. But I do remember that I felt wonderful and important, sharing that ride in the buggy, though I didn’t know why I was chosen to ride with him. I did know that I had shared a small part of that special day with him. I do remember that I was “nice” that day, and that I behaved very well.

My father’s parents, Amos and Ella Yandle, also lived in Pineville, a little over a mile from Aunt Ola’s house. The Yandle house had Pineville Road in front of it, and their pasture ended at the railroad track , right on the “new” concrete paved Pineville Road. You may remember that the railroad between Charlotte and Pineville is not very far from the highway along the entire way. My Father’s parents also lived on a farm about a mile from the town of Pineville, and my Parks grandparents one and a fourth miles from Pineville, and about that far from where my Aunt Ola and Uncle Vance lived. The Yandle house and most of their farm was between the highway and the railroad, however there was also a large field on the other side of Pineville Road and it sometimes had watermelons and cotton on it.

Once, probably a number of years before I was born, there was an automobile race track—the very first “Speedway” in the vicinity of Charlotte, and believe it or not it was not a paved track—nor was it red dirt. It was made of wood. Richard Petty’s father raced on that “speedway” when my Dad was young. The “road” into the track—at least one of the ways to get there—was on a narrow red dirt road beside my Grandfather Yandle’s farm, and my Dad, who was at that time in his life still living at home with his parents, talked about wandering over that race track area after it had burned to ashes, and picking up some of the very large nails that had held together the boards that made the track and the building for the spectators. Only the nails had survived the fire.

The highway where my Yandle Grandparents lived was different from the place where my mother’s parents lived with my Aunt Ola and Uncle Vance Davis. When the pathway from Pineville to Charlotte was first laid out it sort of wove back and forth over the railroad track. However, when the North Carolina began paving major highways after automobiles began to multiply, the actual route of some of the roads were changed from mud to cement or asphalt, and bridges were built over creeks, rivers, and railroad crossings as well, if the crossings could not be avoided. The road between Charlotte and Pineville was first made horses either ridden or used to pull wagons or buggies. Because the roads stretching from South Carolina into Charlotte in many places paralleled the railroad, there were spots where the road and the railroad tracks were parallel to each other, and other places where the road wandered back and force over the tracks. When Piineville Road was finally paved, it was done by the State of North Carolina, with fewer railroad crossings by the roadways.

oad had been paved for a long time when I was old enough to take notice of it. However, my parents remembered that it began as a red dirt road. The railroad and the old dirt road to Charlotte were almost parallel to each other, and along paths of both of them there was an occasional crossing. the ten or fifteen miles between Charlotte and Pineville. However, there were sections along the path of the old highway where the earlier route of the roadway crossed, and within a mile or so, re-crossed the railroad tracks, and it occurred even after the road and railroad tracks entered the city limits. and a mile or so later, crossed it again. Since this was dangerous with both horse drawn vehicles and automobiles, and to a lesser extent to the trains themselves, when the State of North Carolina were paving the highway, they rerouted Pineville Road in several places to prevent cars and wagons having to cross the tracks several times. During my lifetime the road called Pineville Road had had two names. One is Pineville Road, and the other which is more narrow, Even within the city limits of Charlotte there has been both a Pineville Road, an Old Pineville Road, and a railroad track paralleling each other.

was since they didn’t usually stop quickly if they saw a buggy on the track,e newly paved highway most of the way there when the road had been rerouted there were at least two roadways plus a railroad line entering Charlotte quite close to one another. from Pineville that either almost side by side, or just a reasonable distance from each other little and in a few spots where the original path of Pineville Road was changed when it was paved, there would be three roadways—one was a train track, one was a cement paved highway, and the other was “Old Pineville Road” which might be an ordinary paved tar road, or half of the road would be tar paved, or simply layered with gravel, or inside the Charlotte City Limits, a narrow blacktop street. were three roadways going the same were that . When Pineville Road was paved with cement the road bed was re-routed in some places to avoid railroad crossings when possible. Since there were farms and houses along the original roadbed the dirt roads could not be entirely abandoned since that would limit access to houses and farms. Therefore, the cut off part of the road had have access to the new paved highway. Therefore, there were stretches of road that might have a tar surface, or be half tar and half red dirt, or since the road was rarely actually traveled, it might have half the road paved with tar, and the other side only dirt, with a few rocks scattered upon the roadway. There were several stretches farms and housing, a church, and sometimes Pineville road would connect with a short ******stretch of “Old Pineville Road” was created, with the railroad Therefore, a portion of Pineville Road was moved to avoid having to replace a bridge across the tracks not far from my Aunt Ola and Uncle Vance’s house. That made a little stretch of about a mile of “Old Pineville Road” parallel to both the railroad and the paved highway. The old bridge built over the railroad was in use until I was in college, and then the bridge became unsafe and was destroyed. The stretch of “Old” Pineville road was cut into two “dead end” stretches , and the aid out, a bridge was built over one of the low places that the railroad had leveled out for its track. About a mile further toward Charlotte it suited the railroad to move a little to the left, and that movement of the track formed a level crossing. That was sort of abandoned because the railroad crossed it twice within a mile—one place the rail was below a rickety bridge, and the other was a level crossing, on a sort of curve of the track, where terrain made it difficult to see a moving train. My Aunt Ola and Uncle Vance lived quite near the level crossing. People who lived in the area of either of the houses—Grandfather Yandle’s farmhouse or Uncle Vance and Aunt Ola’s house included, often found that the walking distance between their homes and the town of Pineville could be covered quicker on foot down the track than on the road. Many of the people who lived in that area indeed used the tracks rather than the road when walking. There are a lot of farms that , about a mile and a half from Aunt Ola’s house. From the situation of the Yandle’s farm it was possible to walk down the railroad track behind their house for a little less than a mile and find themselves in Pineville. The Yandles were farmers, and lived very quiet lives. My Grandfather Yandle once bought some property in Charlotte, and lived on the moderate income from six houses in a Negro section of Charlotte, until three of them burned down. A few years late the City of Charlotte decided to build Independence Boulevard, and the city bought the property on which the to build the Independence. Then three of the houses burned down in one night. Afterwards the property was sold to the City of Charlotte so that Independence Boulevard could be built, so they had that to live on, in addition to their farming efforts. Only my Dad and his youngest sister married when they were young, though Daddy was the only one who had children. My Aunt Martha married late in life—to a boy only four or five years older than me, and I was about twenty at the time. Martha was older than my father, and only their Pauline. Aunt Helen Martha and Allen seemed to love each other, and reported to their family that they had a wonderful marriage. My Grandmother Yandle was blind, and she was very frail, having been ill for a lot of her life. She told me once that she had never “seen” me, even when I was an infant. She had seen my sister as a small child, but not me. That household was made up of my Grandparents, one son, Eddie, and two daughters, Helen and Martha. One other daughter, Pauline, was married and was the only child other than my father that did not still live at home. Pauline was married to Henry, and they had their own house, and didn’t live with my grandparents. But Pauline and Henry did not have any children,

I was in high school when my father finally installed electricity and running water for his parents and his brother and sister who still lived at home. house. in the house that belonged to my Yandle grandparents; however, I don’t think they ever had a refrigerator as they preferred to keep their “well house” where they stored foods that needed coolness. Their house didn’t have an inside toilet until several years after I was married, and they had no running water in the kitchen until some years after I married. Eventually my Dad built them a toilet by enclosing a portion of the back porch, and at the same time they had spigot water installed in the kitchen for the first time. My uncle Eddie, my Dad’s older brother, his parents, and his oldest sister lived there most of their lives. My Aunt Pauline married when she was in her twenties, but my Aunt Martha married when she was middle aged—to my boyfriend, believe it or not. is parents, and farmed until some time after the close of World War II, and he did not have a tractor—but plowed the hard day, with a mule pulling the plow. It’s hard in this day and age to believe that people were still using kerosene lamps for lights and mules or horses rather than tractors for both plowing and traveling. But it was true. to plow with when I was a child, and a youth. Farmers in Pineville raised most of their own food, but there were a lot of people who did not have electricity or indoor plumbing as I was growing up. In Pineville water was brought from a well or spring, and toilets were outside, a short distance from the house. They cooked on wood burning stoves, spending a lot of time chopping the wood, hauling it into the house, and disposing of ashes. Their water was carried into the house by the bucket full, from a well in the yard, or a spring that was w-a-y—that means a LONG way—downhill from the house. Of course once the water was in the bucket, it was a long steep climb uphill to get to the house.

All the years when I was living at home with my parents we would, upon special occasions, go to church in the Pineville area with my Parks grandparents (my mother’s folks). They worshiped at Flint Hill Baptist Church where (during my childhood and youth) there was actually a hitching post for horse drawn transportation. And there were, in those days, a number of buggies, wagons, and saddled horses tied up there. This was a novelty for me as a little city person. Most of the time I saw horses only when the ice man delivered blocks of ice to homes on our street for the many ice boxes still in use. The more modern Refrigerators with ice making capability was not prevalent in Charlotte until after World War II. During my early childhood we used an ice box—with ice delivered in twenty-five or fifty pound blocks and stored (though it eventually melted, especially in summer) in an “ice box” that would keep milk and meat cool for short periods of storage. In our neighborhood an old—sixty or seventy years—black man toted our ice in about three times a week. The ice delivery “wagon” really was a wagon—hauled by a horse. The old man was poorly clothed, and skinny. We thought he seemed “poor”—meaning he didn’t get enough to eat, and we thought he had no close family. He LOOKED hungry, and dressed cleanly, but in the same clothes day after day. My mother took pity on him and one day asked if he had eaten breakfast—since we were busy doing just that when he came in. So my mother fixed him an egg sandwich wrapped in wax paper, and a pint of coffee in a “thermos” she fashioned from a pint glass jar wrapped in paper napkins and placed inside an empty, well washed tin can that had once been a container for fruit cocktail. She called the old man “Dad” and he was most grateful. He always handed the “thermos” jar and tin back to her, always well washed and ready the next day. All through the period of the war, “Dad” drove the horse drawn ice delivery wagon, and took his breakfast with him as he went on his way. He never missed our delivery, and my mother kept on handing out his breakfast after every delivery of the ice. When the war ended he told us one day that he was retiring, and would not be coming again, and he thanked my mother for her kindness to him. Strangely, the other times we saw horses included the coal man, who delivered fuel by the half ton to houses where coal was burned in stove or fireplace during cold weather. Upon occasion there were horse drawn wagons filled with vegetables, or melons, from small farms near Charlotte, because fresh vegetables were scarce in stores. Food in cans or jars was scarce in grocery stores, also, but we could, and did, buy vegetables from farmers who sold their bounty from wagons and trucks along the streets in Charlotte. Those men didn’t require “ration stamps” which the government distributed so that people with money couldn’t buy all the food and make life difficult for those who couldn’t pay “extra” just to get food. Within the city one could not go out and cut down a nearby tree for fuel. My uncles and aunts often had to do just that, as they lived in the country and had access to wood for making fires for the winter. In the city we used coal and oil very carefully. One had to have not only money, but a “ration” book with “stamps” that could be traded for food, coal, gasoline, shoes, and other products. If we actually bought food in tin cans, we washed the cans, took out both “ends” of the can, flattened the can itself around its “ends” and I took them to school to be deposited in a basket so that they could be recovered and melted down and used again.

All the farmers I knew or heard about were unlikely to have sent their horses or mules to the abattoir, even if they had moved up to tractors. Gasoline was so scarce that some returned to using horses, and we saw horse or mule drawn wagons on our street that were filled with vegetables or watermelons that were for sale in the neighborhoods of Charlotte. People in our neighborhood who bought regularly from passing farmers faired well in harvest time, as the farmers would return again and again into the area where they could vend their wares with some certainty. My Dad and our back-door neighbor, and two “older” families who lived across the street from us, were the families on our block of Eleventh Street who had automobiles or trucks. Almost every one either walked or rode a bus. I was six years old when streetcars stopped running along Eleventh Street and buses took over their routes.

needed to travel for several miles. Now in the early 1930’s many of our kin, and many citizens of Pineville and its environs used automobiles or trucks to travel to church. However those hitching posts at Flint Hill Baptist Church stayed there until I was in my late teens or early twenties. As I was growing up changes were inevitable. The “old” folks who looked askance at motorized equipment used horses, but their grown-up children embraced the machine-powered contraptions that made their labor easier, and each year of my life there were fewer horses traveling the streets of Charlotte. By 1942 horses were rarely seen, until the government started building war related buildings or clearing land for quickly needed buildings, or just cleared space, for instance, at or near the air port space. Builders were at times compelled to use real horses to provide their “horse power.” I was a ten years old in February of 1941 when the war began. I remember shedding tears when I saw dead horses that had, literally, been “worked to death” hauled down Graham Street dangling from wrecker trucks.

After the beginning of the War there were more automobiles and trucks everywhere. Even small farms began to grow more food than was needed for the family who owned it, as scarcity of food was one of the things that was quickly felt, especially in cities, as the war progressed. People who had a patch of ground near their homes began growing Victory Gardens because both food and transportation were difficult to achieve. Gasoline, shoes, and sugar were among the items that became subject to rationing, with little books of detachable stamps that had to be turned over to the grocery store, or in the case of other rationed items, the stamps were surrendered at the cash registers of clothing and shoe stores, like a Belk store, or wherever shoes were sold, or especially where food—groceries—were sold. Gasoline was rationed. Vegetables were scarce, and sometimes meat was unavailable. Ration stamps were furnished to all citizens, so that people who could afford to buy plenty of food could not buy up all the food, leaving people who could not hoard food without enough to eat. Canned food used metal cans and had to be transported by train or by truck, both being heavily used by the war effort. Cans used as food containers became so scarce that a lot of food suppliers went back to glass jars instead of cans. There were scarce items in cities like Charlotte. Cuba supplied most of the sugar we used, so Sugar was rationed. Meat was rationed. Charlotte was growing and expanding because of the demands of the war. Our airport was used by the Army Air Force, and portions of it were off limits to visitors. Soldiers wandered the uptown streets, especially on week-ends. A childless neighbor just across the street from our house was a little older than my parents, but she and her husband opened their home to servicemen on the week-ends, and a lot of them treated her like a much loved grandmother, and wrote to her when they were transferred, and continued after the war was over.

It was impossible to buy a “new” car, and not much easier to purchase an old one. Gas was rationed, and there was little if any “joy” riding. People walked, or took a bus to work. My Dad had more ration stamps than an “ordinary” father because he was doing paint jobs for places like Esso Standard Oil refineries, and buildings like Camp Butner, which was a military base. He was away from home a lot in those days. For a while only my mother and I were at home, as Ella Cornelia was in college. However, college did not appeal to her, and she left before the close of the first semester, and went to work in a doctor’s office in Charlotte, as a great many nurses had left their jobs at home to volunteer to work in Amy, Navy, and Marine hospitals. Doctors became scarce, and those still in practice in small cities and large ones usually had more patients than they could easily manage.

Items that had been available and plentiful at the grocery store became scarce. Most Sugar came from Cuba, and so Sugar was rationed. Table meat, like bacon, chicken, beef, and pork became scarce. Gasoline was often unavailable as more and more motorized vehicles were being used. Meat was not plentiful, Small farmers enlarged their gardens and fields if at all possible, and vegetables were sold door to door as grocery stores were more and more often without enough of their goods to serve their customers. When a new store was opened clerks were hard to find, and more and more women were used in the market-place. Women who had never worked outside their own homes donned overalls and went to work, leaving the older and/or younger folk to do the work at home.

and on small farms in the country. to work their farms. Even so, the older folk still clung to the old ways. Tractors became more likely on the larger farms where the owners were the same age, or a tad younger than my parents. My father, Leroy Yandle, spent some months at a special school, learning how to repair automobiles, and keep their motors in good running order. *** same age as my parents did have automobiles or trucks, and most of them used tractors on their farms, but some of the members of Flint Hill still traveled by horses—and my maternal grandparents were among them.

As a child I saw and experienced many events similar to those written about in the Little House books, though their “era” was much earlier than mine. Life was very different than the present. Both Paw-paw and I were born before there were any effective antibiotics. Telephones were being used by businesses, but there were few households that had telephones until after the end of World War II. I was about six years old when my parents installed a telephone in our hallway. My Dad was a painting contractor and used it for his business. Our neighbors would, upon occasion, ask to use our phone, because there were few telephones in ordinary houses. Only two families on our block had telephones before I was more than ten years old. Most homes in towns like Fort Mill and Pineville were unlikely to have telephone service. Though the business sections of the smaller towns as well as the city of Charlotte, and “rich” home owners all over the area were using them. By the time I was married (1954) most homes—though not all—had telephones. Television had been invented, but it was only black and white—not color TV when your mother was young. Only the “rich” had television sets at first. Though Paw-paw’s parents already had television when we married, my parents did not have television until after your Mother had married.

You probably have heard that my sister Ella Cornelia was not a splendidly healthy person after her tenth birthday. She had pleurisy and other illnesses when she was ten or perhaps twelve, and it damaged her heart. There were few or no effective medicines at that time. Even so, Medicine had advanced in those years beyond the practices available to people when my parent’s were young. When my father’s sister, my Aunt Helen, was a young girl some illness attacked her while she was in her teens. Her doctor—I think probably in desperation trying to help her—gave her a “medicine” that rotted her teeth out before she was eighteen. She survived the treatment and the illness, but began wearing false teeth in her late teens.

When my sister was ill at the age of ten years the best treatment for her was bed rest.

I, myself, was about twelve when the first real antibiotic, other than sulfa, was introduced. This was, of course, during World War II, and the beginning of the story about my first dose of penicillin began with my dad, a painting contractor, who painted the house of a big-wig at the Standard Oil Company in Charlotte. The oil man had two problems: one was that his wife wanted their house painted—now! And the other was that the Standard Oil tank farm had problems because their tanks were rusting and springing leaks. My Dad was quite well known in Charlotte as an excellent painting contractor. He worked from home, and had done jobs for people like Mr. and Mrs. Ivey who owned the most sophisticated department store in Charlotte, and a bunch of other important people, most of whom had fabulous homes. Therefore my dad got the job of painting the house of the top man in Charlotte for the Standard Oil Company. While Daddy was working there the home owner mentioned the rusty, leaking tanks at the oil terminal where he worked. He asked my father if he knew anything about painting the outside of huge tanks. Daddy said he would think on it.

That was a beginning. My Dad “invented” a device that would place a painter on the side of the tank at a desired level, and allow him to move horizontally around the huge tank. When the tank had been circled at that level, the worker could lower the walk board, and start around the tank again with a spray gun, covering the entire tank with a fresh coat of protective paint. The tops of those tanks were movable—that is—they floated on top of the oil, instead of hanging on to the top of the tank. If the tank was full—the “lid” was at the top of the tank. If the tank was half full then the “lid” of the tank was at the half-way mark—touching the oil, not allowing dangerous fumes to gather in tight spaces where combustion could occur. If there was even a tiny opening along the sides of filled tanks due to rust or damage, the weight of the flammable liquid would push little sprays of oil through the hole onto the ground as if it were pressurized. Of course, these little sprays could ignite if a stray cigarette was quite close to it. Therefore that job was one where you didn’t want any sort of spontaneous combustion. All during the war Daddy painted oil terminals in North and South Carolina, and in Savannah, Georgia.

All during the war Daddy painted oil terminals in both North and South Carolina, and even in the area of Savannah, Georgia. Of course this sort of job meant he was away from home for weeks at the time. That left me, my sister, and my mother without automobile transportation, as Mother did not drive. When Daddy was away we didn’t have a car anyway. The armed services had first dibs on gasoline, so oil and gas was rationed for automobiles used for daily commuting. That meant that we had to ride a bus if we needed to go further than we could walk. If we were a half mile from the grocery store we had to tote our groceries in brown paper bags. If Daddy was not in Charlotte, we stayed home on Sundays or took a bus to church. Riding the bus was expensive—each ride cost seven cents per person.

When school was out ****, and a little smaller when the , and time consuming. Daddy could not commute daily while he painted the tanks on the coast of North and South Carolina and Georgia. He was away from home for weeks at a time. There were, of course, a lot of men who were away from home serving in the armed services in those days, and my Dad and his workmen were doing what they could to protect the oil and gas those soldiers, sailors, and airmen used.

ng that job the man talked to him about a problem he had with the huge tank farms done some work bid a job in Savannah to paint the outside surfaces of the tremendous tanks that held all sorts of oil products that came in on the floating tanks of

had penicillin when I was about twelve. It was administered through a needle, and I came quite near to fainting shortly after I had the shot. My mother and I were waiting a hot sidewalk for my Dad to pick us up in his truck. The army, navy, and air force had access to some antibiotics, but civilian use was not ****Both sulfa and penicillin were used for soldiers during World War II (which was still going on at the time I had that shot)

Communication and new inventions were slow when I was a child. Both Paw-paw and I were in were children when motorized travel was growing rapidly into our culture. Automobiles appeared in North Carolina long before I was born, but about the time when they were really in production, the “Great Depression” occurred, so that the automotive industry was at least slowed in its growth. My sister and I were part of the first generation of children to whom long journeys meant driving in a car.

My Dad had an automobile most of my life. However, when I was about five years old I actually rode to church (Flint Hill Baptist, near Pineville) in a buggy driven by my Grandfather Parks (my Mother’s father). It was a special treat for me, but it was a most important day for my grandparents. They were quite old, and had planned within the next week or so to move away from the house they had lived in for perhaps twenty-five or thirty years. Their house was built by Grandfather Parks with the help of my mother, the only one of their children still at home at that time. Even I have one vivid memory of that house. I was probably four, or possibly five years old. In those days I was quite aware that there was a phrase which ruled most houses where there were children: “Children should be seen, and not heard”. Sitting and watching grownups talk was no fun. So when it began to rain. I could hear the drops fall with a pitter-pat upon the tin roof of the house. My mother agreed that I could go out onto the front porch to watch the rain fall onto the edge of the porch making “raindrop soldiers” that were really droplet splashes on the steps and the edge of the porch. I could hear the rain ping on the tin roof as I sat upon the humped top of an old trunk set against the wall of the house. I felt blessed and entertained because of the sound of the downpour on the tin roof, and the silvery march of the droplets on the edge of the porch. I sat safe and dry on the curved top of the old trunk, and probably sang the little song about rain that I learned when I attended Kindergarten at the age of five—the same song I have sung to the children around me when a steady rain drops silvery plop-plash raindrops on porches, cars, roadways or other outdoor places. 

    “The little raindrop soldiers are marching from the sky,
      With uniforms of silver, I see them marching by.
      There little feet go pit-ter-pat, pit-ter-pat, pit-ter-pat.

Their little drums go rat-tat-tat, ah- rat-tat-tat-tat-tat”

You might even remember that I sang that song to you when you were small. Not too long ago when I was reading to Ashley and Dylan as part of their schooling I sang that song to them. The rain was thumping on our roof, and drops were splashing a silvery pattern on our deck. Apparently I hadn’t sung about raindrops for a long while, because they both peered out the large door in our dining area to watch the rain fall in tiny fountain-like circles.

As a very small child I had another wonderful experience quite close to the time I watched the rain fall on the porch of my grandparents. This was on a Sunday. My Dad owned an automobile, and I don’t remember what kind it was. I didn’t ride in it often. We were going to Pineville to see my mother’s parents, Granddaddy and Grandmother Parks. When we arrived I was informed that there was a wonderful trip ahead for me. I was going to ride to church with Granddaddy Parks—just the two of us—in a buggy behind a beautiful white horse named Pink. Pink was not really pink, of course. He was white with a few small black dots on his coat. However he was old, and his hide was thin, so that when the sun was bright, he looked pink. We were traveling to a country church—Flint Hill Baptist—located between Pineville and Fort Mill. My buggy ride was a “milestone,” not only for me, but it signified major changes in the lives of my Grandparents. The Sunday of the buggy ride was the last Sunday my Grandfather would drive his horse, “Pink” in his own buggy from his own home to the church he had attended for many years.

My grandparents were going to move the next week into the home of his daughter, Ola, and her husband Vance Davis. My grandparents were getting old. They had lived for many years in a tin roofed country farm house which had neither electricity nor running water. They were going to move into the home of my Uncle Vance and Aunt Ola (Ola was my mother’s sister) for the rest of their lives. Since it was the last time Grandfather Parks would leave his own home of many years to drive to church, he refused to ride in Uncle Vance’s 1929 Ford automobile, and chose to drive his buggy behind his horse Pink. And on that occasion—wonder of wonders—I, at the age of about four or five, and most especially only me, got to ride in the buggy with him. It was a great treat. I even remember that my dress was pink. I discovered that day that there was a cemetery off to one side of the yard of the church—which was customary in that day and time. And I learned that my mother’s youngest brother was buried there in the family plot.

I discovered that in that church men and women sat on separate sides of the church. And to my surprise my Granddaddy, because of his position within the church, sat just below the pulpit at the same level as the benches, but facing the congregation. The pulpit was mounted on a stage-like platform. Granddaddy sat there for the entire service, but during the sermon he went to sleep and snored, but no person in the church laughed.

This was the church that the entire Parks family had attended all of my mother’s life. Flint Hill Baptist Church is, so far as I know, still a going concern. In those early times when a church was founded it was customary to have a cemetery somewhere on the property where members of the church could be buried. My grandparents, as well as my uncle and aunt, are buried in the cemetery at Flint Hill. So far as I know the church is still there, though I haven’t seen in years.

Back to Now, instead of when I was a child: As for Paw-paw and me, our pattern of days has few surprises and is much the same week after week. Of course, Jessica and Matt still live in our house, and each year I have helped home school Ashley and Dylan. That has been a wonderful treat for me. They will, of course, soon be using the computer to complete their studies, but so long as I can be of help, I will joyfully read to the children—which has been my task for the most part. After school Ashley and Dylan usually stop by Paw-paw’s room to choose a treat, or get paid for bringing in our mail, as he, too, enjoys seeing them and interacting with them often.

Sundays and Wednesdays are church days, and we usually go to the evening meetings on both days. I still need allergy shots every three weeks on Mondays and we try to see our chiropractor at least once every week. The only people we know here in South Carolina are fellow church members and the physicians we visit. Though I tried to make friends with some of the people who live on our street, I haven’t been successful in that endeavor. I went to the house next door to us (the up-hill one) soon after we moved in, and when the door opened I discovered that the house was so full of cigarette smoke I couldn’t even stand in the doorway. I was embarrassed because I had to back out of the door as my allergies are extremely sensitive to cigarette smoke. I did explain to the lady who came to the door, and even apologized to her, but she made no effort to be friendly towards me. The lady and her grandchildren were the only ones at home during the day, and were our nearest neighbor. The children were about ten and twelve years old, and they played in their yard in the afternoons, but strangely they didn’t reach out to Dylan and Ashley. Since I couldn’t go to her house that quick exit on my part was the end of all efforts to make friends, and I have found it strange that none of the folks who lived here before we moved in made any effort to be friendly or neighborly. Therefore, the Beatty and Bingham households were the only familiar ones.

Some of the folks that lived here when we first moved in have already moved away. Other folks have moved in, stayed about two or three months, and then moved out. None of the people who live near us is very eager to become friendly. In most instances we don’t even swap “howdys” since they ignore us.

The people who live next to our house on the down-hill side are young folks. I thought I would be nice and we could become neighbors.
