The wife was pregnant when they moved in, and when their child was born we took to them a small gift for the child. The mother did open the gift, and did say thank you, but we were not made really welcome, nor offered a seat in their living room. Therefore, we left fairly quickly. They had not been in the house very long when their child was born. They did have a large dog which was quite friendly. The dog developed a limp, and some one of her neighbors (not us) called the Humane Society, and they made Missy, our neighbor, put her dog to sleep. She accused me of calling the Humane Society and told me to stay out of her yard and leave her alone. Therefore, I am reluctant to even speak to her, though sometimes I try. The funny thing is that she will talk to Pawpaw, and smile at him, and if he calls me over, she is “nice” to me, but she never, never, makes any effort to speak to me if I am alone. I often wonder if her head is screwed on tight.

Ella Cornelia seems to be doing O.K. I haven’t seen her lately but we talk upon occasion by phone. I want to go spend the day with her soon. I’ve done that several times since we have been living in South Carolina. She spent a several days with me while we were living at the big old house on Highway 9. It was great to have her there.

There is a “happening” I would like to tell you about, simply because it is a little unusual. When your mother was still in school we went for a drive one Sunday afternoon. I don’t recall that Fred was with us on this occasion. I think your mother was still in college. We stopped at the home of my Aunt Ola. By that time she and her husband Vance were living alone as my grandparents had passed away. I think that by that time they had electricity and running water in their home.

When I was about eight years old my Grandmother Parks suffered a heart attack and died, but Grandfather seemed to be very strong and healthy. He chose as his particular chore the oversight of a young cow, and was feeding it grasses to wean it from its mother’s milk. On a sunny and pleasant afternoon he volunteered to walk down Old Pineville Road to collect the mail from the mailbox at the edge of newer Pineville Highway, just across the railroad tracks. gather any mail from the mailbox Grandfather had two goals when he told Aunt Ola he wanted to go the mail box to get the mail. He wanted to save her the trip to the mailbox, but he also wanted to stop near the railroad track to cut six foot tall Jimson grass for the young calf he was pampering, teaching it to eat grass rather than its mother’s milk. He picked up the mail, and stooped to cut Jimson Weed where the railroad crossed old Pineville road. Aunt Ola thought he would be safe enough since the morning train had already passed. However, World War II was in full swing, and not far from Aunt Ola’s house there was a new and “secret” plant making essential war products. The trains that carried the products away did not blow a whistle to indicate a train was crossing a roadway in order to prevent sabotage of the materials manufactured at the “swar —for secret security of materials leaving that special plant--that is did special c Just within the railroad right-of-way was a large stand of Jimson grass Grandfather had discovered that the calf liked the really tall Jimson stalks of grass that grew along the railroad track right-of-way where the track crossed Old Pineville Road. Grandfather Joe Parks had lived most of his life on a farm, away from highways, and so Aunt Ola was careful not to let him go into any area that was unsafe for him. The road in front of their house seldom had traffic on it, and the afternoon train had already passed on the railroad tracks that had to be crossed to reach the mailbox. *My parents thought of Pineville Road as the “new” road after it was paved. , When the highway was quite deaf, and Aunt Ola was careful there was a lar He failed to hear an approaching train because World War II was in full swing, and military trains did not blow at level crossings during the war to prevent attacks on trains carrying war materials or soldiers. The secret plant was known locally as “the shell plant” and no one who didn’t work there ever knew what it manufactured. Trains left that plant and mostly traveled toward South Carolina with its packed cars, and may have gone to the coast to be taken overseas. For security the trains from that plant never blew their whistles or horns at the level crossing where the “Old” section of Pineville Road intersected with the more modern Pineville Highway.

You may remember that when the road to Pineville was paved, and became “highway” for motored traffic, a little section of the road was

s profoundly deaf, liked to pick up the mail, and having worked from sunup to sundown all of his life, was eager to do his part on Uncle Vance’s farm. He wanted to walk down to the mailbox to get the morning mail, and since he did not have to cross the road itself to reach the mailbox, he delighted in completing this “chore” each day. Aunt Ola felt that she did not need to walk with him since the regular morning train had already passed. Therefore Grandfather set off on his own to pick up the mail from the box located on busy Pineville Road, . just beyond the level crossing. The mailbox was on the same side of the road when the expected and scheduled train had passed Aunt Ola agreed that he could pick up the mail. Before his return she heard a train, and it was stopping. The engineer of the war material train ha The and did not hear the train coming. He was buried beside his wife at Flint Hill Cemetery. Old Pink, the horse, spent the rest of his life in a wide pasture, near a lot of trees, with fine grass and a pond of water.

Now I want to continue this story—but Aunt Ola and Uncle Vance looked after her parents, and lived the rest of their lives on their farm , and thrived. And now I will tell you about a “coincidence” that occurred one Sunday evening when we were visiting Aunt Ola and Uncle Vance, some years after Grandmother and Grandfather died. The important part was that Louise and Fred were with us as we made the visit. Louise was in college at the time. Although there was no “extra” automobile in the driveway of my Aunt Ola’s home, we discovered that there was already an older gentleman I didn’t recognize sitting by their fire. He was their closest neighbor, and had lived just across the road from them for many long years, though I had never met him that I remembered My father had gone to school with him. His name was Audrey Bailes. He was dressed in overalls, as was my Uncle Vance. I

Now I will digress a little and explain that the road leading to Aunt Ola and Uncle Vance.s house had once been a part of the “Old Pineville Road”. When automobiles came into style and roads began to be paved, many roadways were changed, the better to accommodate automobiles. These changes affected Pineville Road. At some time, probably in the 1920’s or 1930’s the existing country road was “improved” and paved. During this effort the road’s right-of-way was slightly altered to avoid use of a very old wooden bridge that arched over the train track, and about a mile from that bridge the road re-crossed the same railroad at a level crossing. , probably in more than one location, but I knew about one of them that at least two locations between Charlotte and Pineville. The major reason for moving the bed of the highway was that part of its original path crossed the railroad twice within a little bit over one mile—and though one of the crossings was on a narrow wooden bridge, the other one was a level crossing. When Pineville road was paved for automobiles traffic and road traffic became more prevalent, there were designers who altered the path of the existing roadbed and decided to avoid both the decaying wooden bridge as well as the level crossing, and built the new road a few feet further away from the railroad track, thereby avoiding crossing the tracks at all. This reasonable improvement placed Uncle Vance’s farm and those of his neighbors on a rarely used stretch of “Old” Pineville Road, which was (during my childhood) a “half and half” road—paved on one side (for cars) and graveled on the other (for horses).

Now, back to my story. Uncle Vance and Aunt Ola lived near the level crossing of the railroad on Old Pineville Road, and as a child I visited them, along with my family, quite frequently. I played in the yard, and roamed around his saw mill, played in his huge pile of sawdust, or visited his chicken house, or his milk cow barn, or we went into the lower pasture by the pond where the cows grazed, along with the horses. There were woods beyond the pasture where wild grape vines grew and climbed trees making vines like the ones Tarzan could swing on. If the weather was unpleasant there was the attic where old furniture was stored, including a wind-up record player with records from the 1920’s. We always enjoyed our visits to Uncle Vance and Aunt Ola’s house

congregation. My Dad visited that church yard a many a Sunday evening in summer when he was young because he loved to listen to the singing. I seldom paid attention to the other houses or buildings along that road, though I knew Uncle Vance and Aunt Ola knew most of those people, but I had seldom met any of them. Then there came the evening when Bobby and I, along with Louise and Fred, stopped late one afternoon to see Aunt Ola and Uncle Vance and found that they already had a visitor, who was their neighbor, just across the road from them. His name was Audrey Bailes. Like my Uncle Vance, he was a farmer. A sad thing happened to him when he was a young father of two children. His wife left him and ran away with another man. Audrey had to raise his son and daughter by himself. I’m not sure where he lived while his children were growing up, but in his old age he lived right across the road from my Aunt Ola and Uncle Vance. He was a skinny, not overly tall man, and he often visited Uncle Vance, especially after his children married and moved away from Pineville. ****

About the time I Paw-Paw and I started dating Paw-paw Audrey married again. Of course I saw him as a skinny, old, and not very interesting. He was a farmer, and I never saw him dressed in anything but overalls. He was about the same age as my parents, with grown-up children and lots of brothers and sisters and had gone to school with my Father. He had lots of kinfolk, but none who lived near-by. His wife had simply walked off one day years ago, and Audrey had finished raising his children by himself. My mother told me about his wife simply packing a sack with her belongings and walking out of the house to live with another man. Apparently she was not good at keeping house or being economical, because the day she left she had no shoes, and left barefooted.

During my childhood Audrey often visited Aunt Ola and Uncle Vance at the same time we did. My parents grew up in Pineville, and were acquainted with Audrey since their school days. Upon one visit when your Mother and Uncle Fred were with us, we learned that Audrey was getting married. I mentioned that to my mother-in-law (your mother called her Grammy) and to our surprise we discovered that Paw-paw’s father, Fred Oliver Beatty, whose mother was Harriet Beatty (Louise’s Great Grandmother) was the sister of Audrey Bailes. Louise was therefore kin to Audrey on Grandmother Beatty’s side of the family.

Aunt Ola and Uncle Vance welcomed Audrey’s new wife, and I think they “stood up” with them at their marriage. She was a pleasant little woman who worked in Charlotte at Belks Department Store. Within a year or so we learned that Audrey and his wife were expecting a child. I mentioned that fact to Paw-Paw who said, “You know, I have an Uncle Audrey Bailes who lives near Pineville.” So we asked our families, and sure enough, Bobby’s Great Uncle Audrey was the same person who lived across the road from my Aunt Ola and Uncle Vance Davis. There was a definite family connection.

I digress a little, and go back to my own childhood, close to twenty years later. It was a significant day in my grandparent’s lives, because it was the last Sunday they would depart from their own home to go to church, as they were moving the next week from their own home which had no running water (a well instead) or electricity, into an electrified house with my mother’s sister, Ola Davis, and her husband Vance. They were quite old, and unable to maintain their animals and fields.

They moved from their home to their daughter Ola’s house, on “Old Pineville Road”. You may remember traveling on the “new” Pineville Road that extended South Boulevard all the way to Pineville and beyond. There were at least two sections of the original road that because of homes and businesses along the original path of the road was extended to Pineville as a two-lane paved road which . Ola had no children, and was still living in the Pineville area, near their church and friends. Aunt Ola and Uncle Vance were very interesting people. Ola worked at the Shell Plant (a “hush,hush” place where whatever they made contributed to the “War efforts” during World War II.) I never did find out what they were making there. as it was During the next week they moved out of their home of perhaps forty or more years, one that Grandfather Parks built with my mother’s help (his sons were not at home) together, while my Grandmother rode in the car with my parents. I loved every minute of the ride behind the old horse, who’s name was Pink. It was a “milestone” in my grandfather’s life as well as in mine, because there was no need in his future for him to use the horse just to ride to church. They were moving in with my Aunt Ola Davis (my mother’s sister) and her husband Uncle Vance, and they had a fine four seat Ford Automobile. .

My grandparents’ new home was closer to Charlotte than their old home place, making it easier for us to visit. Also, the older folks had less to do—Uncle Vance did the field work, and the wood chopping, and Aunt Ola did the cooking and canning and looked after the milking and chicken feeding/egg collecting, and so forth. It made life much easier for Grandmother and Granddaddy, who would help only if they felt like it. It would be easier for Aunt Ola to look after her parents when they were living with her, instead of six or eight miles away. Aunt Ola had no children, and she and her husband Vance had extra rooms in their home to comfortably take them in. Several years later at my grandfather’s funeral there were still hitching posts in the church yard. Flint Hill Baptist Church eventually removed the hitching post, but only when there were no more members who came to Church in horse drawn vehicles.

Sadly, my Grandfather Parks was killed by an unscheduled military train soon after World War II began. There was a “sensitive” manufacturing plant between Pineville and Charlotte, which was “hidden” to some extent. The people who worked there didn’t talk about what was manufactured there, nor did they gossip about what they did while they were there. My father’s sister, Martha Yandle, as well as my Mother’s sister, Ola Davis, both worked at the plant as the war lengthened. The trains that arrived and/or left that plant never blew a whistle at level railroad crossings in fear of giving away regular schedules to anyone who wanted to sabotage military shipments. In places where truck, bus, and automobiles could safely cross the tracks people now had to really Stop, Look, and Listen carefully during World War II, because no hint was given that a train was coming—until those who wanted to cross the tracks could see or hear the wheels turning on the metal tracks. There were regular scheduled trains, but there were also military shipments that did not have a regular schedule. My Aunt told Granddaddy Parks he could cross the tracks to pick up the mail because the mid-morning train had already passed the crossing. On his way home Granddaddy paused beside the track to cut Jimson weed for his calf. He was profoundly deaf, and failed to either see or hear the approaching train. The train tried to stop, but it did not blow its whistle—and my Granddaddy Parks was struck by the train as he cut the tall Jimson grass for his calf.

I was far too young to even realize where the Parks home place was, but it was near the park where President ______ ‘s homeplace has been restored.
p

Reflections

I am now seventy-five years old. My husband is eighty. We have lived through horse-and-buggy days to see men walk on the moon. We have seen the discovery of penicillin, the end of polio, and the invention of television and computers. Life has been full of changes, some sad, some wonderful. I have tried to put down these memories so that my children, Louise and Fred, and my grandchildren will know where they came from.

Iris Jean Yandle Beatty

A Note from Ken

I recovered these fragments of Mimi's memoir from her old computer, preserving them alongside audio recordings from my time at her home on Autumnvale Drive, circa 2008. It is a privilege to share these memories with those who knew her. She loved me dearly, as I did her, and I miss her deeply.

memoirfamilyhistoryCharlotte

Iris Jean Yandle Beatty

Born in 1931, Iris Jean Yandle Beatty lived through the Great Depression, World War II, and witnessed the transformation of the 20th century. She wrote her memoirs at age 75 to preserve family history for future generations.

Charlotte, North Carolina
